DOC.HEAD: Opposition Says It Will Accept A Fair Loss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs at bottom with Ortega newspaper interview.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MGA3, MGA4
DOC.TEXT: The opposition coalition will recognize an election victory by President Daniel Ortega's Sandinista party if the vote is fair and the count is honest, vice presidential candidate Virgilio Godoy said Friday. ``We will forget all the unfair campaign practices of the FLSN (Sandinistas) if the final voting process Sunday is clean,'' Godoy told a news conference. ``If there is fraud _ and we are not saying now that there will be _ we will issue a public protest and then consider other forms of passive resistance,'' Godoy said. Elliott Richardson, the head of the U.N. observer mission, told a news conference he expects a fair election. ``I've given a lot of thought to how the system could be beat,'' he said. ``I haven't yet been able to come up with a good scheme.'' Richardson is a former U.S. attorney general. The final U.N. pre-election report he released concludes that the election has done much to move Nicaragua toward becoming a pluralistic society. Meanwhile, former President Jimmy Carter, perhaps the most important of the estimated 2,000 observers of Sunday's vote, arrived in Managua. He was meeting the main presidential candidates as well as other leading observers during the afternoon. Carter drove through streets filled with Sandinista banners, posters and placards, past people wearing ``Daniel Presidente'' caps, backpacks, and T-shirts. Eight feet in the air, black-and-red Sandinista helium balloons decorated the fronts of many businesses. In contrast, a lone red-and-white UNO (United National Opposition) banner hung across one boulevard. The minor Social Christian Party's blue fish symbol was more evident, drawn by hand on walls. Ortega, his voice hoarse and gravelly after days of publicly speaking, maintained his conciliatory attitude towards the opposition he expects to beat soundly on Sunday. ``The Sandinista National Liberation Front is in agreement with Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's call to avoid violence,'' said Ortega after meeting with Joao Baena Soares, secretary-general of the Organization of American States and another top observer. Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro of the opposition coalition are the leading presidential candidates. Eight others are running but are given little chance. Also at stake are the vice presidency, a 90-member National Assembly and 146 city, town and regional councils. About 1.75 million people are registered to vote. Godoy dismissed a recent poll by the Washington Post that indicated a big Sandinista lead as ``lacking credibility.'' ``Nicaraguans are afraid. When the Nicaraguan is polled, he is always trying to figure who is conducting the poll and his motives,'' he said. Ortega said he was certain of victory and trusted Mrs. Chamorro's desire to avoid violence, but that he was still worried about more radical elements of the opposition. Military sources said Friday that a large contingent of Contra rebels, perhaps as many as 300, has descended from mountain camps in the central province of Chontales. Adolfo Vargas, a member of the Villa Sandino city council, said groups of 20 rebel fighters had been spotted in the bush and fields near the main road to the Atlantic coast. He said the government fears they may try to provoke violence or intimidate voters on election day, although the Contra leadership has said the guerrillas have been told only to defend themselves and not to interfere in the election process. On Thursday, Ortega said the Sandinistas have spent about $7 million on their campaign. He said any complaints about the illegal use of government property should be filed with the Supreme Electoral Council or the international observers. Godoy said the opposition coalition spent less than $1 million ``because the money promised by the United States never arrived.'' However, other political sources said the coalition did receive money from the United States through private donations and other channels. U.S. officials have said that if Ortega wins a free and fair election, the Bush administration would consider normalizing relations with Managua, as long as other conditions are fulfilled as well. Those include stopping the export of arms to leftist guerrillas in El Salvador and honoring human rights. Ortega, in an interview published in Saturday editions of The New York Times, was quoted as saying that if re-elected he would not provide arms to the Salvadoran guerrillas. In the past, Ortega has said he would respect regional agreements prohibiting giving arms to the guerrillas.

DOC.HEAD: Shell Spill: 672,000 Gallons, 16 Times Greater Than Suspected
DOC.TEXT: A pipeline break at a Shell oil refinery near the Mississippi river spilled an estimated 672,000 gallons of crude oil, 16 times more than the company originally said, the state announced Thursday. Monday's accident was the latest in a series of mishaps at the refinery in the last two years. ``In pipeline leaks alone, there has been more than a million gallons of product loss since mid-December,'' said Will Flower, a spokesman for the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. ``There was a 300,000-gallon gasoline spill.'' The new estimate of Monday's spill was released by the state EPA, which is calling for a multimillion dollar study of a series of leaks, spills and fires at the refinery near St. Louis, Mo. ``Shell called us this morning with the updated figure,'' Flower said. He said no oil reached the river or a nearby marsh after the rupture in the pipeline, which leads from a storage tank at the refinery. ``The cleanup could take weeks, if not months,'' Flower said. Calls to the Shell refinery went unanswered late Thursday afternoon. Clean-up crews on Thursday used absorbent booms to soak up oil that washed into a retention pond built to catch spills, Flower said. The pond discharges into a marshy area, but there wasn't any noticeable oil in the marshy area, he said. On Wednesday, the Illinois EPA called for a study of the refinery to discover the cause of its recurring accidents. ``At this time, the entire Shell facility is a prime candidate for a hazard and operability study,'' Flower said. ``They do seem to be getting worse, and we feel a real strong need to get a study under way.'' Illinois Attorney General Neil F. Hartigan filed a lawsuit in September against Shell, seeking $1.2 million in penalties for the various environmental mishaps. Last week, Hartigan amended the suit to include nine other accidents at the refinery since late November.

DOC.HEAD: Women, Men's Survival After Heart Attacks Equivalent, Researchers Say
DOC.TEXT: Contrary to previous findings, women survive as well as men after heart attacks if their age and other illnesses are taken into account, a new study says. ``Merely being a woman in and of itself does not appear to be a risk factor'' in connection with heart attacks, said lead researcher Dr. Nicholas H. Fiebach of Yale University School of Medicine. Fiebach and his colleagues explored the issue after two previous studies yielded conflicting results. The new study involved 332 women and 790 men who had suffered heart attacks, and found that 29 percent of the women and 23 percent of the men died within the three years after the attack. But ``when we did a statistical analysis that took into account differences in age, diabetes and hypertension, the differences in mortality weren't there anymore,'' Fiebach said in a telephone interview Thursday. Heart disease is the leading killer of men and women, but women tend to be stricken when they are older and have more health problems, said Fiebach, whose study appears in Friday's Journal of the American Medical Association. Women were more critically ill when they were admitted to the hospital, and a greater proportion of them died there than did men, the researchers found. After being discharged from the hospital, however, the women's adjusted death rate appeared to be a little better than men's, though the difference was not statistically significant, Fiebach said. That finding is consistent with the fact that women in general tend to outlive men, he said. Critics of government-funded research have said recently that it has focused too heavily on middle-aged white men, leaving a gap in knowledge about women's health risks. ``It looks, from all of the studies we have to date, like the main risk factors for coronary heart disease in men are probably similar to the risk factors in women,'' Fiebach said. He said researchers need to study whether risk factors _ traits that correspond with above-average risk _ exist in women when they don't in men. ``We know there is some relationship between female hormones and coronary heart disease and menopause,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: News Editor Named in Tennessee
DOC.TEXT: Steve Baker, state editor for The Associated Press in Seattle since 1987, has been named the AP's news editor in Nashville. The appointment was announced Thursday by Nashville Chief of Bureau Kent Flanagan. Baker, 35, joined the AP in Nashville in 1981 and was named Knoxville correspondent in 1984. He moved to Seattle three years later. Baker is a native of Portsmouth, Va., and a graduate of Washington and Lee University. He began his journalism career at the Chattanooga News-Free Press.

DOC.HEAD: Nominees Announced for 42nd Annual Writers Guild Awards
DOC.TEXT: CBS, with 18 mentions, led the field Thursday when the nominations were announced for the 42nd Annual Writers Guild Awards. PBS, with 12 nominations, was second among the networks cited, although five of its nominations were in a single category. ABC had 10 nominations, followed by NBC with six. All the nominees were originally aired between Sept. 1, 1988, and Aug. 31, 1989. The winners will be announced March 18 at dual ceremonies in New York City and Beverly Hills, Calif. The awards honor outstanding achievement in writing for 13 television and two radio categories. The full list of nominees:

DOC.HEAD: Trial Judge Upholds Release On Bond Of Noriega Co-Defendant
DOC.TEXT: The trial judge in the drug trafficking case against ousted Panamanian leader Manuel Antonio Noriega upheld the release on bond of co-defendant Daniel Miranda on Thursday, but changed his bail conditions. Miranda and defendant Eduardo Pardo, who has pleaded guilty to a charge of illegal travel, were accused of flying $800,000 in drug money from Fort Lauderdale to Panama in 1983. A week ago, Pardo became the first of Noriega's co-defendants to plead guilty. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler upheld the pretrial release order of federal Magistrate Peter Palermo, but changed the amount of corporate surety bond from $100,000 to $200,000, while lowering the level of personal surety bond from $900,000 to $800,000, said Miranda's attorney, Michael O'Kane. O'Kane said the change in the corporate surety bond has doubled the 15 percent Miranda's family will have to pay to get him out. The personal surety bond will be backed by mortgages, he said. ``If the family can come up with $30,000 then he can get out. I thought that (Hoeveler) would uphold Palermo's decision,'' O'Kane said. ``But it increases the money he has to come up with, and that will make it a little harder.'' Miranda, who has been held at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center south of Miami, would be the second Noriega co-defendant released on bond. Brian Alden Davidow, who surrendered in February 1988, was released on bond four days after the indictment was handed down. Noriega is accused of accepting $4.6 million in bribes from the cartel. The Panamanian leader, who surrendered to U.S. troops after the December invasion of his country, has disputed the right of a U.S. civilian court to judge him. That question and other pending motions will be considered when Noriega and four co-defendants are to appear before Hoeveler Monday. Pardo faces up to five years in prison and a $10,000 fine and will face sentencing April 25 on the single count of illegal travel. Prosecutors say Pardo and Miranda flew a Lear jet fitted with secret compartments so that money could be hidden. But O'Kane said when Pardo pleaded that Miranda didn't know the money came from drugs. ``I guess Pardo's guilty. That doesn't mean that Miranda is,'' O'Kane said at the time.

DOC.HEAD: Police Evacuate Area Surrounding Mystery Truck
DOC.TEXT: A pickup truck loaded with drums of suspected explosive material erupted in flames near an Internal Revenue Service office Thursday, snarling traffic and forcing the evacuation of thousands. The abandoned truck burned itself out shortly after the fire was reported at 5 a.m., but police closed off a 15-block area for at least 13{ hours as a police bomb squad worked to defuse what appeared to be a makeshift bomb. ``The potential danger was very great,'' Assistant Police Chief Robert Vernon said Thursday afternoon. Vernon said material in the five drums appeared to be extremely dangerous, but it was not immediately identified. As he spoke, a fork lift operator was lifting the barrels out of the back of the truck. ``We can't say at this moment that it would have flattened so many blocks, but we have to assume the worst,'' Vernon said. The assistant chief added he could not remember an explosive situation ``quite this large. It looked to experts that it had the potential of being a large explosive device.'' The truck was parked outside a City National Bank building that also houses an IRS annex and other offices. Several explosions accompanied the early morning fire, said Cmdr. William Booth. ``It was shooting out flames,'' said Jim Nord, a 21-year-old tow truck driver who said he saw the truck burning early Thursday. ``There were explosions that sounded like shotgun blasts.'' Officers allowed the fire to burn itself out, called in bomb squad and hazardous materials experts and cordoned off the area. Agents from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms also were called in. Booth said the substance in drums ``can be easily ignited and can explode.'' He said the material ``is something our people know how to handle.'' The street closure created nightmares for rush hour commuters in the heavily commercial district. A fifth-floor window in the IRS office was broken, said Officer Sylvia Palacio of the West Los Angeles station. But it was unknown whether the broken window was related to the truck fire. IRS spokesman Robert Giannangeli said the agency had received no bomb threats. He said up to 250 agency personnel, including auditors, return examiners and criminal investigators, were based at the office. While the investigation took place, several thousand workers and residents were asked to evacuate the area. The Red Cross set up a shelter for evacuees at the Westwood Park & Recreation Center, said Red Cross spokeswoman Barbara Wilks.

DOC.HEAD: For Families Split at Border, No Reunification in Sight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: From across a gurgling brook, Abrahim Baht can see the house of his brother inside India but cannot go over to visit. When someone marries, Baht can hear the celebration from the house, which is about 10 yards away. When there's a death, the mournful wailing also reaches his ears. Baht, 80, is banned from the house of his brother, Suleiman, by a cease-fire line that separates India from Pakistan. Indian troops man bunkers opposite Baht's corn fields where the snow-capped mountains of the Himalayas stretch into the heavens. Pakistani trenches line the hills behind him. Sometimes a rattle of automatic weapons fire cuts through the peace of Bugina. Baht and his 70-year-old brother are Kashmiris, the people who have inhabited this Himalayan village for centuries. Their land was split between India and Pakistan in 1947 following the end of British colonial rule. The two countries fought wars over the region in 1948 and 1965. Now, although few fear another conflict, tensions are heating up again on the line. On Jan. 20, Indian troops launched a crackdown on Moslem separatists in India's state of Jammu-Kashmir, the only state in predominantly Hindu India with a Moslem majority. The separatists want either an independent Kashmir or union with Pakistan, a Moslem nation. Tensions escalated when Indian troops killed several Pakistani students Feb. 11 on the border after the students tried to cross into India in solidarity with the separatists. The recent troubles have made it even harder for Baht and his brother. When times were good, the men would meet on a small rock in the middle of the stream and gossip about life on either side. Sometimes they would bring dishes for each other, made by their wives. There are no telephones. Now, Pakistan and Indian troops have forbidden them from even talking. ``Don't let me catch you sneaking to the brook, old man!'' Pakistan army Lt. Raza Aqeel shouted at Baht one recent day near the cease-fire line. ``You've lived a long time. Don't end it with an Indian bullet.'' ``They are my people, how can I ignore them?'' Baht growled as his beard, dyed red with henna, bobbed up and down. ``Politics has divided my house in two. My heart is weeping.'' Aqeel commands the posts above Baht's house and is responsible for security in Bugina, a village of about 500 people. ``We are ready for the enemy,'' Aqeel said, full of a soldier's bravado. ``We have all the newest weapons and we are sure to win.'' The young lieutenant's bluster is not shared by Mohammed Arfan, a 45-year-old farmer who lives in a big blue house just yards from the Baht clan. Arfan fled to Pakistan after the 1965 war, which like the 1948 conflict, was lost by Islamabad. He joined the Pakistan army, traveled throughout the country but chose to settle in Bugina because it was the nearest he could get to his native home. ``This is my valley and fighting would only make us poorer,'' said the 45-year-old father of six. ``I wish the politicians would forget us and then maybe we could live in peace.'' Arfan grew up on the Indian side of the cease-fire line. To this day, his father and three brothers live in a small compound across the creek in India. ``I came back in 1970. I was homesick for the Kashmir but living here mixes happiness with pain,'' he said. ``I am so close to my people I can smell their cooking but I can't shake the hand of my father.'' Two weeks ago, one of his nephews was married on the Indian side. ``Listening to the noise was like a dagger splitting you in two,'' said another relative Mohammed Dayub, who operates the village's flour mill. ``I wanted to make them cakes.'' Bugina is populated by devout Moslems. Men often conduct their noon prayers on rocks amid the roaring blue waters of the Neelum River, which means turquoise in the Urdu language. Women cover their heads in public and are generally banned from the bazaar in the nearest town, about a mile away. Thus, it is to their god, Allah, that many in Bugina look to solve the problems of Kashmir. India is not expected to give up its portion and Pakistan would not tolerate an independence movement on its side of the cease-fire line. Says Baht, pointing to his brother who has come out of his house on the other side of the line: ``All we can do is pray.''

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Voting: Indelible Ink, Two Counts, 1,000 Observers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Nicaraguan voters will mark three separate ballots in Sunday's election, then dip a thumb in nearly indelible blue ink to ensure they won't vote again. More than 1.7 million people have registered to vote in the elections for president, National Assembly and municipal councils. The voting age is 16. Voting in the nation's 4,394 polling precincts begins at 7 a.m. and ends at 6 p.m. Anyone in line to vote at closing time will be allowed to mark the paper ballots that bear party or coalition symbols as well as the names of the candidates and their affiliation. Election officials will check voter registration cards against a master list of voters before permitting people to vote. The registration cards do not bear a photo of the voter but they indicate each citizen's name, address, age and a registration number. They also indicate where the bearer is allowed to vote and where his or her name should be on the master registration list prepared by the Supreme Electoral Council, the national election authority. The ballots are cast in a booth to assure privacy, then put into boxes, one for each race. Then each voter is required to dip a thumb in bright blue ink, donated by Venezuela. Election observers who have sampled the ink say it takes days to wash off. Once the polls close, the ballot boxes will be opened and counted in each precinct in the presence of poll watchers from each party, election officials and any accredited international observers who are present. The results and other information, such as who witnessed the count, will be compiled on official tally sheets and the results will be telegraphed to central office of the Supreme Electoral Council in the capital as well as the regional council. Officials say they will begin releasing preliminary results on election night. The president of each precinct will deliver the ballots, registration lists, tally sheets and other materials to one of the nine regional election centers for a second count. Observers from both the United Nations and the Organization of America States will be present in each of the nine regional centers as well as many local precincts and they will also be given copies of the official tally sheets. There are more than 1,000 official observers accredited by the Supreme Electoral Council. Both the United Nations and the OAS will do parallel tallies to check against the official results. Many of the voting procedures were designed with input from the observer teams and the political parties, each of which is represented on the Supreme Electoral Council.

DOC.HEAD: Nose Gear on Canadian Air Force Jet Collapses; No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: The nose gear of a Canadian Air Force jet carrying some members of the Canadian Parliament collapsed when the plane landed at the Charleston International Airport late Thursday, authorities said. There were no injuries among the 62 people aboard the Boeing 707 in the 4:37 p.m. accident, said John Whiteside, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration in Atlanta. ``It slid to a stop on the runway after the landing gear collapsed,'' said Whiteside. ``There was slight damage to the nose of the aircraft.'' Capt. Alain Francois, the public information officer for the Canadian Forces in Ottawa, said a number of members of the Canadian Parliament were among the 53 passengers on the craft. He did not say how many. He said the plane had left Ottawa earlier in the day but did not know the purpose of the trip to Charleston. Capt. Paul Tessyman, a spokesman for the Canadian Air Force Base in Trenton, said the families of the parliamentarians had been notified that they are safe and the legislators will be returning to Canada on Monday. The Air Force Base and the Charleston International Airport share the same runways. Officials said the accident would be investigated by both American and Canadian aviation officials.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Begins Inquiry Into Stuart Shootings Case
DOC.TEXT: The FBI has begun a preliminary inquiry into the way Boston police investigated the circumstances surrounding the shooting of Carol Stuart, who was apparently the victim of a fatal plot concocted by her husband. Initiated at the request of U.S. Attorney Wayne Budd, the probe was undertaken ``concerning allegations that individuals were coerced or intimidated into making statements implicating Willie Bennett,'' according to a statement issued Thursday by FBI special agent Thomas Hughes. Bennett was named as a suspect after the pregnant attorney was shot Oct. 23 and her husband, Charles Stuart, was seriously wounded. His name was cleared after Stuart apparently committed suicide Jan. 4 upon learning that his brother had implicated him in the crime. Stuart originally told police a black gunman had murdered his wife in the city's Mission Hill neighborhood, touching off a massive search in which black residents allege their civil rights were violated and witnesses were coerced. Police Commissioner Francis M. Roache was advised of the inquiry and has promised the department's cooperation, the statement said. Roache and Suffolk County District Attorney Newman Flanagan did not immediately return messages late Thursday night. Mayor Raymond Flynn, in an interview with television station WGBH, said he welcomed the probe and vowed to take disciplinary action if any police officers were charged with wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Pop star Stevie Wonder says justice is sweet following a jury's rejection of a $25 million claim that his Oscar-winner song ``I Just Called to Say I Love You'' was stolen from another songwriter. The plaintiff, Lloyd Chiate, claimed Wonder's song, part of the movie soundtrack for ``Woman in Red,'' was taken from a song he co-wrote titled, ``I Just Called To Say.'' ``I knew the truth in my heart all along,'' said Wonder. ``I'm very sorry a lot of people had to spend a lot of precious time in this courtroom. But I do appreciate and respect justice.'' Wonder, 39, offered to try to smooth over the dispute by writing a song with Chiate and Lee Garrett, co-author of ``I Just Called To Say,'' and donate the proceeds to charity. ``Then we all really win,'' Wonder said. Chiate wasn't present when the jury announced its verdict Thursday. His attorney, Herbert Dodell, said his client was wronged by a star-struck jury and a biased judge.

Soviet beauty queen Anna Gorbunova declared her delight at becoming a ``true Christian'' after her baptism in a Ukrainian Orthodox church here. Ms. Gorbunova, the Moscow secretary who became the first Miss USSR last year, said she loved Sydney so much she decided to be baptized Thursday during a promotional trip to Australia. ``I was very nervous in the ceremony; I had goose bumps all over myself,'' Ms. Gorbunova said through an interpreter. In the Soviet Union, especially in the period before President Mikhail Gorbachev consolidated power, ``there have been too many restrictions concerning the practice of religion,'' said Ms. Gorbunova's manager, Alexander Djamirze.

Sisters Loretta Lynn, Crystal Gayle and Peggy Sue will make their Grand Ole Opry debut as a trio Saturday night, a spokeswoman said. The three country music singers, daughters of Ted and Clara Webb, have been singing together at concerts for the past year but this will be their first time together on the country music show, spokeswoman Susan Sizemore said. The performance will be televised on the cable station The Nashville Network at 8:30 p.m. EST. They will be interviewed on TNN's ``Grand Ole Opry Live Backstage'' at 8 p.m. EST.

Actress Valerie Harper says the suicide of Joan Rivers' husband shook her out of the doldrums after she was fired from her top-rated NBC sitcom. ``The week I was fired was the same week that Joan Rivers lost her husband. I thought, `My God, I'm blessed.' Think of people with real problems, who live with illness, with drive-by shootings in their neighborhoods,'' Harper told USA Weekend magazine in Sunday's edition. In her new show, ``City,'' Harper appears opposite her old show, ``The Hogan Family.'' She said she had some fears about becoming a Hollywood pariah when she sued producers of ``Hogan'' following her dismissal. ``There was definitely a buzz around town: `Has she gone mad?' If I'd been a young actress ... I might have been destroyed,'' Harper said.

A criminal charge was filed against a man who allegedly wrote a letter threatening the life of singer Debbie Gibson. Assistant U.S. Attorney Thomas M. Bauer said Thursday that Richard C. Pelfrey, 37, was charged with mailing threatening communications and faced a maximum sentence of 20 years imprisonment and a $250,000 fine if convicted. Authorities said the letter mailed to Joseph Gibson, Ms. Gibson's father, included a threat to kill Miss Gibson if she played at Blossom Music Center in Cuyahoga Falls. She performed at the center Sept. 13 without incident. Pelfrey's lawyer, Susan Pritchard, did not return telephone calls Thursday.

A free-lance photographer claimed he was roughed up by two of rock star Janet Jackson's bodyguards at a hotel. Doug Mays, 40, of Moss Point, Miss., wanted the bodyguards arrested after the scuffle Wednesday, but police officer Richard Baily said he couldn't file charges because the parties involved gave conflicting statements. Mays and his wife, Sammie, 32, said they were headed for the 15th floor of the hotel to meet ``Good Morning America'' host Charlie Gibson who was doing his television program from Pensacola. Mays said they tried to get off the elevator on the 14th floor, reserved for members of the Jackson tour, in search of a soft drink machine. The photographer said he didn't know Jackson was in town. The bodyguards ``shoved me back in the elevator,'' said Mays, whom police said was not hurt. The bodyguards, Jack Colen, 56, of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif., and Marcus David Johnson, 30, of Huntington Beach, Calif., told police they pushed Mays after he used racial slurs when they told him to leave.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Boxing heavyweight champion James ``Buster'' Douglas' next fight may be in a courtroom, courtesy of a breach of contract lawsuit filed by promoter Don King. King is seeking several million dollars in damages and also is asking the U.S. District Court in Manhattan for an injunction to prevent Douglas from fighting without his involvement. Douglas won the title with a shocking 10th-round knockout of Mike Tyson on Feb. 11 in Tokyo. Douglas has said he will not fight for King because the promoter challenged the result of the bout by claiming that Douglas got a long count after being knocked down in the eighth round. King's lawsuit claims he had an agreement with Douglas to promote future fights. Douglas signed a conditional contract with Steve Wynn's Mirage hotel-casino in Las Vegas for two fights, the first probably against Evander Holyfield.

DOC.HEAD: Warplanes Blast Guerrilla Base in Southern Lebanon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with air attack Friday, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes on Friday blasted a guerrilla base in southern Lebanon in Israel's fourth air raid in less than a week in the same area, the military command said. It was the second attack within 24 hours at the base near the village of Liba, four miles east of the port city of Sidon. All targets were hit and the planes returned safely to base, the command said. The statement said the base was used by a terrorist organization to launch attacks against Israel. It did not identify the group. The same base was hit Thursday, and Beirut radio stations reported at the time Israeli warplanes struck a base belonging to a Lebanese fundamentalist Moslem militia known as the Islamic Grouping. Three guerrillas were reported injured in Thursday's raid. On Saturday, Israeli aircraft attacked a position near Sidon used by the mainstream Shiite Moslem Amal militia. On Monday, Israeli jets bombed a base near Sidon belonging to the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a Marxist PLO faction.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Pet Tiger Needs Insurance Policy
DOC.TEXT: The judge gave Dennis Schaeffer a choice: Either he gets a $5 million insurance policy for his pet tiger, or back to jail he goes. Schaeffer, 42, is accused of threatening police with his striped pet, Tanya, when they went to his home with a warrant to arrest him in a domestic dispute earlier in the month. Schaeffer opened the tiger's cage and commanded it to ``take care of them'' if they got closer, police said. Schaeffer was charged with reckless endangerment and resisting arrest. He was freed on $10,000 bond, but Common Pleas Judge Michael Joyce on Wednesday said that unless Schaeffer gets liability insurance, neither he nor his tiger can remain on the loose. Schaeffer also must build two secure fences around his home, where Tanya is being kept, Joyce said. There is no space for the tiger at the Erie Zoo, zoo officials said. Schaeffer's lawyer, Daniel Brabender, said he doubted even Lloyd's of London would underwrite a policy for Tanya.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Drive to Unify Germany Cannot Skirt Potholes
DOC.TEXT: The drive to unify Germany, which has the enthusiastic support of the Bush administration, may have to slow down to deal with some painful questions about borders and with echoes of a horrible past. The pace has picked up to the point Secretary of State James A. Baker III would not be surprised if there is union of West Germany with East Germany by the end of the year. Many West Germans say they are sure of it. As Baker and his key advisers see it, free elections in East Germany in mid-March will legitimize the government that emerges. The elected leaders then could begin unification talks quickly with West Germany. The catchy ``Two-Plus-Four'' formula that Baker persuaded the Soviet Union, Britain and France to approve at an Open Skies conference last week in Ottawa gives the Germans a lot of room to decide their country's future. The Big Four allies of World War II then would meet to discuss security issues. But the formula is vague on how much influence the four _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France _ would have over sovereign German policy. So far, the main U.S. goal is that Germany remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. However, there is a lot more on the minds of the Soviet Union and Poland, bloodied victims of German invasion a half-century ago. They are seeking reassurance the mighty country about to emerge is not looking eastward to recover territory lost at the end of World War II. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev acknowledged again on Tuesday that the two Germanys had a right to unify. But he stressed the Soviet Union's own ``inalienable right'' to make sure unification does not lead to ``moral, political or economic damage.'' Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, meanwhile, suggested unification would not happen ``as quickly as they imagine in Bonn,'' adding that ``it requires several years.'' The German lebensraum that drove the world into its costliest war in 1939 is on the minds of lots of Europeans. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has said repeatedly the new Germany would encompass West Germany, East Germany and the now-divided city of Berlin, but it would seek no other territory. The two Germanys have signed agreements recognizing Poland's western border. But West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who will visit President Bush this weekend at Camp David, has said he cannot make promises about the border on behalf of a united Germany. Other victims of Nazi aggression also are anxious. Moshe Arad, the Israeli ambassador to Washington, told the American Jewish Congress in West Palm Beach, Fla., Monday that Israel recognizes the right of the German people to determine their own destiny. At the same time, Arad said, ``we are totally justified in observing with trepidation the movement toward German unification.'' The Nazis and their accomplices tried to extinguish European Jewry in World War II. They nearly reached their goal, killing 6 million. Poland, which was crushed by the German war machine, is seeking a peace treaty to secure its western border. ``We are demanding that before the reunification,'' Prime Minister Tadeausz Mazowiecki said Wednesday. ``The total removal of those ambiguities must take place.'' So far, the Bush administration will not expand the group of four to include Poland or other European countries. The U.S. position rests on the agreement at the end of World War II that gave the Big Four allies special rights over vanquished Germany. But Mazowiecki said ``it is unthinkable in today's democratic world to have this form of Yalta, where one group of countries could decide about another.'' West Germany has rejected a role for Poland, but approval of the ``Two-Plus-Four'' plan in Ottawa does not deter the Soviet Union from supporting Warsaw's claim. The uncertain situation has had an ironic twist. The Solidarity-dominated Warsaw government wants to keep Soviet troops in Poland as insurance against the new Germany even as it breaks away from Leninism. Genscher, with U.S. support, has offered to keep NATO forces from moving into what is now East German territory after unification. But evidently the offer is not enough to quiet everyone's nerves. Kohl's talks with Bush and Baker will have to take these concerns into account.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid cover diplomacy for The Associated Press out of the State Department.

DOC.HEAD: Landfill Fight Latest in War Between Cape Community and Uncle Sam
DOC.TEXT: Stop dumping your trash on our national seashore, the federal government is telling the Cape Cod, Mass., community of Provincetown. Stop playing Big Brother with our land, is the town's response. What began as a squabble over the future of the Provincetown landfill has escalated to a Cabinet and congressional-level fight. On the surface is a dispute over the future of a town dump located on federal property. Underneath, according to some participants, is the latest skirmish in a dispute between a small community and the federal government over one of the nation's most popular seacoast attractions _ the Cape Cod National Seashore. ``The seashore has an `I don't care' attitude,'' Sandra Turner, Provincetown's public works director, said Thursday. ``This is Big Brother _ the federal government _ and it's picking on this tiny community.'' The federal government no longer wants Provincetown to use National Seashore land for its town landfill. Seashore officials have given the community of 3,200 year-round residents on the tip of Cape Cod until October to find another place to dump their trash. Seashore officials say the landfill threatens the pristine sand dunes and scrub pine forests that form the spectacular landscape on the tip of Cape Cod. The dump ``has adverse impacts on groundwater, wetlands and ponds,'' said Andrew Ringgold, superintendent of the Cape Cod National Seashore. ``There's windblown litter all through adjacent areas ... It's just totally incompatible with the mission of the National Park Service.'' The town argues it may use the landfill under an agreement reached in 1961 when the National Park Service established the National Seashore _ a move that swallowed up 80 percent of Provincetown's land area. The rancor over the landfill dispute has much deeper roots, according to local and regional officials. The town has feuded with the seashore over beach access for local fishermen driving off-road vehicles, over the extension of a commission designed to hear local concerns about the seashore management, and over a federal plan to demolish dune shacks viewed by locals as historic relics. Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., met with Constance Harriman, an official in the Department of Interior, regarding the landfill dispute. ``Should this decision stand,'' Studds said, ``it would worsen the already strained relationship between the town and the federal agency.'' Ringgold said his first responsibility is to the environmental integrity of the seashore. But he conceded that good public relations with the six communities that encompass the seashore are crucial. ``One of my biggest responsibilities is to develop and maintain cooperative working relationships with officials of these communities,'' Ringgold said. But he added, ``cooperative working relationships doesn't always mean we're going to agree on everything.'' Ringgold, who took over his job in November, was not around during the earlier battles between the town and the park service. On July 4, 1989, a parade of four-wheel-drive vehicles drove through Provincetown to underscore the local popularity of motor access to the dunes. There have been delays in recent years in receiving federal approval for meetings of the Seashore Advisory Commission, a sounding board for local concerns about the seashore and its management. And only after a long battle did local preservationists save dune shacks _ some of which were used by famous authors and artists _ from demolition. But Ringgold said he resents the efforts by locals to portray the seashore as a faceless bureaucracy beating up on a tiny community. ``I don't think that this ought to be painted as a P.R. problem or a battle with the town,'' Ringgold said. ``It's just an accident of geography.''

DOC.HEAD: Infant Seat Rule Could Increase Travel Cost For Young Families
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Air travel for families with young children could become more costly under the airline industry's proposed infant safety seat requirement. In an unusual step, the Air Transport Association asked the Federal Aviation Administration to set a tougher requirement than the agency itself is considering. The FAA on Thursday proposed regulations to require airlines to allow passengers to use safety seats if they want to _ airlines now have the option of barring them _ and said it would consider making the seats mandatory after receiving public comment on the issue. The ATA, which represents major air carriers, wants the seats required for all passengers under 2 years old. The ATA proposes that the rule change go into effect a year after it is adopted. The proposal, if adopted by the FAA, could require thousands of parents each day to buy tickets for children who now fly free. Airlines, however, still would have the option of offering free rides or reduced fares. ``If you buckle your children up at 50 miles per hour, why not at 550 miles per hour?'' asked ATA President Robert Aaronson. He referred to laws in all states that require safety seats for infants in automobiles. FAA rules say children under 2 may be carried in adult airline passengers' laps. Airlines previously encouraged infant seat use but opposed rules to require them. FAA Administrator James Busey said he welcomed the industry's ``willingness to enhance passenger safety.'' The airline group also announced a campaign to distribute cards advising parents to buy tickets for their youngsters and take along car safety seats when they fly, even though they are not now required. Concern over infant safety seats increased after the July 19 crash of a United Airlines DC-10 at Sioux City, Iowa, in which an unsecured infant was among 112 people killed. Scores of other passengers escaped. In the Avianca crash that killed 73 people in New York a month ago, 17 infants were among the 159 passengers. One child was killed and six were injured. Aaronson told a news conference that the 5,000 to 10,000 infants carried by U.S. airlines daily would be ``far safer'' strapped into car seats than in adults' laps. Nearly all car seats carry labels saying they are approved for planes by the FAA. If the rule is imposed, Airlines likely would continue to accept infants free on flights when extra seats are available, he said, acknowledging that parents might have to pay full or discount fares to take them on heavily booked flights. Asked why the industry does not adopt the infant seat requirement on its own, Aaronson said there is a growing consensus among airlines, medical organizations, consumer groups and others that a uniform FAA rule would be best. Just before the ATA news conference, Rep. Jim Lightfoot, R-Iowa, and Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., told a news conference they will push legislation that would order the FAA to require the seats. ``If you have a corpse on an airplane, it has to be tied down,'' said Lightfoot, ``but a kid can be left to fly free around the cabin.'' Bond said that when he was Missouri governor he had difficulty getting airlines to allow him to use a car seat for his infant son. Bond held a lifelike doll against his chest and, to demonstrate what could happen aboard an airliner, tossed it out of his hands. ``A baby becomes a ballistic,'' he said. The FAA has resisted calls for tougher rules, partly because of the cost to parents and the low number of infant casualties in airliner accidents. A Harvard Medical School study estimated in the early 1980s that three lives could have been saved over five years with the use of safety seats.

DOC.HEAD: A Wink for the Defendant, but Trouble Recalling Details
DOC.TEXT: The witness was affable. He took the oath, took the stand, winked at the defendant, stated his name, spelled it out, ``Ronald R-E-A-G-A-N,'' and said he used to be in politics and before that in the movies and ``prior to that I was a sports announcer in radio.'' But in his command performance for the cameras of the court, Ronald Reagan had trouble remembering. Dates. Pictures. Documents. Memoes. Aides. Meetings. He is 79 years old now, and some of the events he was questioned about took place years ago. He has always denied directing them. ``There were so many meetings and so many different places,'' he said on the witness stand. ``I know it is tough, Mr. President,'' said lawyer Richard Beckler. Asked if he had dispatched John Vessey to Central America, Reagan had trouble identifying Vessey, who served as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff from June 1982 to September 1985. Counsel: ``Could you explain to the members of the jury who General Vessey was?'' Reagan: ``Oh, dear. I could ask for help here. The name I know is very familiar. I am wondering if _'' Counsel: ``This is in connection with a trip by the Joint Chiefs of Staff.'' Reagan: ``Well, that _ I don't _ I don't think this was my military aide, but obviously he was in a position to do this if he was the chief of staff.'' Questioned in his videotaped deposition last week, to be used in the trial of his former national security adviser, John M. Poindexter, Reagan was treated with deference. ``Mr. President,'' he was called. At one point, a lawyer went too far _ directing the witness, ``perhaps you could tell the jurors as much as you can remember about that whole scene right there with Mr. Jacobson'' _ and Judge Harold Greene interrupted. ``No,'' said Greene, ``No, no, no, no, no. We're not here to inquest the entire Contra affair.'' Greene himself is a testament to the democratic system. He was born Heinz Grunhaus in 1923 in Frankfurt an der Oder in what is now East Germany. He presided over one of the most important cases _ the breakup of AT&T _ in American commercial history. Now he is presiding over a trial of a former top presidential aide charged with obstructing Congress, conspiracy and making false statements about the sale of arms to Iran and the transfer of the proceeds to the Contras. Poindexter wants to show he was following Reagan's orders. Reagan was generally relaxed, genial, occasionally testy. He offered a broad wink to defendant Poindexter. He talked directly into the camera. It was vintage Reagan: a man of iron conviction on the big picture, but fading on the details. He told anew of Lenin's plot to take over Eastern Europe, then ``the hordes of Asia,'' then Latin America so America would be left alone, ``the last bastion of capitalism.'' But he was rusty about the role of Col. Oliver North. Asked what he thought North had been doing, he said: ``You have to have people that can be available to make contact with the leaders of the Contras and so forth, sometimes closer than just writing a letter. ... It was my understanding because his name would crop up in memos and so forth that that's what he was doing.'' He was asked if he remembered what position Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., took on Contra aid when he ran the House Intelligence Committee. ``I don't recall what position he was taking or where he was. There are 435 of them, remember.'' He was asked about a meeting with a European prime minister. ``Since I met with 400 heads of state, heads of government, foreign ministers and so forth in the eight years, no I can't recall what I particularly said to any of them.'' He was asked if he remembered reading a memo which bore his initials on the bottom. He said the papers generated in his White House were numerous. ``There are 50 million pieces of paper.'' He was asked if he recalled meeting Contra leader Adolfo Calero, who posed with him in a White House picture. ``I hate to keep throwing figures at you,'' he said, ``but I have been told that because of the business of our Hollywood photographers, I have got something over a million photos of people that came in there as visitors.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Reagan's Testimony, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some of the highlights from former President Reagan's testimony for John Poindexter's upcoming trial in the Iran-Contra affair: _Reagan said he never ``had any inkling'' his aides were secretly arming the Nicaraguan Contras. _He said he remained unconvinced there had been a diversion of Iran arms sale money to the rebels until prosecutors confronted him with the report of the Tower Commission he appointed. _Reagan said he would have expected Poindexter, his former national security adviser, to inform him of any diversion of funds to the Contras ``unless maybe he thought he was protecting me from something.'' _Reagan said he agreed with a letter Poindexter sent to Congress saying the White House was complying with the congressional ban on help for the Contras _ a letter that forms part of the basis for one charge Poindexter faces. However, Reagan said he was unfamiliar with references in the letter to earlier denials that North was raising funds or supplying the Contras with military advice. _During cross-examination, prosecutors introduced evidence that Poindexter lied to Reagan about the secret aid operation after a C-123 cargo plane was shot down over Nicaragua during a supply flight on Oct. 5, 1986. In written interrogatories to the Iran-Contra grand jury earlier, Reagan said Poindexter first told him that the sole survivor of the crash, Eugene Hasenfus, was not connected with the U.S. government. _Reagan may have helped Poindexter by testifying that he could not recall when he knew about a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. The shipment figures in four of the five criminal charges against Poindexter. Poindexter is accused of telling Congress in November 1986 that U.S. officials didn't find out that Hawks were aboard the 1985 shipment until January 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 34,890.97, down 935.87 points, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Chattanooga Sues To Halt Showing Of `Oh! Calcutta!'
DOC.TEXT: The city wants ``Oh! Calcutta!,'' Broadway's long-running nude revue, to bare all somewhere else. Officials filed suit Thursday in Hamilton County Chancery Court to block the showing of ``Oh! Calcutta!'' at the Tivoli Theater on grounds the musical is obscene and lewd. ``Oh! Calcutta!,'' the second-longest Broadway musical with 5,959 performances, raised eyebrows and was threatened with banning when it opened in 1969, when nudity on stage and screen was still something of a novelty. Many critics consider ``Oh! Calcutta!'' a fairly tame show, but its current six-month tour of more than 90 cities has shown the passions it aroused 20 years ago still linger. On Feb. 7, the city authorities of Springfield, Mo., forced the actors to wear bras, flesh-colored underwear and G-strings during a performance before 5,000 people _ the first time the Calcutta cast had been clad. A Chattanooga promoter wants to stage the play May 2 or May 6, but the Memorial Auditorium Board, which runs the Tivoli, voted last week against bringing in the production. Al Stewart, spokesman for the musical's promoter, Singer Entertainment Consultants of Port Murray, N.J., said the play was not obscene. ``Something that has been around for 21 years and has played in 15 countries before 60 million people, I wouldn't go that far ... to say it is obscene,'' said Stewart. ``It is done in art. It's theater.'' City Attorney Randy Nelson said the board ``just wants to do what it feels is best for the community and have shows that are in tune with community tastes.'' The 10-page lawsuit contends the musical violates the state's obscenity law, as well as state and local laws against indecent exposure and a local ordinance against lewd and indecent conduct. The musical includes simulated intercourse. Officials filed the lawsuit because the Tivoli is publicly owned and can only deny use if an event violates local laws or business criteria. It is not the first time in recent history that city officials tried to ban a theatrical production. In 1975, an effort to block a production of the rock musical ``Hair'' went all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court. The justices did not rule on whether ``Hair'' was obscene, but they did strike down the ban on grounds that officials did not have sufficient evidence to halt the play. ``The reason the city lost the `Hair' case was, they (banned the play) without first-hand information. They did so on hearsay,'' said David Johnson, manager of the Tivoli. ``Here, they have read the actual script of this particular presentation.''

DOC.HEAD: Whodunit: Ranch Animals Die, Nobody Knows Why
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: There are 270 dead sheep, 100 aborted calves, six sick people, traces of chemicals and sightings of a mysterious crop duster airplane. And while some tantalizing hints have been raised, no one really knows the solution to this rural whodunit in southeastern Washington's cattle and potato-growing country. ``How to poison that many animals that fast is still a mystery,'' said Clarke Brown, a state Department of Agriculture investigator. ``For that many to get poisoned without finding the obvious source is extremely unusual.'' Investigators are focusing on two farm chemicals but say they don't account for all the problems. In fact, they say the animal deaths, which occurred in adjacent fields, could be unrelated. According to the investigators, some evidence was initially withheld by witnesses, and so much time passed before a veterinarian was called after the mid-January cow abortions that any chemical traces had disappeared. ``All I know is a bunch of cattle died, and sheep,'' said Len McIrvin, the rancher who lost 15 cows and about 100 calves in the spontaneous abortions. One possible culprit, the Hanford nuclear weapons plant, has been ruled out by investigators. The government plant, the most contaminated nuclear waste site in the nation, is a few miles west of Burbank. Its proximity seems to have made residents of the Snake River town of 700 immune to sudden panic. ``We've lived around a nuclear plant all our lives,'' John Hash of Burbank said. ``Why worry about a few sheep dying?'' Investigators admit they may never know the full story. ``I've been involved in looking at cases for 15 years and I've never seen anything like it,'' said Lynden Baum, an investigator for the state Department of Health. This much is known: _ About 270 sheep were found dead in a field near Burbank on Nov. 21. Investigators have ruled out overeating, bad water, weeds or diseases. Tests of the animals' stomach fluids found traces of the pesticide aldicarb, used to kill insects in potatoes. Investigators don't know how the chemical got there, but there is some suspicion that the sheep may have eaten from bags of aldicarb that had not yet been used, Brown said. ``The bags were not mentioned for the first full week. We were well into the investigation when we learned that some bags were out there,'' Brown said. The only known farm chemicals being applied at the time the sheep died was Telone, used to control worms in potatoes. It was found in the kidney of only one sampled sheep, Brown said. _ Six people who traveled in the vicinity of the field that day have reported becoming ill with respiratory problems. Three are still reporting breathing problems, the Agriculture Department said. ``We don't know what hurt the people,'' Baum said. _ One dead Hereford cow was found in an adjacent field the day after the sheep died, along with signs that four pregnant cows had aborted. In mid-January, two weeks before the calving season, about half the 226 heifers on McIrvin's nearby Diamond M Ranch had miscarriages. The normal miscarriage rate that late would be almost zero, McIrvin said. About 15 cows also died in January. Ranchers did not call a veterinarian into the case until last week, Brown said. By then it was impossible to find traces of chemicals in the animals, he said. ``We assumed what was killing the sheep killed the cattle,'' McIrvin said. _ A ranch employee who became ill waited several months before reporting the sighting of a propeller-driven airplane dropping a white powder near the cows on Nov. 21. Others nearby saw no airplane. Officials aren't sure why the plane was not reported before.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Charles Raps Cities as Symbols of `Throwaway Society'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Prince Charles makes it plain as the nose on his royal face that he isn't very fond of modern British architecture. What then, an American asked, does he think of Washington's gleaming new skyline of glass and steel? The 41-year-old heir to the British throne rocked on his heels at the embassy reception Thursday, paused a long moment and smiled mischievously. ``I prefer Paris,'' he said. His reply foreshadowed the indictment of modern urban design that he delivered a few hours later at a black-tie awards gala of the American Institute of Architects at the National Building Museum, where roast beef was served by candlelight at $250 a plate. If the 1,200 architects and their guests wanted their dessert laced with princely scorn, Charles scorn, Charles didn't disappoint them. ``Much of the commercial building of today bears as much relation to architecture as advertising slogans bear to literature,'' he said, charging that their designers ``ransack history as if it were a wardrobe full of old clothes.'' Charles challenged American architects to reverse the trend toward cities that are ``the epitome of the throwaway society'' _ torn down and rebuilt by successive generations _ and design buildings of lasting beauty that are fit for human beings. ``It sometimes seems to me that the richer we get, the uglier we tend to make our surroundings,'' he said. ``What is worse, not only do we seem to have mislaid the ability to create beauty, but we also set out to destroy what beauty there is left in the world.'' The prince said his invitation to speak was mystifying, considering his criticism of the ``Frankenstein monsters'' created by some British architects. ``Is there an epidemic of masochism sweeping the ranks of the AIA?'' he asked. The audience roared. Charles' speech was the highlight of a one-day Washington visit that also included lunch with President Bush and his top advisers at the White House, a visit to AIA headquarters and a British Embassy reception. Outside the banquet hall, about two dozen protesters stood behind police lines silently holding placards demanding withdrawal of British troops from Northern Ireland. But Charles was greeted by friendly demonstrators when he arrived at the AIA's Octagon Museum in midafternoon to open an exhibition of artifacts from Sir Christopher Wren's design and construction of St. Paul's Cathedral in London. ``Gee, whiz,'' Charles said as he emerged from his Rolls-Royce limousine and saw picketers waving signs that read, ``Our Knight in Shining Armor'' and ``Humane Architecture _ Happy People.'' As he left AIA headquarters, the prince shook hands with 10-year-old Christopher Wren of Chevy Chase, Md., whose mother, Sherry, said he decided to become an architect when he learned about his famous 17th century English namesake. ``I hear you're a practicing architect,'' Charles said. ``Well, I'd like to be someday,'' young Christopher replied, adding that he already had a drafting table and a portfolio of designs. ``It was really neat meeting him,'' the boy said after Charles left for the embassy reception honoring alumni of the Marshall Scholars program. Under the program that began in 1954, a small group of exceptional American students _ currently 30 each year _ are chosen to spend two or three years at British universities, with all expenses paid by the British government. Charles urged the alumni to ``use the power of the lobby'' to carry out his goals of improving education, protecting the environment and encouraging private investment to revitalize deteriorating urban neighborhoods. Embassy sources said the prince's luncheon discussion with Bush dealt with environmental concerns and Charles' plan to visit Hungary in early May. One purpose of that trip, they said, will be to explore opportunities for private investments aimed to building a free-market economy in that country. Charles returns to London today after meeting at the embassy with a group of U.S. environmental experts.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Sees Farmers Sowing More Debt This Year
DOC.TEXT: The typical farmer may be ready to buy something new for the first time in seven years instead of paying off old debts. It could be additional land, machinery or other items needed to produce crops and livestock, says the Agriculture Department. In any case, the purchases probably will require at least some borrowed money. Farm debt nationally is expected to grow slightly in 1990, ending an unprecedented paydown that began in the mid-1980s. For most farmers, there was little choice as heavy debt loads and declining land values shrank their options. But now, after several years of financial recovery, the department's Economic Research Service says 1990 will be a turning point and farm debt will grow again. Economist Jerry Stam said Thursday it will be a ``real weak'' turnaround, certainly not the thunderous kickoff of another boom era. That happened in the 1970s, when soaring farmland prices and quick credit convinced thousands of farmers prosperity was around the corner. It wasn't, and in the early 1980s the financial crunch was on. As land values plummeted, so did credit ratings and farmers had to reorganize to survive. Paying off some of the old debt was part of the drill. Total U.S. farm debt peaked at $192.7 billion in 1983, more than double what it was a decade earlier. Since 1983, farm debt has declined for six straight years to an estimated $135.6 billion in 1989, at $57.1 billion the biggest paydown on record. Now, Stam said, ``The lenders are really competing for top-quality loans, so they're starting to fight over market share again.'' ``But the farmers have so adjusted to the way they're operating that I don't see any great change (in total debt). It wouldn't surprise me if it didn't do much at all,'' he said. Until the six-year paydown, there had been only one year _ 1953 _ since 1945 in which farm debt did not increase. The figures by themselves are boggling. In 1945, farmers owed $6.7 billion. It took until 1977 for farm debt to top $100 billion. The figures do not include ``operator household'' debt owed for consumer items such as cars, furniture and other family items bought on credit. Stam said an end to farm debt increases in 1990 depend on a number of factors, including farmland values, net cash income and decisions by farmers to buy additional land or replace worn machinery. The record $57.1 paydown in the six years after farm debt peaked in 1983 was also spurred by writeoffs of bad loans by major lenders, Stam said. In all, those totaled about $13.8 billion. Stam said the Farmers Home Administration accounted for about half of the writeoffs, with commercial banks and the Farm Credit System the remainder. The historical upward creep of farm debt, culminating in the recent tumble, is not necessarily an indicator of good times or bad for farmers. ``I think you have to compare it with income, cash flow and a lot of other things,'' he said. ``Of course, in the condition we had in the '70s everybody said it was a good thing to leverage and all that. We got fooled. It's neither good nor bad by itself.'' Stam said that in the final analysis, farmers must have enough cash flow to cover expenses. But, he added, ``In modern agriculture, it's hard to operate without the use of debt capital.''

An Agriculture Department analysis shows cattle producers are headed for another year of record-high market prices. And consumers will pay more for burgers, steaks and chops. Total beef production by slaughter plants is expected to rise about 2 percent because of increased cattle marketings and heavier weights, the department's Economics Research Service said Thursday. But an expanding U.S. population and increases in net beef exports will more than offset the larger output, the report said. That will mean less beef available on a per capita basis. Consequently, market prices of Choice-grade fed steers sold on the Omaha, Neb., market in 1990 may average about $1 more than last year's record of $72.50 per pound, the report said. That would push retail prices up 1 percent to 3 percent. Hog prices also are going up and may average in the range of $47 to $53 per 100 pounds in 1990, compared with a little more than $44 last year at the major markets. ``Retail pork prices have risen in recent months, reflecting higher hog prices and wider farm-to-retail (marketing) spreads,'' the report said. ``Retail pork prices for the year may increase 6 percent to 8 percent from last year.''

Production of farm-grown catfish continues to rise from year-earlier levels, but the Agriculture Department says prices paid to growers are down. Processors turned out 33.1 million pounds of catfish in January, up 23 percent from a year earlier, a monthly report said. Prices paid to growers for fish delivered to plants averaged 73 cents per pound, down five cents from January 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Rallies Republicans, Says Cold War Almost Over
LaserPhoto TN1
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle told a gathering of Republican members of Congress that the revolutions in Eastern Europe were a testament to American democracy, but he said American society was troubled. The United States is confronting a growing underclass of impoverished, single-parent households that threatens the workforce of tomorrow _ a labor pool that will have to be highly trained and educated, Quayle said Thursday night. His speech was briefly interupted when several hecklers shouted from the balcony, ``Stop the killing'' and ``Dan Quayle, there is blood on your hands,'' apparently in reference to American involvement in Central America. Two of the hecklers were arrested, charged with disorderly conduct and disrupting a meeting and later released. A third demonstrator was detained when he allegedly lunged at Quayle outside the building where the speech was held. Quayle said 15 million children are growing up in homes with no father, 25 percent of the nation's children live in single-parent households, and a majority of black children live with only one parent. ``How will we compete with Japan and Germany and other nations that do not have this underclass?'' he said to a gathering of about 200. ``How will we produce a skilled workforce without strengthening the family structure.'' Quayle's speech opened a retreat of Republican members of Congress sponsored by The Congressional Institute. The Institute is a Republican think tank set up several years ago to study public policy issues. The Princeton conference is focusing on long-range economic, social and demographic changes. ``The revolution of 1989 was no accident. It erupted from a swelling realization that Democratic values are the wave of the future, economic freedom generates wealth, and political freedom is a requisite for peace and prosperity,'' Quayle said. ``The Cold War is not over but its funeral is close,'' he said. A protest outside the hall was waged by activists for homosexual rights, AIDS research, a stop to American involvement in Panama and Central America, and abortion rights. As he left the auditorium, Quayle greeted some of the protesters, one of whom was grabbed by police after lunging at the vice president, said Princeton police. Christopher Paciorek, an 18-year-old Princeton University student, was released with a complaint summons, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar closed at 146.47 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market Friday, up 1.24 yen from Thursday's close.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Surprised, Confused by New Soviet Troop Idea
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials are confused over a Soviet proposal for troop cuts that they say is a step backward from an earlier agreement. Soviet negotiators in Vienna suggested Thursday the East and West blocs agree to a ceiling of 700,000 and 750,000 soldiers each in Central Europe, say American and East German diplomats. But U.S. and Soviet officials involved in the conventional force reduction talks already had agreed not to set an overall ceiling and instead to limit the Americans to 225,000 and the Soviets to 195,000 troops in Europe. ``We are so confused we cannot be indignant,'' said one administration source in Washington, commenting on the latest Soviet suggestion. He spoke on condition he not be further identified. Soviet envoys floated the idea as a suggestion but met with such opposition they decided not to make it a formal proposal, the official said. ``They could not even get their Warsaw Pact allies to agree to it. And the Western response was, `this is a non-starter,''' said the official. The issue of troop levels in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact has been complicated by the announcement by three members of the Eastern Bloc, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland, that they were cutting the armed forces. The Soviets and East Germans argue the combination of troop cuts would leave NATO with a maximum of 1 million soldiers, compared to 700,000 for the Warsaw Pact. ``That situation is totally unsatisfactory,'' Ernst told reporters in Vienna. Ernst said the overall ceiling suggested by the Kremlin would include national armies and Soviet troops stationed on foreign soil. Last week, Soviet and American officials cleared the way for the 16 NATO and seven Warsaw Pact nations to sign a conventional force reduction agreement by the end of the year, as proposed by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Under that deal, the Soviet Union and United States would reduce to 195,000 each their forces stationed in Germany, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Hungary, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Poland. Another 30,000 U.S. soldiers would be allowed in Britain and southern Europe to compensate for the distance between the United States and Europe. Hungary and Czechoslovakia are negotiating for total withdrawal of Soviet forces from their territory. About 50,000 Soviet troops are in Hungary and 75,000 in Czechoslovakia. The alliances have not agreed on how to define some types of weapons to be covered in the proposed pact, or on rules for counting attack aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Former Defense Secretary Says It's Too Soon for Military Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Former Secretary of Defense Caspar Weinberger says it is too soon to seek a ``peace dividend'' because of the fall of communist regimes in Eastern Europe and warming relations with the Soviet Union. Accepting the annual ``Statesman of the Year'' award at George Washington University on Thursday, Weinberger said, ``I think it is vital that we remember that it was a strong defense and a greatly strengthened defense that led to a lot of these changes.'' Weinberger led the Pentagon during most of the Reagan administration, a period that saw a large increase in American military spending. Reagan and his supporters argued it was the military buildup that forced the Soviets to seek accommodation. ``It's awfully early for us to assume that things are such that we can, in effect, dismantle the military strength that helped bring the situation about and hunt around for a peace dividend,'' Weinberger said. He said any such shift of money from the military, ``is not going to be used to reduce our deficit; it will be used for ... federal programs that are perceived to be more popular'' than military spending. The former secretary said the Soviets ``have not yet dismantled their military. What they are doing is taking out their oldest tanks and oldest artillery and oldest planes and their oldest nuclear weapons and they are modernizing all of those categories. ``And the Soviet Union remains the only country in the world that can destroy the United States overnight,'' he said. Weinberger also argued that Americans ``ought to worry a little bit about the effect on our economy of these very deep cuts.'' ``You don't do a defense budget because it's a very good jobs bill,'' he said. ``You don't do it to help the economy. It does not hurt the economy, however. ``The fact is that the defense spending we did was a substantial help to the economy, and if you reduce the armed forces sizably and if you stop weapons systems you are going to affect employment.'' Weinberger, now publisher of Forbes magazine, was the third person to receive the statesmanship award. It is presented by the alumni association of the school of government and business administration and by the National Law Center at the university. The previous recipients were Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and former Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

DOC.HEAD: Parties Line Up on Opposite Sides in Campaign Finance Reform
DOC.TEXT: A veteran Senate Republican says his party will fight against strict campaign spending limits because the curbs would favor the majority Democrats. ``It's not going to happen,'' Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, said Thursday as the Senate Rules Committee began hearings on the politically divisive issue of campaign finance reform. Stevens, the ranking Republican on the committee, told two Democratic witnesses that spending curbs on all candidates would allow incumbents to win ``99 percent of the time.'' Challengers, he said, have to outspend incumbents to win elections. ``I don't think our side of the aisle is going to change,'' he said, while Democrats control the Senate 55-45 and the House 257-175. Stevens suggested Democrats drop proposals for spending limits and public financing, and pass legislation that would curb mailing, broadcast fees and other costs that would win wide bipartisan support. Stevens added public financing wouldn't curb runaway costs because the government money would only become a substitute for private donations. But Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz. and Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan. told the committee campaign spending limits and public financing were essential to any agreement on campaign finance reform. DeConcini, testifying on a bill he introduced this week, told the panel, ``Reform without spending limits is no reform at all. From 1976 to 1986 the cost of running a Senate campaign didn't double, didn't triple, but increased fivefold.'' DeConcini's proposal, which would apply only to the Senate, would base general election spending limits on a state's voting age population. The general election limit would be no lower than $400,000 and no more than $5.5 million. The primary limit would be 50 percent of the general election figure. ``Fully half of the Senate races would be kept below $1.5 million for the total spending cycle,'' DeConcini said. He conceded the figure was high but said it would be ``a great improvement'' over the average of $3.7 million in 1988. A formula based on the amount of small contributions received would determine the amount of public financing. ``This would substantially reduce the amount of time a candidate is forced to spend on fund-raising, and would return the focus of a campaign to the issues of the day,'' DeConcini said. Glickman backed DeConcini and urged that spending limits and public financing also apply to House races. ``A potential challenger often must be a millionaire in order to stand a chance against a sitting incumbent,'' Glickman said, noting ``most of my colleagues in the House have few serious challengers.''

DOC.HEAD: `Peace Dividend' Should be Used to Cut Deficit: Governors
DOC.TEXT: Governors would like more federal money for education, health care, transportation and repairing bridges and roads. But most of the state officials say they'd just as soon see any ``peace dividend'' used to reduce the federal deficit. With few exceptions, the governors responding to an Associated Press survey said they expect defense spending to drop as a result of the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe where communist regimes have crumbled in recent months. They sounded much more confident that federal funds would be freed for domestic needs than has President Bush or his budget director, Richard G. Darman. Gov. William Donald Schaefer, a Democrat from Maryland, has drafted a letter to congressional leaders urging that any defense savings be used to ``ease the pain of transition for the workers and businesses most affected by the reductions.'' An aide to Schaefer said Thursday that several other governors, including Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts, Richard Celeste of Ohio and L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, were joining the Maryland governor in the appeal. Schaefer hoped to use the annual winter meeting of the National Governors' Association, opening Saturday, to argue his case. Schaefer wants money for retraining displaced workers, increasing research and development, and rebuilding the nation's infrastructure. Bush has brushed aside suggestions that a substantial ``peace dividend'' is in the offing. ``Many speak of the peace dividend. Few discuss the short-term cost of peace,'' he said in an address to the Commonwealth Club in San Francisco earlier this month. ``There will be costs as we cross the bridge to a better future,'' he added. In an introduction to the Bush's 1991 budget, Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said people were overestimating the dividend. He portrayed members of Congress as devising spending plans that would total ``about 10 times the overestimated dividend.'' Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana, a Democrat, predicted the savings from reduced military spending could total $100 billion over the next three years. ``The thing that can help Louisiana the most is to lower the deficit,'' he said. ``There's no question there's going to be a dividend if you're using that term in the sense that the defense budget will come down,'' said Republican Gov. William Clements of Texas, a former deputy defense secretary. Arguing that any such savings should go toward reducing the deficit, Clements said, ``The proliferation of our domestic programs is a no-no as far as I'm concerned.'' Clements' emphasis on reducing the budget deficit was echoed in the responses of most of the governors. ``First and foremost, we should reduce the national budget deficit,'' said Republican George Deukmejian of California. ``Any peace dividend should go primarily to balancing the budget,'' said Democrat George Sinner of North Dakota. A few governors were hesitant about advocating sharp cuts in defense spending. ``I believe the peace dividend is probably overstated,'' said Gov. Mike Hayden, a Republican from Kansas. ``If there is one, it should be used to lower the deficit.'' Republican Gov. Stan Stephens of Montana warned against getting ``carried away with the euphoria of what is happening in Eastern Europe.''
