Stephens said that if there was a peace dividend it should be used to lower taxes. ``It belongs to the people,'' he said. ``I think we should give the taxpayers of this country a break.'' Among the dissenters from the call for earmarking the money for deficit reduction were Govs. Robert Casey of Pennsylvania and Neil Goldschmidt of Oregon, both Democrats. Goldschmidt called for ``shifting resources to those things we care about in life _ arts, science, health, education and, above all, children.'' ``As billions are pared from the Pentagon budget, it's time for the federal government to return a substantial portion of that dividend to the states,'' said Casey. He singled out mass transit as an area where federal funds are needed. He said the budget proposed by Bush includes no money for the Philadelphia area transit system, which was receiving $27.4 million this year.

DOC.HEAD: West Germans Claim East German Land, Buildings
With PM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: With the opening of the Berlin Wall, West Germans are crossing the border to press thousands of claims on land or buildings East Germans live in. The claims may even affect some of East Berlin's most important public buildings. They are another reminder of the difficulty of uniting the two Germanys despite recent political progress. According to the Hamburg-based newsmagazine Spiegel, the East German Foreign Ministry is built on land claimed by a West Berlin lawyer, and the ground below East Berlin's huge TV reception tower is claimed by a Swiss insurance company. At least 500,000 West Germans have claims on buildings or land in East Germany that was confiscated with little or no compensation by Communist authorities, West German officials say. Many of those making claims escaped to the West during the postwar Soviet occupation or after Communist East Germany was founded. Others are the children of refugees or West Germans who have inherited property from relatives in the East. Now, after years of silence, some of those owners are trying to get their possessions back. The issue rests on complicated legal ground and could lead to lawsuits, authorities on both sides of the border say. ``A whole morass of property problems is coming down on us that we'll somehow have to solve,'' said Jutta Probst, a spokeswoman for the Gesamtdeutsches Institut in West Berlin. The institute is a branch of the Bonn government that monitors East Germany. A special commission has been set up with representatives from both German governments to consider property disputes, Ms. Probst said in an interview. ``Aggression is mounting on both sides, from the owners who want their property back on the one hand and East Germans who fear the consequences on the other,'' she said. Most of the confiscated property is owned or controlled by the East German government. But officials say that little can be done before East Germany's first free elections set for March 18 and the replacement of state ownership with private property. Meanwhile, confrontations between West German owners and their tenants across the border are becoming increasingly common. ``Several of my friends have had owners from the West suddenly drop by and are really frightened now,'' said Liselotte Nikolenko, an East Berlin retiree. ``They're worried that either their rents will be hiked so high they can't pay or they'll be forced out because the owner decides to do something else with his property,'' Ms. Nikolenko said. Deputy Mayor Reinhild Zagrodnik said ``hundreds of calls daily'' are coming in from worried renters. ``There have been incidents of owners just appearing on the doorstep, and there were _ I'll put it very politely _ discussions,'' she said. Spiegel, in the Feb. 12 article entitled ``Fear of Rent Sharks,'' said a West German homeowner had armed himself with a special spray to fend off his East German tenant's ferocious dog. Fear of rent increases is well founded. Held down by the government to immediate postwar levels, rents are inexpensive even by East German standards. An East German employee rarely spends even 10 percent of his monthly income on rent. The West German government has paid $3.2 billion in compensation to people and companies who have lost property in East Germany, a spokesman of the Federal Compensation Office in Bad Homburg said. Those payments, however, have not covered all claims. Any people who later recover property have to pay back compensation, the office said.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Warns Cost of Untested Stealth Will Rise
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon should delay buying the B-2 bomber until it is certain the aircraft can pass critical flight tests, says an investigative agency that forecasts the program will cost more than its estimated $70 billion. In its first unclassified report on the radar-evading aircraft, the General Accounting Office said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is reviewing a revised cost estimate for the program due to changes in the inflation rate and a recent strike at the Boeing Co., a major subcontractor. ``We estimate that the changes will add another several billion dollars to the B-2's estimated cost,'' said Frank C. Conahan, assistant comptroller general and a member of the GAO, the investigative arm of Congress. Questioned after the House Armed Services Committee hearing about the increase, Conahan said that due to inflation, the revised five-year plan for defense spending beginning in fiscal 1992 shows a jump of $51 billion for all defense programs. Conahan said he did not know how much of the $51 billion was for the stealth bomber. The Air Force was forced to raise the cost of buying 132 B-2 bombers due to a redesign of the plane to enable it to fly at low altitudes, extensions in the production schedule and underestimates of material costs. In 1981, the service said the planes would cost $32.7 billion, but by june 1989 the cost had risen to $70 billion. The GAO official also told the committee the cost of the electronic navigation and communications systems for the B-2 had increased from $1.9 billion in 1986 to $5.7 billion in 1989. The GAO recommended Cheney and the plane's contractor, Northrop Corp., analyze the cost of a production delay and provide Congress with the study of alternative plans for acquiring the plane. The bat-winged, stealth bomber is considered the most expensive in history at $530 million apiece. ``We believe that it would be prudent to reduce the pace of funding and production for the B-2, to limit up-front investment until the critical performance elements of the aircraft are adequately evaluated,'' Conahan said. The GAO official said he did not have any estimates on what a production delay would cost, but several members of the panel said Northrop Corp., has determined a one-year slowdown would cost $4.2 billion. Rep. Norman Dicks, D-Wash., a guest of the committee, lashed out at Conahan's assessment for failing to include the cost to the American taxpayer of a production delay. ``Why don't you go back and do the job right,'' said Dicks, whose district includes the Boeing Co. ``We have responded to what we were asked to do,'' Conahan answered. Dicks said Congress already scaled back the program in fiscal 1990 when it reduced the Bush administration's request for three bombers to two and trimmed about $400 million from the program. The administration, in its $292 billion defense budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, has requested $5.5 billion for five B-2 stealth bombers. Under the current plan, critical performance tests on the aircraft won't be done for at least three years. ``It has been during this critical performance testing that significant performance problems have been discovered in other advanced weapon system programs,'' Conahan said. The buying schedule during that testing period raised concerns among the committee members. ``We would have bought 31 aircraft and spent $48 billion and we won't know whether it's performing,'' said Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the Armed Services Committee. ``This flyway robbery is being done of the taxpayers money ... $48 billion before we have any idea whether the B-2 aircraft is going to work,'' said Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a member of the panel, said on the House floor.

DOC.HEAD: Investment in Eastern Europe Driving Up Interest Rates, Says Fed Chairman
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Investors flocking to take part in tremendous investment opportunities in Eastern Europe are driving up long-term interest rates around the world, Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan says. However, the central bank chairman said the trend probably won't continue. Greenspan, presenting the central bank's semiannual report to Congress on Thursday, said money is flowing to nations emerging from 40 years of communist rule because ``the potential for growth is extraordinary.'' The resulting competition is driving up interest rates in the United States and other countries. Long-term rates started heading up in early January, with the 30-year U.S. Treasury bond hitting a nine-month high of 8.66 percent on Tuesday. ``This is an extraordinary change in the nature of world savings and investment and I don't think it has any exact historical precedent,'' he said. ``It's the most important financial issue of the decade.'' But Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee rates probably would not continue rising unless some currently unknown need for investment is revealed. ``There is a very general knowledge of the size of the potential investment and I would suspect that most of the information about this is already in the markets. Hence, unless something fundamentally new occurs ... I'm not that concerned that interest rates would just continue up,'' he said. Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the committee, said that by relying on foreigners to help finance trade and federal budget deficits, the United States is in danger of losing control over domestic interest rates and of its economy in general. ``I must tell you I think we are boxing ourselves in,'' he said. Riegle said research by his staff shows foreigners last fall held about 20 percent of outstanding U.S. government debt, up from 15 percent five years earlier.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Winter Carnival organizers here in the state's snow capital are projecting a big turnout for an unusual screening _ the ``Snowbank Drive-In Movie.'' The 1960s movie, ``Back to the Beach,'' starring Frankie Avalon and Annette Funicello, will be projected against a 15-foot-high snowbank in Valdez's civic center parking lot on March 11, right after a fireworks display. ``The idea came from two of the staff members at the civic center,'' Nancy Peterson, Valdez parks and recreation director, said Thursday. ``One of them was just driving by one day and noticed a sharply cut snowbank and came up with the idea.'' This season's snowfall of 423 inches _ over 35 feet _ already has broken the previous mark of 384.7 inches for the 1986-1987 winter, the National Weather Service said.

The campaign posters, stickers and buttons might not have been authentic, but that didn't stop hundreds of Kennedy buffs from swarming a store to buy props used in a miniseries about the family. The shoppers who came to the Building 19 store this week bought props from ``The Kennedys of Massachusetts'' network television miniseries that ended Wednesday night. The thousands of items included an old-style newspaper stand, campaign paraphernalia bearing the name Kennedy, typewriters and desks. ``You name it. Whatever you saw in the movie, and most of it is there,'' said Brian Hickey, a salvage buyer for the Hingham-based chain. ``There are hospital beds, luggage, clothing, old newspapers.'' The shoppers apparently did not mind the store's disclaimer: ``We don't know if the antiques are really antiques, and we don't know if the reproductions are authentic ... But we do know that they came from this production.''

DOC.HEAD: Dole Will Keep Pushing for Vote on Armenian Genocide Resolution
DOC.TEXT: Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole says he'll keep pressing his reluctant colleagues for a floor vote on a resolution to designate a day commemorating an Armenian genocide. Dole, R-Kan., failed to cut off debate on the controversial measure Thursday as the Senate refused by a 49-49 vote to break a filibuster. Sixty votes are needed to invoke cloture. Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., led a filibuster for three days, arguing the resolution could irreparably damage U.S. relations with Turkey, a member of NATO. ``Senate approval of this resolution would offend a trusted and loyal ally ... an ally that protects NATO's southern flank, an ally that provides access to a variety of important military facilities,'' Byrd said. Another cloture vote is scheduled next Tuesday. If he fails to break the filibuster and bring the measure to the Senate floor, Dole has said he'll try to find other ways to force a vote on the resolution. The House might be able to tackle a companion bill or ``perhaps creative minds can concoct an amendment to some upcoming bill,'' he said. Addressing senators who may want to skirt a vote on the resolution by keeping it off the floor, Dole said: ``I hate to burst any bubbles, but _ to paraphrase a comment a champion boxer once made about his opponent _ you can run, but you can't hide.'' Democrats and Republicans showed little party loyalty on the procedural vote. The Bush administration opposes the resolution, although it is favored by Dole and several GOP senators, such as Pete Wilson of California and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania. Members of Byrd's party also went against him, including Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell of Maine and Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The resolution would designate April 24 as a ``national day of remembrance'' of the ``Armenian genocide of 1915-1923.'' A massacre of 1.5 million Armenians allegedly occurred in the Ottoman Empire before the establishment of the Republic of Turkey. But the Turks contend at most 600,000 Armenians died, some of disease, famine or attacks by marauding bands during World War I. Although Dole said he is willing to compromise on language in the resolution _ the Turks are furious about the word ``genocide'' _ he said he won't sacrifice principles. The Bush administration, meantime, issued a statement saying it opposed the Senate resolution because it ``lacks balance.'' Officials said President Bush would veto it if it passed both the Senate and the House. A companion measure is in a House committee. The administration said it ``supports commemorating the victims of that tragic period. Such a commemorative resolution must be balanced, however, in recognition of the differing views of how the terrible events of 1915-1923 should be characterized.'' Turkish officials call the resolution a national insult, objected strenuously to the word ``genocide'' and threatened to retaliate if the measure passes. In Ankara, Premier Yildirim Akbulut did not specify what Turkey would do, but added: ``The United States will lose its respected position in the eyes of the Turkish people.''

DOC.HEAD: Governors, White House Oppose Tax Hike to Replenish Unemployment Reserves
DOC.TEXT: Only four states _ Hawaii, Mississippi, South Dakota and Vermont _ have enough unemployment insurance in reserve to maintain jobless benefits for 18 months in a severe recession, congressional auditors say. And only 22 state programs could survive a year without raising unemployment compensation taxes, curtailing eligibility or borrowing heavily from the federal government, as they did in the last downturn in 1981-82. Three states _ Illinois, Michigan and Ohio _ with the highest concentration of the manufacturing workers who would be most subject to layoffs in a recession have reserves of six months or less, a House subcommittee was told Thursday. Nonetheless, the Bush administration and the National Governors Association told the panel they oppose a bill by House tax writers to raise the federal unemployment insurance taxable wage base from $7,000 to $10,000 by 1993. ``We see no programmatic justification for such an increase,'' Deputy Assistant Labor Secretary Carolyn Golding told the House Ways and Means Committee's subcommittee on human resources. She testified that as of Dec. 1, overall state accounts had reserves totalling nearly $38 billion, compared with just $8.6 billion a decade ago. Employers must now pay $434 in combined state and federal taxes a year on the first $7,000 of each covered worker's wages. About $56 goes to the federal government and the states get the rest. Thirty-six states have adopted bases above the $7,000 level _ ranging from $7,100 in Connecticut to $20,900 in Alaska _ subject to state taxes. The federal base was last raised in 1983, when it was $6,000. Subcommittee Chairman Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., and other tax writers want to raise the base to $10,000 over the next three years to avert a repeat of the eligibility cutbacks by many states at the depth of the last recession. By 1983, the system had run up a $21 billion debt. It was paid off last year with the exception of Michigan, which still owed $800 million as of last June, after the Reagan administration began charging states interest on their borrowings. Although the state and federal Unemployment Trust Funds now have combined reserves of $45 billion, the General Accounting Office said that would last only 11 months in a recession similar to the 16-month downturn in 1981-82. The reserves ``still appear to be inadequate to handle a severe recession,'' Assistant Comptroller General Lawrence Thompson told the subcommittee. Using a model developed by the Labor Department, congressional auditors projected 13 state funds becoming insolvent to the tune of $8.9 billion if a similar recession begins next year. The governors expressed anger at having to close unemployment offices and spend more to run the program because of a $124 million shortfall in fiscal year 1990 from budget cuts and more claims as a result of greater joblessness than they had anticipated. But they said through a representative at the hearing, Ohio Employment Services Administrator Ellen O'Brien, states should get a larger share of the existing taxes rather than have to raise taxes. ``Employers who finance this system through the Federal Unemployment Tax Act are investing enough money to provide adequate service,'' she said. ``No new taxes are necessary to return the program to its proper funding level.''

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Judicial Candidate Clears Committee Hurdle
DOC.TEXT: The Senate appears set to confirm conservative civil rights official Clarence Thomas as a federal appeals judge, but his progress still is being plagued by doubts about his record in the Reagan administration. ``Mr. Thomas has the ability to serve with distinction on the Court of Appeals,'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said Thursday as the Senate Judiciary Committee voted 12-1 in favor of the nomination. Opponents said it seemed certain that the full Senate would confirm Thomas, who as head of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission over the last eight years was one of the Reagan administration's most visible blacks. The solitary vote against Thomas on the committee came from Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, who said the nominee's remarks at his confirmation hearing two weeks ago left him ``flabbergasted.'' But efforts by civil rights forces to block Thomas lost momentum when Benjamin Hooks, head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, announced that he would not stand in the nominee's way. The chief complaint has been that thousands of age discrimination cases expired without government action in recent years. Thomas said that state fair employment commissions were to blame. He came in for renewed criticism late Thursday, however, as Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., inserted a statement in the Congressional Record, complaining that several thousand age discrimination claimants ``during Chairman Thomas' watch lost their rights largely due to EEOC neglect and mismanagement.'' Pryor echoed civil rights groups in saying that Thomas fell short in estimating at his confirmation hearing that the number of lapsed cases was around 900. Pryor, chairman of the Senate Aging Committee, said many answers that Thomas gave at the hearing ``appeared to be shaky attempts at revisionist history.'' Pryor said he had not yet decided how to vote on confirmation. Congressional liberals did not hide their concern over speculation that within a few years Thomas could be ripe for advancement to the Supreme Court. ``I have some concerns about this man in terms of whether I could support him for the Supreme Court,'' said Sen. Herb Kohl, D-Wis. Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., said standards for a Supreme Court justice are different from those for the appeals bench. The Senate is considering Thomas for the vacancy left by the resignation of Robert Bork from the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. Bork resigned after the Senate rejected him for the Supreme Court in the most embittered confirmation fight in decades. Thomas, who climbed from an impoverished childhood in rural Georgia to graduation from Yale Law School, is an outspoken critic of racial hiring quotas and affirmative action programs. Civil rights forces have long been cool to him because of these views. The Alliance for Justice, a liberal court-watcher group that was among the severest critics of the nomination, issued a statement Thursday saying it was ``clear that senators hold grave doubts about the nominee's qualifications.'' The organization said his performance on the bench ``will be watched carefully to determine whether he is truly committed to the rule of law.'' Metzenbaum, a leading congressional liberal, told the committee he had initially expected to vote to confirm Thomas but changed his mind at the confirmation hearing when Thomas blamed state fair employment agencies for problems involving numerous age discrimination cases. In these cases, the statute of limitations for action expired before the complaints were processed. ``I was flabbergasted that he did not know that the state agencies are under contract to process state age discrimination claims,'' Metzenbaum said. He said the federal commission is responsible for enforcing the contract and regulating the actions of the state agencies.

DOC.HEAD: BMW Recalls 62,000 Cars to Repair Seat Belts
DOC.TEXT: The government is recalling 62,000 BMW automobiles because of flaws in some seat belts that might endanger riders who mistakenly think the belts are fastened. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, in its monthly report of automobile defect investigations, also announced Thursday nearly 600,000 child safety seats were being recalled because the handles sometimes loosen when the seats are carried by hand. The BMW problem has been detected in 525i, 535i, 735iL and 750iL cars from the 1989 and 1990 model years, the agency said in its monthly report of automobile defect investigations. The center arm rest sometimes comes in contact with the front seat belt buckle and prevents it from latching, said Tom McGurn, spokesman for BMW of North America Inc. ``It gives the driver or passenger the impression that the belt is secured when in fact it's not, and in the event of a crash it wouldn't be secure,'' he said. The company will begin notifying owners March 2, he said. Also being recalled are 595,127 Century brand child restraint and carrying seats, model 580, agency spokesman Tim Hurd said. The seats work fine as a restraining device in automobiles, but the handle sometimes works loose when the seat is removed from the vehicle and carried. ``The child can fall out of the seat when that happens,'' he said. The government has received 85 reports of loose handles and one injury resulting from the problem, Hurd said. Also reported was a recall of 213 Chevrolet Corvettes with LT5 engines from the 1990 model year. A company engineer discovered cracked fuel line ends that could cause leaks and engine fires, although no fires have been reported, company spokesman Dave Hudgens said. The agency also reported the following new investigations, which could lead to recalls: _A probe of three complaints of breaking cables designed to hold spare tires in place underneath Dodge Caravans and Plymouth Voyagers. Affected are up to 1.2 million vehicles from the 1984 through 1988 model years. _Frame cracks or breaks in Dodge Ram trucks. There have been three complaints, one of which blamed the problem for severing brake lines and causing an accident. _Rear suspension tie rod socket failures in 1984 through 1988 Chevrolet Corvettes. There have been three complaints, two accidents and one injury. About 180,000 of the cars are on the road. _Anti-lock brake failure in the 1989 Jeep Cherokee, the subject of three complaints, one alleging an accident and injury. _A missing steering shaft bolt in the 1990 Mitsubishi Montero, blamed for one accident with an injury. _Engine fires in 1985 through 1990 model school buses with Ford Motor Co. medium-duty truck chassis. Rubber hoses that connect emission control components are believed to be catching fire. _Floorboard cracks in the Ford Bronco, 1989 and 1990 models. There have been two complaints of cracks where the driver's seat is attached to the floorboard. _Power brake loss in Ford E250 and E350 vans. The problem is limited to about 7,500 vehicles with a particular type of alternator.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Seeks to Revise Disability Proposal
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's proposal to modify a proposed civil rights bill for disabled Americans would deny them the protection given blacks, other minorities and women, critics say. ``We are incredulous that the administration would be willing to treat persons with disabilities differently from other victims of intentional discrimination,'' civil rights advocate Ralph G. Neas said Thursday after hearing of the administration's proposal to alter the Americans With Disabilities Act. ``The premise of this law is parity with other civil rights law,'' said Arlene B. Mayerson, a law professor and directing attorney of the Disability Rights Education and Defense Fund, a group that has worked on the bill. In testimony Thursday before a House committee, the acting U.S. attorney general for civil rights reiterated the administration's support of the proposed law. But James P. Turner said its provision governing remedies for job discrimination should be rewritten. ``A new impediment to the quick passage of the ADA has arisen and the administration seeks to resolve affirmatively this difficulty,'' Turner told the House Small Business Committee. ``I speak, of course, of the remedies provisions of the recently introduced Civil Rights Act of 1990.'' Turner said the administration opposes that proposal, which seeks to strengthen the landmark 1964 civil rights law which forbids discrimination because of race or creed. The new proposal would allow lawsuits for compensatory and punitive damages in cases of intentional job discrimination. Turner said that to avoid delays in passing the disabilities law, its reliance on that section of the civil rights act should be deleted. Instead, the disabilities bill should outline specific remedies for violations, including court injunctions, reinstatement and back pay, he said. The proposed law would guarantee the rights of disabled people to employment, goods and services. The Senate version, overwhelmingly passed in September, was a compromise with the White House. Turner suggested the new civil rights bill could upset that compromise. ``Inclusion of such extraordinary relief as punitive damages is simply unwarranted in a statutory scheme as new, bold, and complex as the provision of disabilities rights concepts to the American business community,'' Turner said. Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, countered: ``We cannot understand why the Bush administration would oppose monetary damages for victims of intentional discrimination.'' The conference is an umbrella group for 185 civil rights organizations and is actively supporting both bills. Neas said he believed the House will pass the disabilities act in the spring and will pass the civil rights act in the summer.

DOC.HEAD: Indictment Says Clines Didn't Report Contra Arms Income
DOC.TEXT: A former CIA agent who worked in Oliver North's arms supply network to the Contras is accused in an indictment of failing to report some of his income from the operation. Thomas G. Clines, a business partner of Iran-Contra figures Richard Secord and Albert Hakim, was accused Thursday of under-reporting his earnings to the Internal Revenue Service and of falsely stating that he had no foreign financial accounts. Clines reported receipts of $265,000 for tax year 1985 and $402,513 for 1986, according to the federal grand jury indictment returned in Baltimore, Md. During the period in question, Hakim set aside more than $972,000 in commissions for Clines in an offshore entity code-named C. Tea, according to a congressional report on the Iran-Contra affair issued in 1987. Two counts of the indictment accuse him of under-reporting his gross receipts. Each count carries a maximum penalty of three years imprisonment and $100,000 in fines on conviction. The other two counts accuse Clines of failing to report his foreign accounts, with maximum penalties on conviction for each charge of 10 years in prison and $500,000 in fines. Clines and his lawyer regard the decision to bring the case as an ``ill-advised'' step taken by ``overzealous prosecutors,'' said his attorney, Paula Junghans. Clines intends to defend himself ``to the fullest,'' she added. Sources familiar with the matter say Clines filed an amended tax return for 1985 in the fall of 1987, nearly a year after the Iran-Contra affair came into public view, reporting additional expenses and additional income. Clines takes the position that he has reported all his income from the Contra transactions, say sources familiar with Clines' situation. Clines collected the money in connection with his work for ``the Enterprise,'' the complex of foreign corporations and Swiss accounts which Hakim and Secord used to move money in the Iran-Contra affair. Hakim is a key witness in the investigation of Clines, according to sources familiar with the investigation. Hakim was placed on two years' probation and fined $5,000 on Feb. 1 for his role in the Iran-Contra affair. At the request of his friend Secord, Clines helped procure arms for the Contra rebels starting in 1985. In addition to locating a European arms dealer as a source of weapons, Clines helped arrange for shipping and lined up crews to transport the supplies to the rebels. Clines worked for the CIA for 30 years. He was an agent in Southeast Asia, was involved in the Bay of Pigs invasion in Cuba and became director of training in the directorate of operations, also known as the clandestine services. He also was a close associate of Edwin Wilson, the former CIA agent who is serving 52 years in federal prison for illegally selling guns and explosives to Libya. Clines pleaded guilty in 1984 on behalf of his wholly owned company to inflating bills submitted to the Defense Department for shipping U.S. military equipment to Egypt. He was fined the maximum $10,000 and paid the government $100,000 on behalf of his firm, Systems Services International.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Committee Votes for Trial-Like Hearing for Durenberger
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee plans to begin trial-like hearings on ``substantial credible evidence'' that Sen. Dave Durenberger, R-Minn., broke Senate rules and federal law. Most of the allegations stem from a book promotion arrangement that the Minnesota Republican used to raise $100,000 in possible violation of Senate honoraria limits. Durenberger called on the committee to reach a conclusion ``with all possible speed'' and said, ``It was never my intent to circumvent Senate rules for my own benefit.'' An aide characterized most of the alleged violations as bookkeeping mistakes. Committee Chairman Howell Heflin, D-Ala. said the vote Thursday to proceed from the committee's grand jury phase to the trial stage was unanimous. During the trial stage, the committee will decide whether to recommend disciplinary action to the full Senate. The possible punishments ranges from a reprimand to expulsion. The six-member committee said Durenberger may have: _Violated outside income limits by being paid for speeches in 1985 and 1986. Durenberger made numerous appearances which he characterized as book promotion speeches for his publisher, Piranha Press Inc. of Minneapolis. _Failed to report on his financial disclosure forms for 1985 and 1986 reimbursement for trips he made in connection with the book publishing deal. _Violated a rule by converting a campaign contribution to personal use, and violated federal election law by failing to report and deposit the contribution, which he transferred to his publisher. The check of $5,000 was made out to ``Durenberger for U.S. Senate.'' _Violated federal law and a Senate Rules Committee regulation prohibiting the commercial use of Senate space. The committee said he was paid an honorarium or other fee for six appearances in Senate-controlled areas. _Failed to disclose that he accepted limousine service in the Boston area during 1985 and 1986, in connection with personal travel to Concord, Mass., where he visited a marriage counselor. The committee said it was continuing its investigation into Senate reimbursement that Durenberger received for stays in a Minneapolis condominium he partly owned. The committee's hearings, which could be open to the public, probably will not start before mid-March, said New Hampshire Sen. Warren Rudman, the panel's ranking Republican. The panel has not investigated recently published reports that Durenberger received preferential treatment on $1.3 million in unsecured loans from a St. Paul bank, Rudman said. ``Nothing's closed,'' Rudman said at a news conference. The committee said it failed to find ``substantial credible evidence'' that Durenberger violated rules in obtaining speaking engagements in Boston. He combined the trips with visits to the marriage counselor. The committee said there was an ``absence of evidence'' that Durenberger used Senate staff in connection with his book deal. Durenberger appeared before the committee Feb. 8 at his request and later told reporters: ``The cloud of questions that has been hanging over my head ... has finally started to clear.'' He said in a statement Thursday, ``I made every effort to seek opinion from the appropriate bodies and from legal counsel. And I believed that I had fully disclosed all income received under my financial arrangements.'' Durenberger spokeswoman Carrie Collins said the ethics committee had ``narrowed the focus'' of its investigation. She characterized all the allegations except the possible outside income rule breaking as ``alleged bookkeeping violations.'' The senator's travel reimbursements for his book promotion appearances were added to his disclosure statements last July, only after the Ethics Committee began its investigation. The committee was concerned that ``he didn't disclose them in a timely manner,'' Ms. Collins said. She said the $5,000 check to Durenberger's campaign committee was supposed to be made out to the publisher. ``That was a mistake,'' Ms. Collins said. Groups that sponsored Durenberger appearances in the Boston area provided the limousine service to the Concord, Mass., office of the senator's marriage counselor, the spokeswoman said. ``He regarded it as a convenience and not a gift.''

DOC.HEAD: Defense Secretary Sees 12,000 American Troops Leaving Pacific
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney confirmed for the first time today that the Pentagon wants to cut in its forces in Asia by withdrawing about 12,000 military personnel over the next three years. Cheney wrapped up his two-week visit in the Pacific Rim with a major policy address before the National Press Club, stressing the proposed reductions are ``moderate'' and should not be seen as a ``first step towards withdrawal'' from the Pacific. Cheney is scheduled to return Saturday to the United States. ``The United States intends to remain involved in Asia,'' said Cheney, attempting to reassure governments in the region that have relied on U.S. forces to maintain peace and stability. The defense chief spoke with the governments in Japan, South Korea and the Philippines about proposals for troop reductions and sought increased support for the 120,000 American forces based in Asia, spurred by a Congress that is eager to trim defense spending. The new message has been stark _ there will be fewer troops and less money to pay for them. Amid the lessening of superpower tensions in Europe, Cheney has been pressed by Congress to slash his defense budget and reassess the reasons for keeping U.S. troops in the region. In a question-and-answer session, Cheney declined to cite a specific figure for the proposed withdrawal, but said he'd been discussing ``a range'' of cuts with the host governments. Cheney spoke about such cuts during his trip, but he never spoke openly of any figure. ``It is on the order of 10 percent, scattered about the region,'' Cheney explained. ``The first phase (for the withdrawal) is approximately three years.'' The secretary said there will be more talks with military commanders and Congress before final decisions are made. But he said he believed Congress would resist pressure from some lawmakers for 20 percent to 30 percent cuts and maintain ``a major U.S. presence in the Pacific.'' Increased support for U.S. troops has been the other key topic of discussions with Asian leaders. Asked how much more he had requested from Japanese officials, Cheney said, ``We'd like as much support as we can get.'' The secretary said Japan has ``significantly increased'' its funding for American forces in Japan recently, adding, ``We think that is a very positive trend.'' Cheney met Thursday with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, Defense Minister Juro Matsumoto and Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama. In the daylong meetings, Cheney sought increases in the $2.4 billion annual support toward the $7 billion cost of the American deployment in Japan. Japanese officials, following daylong discussions Thursday with Cheney, called plans for reducing the 50,000 U.S. troops in Japan ``prudent and appropriate.'' And Cheney hinted in his speech there might even be more changes in store. ``We are thinking about some force adjustments,'' Cheney said in his speech, emphasizing they would be ``moderate ... adjustments'' that would not harm the security balance in the region. ``We are not talking about a first step toward withdrawal,'' Cheney said. ``In the future, if there are solid indications that regional stability will not be threatened, we may _ in consultation with our allies _ make other adjustments that would be appropriate.'' To emphasize America's commitment to the region, the secretary announced the aircraft carrier USS Midway, now based in Yokosuka, Japan and due to be retired, will be replaced by the carrier USS Independence in the summer of 1991. The Midway was commissioned in 1945. The Independence, commissioned in 1960, will leave its current home port in San Diego, Calif. Cheney, in a message for Washington lawmakers, also said ``it would be a mistake'' to reduce the U.S. presence in Asia just because of the lessening of tensions in Europe. America must ``look at the region on its own terms,'' Cheney said. The Soviet Union hasn't acted to reduce tensions in Asia as it has in Europe, Cheney said, and he called on Moscow to help calm the region's flashpoints. ``I would welcome Soviet acts that would contribute genuinely to a reduction of tensions in the Asia-Pacific region,'' Cheney said.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Friends Subpoenaed, Sources Say
DOC.TEXT: Eight close friends of Mayor Marion Barry are under subpoena in an expanding investigation into Barry's alleged drug use, law enforcement and city government sources say. The eight men, described by one top city official as ``late night traveling companions'' of Barry's, were subpoenaed Thursday, the sources said. The action came as Barry, according to his press aide, left a Florida rehabilitation center to start a second phase of his treatment for alcoholism. Barry, who had been a patient at the Hanley-Hazelden Center in West Palm Beach, Fla., since Jan. 21, was moved to the Fenwick Hall treatment center off the coast of South Carolina, according to a statement issued by his spokeswoman, Lurma Rackley. A law enforcement source said the eight men would be asked whether they have ever used drugs with the mayor, who was indicted last week on cocaine possession and perjury charges. Barry has repeatedly denied ever using drugs. In addition, subpoenas were served on the city government for records of any city contracts issued to any of those individuals, the source said. Prosecutors want to know whether the mayor ever offered city contracts in exchange for drugs or whether he improperly steered contracts to his friends, the source said. Barry is scheduled to appear in U.S. District Court on Wednesday to enter pleas to the eight-count felony perjury and misdemeanor cocaine possession indictment returned against him last Thursday. The indictment stemmed from an arrest that followed a sting operation in which FBI agents reportedly videotaped the mayor smoking cocaine. Barry's attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, has said the mayor will plead innocent to all eight charges. Rackley said the mayor chose Fenwick Hall after he and his wife Effi consulted with specialists and others familiar with the numerous treatment facilities in the country. The South Carolina center was chosen because it provided what was called ``an adult chemical dependency inpatient family treatment program,'' according to Rackley's statement.

DOC.HEAD: Most in Congress Oppose Bush's Proposed Medicare Cuts
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's proposal to slow the growth of Medicare by $5.5 billion next year would hit hospitals too hard and should be rejected, according to letters signed by a majority of the House and Senate. Signed by members of both parties and sent to the House and Senate budget committees, the two letters complained that hospitals are already under financial pressures. One letter was signed by 51 of the 100 senators, another by 227 of the 435 House members. Medicare is one of the fastest-growing federal programs. It is expected to cost $104 billion this year _ about one-twelfth of the entire federal budget _ and grow to $183 billion by 1995. Last year, Bush proposed restraining Medicare spending by $5 billion. Congress eventually approved $2.8 billion in savings. Of the $37 billion in deficit cuts the president proposed in the 1991 budget he released last month, the largest piece was the $5.5 billion in reduced Medicare spending.
DOC.HEAD: VP Going to South America for Chilean, Brazilian Inaugurals
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle will travel to South America for presidential inaugurations in Chile and Brazil next month and Sen. Edward M. Kennedy will join the delegation to Chile. Quayle also is expected during his March 9-16 trip to stop in Argentina, Paraguay and Barbados to continue U.S. efforts to overcome Latin resentment lingering from the U.S. invasion of Panama in December. Many Latin countries still have not given formal diplomatic recognition to the U.S.-installed government of President Guillermo Endara. Quayle and Kennedy, D-Mass., will attend the inauguration of Patricio Aylwin on March 11 in Chile. Brazil holds its inauguration March 15, installing Fernando Collar de Mello. Elected Dec. 20, Collor de Mello recently made a pre-inaugural trip to Washington, where he met with both Quayle and President Bush. Kennedy, who has long been interested in Chilean affairs, will go only on that part of the trip. Chile's Dec. 14 elections marked a return of democracy to the last South American nation still ruled by the military.
DOC.HEAD: Panel Approves Black Revolutionary Statue For Mall
DOC.TEXT: A foundation honoring Black History Month has won initial approval for the design of a memorial to black Americans who participated in the American Revolution. The memorial, which would be the first on the Washington Mall dedicated to blacks, honors some 5,000 soldiers and freedom-seekers who have received relatively little recognition from historians. ``It was the beginning of the struggle for freedom in America,'' said Maurice Barboza, a Plainville, Conn., native and president of The Patriots Foundation, the group promoting the memorial proposal. ``The Declaration of Independence galvanized the struggle for freedom in America.'' The National Capital Memorial Commission on Thursday unanimously approved the design for the memorial, which is to be located on the Mall near the reflecting pool, midway between the Lincoln Memorial and the Washington Monument and not far from the Vietnam War Memorial.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Leaders Call For Peaceful Vote
DOC.TEXT: The leading presidential candidates, top election observers and the Roman Catholic church endorsed efforts to reduce the possibility of violence in Sunday's elections. ``All parties and alliances should let Feb. 25's voting take place without demonstrations or victory celebrations that could provoke violence,'' said opposition presidential candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. Mrs. Chamorro's United National Opposition and President Daniel Ortega's Sandinista party have accused each other of planning violence, but their rhetoric has toned down as election day approaches. Ortega said he believes Mrs. Chamorro is sincere in her wish to avoid violence, but said he was not so certain of others in her 14-party coalition. ``We need to create a climate of reconciliation and speak a language of peace,'' said Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, Nicaragua's Roman Catholic prelate. ``If Nicaragua does not put an end to violence, violence will put an end to Nicaragua.'' Joao Baena Soares, the secretary-general of the Organization of American States, addressed a special appeal to ``those involved in military activities,'' which would include the Sandinista army and the U.S.-backed Contra guerrillas. Baena Soares and other observers said conditions for a fair vote Sunday exist, although Secretary of State James Baker said in Washington that the United States would have to make up its own mind about that. Baker ruled out normal ties with a Sandinista Nicaragua unless it maintains the democratic opening to the opposition and refrains for a ``sustained period'' from supporting leftist rebels in El Salvador. Ortega has struck conciliatory notes toward both the opposition and the United States as he sniffs victory, especially after a massive Wednesday night rally by 300,000 people, one-tenth of the nation's population. ``After the election I will propose a political truce so that we can concentrate all our forces and resources on lifting the economy,'' Ortega said at a news conference. When asked about Baker's comments, Ortega said: ``I expect Mr. Baker will be disposed to discuss the fundamental problems between us. We have to do away with political rhetoric and work for peace.'' Nicaragua's 1.75 million voters will elect a president, vice president, a 90-member assembly, 144 town and city councils and two regional councils on Sunday. The main face-off is between Mrs. Chamorro and Ortega, who is seeking re-election to a six-year term. Eight other candidates are running for president, but only Erick Ramirez's Social Christians are considered significant. Ramirez's party expects the 14-party UNO coalition to founder whether it wins or loses and hopes to end up as the second largest single party in Nicaragua. With campaigning legally halted as of Wednesday night, candidates and official observers made a round of appearances for the benefit of the international media. Former U.S. Attorney General Elliot Richardson, representing the United Nations, made a trip to the northern countryside and said the elections ``are a step towards reconciliation and unity for all Nicaraguans, who need peace.'' Other observers were already spreading out across the country in anticipation of Sunday's voting. Violence was considered most likely to occur in small towns and rural areas where local feuds combine with politics in a volatile brew. Ortega drew the largest crowd, more than 300 reporters and at least another 100 photographers and television crew members. Actor Ed Asner, singer Jackson Browne and Bianca Jagger, ex-wife of rock star Mick Jagger, were among the celebrities at various functions, drawing considerable attention from press and politicians.

DOC.HEAD: Polar Bears Digging Dens In Refuge Targeted for Oil, Gas Exploration
DOC.TEXT: Biologists say polar bears seem to be making their dens more often on the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, where oil companies want to start exploration drilling. Caribou have been the primary wildlife concern in the debate thus far, with environmentalists arguing that the coastal plain is a key calving area. The discovery of the bears' use of the land gives opponents to drilling more ammunition in the debate, environmentalists said. The Interior Department has recommended opening the refuge to drilling. It has called the area the most promising, unexplored prospect for a major oil find in the country. Congressional action on the refuge has been stymied since the Exxon Valdez ran aground March 24 in Prince William Sound, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of oil. But the push to open the refuge is expected to resume as early as late this year, and the Bush administration is counting on $2.6 billion in oil revenues from the refuge by 1993. The continuing research shows that the 1.5-million-acre coastal plain is the most suitable terrain in the region for pregnant polar bears to make their dens. Because bears that den on land are much more likely to produce surviving cubs, the research suggests that disturbance of denning patterns in the refuge could result in population declines for the species. ``This is more evidence of the tremendous biological values that would be compromised by oil development on the coastal plain,'' said Allen Smith, Alaska director of The Wilderness Society. ``We are on the threshold of seeing impacts that go well beyond what the oil industry is saying.'' Mark Fraker, senior environmental scientist for British Petroleum, said the research does point to the importance of the refuge for polar bears. But Fraker said good planning should protect them from harm. ``By knowing about areas used for denning, it should be possible to place facilities where they avoid dens,'' Fraker said. The polar bear research was conducted by Steven Amstrup, polar bear project leader for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, who stressed that his findings are tentative. Amstrup was the first wildlife biologist to successfully outfit polar bears with radio collars for satellite tracking. His research findings are a result of that trackin. He said most pregnant bears choose to den on pack ice, where harsher weather conditions and ice break-ups lessen the chances of cub survival. ``The greatest concentration of recent land dens has been on'' the wildlife refuge, he said. ``If oil and gas development in ANWR and around barrier islands of Alaska's north coast caused polar bears to avoid current land denning areas, annual production of cubs would be compromised.'' Previous research has identified about 2,000 Beaufort Sea polar bears. Of that number, about 450 are sexually active females. Females get pregnant about every three years, meaning that in any given year about 150 females will dig dens. As many as 15 percent of those will show up on the refuge, Amstrup said. Amstrup's research also raises questions about whether disturbing the polar bears would be acceptable under an international treaty that the United States signed in 1976. The International Agreement for the Conservation of Polar Bears binds the country to protecting females and their young and polar bear ecosystems. Fraker said that treaty is a consideration. ``But it doesn't mean you can't do anything,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Thefts Of Torahs in Metropolitan Philadelpia Investigated
DOC.TEXT: A Torah that survived the Holocaust was among six sacred scrolls stolen this month from synagogues in New Jersey and Pennsylvania and authorities said they suspect a ring that targets religious artificats. John H. Kundts, a FBI spokesman, said Thursday that investigators believe the thefts this month may be related. All occurred in or around Philadelphia. Investigators also are looking into a possible connection between the stolen Torahs and silver pieces with Hebrew writing that turned up at a pawn shop in Runnemede, N.J. It wasn't known if the silver pieces had been removed from any of the synagogues in question. Police and religious leaders said they doubt the thefts are the result of anti-Semitism or vandalism. ``There is no indication of defamation or desecration. They're not painting swastikas or damaging property,'' Kundts said. ``This is a specific criminal act to steal a specific religious object.'' The Torah is a sacred scroll, handwritten on parchment, that contains many of the basic teachings of Judaism. A Torah inside its special holder can fetch up to $35,000, religious leaders said. Two Torahs were taken Feb. 10 from Congregation M'kor Shalom in Mount Laurel, N.J. said Rabbi Fred Neulander. One of the scrolls was known as the Milevsko Torah and was recovered after World War II in Prague, Czechoslovakia. ``The congregation feels violated _ individually and collectively,'' Neulander said. ``Their reactions are very similar to reactions of death.'' Neulander said it would cost between $15,000 and $40,000 each to replace the Torahs. He said he was doubtful they would be recovered because the only means of distinction is the handwriting. ``These are the most sacred possessions we have,'' Neulander said. ``To lose one is devastating.'' Several Jewish institutions, including a school, community center and a synagogue were burglarized in Cherry Hill. N.J., between Feb. 1 and Feb. 3, said Police Sgt. Richard Tomlinson. A Torah was taken from the synagogue. Last Saturday, two Torahs were discovered missing from a synagogue in northeast Philadelphia, and another Torah was reported missing Feb. 5 in the suburb of Cheltenham. There was no sign of a break-in in either case, said Philadelphia Police Capt. Jim Nocco. ``Obviously, it was someone who had free access to come and go without suspicion,'' Nocco said.

DOC.HEAD: Last Stalin Statue Falls, Exhibit Opens on His Era
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Single names thruout are correct
DOC.TEXT: Mongolians renounced the legacy of dictator Josef Stalin, toppling his last statue in the capital and opening an exhibit displaying a torture chamber model and other horrors of the purges he inspired. Cheers broke out Thursday when the 51-foot granite statue was lifted from its pedestal onto a truck and carted away. Some people applauded its removal; some even kicked it. ``The whole people wanted this,'' said Hortsbar, 36, an electrician who passed the statue every day on his way to work. It had stood in front of the national library in the city center since 1951. Workers said they did not know where the statue was taken or what would happen to it. Last month, the ruling Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party bowed to public pressure and removed a smaller statue of Stalin from in front of an army club. It was one of its few concessions to a new, vocal opposition movement that has staged repeated rallies for democratic reform. The movement organized itself this week as the Mongolian Democratic Party. The larger statue's removal under cover of darkness may have been to avoid confrontations in this nation where officials say more than 38,000 people were purged or killed during a Stalin-inspired era of terror in the 1930s and 1940s. At the Revolutionary Museum, just across the city's central square from the library, the nation's first exhibit about that era opened Wednesday. It was organized jointly by the museum and the Ministry of State Security. Titled ``History Will Not Forget Them,'' the exhibit contains pictures of purge victims and documents from the once-secret ministry archives. Its aim is to ``tell the truth of history,'' museum officials said Thursday. Stalin came under criticism in the Soviet Union more than 30 years ago, but until 1984 Mongolia remained in the grip of Stalin protege Yumjaagiyn Tsedenbal, who now lives in Moscow. The purges began under Tsedenbal's predecessor, Horloogiyn Choybalsan, when a northern minority group on the Soviet-Mongolian border was accused of spying for the Japanese. One chart in the exhibit said 19,895 people were executed from 1937 to 1939 alone. Most were ordinary workers and herdsmen, but Buddhist monks, called lamas, were key targets and even some high-ranking officials were accused of being enemies of the revolution. The exhibit included a mock torture room, with a 4-foot-high stool that prisoners were forced to sit on. The room was said to be soundproof. The exhibit dedicated one section to attacks on religion, showing scorched and scarred Buddhist scriptures. It said all of Mongolia's 761 monasteries were destroyed during the purges. Only three or four have been reopened. Although they had no figures, museum officials said attendance was high. At noon Thursday, about 75 people were slowly moving through the small room, studying each display. ``It's the wish of the people to get the truth about what really happened during Stalin's time,'' said Oilzibaatar, a historian at the State Security Ministry who was a consultant for the exhibit. Outside, in temperatures of about 4 degrees below zero Fahrenheit, small crowds watched as workers with hammers and drills dismantled Stalin's pedestal. ``From childhood, I believed that (Stalin) was a good man who did many great things,'' said Lchawgsuren, a 45-year-old member of the ruling party. ``Because of the new policy of restructuring, it enabled us to see also the shadows of this man and his policies.''

DOC.HEAD: Arianespace Shoots For Profit, Not The Moon
With PM-Ariane
DOC.TEXT: Since taking over the commercial end of the Ariane space program 10 years ago, Arianespace has rejected starry visions like the 1960s moon race for the down-to-earth goal of making money. The 31 successful Ariane launches _ five rockets have exploded including Thursday's 44-L launcher _ have brought the company more than $2.5 billion in contracts to put 43 satellites in orbit. Thirty-two more satellites are on the schedule for future launches, worth $2.36 billion. The program got off to a rough start Dec. 24, 1979, when the European Space Agency's first Ariane rocket exploded after liftoff at the launch site in French Guiana. But luck changed after Arianespace took over commercialization of the program from the European Space Agency in 1980, just as private satellites became a vital link in communications. Despite three rocket explosions through 1986, Arianespace successfully focused on turning itself into a cheaper alternative than its main competitor, the U.S. space shuttle. The Challenger disaster in 1986 left Ariane with an enviable monopoly on the satellite launch business, exploiting America's failure to develop unmanned launchers during the shuttle years. Though the shuttle returned to the skies in 1988, Ariane retains a commanding grip on commercial launch services, holding more than 50 percent of all satellites in the lucrative market. Flexibility is part of the success. The series 4 rocket can be configured eight different ways to boost varying payloads into orbit in a more cost-effective mode than the manned shuttle. The larger series 5, due to hit the launch pad in the mid-1990s, will enable Arianespace to put up larger and bigger satellites. The rockets are built by 100 companies in 11 countries. The European Space Agency, which started the Ariane program in 1973, still maintains dreams of a building a Soviet-style European space station and an American-style Hermes space shuttle. Prohibitive costs have kept such projects on the ground while the Ariane rockets have grown into unglamourous but profitable stars. Whether that remains so may depend on how fast Arianespace can identify and correct what caused Thursday's explosion.

DOC.HEAD: Syrian Foreign Minister Pledges Help on Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa has told the sister of one of the American hostages in Lebanon that he will visit Iran soon to push for a hostage release. In a meeting late Thursday, Sharaa said Syria has already told Iran's leaders ``that it is their interest to work with us in gaining the release of the hostages.'' He told Peggy Say, sister of hostage Terry Anderson, that he would ``work intensely with the top Iranian leaders'' on the hostage issue. ``I hope we will be able to arrive at good results,'' he said. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest held of the 18 Western hostages in Lebanon. He was abducted March 16, 1985. Mrs. Say, of Cadiz, Ky., and an Associated Press delegation was in Damascus as part of trip to discuss with world leaders her campaign to free her brother. The meeting came the same day as an editorial in the English language Tehran Times in Iran said the hostages in Lebanon should be released without conditions. The paper is close to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani. The hostages' fate is believed linked to a power struggle within the Iranian government. The Times is close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani, who has offered to help free the hostages before but has been criticized for such moves by hard-line government factions. Sharaa called the editorial ``a good sign'' and Mrs. Say added she found the newspaper's viewpoint ``encouraging.'' Syria has good ties with Iran. It was the only major Arab country to back Iran in its eight-year war with Iraq, which is ruled by a rival wing of the Arab Baath Socialist party. Sharaa told her that a hostage release will be difficult until the clashes between various Lebanese factions ends. Syria is the major power broker in Lebanon. It has 40,000 troops in the country under a 1976 Arab League provision to end the Christian-Moslem civil war. Sharaa said the hostage-takers ``must be isolated. Then they would rush to give up the hostages.'' He said the kidnappers feel comfortable in the ``blackout'' of security in Lebanon. He said the United States was not using its influence sufficiently to bring peace to Lebanon or to encourage Iran to press the kidnapping groups to release their captives. He did not give specifics of what action the United States should take. Mrs. Say thanked Sharaa for Syria's efforts and said hundreds of thousands of Americans are ``praying for Syria and its role as a mediator.'' In its editorial, the Tehran Times said the struggle against Western influence in the Middle East was legitimate and should continue, but that all forces in Lebanon should work to free hostages of whatever nationality. It said the release should be on Islamic and humanitarian grounds, adding, ``Maybe 1990 will be the year for the release of all the hostages.''

DOC.HEAD: Study: Surgery to Correct Nearsightedness Helps Many, But Unpredictable
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: A surgical procedure that corrects nearsightedness gives an unacceptable variety of outcomes, although two-thirds of people who undergo it eventually are able to see without glasses, doctors say. The procedure, called radial keratotomy, changes the curve of the cornea, which acts as a lens for the eye. Surgeons make tiny incisions in the cornea resembling the pattern of spokes in a wheel in a painless outpatient procedure. For four years, researchers tracked 390 patients who underwent the surgery on one eye between March 1982 and October 1983. Visual sharpness was improved to better than 20-40 in 76 percent of the eyes, the researchers reported. Most patients _ 69 percent _ had visual sharpness of 20-200 or worse before the operation, and no one had sharpness better than 20-40, the researchers reported in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. But eleven patients who had 20-20 vision or better with corrective lenses before the surgery suffered a significant loss of visual sharpness after the procedure, even with glasses or contact lenses, they reported. However, ``everybody _ all except one _ became less nearsighted (without corrective lenses), so the operation obviously works,'' said Dr. George O. Waring III, national director of the study. The one patient whose acuity did not improve stayed the same, Waring said in a telephone interview Thursday. Infections developed in two patients, who were successfully treated with antibiotics without losing visual acuity, said John Carter, coordinator of the study, based at Emory University in Atlanta. ``Our study and others have demonstrated fairly well that there are some adverse outcomes, but they are relatively rare,'' said Carter, also in a telephone interview. The surgery, costing about $2,000 per eye, was introduced in the United States in 1976. It is most widely practiced in the Soviet Union. Most patients also saw lines around lights at night because of light bouncing off the scars in the cornea, but it didn't bother them, said Waring. ``It was like dirty glasses or contact lenses,'' he said. One year after the surgery, 48 percent of the patients said they were ``very satisfied'' with it, 42 percent were ``moderately satisfied'' and 10 percent were dissatisfied, the researchers said. Among the 323 patients who had both eyes operated on, 64 percent said they wore no visual correction four years after the surgery, the researchers said. However, the unpredictability of the outcomes remains ``unacceptable,'' 14 years after the procedure was introduced, despite improvements in surgery techniques, the researchers said. ``I think it's safe to say that the predictablity is better now than it was, but there's still a range of outcomes,'' Carter said. Dr. Perry S. Binder of the University of California at San Diego, cautioned that radial keratotomy ``is not intended for all myopic patients just because they wish to see without spectacles or contacts.'' Surgeons who don't specialize in the procedure are leery of it because the tissue being operated on is healthy, Binder said in an editorial in Friday's Journal. An estimated 80 million people in the United States are nearsighted.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Warplanes Attack Guerrilla Base Near Southern Lebanese Port
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes blasted a Palestinian guerrilla base before dawn near this southern port city in the fourth Israeli attack on bases in Lebanon in eight days. Witnesses said the planes drew heavy fire from the guerrillas while they fired rockets at the base and released balloons to detract ground-to-air missiles. There was no immediate word on casualties. In Jerusalem, the Israeli army said the jets returned to base safely. It said the base was used by a terrorist organization to launch attacks on Israel. It did not identify the group. A police spokesman said the raid targeted a base manned by guerrillas of George Habash's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine in hills east of Sidon. The spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said at least three Israeli jet fighters carried out the five-minute attack. The jets fired six air-to-surface missiles against the base, he said. At dawn, around three hours after the air attack, smoke still billowed from the stricken target, a two-story building used by Palestinian guerrillas for about four years. Witnesses in Sidon, 20 miles from Beirut, said the jets roared low over the city, shaking them out of bed. ``We rushed to basements and air raid shelters assuming the city was under attack,'' Fatima Hableh said. Her husband, Hassan Hableh, said he watched the planes releasing scarlet balloons to deflect heat-seeking anti-aircraft missiles. The raiding jets, Hableh said, also released parachute flares that illuminated the area. Guerrilla defenders fired at the planes from anti-aircraft guns. ``I could see tracer anti-aircraft rounds in the sky, exploding around the planes into small puffs of white smoke. But none of the planes was hit,'' he said. Police said the attack came less than 10 hours after a raid that targeted pro-Iranian Moslem guerrillas in the nearby village of Libaa, wounding three fighters. Friday's attack was Israel's seventh air raid this year. On Monday, Israeli jets bombed a base near Sidon belonging to the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, another Marxist PLO faction. On Feb. 16, Israeli aircraft attacked a position near Sidon used by the mainstream Shiite Moslem Amal militia. Guerrillas have launched attacks this year in Israel's buffer zone in southern Lebanon, established in an effort to prevent incursions into Israel. The zone, six-to-10 miles deep, was set up when Israel withdrew the bulk of its army from Lebanon in 1985, three years after it invaded.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilians Set to Celebrate Carnival
DOC.TEXT: Inflation is running at 70 percent. Rio's crime is so bad, pizza companies have suspended deliveries because their drivers are getting mugged. The whole country, in fact, seems headed for catastrophe. But many of Brazil's 150 million residents wouldn't dream of letting all that spoil Carnival, billed as the world's largest party. From the steamy Amazon jungle to the Southern Pampas, they are donning sequined and feathered costumes in preparation for the pre-Lenten revelry, which begins Saturday and runs through Ash Wednesday. ``I work all year long until my body aches. The world's so full of misery and suffering, but Carnival lets me let it all hang out,'' said Leila de Souza, 32. She works at odd jobs, makes $20 a week and plans to parade with one of Rio's famous ``samba schools'' _ clubs from largely black slums. Carnival in Rio features grand balls at exclusive clubs and a costume parade that costs millions to produce. In the northeast, large outdoor dances are led by bands playing on the back of trucks. For the rich, there are balls that attract from 6,000 to 10,000 people each. Rio's Monte Libano Club is charging $10,000 for a reserved box for 12 at its ``Night in Baghdad Ball.'' The club hired 120 security guards to protect drunken partygoers from themselves and each other. It expects guests to swill down more than 2,000 gallons of beer and 1,000 bottles of whiskey. Other popular dances are the ``Grande Gala G,'' for homosexuals, and the ``Girl from Ipanema Ball,'' known for its glorification of the female posterior. ``The soul of Carnival here is the same as it is in other places _ a cry for liberty. We just have a slightly different way of expressing ourselves,'' said Jose Geraldo Machado, a director of Rio's municipal tourism board. Machado said the special nature of Brazil's Carnival derived from the population's diverse cultural and ethnic backgrounds. ``The samba rythmn descends from our African roots, the melodic line comes from Europe, and the visual beauty from the Indians,'' he said. The undeniable highlight of Rio's Carnival, the ``samba school'' parade, is held in two 15-hour marathon sessions on Sunday and Monday nights. Sixteen ``schools'' take part, each with 5,000 dancers and percussionists, who perform original samba music with floats and costumes based on the musical theme. The schools, which compete for a top prize based on points awarded for lyrics, dancing, rhythm, floats, and other categories, march down a six-block outdoor paradeway known as the ``Sambadrome.'' Female paraders usually wear little more than rhinestone bikinis and feather headresses, but some dancers spend as much as $15,000 on their attire. As always, there are complaints that Carnival is in danger of becoming a commercialized ``Brazil Follies,'' not a popular celebration but a show for tourists. ``The poor are the greatest samba performers, but they are increasingly shut out. The cost of a costume is so high, they can't afford to take part,'' said Rio City Councilman Sergio Cabral. But many disagree: ``Samba's in my blood. I'll be out there dancing every year until I drop,'' said Jose Menezes Ferreira, 50, who has paraded with the Villa Isabel Samba School for 40 years. Machado said that depite a bad year for tourism in Rio, the 13,200 parade tickets reserved for overseas visitors, ranging in price from $116 to $170, were sold out.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Begins Inquiry Into Police Handling of Stuart Case
DOC.TEXT: The FBI is investigating claims that city police mishandled their probe into the murder of Carol Stuart by intimidating and coercing witnesses into implicating an early suspect. Police Commissioner Francis M. Roache promised the his department's cooperation with the investigation, according to a statement Thursday from FBI agent Thomas Hughes. Mayor Raymond Flynn said he welcomed the probe and vowed to take disciplinary action if any police officers were charged with wrongdoing. Police named William Bennett as a suspect after the pregnant Mrs. Stuart was shot Oct. 23 and her husband, Charles Stuart, was seriously wounded in the city's Mission Hill neighborhood. Stuart's statement to police that a black gunman shot him and his wife touched off a massive manhunt that many black residents said violated their civil rights. Bennett was cleared of suspicion after Stuart apparently committed suicide Jan. 4, after learning that his brother had implicated him in the crime. The FBI investigation stems from statements by several people who claim police coerced them into implicating Bennett. Derek Jackson, 17, has claimed that police threatened him with 20 years in prison if he did not tell them under oath about an alleged confession made by Bennett. He claims also to have been threatened with a beating. Jackson said he recanted his story when he voluntarily appeared before the grand jury investigation into the Stuart case in November. Three other teen-agers that police said were present when Bennett made his alleged confession also have said they were forced into making false statements. Mary Smith, 43, has claimed that police offered to release her son from juvenile custody and relocate her family if she cooperated in the Stuart investigation. Ms. Smith told police she had seen Bennett on the night of the shooting with what appeared to be a gun, but noted that his clothing was not similar to the description originally offered by Stuart. She said the police threatened to put her daughter in juvenile detention if she did not amend her statement to make it match Stuart's description.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``There were so many meetings and so many different places.'' _ Former President Reagan, struggling to recall details of his administration in videotaped testimony in the trial of his former national security adviser, John M. Poindexter.

``It sometimes seems to me that the richer we get, the uglier we tend to make our surroundings. What is worse, not only do we seem to have mislaid the ability to create beauty, but we also set out to destroy what beauty there is left in the world.'' _ Prince Charles, addressing the American Institute of Architects.

``I was very nervous in the ceremony; I had goose bumps all over myself.'' _ Anna Gorbunova, a Moscow secretary who is the first Miss USSR pageant winner, after her baptism in a Ukrainian Orthodox church during a promotional trip to Australia.

DOC.HEAD: Amid Labor's Woes, AFL-CIO Good-Natured About Challenges Ahead
DOC.TEXT: AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland and Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole sat side by side, anxious for a phone call to go through to coal miners in Castlewood, Va. Rich Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers, placed the conference call at 9 a.m. Thursday so miners who'd been without a paycheck for 10 months could hear him officially announce that the Pittston strike was over. Kirkland, Mrs. Dole, Trumka and three others on a platform for the carefully staged event _ viewed as a coup for both labor and Mrs. Dole _ held phones to their ears. Trumka made the call and was put on hold. Minutes ticked by. Aides rolled their eyes. Reporters moved about restlessly. The line was still dead. ``Some day,'' Kirkland cracked with a grin, ``we've got to get organized.''

Leaders of the 14.1 million member AFL-CIO who held their annual meeting here Monday through Thursday know they took a beating in the 1980s, and they good-naturedly admit they have some patching up to do in the coming decade. Union presidents, staff and local labor leaders from around the nation flock south to Florida every winter for the nation's biggest labor meeting, as the AFL-CIO's 33-member board sets policy and maps strategy for the coming year. At a reception for reporters on the eve of the opening day, a New York journalist noted that the shrimp, cheese and wine was a step up from last year's beer-and-pretzel fare served to the press. ``It's a new labor movement for the '90s,'' quipped AFL-CIO spokesman Rex Hardesty, who has pushed for tight-lipped union officials to improve their dealings with reporters.

It was easy to find a party. Even the hotel put one on, apparently in appreciation for labor's loyalty. The AFL-CIO has used the same Bal Harbour beachside resort since 1956. At the biggest spread of the week, held to honor newly elected vice presidents like Trumka, piles of crab and oysters were served under several huge ice sculptures carved in the shape of union acronyms such as UMW and AFL-CIO. At another event sponsored by an insurance company for unions, bright green cloth bags with the company's logo were free. One union worker said she was ordered to take one by her boss, even though she didn't want to cart it around. ``He said, `Take the bag. They raised our premiums 300 percent.'''

Hardesty bristles at occasional stories written about the opulence of the Bal Harbour resort, where a thatch-roofed cabana ringed by palm trees is just footsteps from the ocean. ``They should just try to keep up with the pace,'' he said. Jo-Ann Mort, a spokeswoman for the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, agreed: ``Not many people are here on vacation,'' she said. ``You have to be on all the time.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Students Occupying Universities
DOC.TEXT: Police clashed with students who staged a weeklong sit-in at universities to protest living conditions and police presence on campuses, the official news agency TAP reported. Hundreds were arrested, it said. In a dispatch late Thursday, TAP reported that officers arrested about 470 people in the raids at the University of Tunis and at other universities throughout the country Wednesday. No injuries were reported. The sit-in was called by the General Union of Tunisian Students to protest poor living conditions and the police presence, according to TAP and Western diplomatic sources in Tunis, who spoke on condition they not be named. Reports in Tunisia newspapers said a ``minority'' of students associated with the Islamic fundamentalist student union were trying to use the university ``as a means of exerting political pressure.''
