It did not elaborate. Other arrests were reported in the town of Souss, 90 miles south of the capital. No details were immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Results Negative on Children's Second Test for Gonorrhea
DOC.TEXT: Three children who initially tested positive for gonorrhea apparently do not have the disease, which means speculation about the owner of the day-care center they attended should stop, the man's attorney said. J. David Bogenschutz, who is defending John Shaver against charges of child pornography, said Thursday that subsequent, negative tests on the children brings the accuracy of the previous examination into question. ``Now the case has gone from something with the stigma of gonorrhea and possible child molesting to the fact the state has some pictures they don't like,'' he said. ``And maybe it's time to take a look at how the testing is being done before someone really dangerous does fall through the cracks.'' Police have not charged Shaver, 56, with molesting children. He was arrested Jan. 28 and charged with five counts of possessing child pornography for magazines police say they found in his home. Police also seized hundreds of nude photos of children. Shaver was tested for gonorrhea this month, and proved negative, after police said the children who attended his now-closed Rainbow Learning Center had positive throat cultures for the disease. Police spokesman Ott Cefkin said health officials have told police that false negatives are not uncommon on gonorrhea tests. ``We were told that the health department was 100 percent sure when they found the gonorrhea that they were certain that that was what it was,'' Cefkin said. ``They said it was virtually impossible to have a false positive. ``And now you have a negative. It could be a false negative,'' he said. Prosecutors were considering having a third test done on the children, Bogenschutz said. Police Capt. Bruce Smith said Thursday that even if John Shaver had tested positive for the disease, police wouldn't have charged him with child molestation because the three children have not incriminated Shaver. Shaver was hospitalized briefly following a suicide attempt before being arrested again on charges of using photos of children to make pornographic montages. He later posted bond and was released from jail.

DOC.HEAD: Sihanouk Returns To Live In Cambodia After 11-Year Exile
DOC.TEXT: Prince Norodom Sihanouk today ended 11 years of exile and returned to the land he once ruled, greeted by Cambodians who waved flags and chanted ``long live his royal highness.'' ``All Cambodians want to live in Cambodia and die in Cambodia,'' the guerrilla leader told about 100 reporters bused in for the homecoming. ``I am 68 years old and I feel more and more I could die on foreign soil, even if it is friendly foreign soil like China or North Korea.'' Since fleeing after Vietnamese invasion in December 1978, Sihanouk has lived in palaces and luxury hotels in China, North Korea, Thailand, France and other countries that back his guerrilla movement. Starting today, the prince was to take up residence in a one-room house without running water or central heating, said his spokesman, Ek Sereywath. The prince smiled and waved as his car crossed from Thailand to parched scrubland about 300 feet inside the western border province of Oddar Meanchey, where his guerrillas have made significant inroads in recent months. About 100 civilians greeted him, as did dozens of rifle-toting guerrillas. Sihanouk said he would live in the ``liberated zone'' until the entire country was liberated from the Vietnamese-backed government. Officials said the prince is to live with his wife, Monique, and two aides. Cooks will be on hand, and food and supplies will be brought in from Thailand. Ek said the prince will divide his time between two newly liberated villages that have been renamed Sereipheap, or Freedom, and Ekareach, or Independence. Officials said Sereipheap was about 12 miles from the Thai frontier but did not give a location for Ekareach. Reporters were not allowed go to see either village. ``They have artillery not far from my house so I have to keep the location secret,'' the prince explained. Sihanouk said he would not command his army from his new home, but instead concentrate on helping civilians in the liberated zone with food, medicine and clothing. Sihanouk ascended the throne in 1941 and led Cambodia to independence from the French in 1953. His rule ended in a 1970 military coup after he resisted U.S. attempts to draw Cambodia into the Indochina War. He spent 1975-78 under house arrest as the Communist Khmer Rouge group embarked on a radical agrarian revolution in which hundreds of thousands of people died of famine and in slave labor camps and execution chambers. Since 1982, Sihanouk has led the guerrilla coalition that also includes the Khmer Rouge and the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. He resigned as coalition president recently, citing charges that he was ``an accomplice'' of the Khmer Rouge. Sihanouk's return home came after peace talks in Bangkok Wednesday with Hun Sen, prime minister of the Vietnamese-installed government. Their joint communique vaguely agreed on the need for a U.N. presence in the country and formation of a ``supreme national body,'' but there apparantly were no breakthroughs. Sihanouk said he repeated his demand for dismantling of the Phnom Penh government and installing an interim authority comprising personnel from the United Nations and from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. But he said the Khmer Rouge opposed a U.N. administration. The guerrillas, the Hun Sen government, Vietnam, France and Southeast Asian countries are to meet in Cambodian peace talks starting Monday in Jakarta, Indonesia.

DOC.HEAD: Suit by Smoker's Widow Against Cigarette Company Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: A judge dismissed a lawsuit filed by a smoker's widow despite a state Supreme Court ruling that she had the right to sue R.J. Reynolds Co. for failing to warn her late husband of smoking risks. Ann Forster claimed that her husband, John Forster of Golden Valley, who died of lung cancer in 1985 at age 46, had relied on representations by Reynolds that cigarette smoking was not hazardous. He had smoked Camel cigarettes for more than 30 years. In the ruling filed earlier this month, Hennepin County District Judge Jonathan Lebedoff said Forster could not show that her husband had relied on the slogan, ``I'd walk a mile for a Camel'' as an indication that smoking was not harmful. Forster claimed that the cumulative effect of 30 years of advertising, promotion and public relations was to convince consumers that there were no health dangers associated with smoking. Also dismissed was her claim for breach of express warranty on the product. Lebedoff ruled that because John Forster was expected to know about the hazards of smoking, he could not have relied on any promise to the contrary. Forster claimed that R.J. Reynolds had a duty to warn about the hazards of smoking before 1966, when the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act, requiring such warnings, went into effect. Lebedoff said the company was not obliged to warn consumers of health risks before 1966. The Minnesota Supreme Court ruled a year ago that the labeling law made cigarette companies immune from lawsuits claiming that customers were not warned, but said that it did not relieve them of the duty to tell the truth in their advertising. Lebedoff said he was reluctant to dispose of the case as he did and was not insensitive to the effect it will have on the Forster family.

DOC.HEAD: South African Church Leader Attacks Thatcher's Stand
DOC.TEXT: The general secretary of the South African Council of Churches today said Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has moved too soon to lift sanctions against South Africa. ``The key issue is the dismantling of apartheid and when we have reached the stage where the dismantling of apartheid is irreversible, we will blow the whistle,'' the Rev. Frank Chikane said as he arrived at Heathrow airport. ``We are saying that no one has the right to blow the whistle _ particularly the prime minister of this country.'' Britain split with its partners in the European Community earlier this week and announced it would lift a ban on new investment in South Africa. Mrs. Thatcher has argued that it is important to make a gesture of support for South African President F.W. de Klerk following his decision to release black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela from prison. ``We have asked for sanctions. We have understood that anything we do to remove apartheid is costly and we are prepared to face that,'' Chikane said. ``Our concern is that Mrs. Thatcher's position has been that of consent for the leadership of the apartheid system, rather than the people's organizations. ``It is clear she is operating at a level of the interests of business rather than the interests of the victims of apartheid.' Chikane plans to go to Parliament on Tuesday for an anti-apartheid protest.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea to Hold Election in April
DOC.TEXT: North Korea will hold a parliamentary election in April, six months before the scheduled end of the lawmakers' four-year terms, its official news agency announced today. The Korean Central News Agency said the decision by the Standing Committee of the eighth Supreme People's Assembly to hold the assembly election was made in a meeting Thursday. Members of the current assembly were chosen in an election held in November 1986. The report, monitored in Tokyo, did not say why the election was being held six months early. The assembly, North Korea's legislature, officially is the highest government body, but generally serves only to ratify decisions made by the Communist Party. In the past, the assembly usually has met only twice a year, each time for a few days. A 15-member Standing Committee elected by the assembly performs legislative functions when the assembly is not in session. At the first assembly session after the election, the assembly's key posts, including chairman and vice chairman, are elected, and the new Cabinet is formed.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Spreads South, East; Wet Weekend in Soggy South
DOC.TEXT: Bitter cold began its assault on the eastern half of the nation today, creeping into the upper Great Lakes from Canada. Rain continued, prompting parts of the water-logged South to stack sandbags in preparation for a wet weekend. An arctic snap was due from Minnesota to Georgia to Maine by Sunday morning with readings as many as 25 degrees below normal. Tornadoes touched down Thursday along the Gulf Coast of Mississippi and in Alabama, devastating dozens of homes, snapping trees and utility lines and injuring about 30 people. Wreckage from Thursday's storms littered a 12-county area extending south of Montgomery to the Florida state line and east to the Georgia line. Sub-zero temeratures were due today and Saturday from eastern North Dakota to northern Wisconsin. The East Coast soaked in mild, humid air in advance of the approaching arctic blast. Rain extended from Michigan to Florida. Snow continued in northern Maine while southern New England received more rain. New York state and areas near the nation's capital were swathed in fog. On Thursday, Helena, Mont., broke a 109-year-old record high for Feb. 22 by one degree with a reading of 55. Other highs shattered for the date included 57 in Concord, N.H.; 58 in Portland, Maine; 61 in Providence, R.I.; 63 in Boston; 78 in Charleston, S.C.; and 80 in Columbia, S.C. The warm spell was broken later in the day, with clouds and cooler temperatures. Rain soaked many of the Atlantic states, and snow hit Portland today. A threat of showers and occasional locally heavy rain continued. Flood watches were posted for northwestern Pennsylvania, eastern New York state and southern Vermont. Winds from afternoon thunderstorms gusted to 70 mph at Charlotte, N.C., toppling trees that triggered scattered power outages. Thunderstorm gusts caused damage near Mooreville, N.C., and in Savannah, Ga. The National Weather Service in Columbia said a 70 percent chance of rain and scattered thunderstorms are expected today, but should end by tonight. The coldest temperatures in the nation Thursday was 57 below at Chandalar, Alaska, and in the lower 48 states, minus 1 at Duchesne, Utah. Thursday's hot spot was Sarasota-Bradenton, Fla., with a reading of 88. Marie 24 cloudy; San Antonio 40 fair. _WEST: Albuquerque 33 fair; Anchorage 6 cloudy; Boise 33 fair; Casper 31 fair; Fairbanks -20 fair; Great Falls 38 fair; Honolulu 66 fair; Las Vegas 46 fair; Los Angeles 60 partly cloudy; Medford 39 fair; Pendleton 39 foggy; Phoenix 53 fair; Portland, Ore., 41 fair; Reno 21 hazy; Salt Lake City 32 fair; San Diego 56 fair; San Francisco 51 fair; Seattle 40 fair; Spokane 32 foggy. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 45 fair; Montreal 34 rain; Ottawa 32 snow; Regina 34 snow; Toronto 34 cloudy; Winnipeg 16 cloudy; Mexico City 54 fair; Nassau 73; San Juan 74.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. General Assembly Scheduled to Approve Global Anti-Drug Plan
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations has developed a drug-fighting plan that calls for global cooperation in targeting smuggling, money-laundering and illicit crops. The battle plan shaped during a four-day special session on drugs and expected to be approved today is ``another blow against those trying to peddle drugs around the world,'' said Melvin Levitsky, assistant U.S. secretary of state for narcotics matters. The plan urges countries plagued by trafficking to establish joint border checkpoints. It also encourages national drug enforcement agencies to work with Interpol, the international law enforcement organization, to help investigate drug-linked activities and train personnel in countries facing mounting narcotics problems and related crimes. The document, however, stresses that the anti-drug efforts must not violate the international rights of any countries. ``It is very important to create an international code against drugs so that those who either take drugs or sell drugs are considered pariahs in the international community,'' Levitsky said. A senior U.S. administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said some of the measures were not as strong as American negotiators had hoped they would be. He said the U.S. government wanted more precise language outlining the obligations of all countries in the areas of law enforcement and economic aid for nations battling powerful drug traffickers. ``But it's a document we can support,'' the official said. The plan stresses the need to prevent the international banking system and other financial institutions from being used for laundering profits from the illicit drug trade. It also calls for prompt eradication and substitution of crops that produce raw material for illicit narcotics, such as coca plants used in making cocaine and opium poppy plants that yield heroin. Measures to expand opportunities for trade and investment for countries where illegal drug production has led to severe economic problems should be high priorities, the document said. The plan also calls for steps to prevent covert transfers of arms and explosives to drug traffickers, and urged strict measures to prevent private aircraft and ships from engaging in illicit trade.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Warns of Growing Problems in Food Situation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with East Berlin mayor resigning; picks up 3rd pvs, `Communist Premier...'
DOC.TEXT: Panic-buying by East Germans is emptying store shelves of flour, sugar and meat, but the government promised emergency measures to keep up basic food supplies and called in the army to help with food deliveries. In East Berlin, Communist Mayor Erhard Krack resigned today, assuming political responsibility for a rigged election in May. He was the latest Communist official to quit under pressure in recent weeks. Others have defected to the left-wing Social Democratic Party, widely expected to be the dominant political force in East Germany after elections March 18. The party on Thursday opened its first national convention in Leipzig. Communist Premier Hans Modrow and other East German leaders have called for an end to the hoarding and panic-shopping that have hit the nation's already poorly stocked stores. ``We are in an extraordinary situation in which emergency measures have become necessary,'' Commerce Minister Manfred Flegel told a news conference Thursday in East Berlin. He said the government has ordered stepped-up slaughtering of animals for more meat and more shifts in food production. He said it was considering extra imports. Officials may have to dip into the national emergency food reserves the government keeps on hand in case of a major crisis, Flegel said, but he declined to elaborate. ``The government will maintain a stable food supply under all circumstances,'' Flegel said. ``The army has already had to provide vehicles to help with food deliveries.'' Flegel said the government-run food stores were reporting ``three to four'' times their normal revenue as consumers rush to buy flour, sugar, meat, butter and jam. Tens of thousands of East Germans also have bought food in neighboring West Germany and West Berlin. A cut in subsidies for food production has helped to trigger the run on food. East Germans also are concerned about the expected adoption of the West German mark as a first step toward a unified Germany, and the rate at which they will be able to exchange their savings. In Leipzig, Social Democratic chief Ibrahim Boehme told more than 500 party delegates that the Social Democrats ``are asking people to stay in this country and to work together in building up a democracy.'' Boehme was referring to the continuing daily drain of about 2,000 East Germans to the West despite moves toward reform and German unification since the hard-line Communist government of Erich Honecker was ousted in October. East Germany's Social Democrats will make former Bonn Chancellor Willy Brandt an honorary chairman during the convention. The leftist West German Social Democrats under Brandt's guidance have been providing support to their East German sister party. West German politicians have been become increasingly active in the East German election campaign, leading to protests from the Communists. Modrow's caretaker government called for slashing the armed forces of the unified Germany by two-thirds of present combined forces, and called for some U.S. and Soviet troops to remain during the unification process. East Germany's defense minister, Adm. Theodor Hoffmann, said a joint German military should be reduced to about 300,000 members initially, and later to 150,000-200,000. West Germany belongs to NATO and East Germany is in the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. About 380,000 Soviet soldiers are stationed in East Germany and NATO has more than 300,000 in West Germany, including about 250,000 Americans. In Munich, the Sueddeutsche Zeitung daily newspaper said Modrow had decided against being the embattled Communists' top candidate in next month's national elections. However, a party spokesman said no final decision had been made. In Bonn, a West German government spokesman said only the government of a united Germany could give Poland a guarantee of its borders, West German television reported. The ZDF television report quoted government spokesman Dieter Vogel as saying the formula for achieving German unification had been set by the victorious World War II Allies in Ottawa last week. Under the plan, the Allies and the two Germanys would take part in unification talks. But he said this would include consultations with Poland's government, according to the TV report. Poland, invaded by a unified Germany in World War II, has demanded West Germany guarantee that the existing borders of the Germanys would not change under unification. Some West German conservatives believe that Germany maintains a claim on Polish territory that belonged to Germany before the war.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher against other major currencies in moderately active trading in Europe late this morning, but traders said the U.S. currency was expected to remain in a narrow range. Gold prices fell. The main feature of the foreign exchange market was that the Bank of Japan moved twice to support the yen in Europe through the sale of dollars, selling the dollar at 147 yen, market sources said. Traders said it appeared the Bank of Japan was trying to force the dollar to hold at or move below 147 yen and might intervene directly or through other central banks throughout the day. The yen support in Europe follows dollar sales by the Bank of Japan in Tokyo earlier in the day, dealers said. Reports that Japan's Ministry of Finance has come out against a further rise in the country's discount rate against the judgment of the Bank of Japan had led to dollar buying by investors throughout the Asian day. In Tokyo, the dollar was up strongly against the Japanese yen, closing at 146.47 yen, up 1.24 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 147.05 yen. In Europe, the dollar benefited from a sudden weakness in the West German mark, traders said. But traders said the dollar ran into strong resistance as profit-taking set in. Traders said the dollar was viewed as weak from a fundamental point of view. ``The U.S. economy seems to be entering into a situation of stagflation and that's not good,'' one Milan trader said. The mark has lost some of its attraction because of indications that the German monetary unification might not be as smooth as believed earlier. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: _1.6764 West German marks, up from 1.6695 _1.4747 Swiss francs, up from 1.4725 _5.6748 French francs, up from 5.6580 _1.8915 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8845 _1,238.85 Italian lire, up from 1,234.25 _1.2010 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1945 In London, the dollar traded at $1.7081, compared with $1.7145 late Thursday. Gold opened at $414.50 in London and by midmorning, London's major gold dealers fixed a recommend price of $415 a troy ounce, down from $417.45 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $415.25, down from $417.25 late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped $3.14 an ounce today to close at $413.69. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.24 a troy ounce from Thursday's $5.28.

DOC.HEAD: Carnegie Commission Honors 19 Heroes
DOC.TEXT: Dale Layton wasted no time when he spotted a train bearing down on a man in a wheelchair stuck on railroad tracks. ``I knew if I was going to get there I was going to have to get with it,'' said Layton, one of 19 Americans and Canadians recognized Thursday by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission for risking their lives to save others. Layton, a retired funeral director from Canby, Ore., heard the train's whistle blaring non-stop, and saw the train careening toward Lawrence Supnet, 28, of Portland, stuck in the tracks at a crossing on Nov. 17, 1988. ``I turned and ran just as fast as I could run,'' Layton said in a telephone interview. ``I just gave the chair one yank and tilted it back. I bet it wasn't five heartbeats from the time I grabbed it and the time the train was there.'' Layton and the winners received a medal and $2,500. The commission has honored 7,424 people since its founding in 1904 by industrialist Andrew Carnegie. Five of those honored Thursday died in their rescue attempts. One recipient, James Stack III _ who had recently left prison after serving two years on a rape conviction _ was honored for coming to the rescue of a stabbing victim during an attack March 14, 1989, on a bus in Bloomington, Ill. The others recognized were: _Garry W. Proffit, 34, of Hollywood, Md., drowned trying to pull a man from a water storage tank in Lusby, Md., on Sept. 15, 1988. _Michael G. Martinez, 40, of Hialeah, Fla., died of a heart attack after saving an unidentified woman from drowning in the Atlantic Ocean at Miami Beach, Fla., May 29, 1989. _John K. Aiena, 44, of Beaumont, Texas, died trying to save a man from drowning in a Port Arthur, Texas, marina May 26, 1989. _Betty B. Lamb, 69, of Sacramento, Calif., died trying to save her 3-year-old grandson from drowning in the Pacific Ocean July 12, 1989, in Jenner, Calif. The child also died. _Keith A. Jensen, 33, of New Denmark, New Brunswick, died trying to save his parents from their burning home Jan. 31, 1988, in New Brunswick. _James K. Webb of Fishkill, N.Y., and Richard Gustin of Lagrangeville, N.Y., both 25, helped rescue three men from a burning car in Buchanan, N.Y., on April 11, 1989. _Anthony J. Vaca, 23, of Antioch, Calif., pulled three men from two vehicles that caught fire after colliding in Antioch on March 23, 1989. _Donald L. Dobson, 31, of Reading, Pa., dragged a woman from a burning apartment in Spring City, Pa., on May 26, 1988. _Denise Boczek, 31, of Camarillo, Calif., helped save a 7-year-old boy from drowning in the Pacific Ocean at Oxnard, Calif., on June 22, 1989. _David E. Kamerath, 47, of Salt Lake City, Utah, rescued a 6-year-old girl from the second floor of her burning home April 21, 1989. _John M. Mattson, 24, of Pickering, Ontario, struggled with a man who stabbed a store owner during a robbery on Aug. 15, 1989. _Jeffrey A. Jones, 33, of Cathedral City, Calif., pulled an injured man out of a pickup truck March 4, 1989, as a train approached in Coachella, Calif. _Marc Branch, 27, of Paquetville, New Brunswick, rescued a 16-year-old girl from an overturned burning car Oct. 14, 1987. _Donald L. Reed, 51, of Moscow, Idaho, saved two women from drowning after their boat sank in the frigid Snake River April 15, 1989, in Pullman, Wash. _Karen A. Caylor, 29, of Pittsburgh pulled a woman from a car that was sinking in a canal May 16, 1989, in Naples, Fla. _Christopher M. Rumbaugh, 27, of Orlando, Fla., pulled a woman out of a burning car June 8, 1989, in Tavares, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Martinez Calls for Investigation of Platinum Rap Album
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bob Martinez called for a criminal investigation of a rap group because of its hot-selling album with sexually explicit lyrics. Martinez asked Peter Antonacci, Florida's statewide prosecutor, to conduct an investigation into whether Florida's Racketeer Influenced, Corrupt Organizations Act and obscenity laws have been violated by the widespread distribution of records by ``The 2 Live Crew'' and other rap groups. A Fort Myers judge ruled two weeks ago that there was probable cause to find that ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' was obscene and ordered the album, which has sold more than 1 million copies, pulled from the shelves in Lee County. Shortly after Martinez released his letter Thursday, a jury acquitted an Alexander City, Ala., record store owner of obscenity charges for selling a sexually explicit tape of ``Move Somethin''' by 2 Live Crew. The Circuit Court jury took less than 1{ hours to decide in favor of Tommy Hammond, who earlier was found guilty in Municipal Court in what the American Civil Liberties Union called the nation's first obscenity conviction for music. Hammond had appealed that conviction and was granted a trial in the higher court. In Martinez' letter, he said he was appalled that music a judge has already determined may be obscene was easily available to Florida children. He said he was horrified by reports that seventh-graders can recite some of the lyrics. Some of the four-member band's lyrics include descriptions of gang rapes, sex acts and sadomasochism. A spokeswoman for Skyywalker Records, the Miami record company that produced the album, referred inquiries to the company's lawyer, who was unavailable for comment Thursday. Martinez said he did not think the state should try to censor ``the kind of legitimate public expression protected by the First Amendment.'' He claimed that 2 Live Crew's album doesn't meet that standard. Under state law, the penalty for distributing an obscene record or tape is a maximum five-year sentence and a $1,000 fine. The state Racketeer Influenced, Corrupt Organizations statute, which includes obscenity violations, carries a maximum prison term of 30 years. ``Since the sale of the recording apparently has numbered in the tens of thousands, the pattern of racketeering activity is arguably present,'' Martinez wrote Antonacci. But Charlene Carres, a Tallahassee attorney for the ACLU, said works with literary, artistic, political or scientific value were not covered by the obscenity statute. From Washington, People for the American Way issued a scathing statement, noting Martinez' failed attempt last year to pass an anti-abortion statute. ``First Governor Martinez tried to rob women of their reproductive rights,'' said Elliot Mincberg, legal director of the organization. ``Now he's advocating censorship and taking aim at the First Amendment. One wonders what fundamental right is next on his hit parade.''

DOC.HEAD: Law Faculty Votes to End School Payment of Professors' ABA Dues
DOC.TEXT: Law professors at the University of Notre Dame voted to end the school's payment of their American Bar Association dues to protest the association's vote to condemn curtailment of abortion rights. The school traditionally has paid the $1,900 ABA dues for each of the 30 law faculty members. But they voted Monday to end the perquisite and leave each law professor the decision to maintain membership at their own expense. ``We're not saying they should have taken the opposite position,'' said law dean David T. Link of a bar association vote opposing government intervention in a woman's decision to end a pregnancy. ``They just shouldn't be in this when you think of the division that still exists among members of the bar association and in the courts,'' he said Thursday. No other law school or legal organization has taken a similar step, said Nancy Slonim, a spokeswoman at the ABA's Chicago headquarters. The Texas state bar has scheduled a vote to decide whether to withdraw from the ABA's policy-making house of delegates over the abortion issue. The delegates, meeting Feb. 13 in Los Angeles, voted by a 2-1 margin to oppose legislation or other government action ``that interferes with the confidential relationship between a pregnant woman and a physician, or with the decision to terminate the pregnancy.'' Supporters of the resolution were reacting to the Supreme Court's Webster decision in 1989 affirming Missouri efforts to restrict access to abortion. Link said the faculty stand should not be interpreted as opposition to women's rights. ``Like any other constitutional question, it's not a matter of whether rights exist, but how do you balance competing rights,'' he said. About 80 percent of the law faculty at the Catholic school are members of the Roman Catholic Church, Link said. But the faculty vote represented a professional, not a religious, objection, he said. Link did not disclose totals of the vote. ``The ABA ought to take positions in things unifying to the ABA, rather than divisive, because it interferes with the rights of some minority members,'' Link said. The ABA has received about 80 resignations from among 365,000 members nationwide since approving the abortion policy, Ms. Slonim said. The association has taken stands on controversial, unresolved issues, including opposition to discrimination against homosexuals and opposition to the death penalty for juveniles and the mentally disturbed, she said. Link said he may resign his personal membership if the ABA resolution is allowed to stand. Notre Dame enrolls 510 students in its 121-year-old law school, the nation's oldest Catholic law school.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Tries to Dissuade Local Opposition to Pesticide Spraying
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Deukmejian unsuccessfully tried to persuade local officials to abandon their newest legal challenges to the state's aerial pesticide spraying program to eradicate the Medfly. The Republican governor met in Pasadena on Thursday with Pasadena and Glendale city officials, but the discussion yielded no agreements on the state's pesticide spraying program or on a new Pasadena ordinance prohibiting low-level nighttime helicopter formation flights. Deukmejian said spraying of the pesticide malathion will continue despite local leaders' growing opposition and their concerns the pesticide could cause health risks. ``I know in my own heart that what we are doing is not harmful to the people. Not only in my heart, but in my mind based on the evidence,'' he said. After the meeting, Pasadena and Glendale city leaders said they will continue to oppose spraying because of health concerns. ``There continues to be a very honest difference of opinion,'' said Glendale Councilman Carl Raggio. ``We went into the meeting with that and came out of the meeting with the same feelings.'' A joint lawsuit by the cities of Los Angeles, Burbank and Glendale was filed against the state in Superior Court Thursday, seeking an immediate halt to helicopter missions raining malathion on Southern California communities. The Orange County cities of Garden Grove, Huntington Beach and Westminster recently failed in a similar suit heard by a Sacramento County Superior Court Judge. The suit filed Thursday alleges the missions violate residents' civil rights because they have a right to be free of health risks from toxic chemicals. Helicopters took to the skies overnight to spray a 30-square-mile area of the Verdugo hills in Burbank and Glendale as part of the state's $30 million Medfly eradication campaign, which covers over 400 square miles of Los Angeles and Orange counties. Pasadena City Attorney Victor Kaleta was awaiting a police report that could enable him to file criminal misdemeanor complaints against helicopter pilots who sprayed malathion over the city early Thursday. Agriculture officials maintain malathion is safe and its use necessary to prevent the Medfly from causing up to $200 million in annual losses to the state's agricultural industry. The Medfly lays its eggs in more than 250 varieties of fruits, vegetables and nuts grown in California. The crops are destroyed when the larvae hatch and growing maggots eat their way out.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0457 to CORRECT category code.
DOC.HEAD: Battle Ahead For Early California Primary Proposal
DOC.TEXT: The state Senate passed a bill giving California one of the earliest presidential primaries in the nation, but political leaders said the real fight over the bill was still to come. The bill approved in the Senate on Thursday would jolt the nation's candidate-selection process. It had been bottled up in the Senate since September and was approved only after its supporters promised to send it to a Democrat-dominated two-house conference committee for more negotiations. But Democrat and Republican leaders expressed doubt that the committee could draft a bipartisan compromise the bill appears to need to become law. ``It's not looking very good right now,'' said Senate Republican leader Ken Maddy. In June, the Assembly approved a version of the bill that would schedule California's primary election on the first Tuesday in March during presidential election years, with the change beginning in 1992. That would place the primary of the nation's most populous state, now one of the last to be held, on the heels of the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary. According to the latest state Finance Department figures, California has about 29.1 million people. California has not played a key role in a presidential primary since 1972, when George McGovern's victory propelled him to the Democratic nomination. Supporters of the bill say a June primary usually gives California voters little voice in selecting presidential nominees. In non-presidential years, the primary would remain on its current date, the first Tuesday after the first Monday in June. The vote Thursday in the Democrat-controlled Senate was 24-11. Six Republicans joined 17 Democrats and an independent in supporting the bill. Seven Republicans and four Democrats voted no. The bill has hit a series of snags since it was introduced. Senate Republicans fear the reapportionment of their legislative districts following the 1990 census may not be completed by March 1992. They do not want to run for re-election in 1992 in the current districts, which were drawn up by Democrats. One solution would be to hold two primaries, one in March for presidential candidates and another later in the year, probably June or September, for state and congressional candidates. But Senate leader David Roberti, a Democrat, is strongly opposed to the idea of two primaries, saying three statewide elections in a year _ a general election and two primaries _ would boost costs and reduce voter turnout. ``I am opposed; I am very opposed,'' he said, adding that a two-primary bill would face ``rough sledding'' in the Senate. Whatever the conference committee produces would need final approval from both houses to go to Republican Gov. George Deukmejian, who has said he favors the idea of two primaries.

DOC.HEAD: Policewoman Shoots Man to Death Across From White House
DOC.TEXT: A police officer shot an apparently homeless man to death in a scuffle just across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House. U.S. Park Police officer Katherine Heller came across a man in Lafayette Park on Thursday evening who had been assaulted, said Lt. Reginald L. Smith, spokesman for District of Columbia police. Heller then radioed a description of the alleged attacker and another Park Police officer, Scott Dahl, spotted a man fitting the description of the suspect, Smith said. Dahl approached the man, who began fighting with the officer and managed to take the officer's pistol away from him, Smith said. At that point, Ms. Heller approached and shot the man in the chest, he said. The wounded man, who was not identified, was pronounced dead at George Washington University Hospital. The officers were treated for minor injuries and released. On most evenings, homeless men and women are scattered through Lafayette Park, sleeping on benches or huddled near its information center. A Park Police official told The Washington Post that the slain man was a regular in the park.

DOC.HEAD: Outcry Over Lenient Sentence for White Farmer who Beat Worker
DOC.TEXT: An opposition lawmaker said today the government should investigate a magistrate's decision to impose only a small fine on a white farmer convicted of beating a black worker who died the next day. The farmer, Wilhelm Rabe, was fined the equivalent of $40 on Feb. 12 for assaulting Ekati Xaba last year on a farm near the eastern border with Swaziland. Magistrate J.D. Jacquire accepted evidence that Rabe had beaten Xaba with an electric cord, but rejected testimony that the worker also was thrown to the ground and kicked. Jacquire said there was no proof that the beating caused the brain haemmorrhage and ruptured spleen that were blamed for Xaba's death the day after the beating. Lester Fuchs, a Parliament member for the anti-apartheid Democratic Party, said the sentence was excessively lenient and could cause negative publicity for South Africa at a time when the government is promoting racial reconciliation. He asked that Justice Minister Kobie Coetsee account for the magistrate's ruling. According to The Sowetan, the country's largest black-oriented daily newspaper, two people who witnessed the beating had given statements to police but were never called to testify in court. The Sowetan said Xaba's widow and six children were forced to leave the farm after his death and now live in a one-room cardboard shack. There have been at least two other similar cases in the past three years, in which white farmers avoided prison despite being convicted of fatal assaults of black employees. Several blacks convicted of murdering white farmers are on Death Row, facing hanging if the government lifts a recently declared moratorium on executions.

DOC.HEAD: Citizens' Groups Gear Up for Mass Rallies Over the Weekend
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to recast lead. Pickup 3rd, `The appeal...
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party today repeated an appeal for Soviets to avoid ``chaos'' during nationwide rallies planned this weekend, indicating a growing concern the protests might lead to renewed unrest. The party's policy-making Central Committee urged ``the Soviet working people'' to ``rebuff all who push people to chaos, provoke conflicts, ethnic strife and enmity and create instability in society.'' The appeal was issued Thursday and repeated on radio and TV today. Rallies are planned Sunday, a week before the balloting in some republics, and grew out of the success of a Feb. 4 protest when tens of thousands paraded through Moscow demanding the Communist Party give up its grip on power. The rallies and demonstrations will be the first major public gatherings since the Central Committee voted to renounce its monopoly on power Feb. 7, paving the way for establishment of a multi-party democracy. Many of the rallies are being organized by Popular Front movements striving for greater pluralism since they sprang up in the last two years. On Tuesday, the Soviet legislature issued a decree calling on local authorities to crack down on illegal protests Sunday and to strictly control those demonstrations that are permitted. Organizers of Sunday's rally in Moscow have received permission to gather, and the official news agency Tass quoted Vladimir Kamchatov of the Elector's Association as saying that up to 300,000 people could turn out. Demonstrations are planned in a number of provincial cities in the sweeping Russian republic, which stretches from Finland to the Sea of Japan, and come shortly before elections to the local legislatures in Russia on March 4. Elections are scheduled in the Ukraine and Byelorussia on that day as well. Groups in the Uzbekistan capital of Tashkent have been denied permission to hold an outdoor rally, although an indoor meeting will be allowed. Leningrad activists were denied a request to stage a march and instead will hold a rally at a sports complex. Mikhail Tkachev, leader of the Byelorussian Popular Front, said his movement will demand registration of candidates that local authorities have refused to place on the ballot at the meeting in the capital of Minsk. At the rally, he said, demonstrators will ``express our distrust in the republic's political leadership and press for their resignation and the banishing of party organizations from enterprises, colleges, army and law enforcement organs.'' Demonstrations are planned throughout the Ukraine, which last summer was rocked by strikes and where regional party leaders have been resigning with growing regularity under public pressure. All independent political groups have been invited to take part in a rally in the Ukrainian capital of Kiev, while the regional strike committee formed last summer is leading the rally in Donetsk. In Azerbaijan, where a state of emergency imposed Jan. 20 following a bloody week of ethnic unrest is still in effect, Yusis Samed Oglu of the Popular Front said no rallies were planned out of fear that soldiers would use force against the crowd. The three Baltic republics where the drive for independence is strong and the achievements in gaining autonomy have been greatest of all 15 republics are so far taking a low-key approach to the day of demonstrations. Rallies are not scheduled in Lithuania, which is holding elections Saturday, or in neighboring Latvia, which is gearing up for elections to the republican legislature on March 18. However, activists in the third and smallest Baltic republic of Estonia said a gathering was being organized for Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Clash Outside Vienna Opera Leaves 69 Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with police giving number of casualties, blaming right-wingers for clashes. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of demonstrators clashed with police outside the Vienna State Opera as socialites waltzed inside, and authorities said today that at least 69 people were injured. The 1,300 demonstrators were demanding that funds raised to finance the annual opera ball be spent for social programs to help the poor and homeless. The violence outside the opera peaked as President Kurt Waldheim and his wife arrived to attend the event Thursday night. But the nearly 3,000 police officers on hand ushered them and other dignitaries safely inside. Although two leftist groups received permits for the protest, police said they were not responsible for the violence. Police President Guenter Boegl said the clashes were triggered by right-wing radicals who joined the protest. A police communique today said at least 69 people were injured in clashes around the opera, including 60 policemen and nine demonstrators. Ten other demonstrators were taken into custody, it said. The demonstrators were protesting the display of wealth and pageantry at the ball. Some posters said, ``Gobble up the rich.'' Police used shields to ward off stones and bottles as they charged the crowd with clubs and dogs, witnesses and reporters said. Scuffles also broke out between demonstrators and groups of right-wingers, police reported. Reporters watching the scene said police action at times appeared uncoordinated and haphazard, with some officers rounding up inactive demonstrators and others driving into the crowd on motorcycles. Some of the chaos may have resulted from police radio contact being briefly disrupted by pirate transmitters, deriding or abusing police officials. Radical demonstrators smashed shopwindows and damaged cars in streets near the opera, a police statement said. Cordons of police ringed the opera, blocking access to the building. In demonstrations last year, about 40 people were reported injured. Inside the opera, an unsmiling Princess Caroline of Monaco was almost crushed by more pushing and shoving by scores of news photographers trying to get the best shot. One stepped on her gown. Caroline ascended to her box, trying to ignore the photographers. She later refused an interview for Austrian state television, sitting stolidly in a box. About 7,000 people attended the opera ball. The price of a ticket was $183. The most expensive box cost more than $12,000.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Grants Taxi Driver Three Divorces So He Can Marry Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT `to' to `from;' SUBS 5th graf, `Kamara married...', to fix typo in `where.'
DOC.TEXT: Taxi driver Alie Dura Kamara got divorced this week _ from all three of his wives. His lawyer says he wants to marry again. ``The gentleman is from West Africa, and I had to tell him that Americans have some strange and quaint habits about wives _ only one at a time,'' said Kamara's attorney, Gregory Z. Schroeder. ``It's the first time I've granted three divorces at the same time to one man,'' Fulton Superior Court Senior Judge Charles A. Wofford said Thursday. Wofford said he wondered how Kamara, 40, had avoided being charged with bigamy. Asked about that, District Attorney Lewis R. Slaton was frank about it. ``We don't have any room in our jail for bigamists,'' he said. ``They're just going to have to wait their turn. We'll get to them when we can.'' Kamara married his first wife in 1976 in his native Sierra Leone, where having multiple wives is a sign of prosperity. The couple moved to the United States, then separated in 1981, according to court documents. He married a second woman in 1983, and separated from her before marrying in Atlanta for a third time in 1986. None of the women contested the divorce. Kamara retained custody of two children. Schroeder said Kamara wanted the divorces because he wants to ``clean up his life.'' ``I think he wants to get married again,'' Schroeder added.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Will Visit Three Cities April 21-22
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New graf at end to ADD that Velehrad site of a pilgrimage shrine.
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II will visit Prague, Velehrad and Bratislava during his April 21-22 trip to Czechoslovakia, the Vatican announced. The statement Thursday was the first official Vatican confirmation of the itinerary of the trip, the pope's first to a Warsaw Pact country other than his native Poland. The pope was invited by Czechoslovakia's new non-Communist president, Vaclav Havel, and by Cardinal Frantisek Tomasek, archbishop of Prague and the country's Roman Catholic primate. Velehrad was included on the pope's intinerary in Czechoslovakia because it is the site of a pilgrimage shrine.

DOC.HEAD: Malpractice Reaction: `They May Quit Delivering Babies in This State'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4-5th grafs, `Mark and...', to add doctor's defense to the suit, note that baby weighed more than 10 pounds. Picks up 6th graf, `We're working...'. Other minor editing.
DOC.TEXT: A record medical malpractice award is causing some West Virginia obstetricians to turn away new patients and consider leaving the state, where their ranks already have been halved in five years. ``Some will probably leave if they get a chance. I would leave,'' Dr. Ujjal Sandhu said Thursday. ``I don't want to worry about losing my shirt. The patients will have to go out of state just like the doctors are leaving.'' A county jury in Charleston last week awarded a couple $15.25 million after they claimed their obstetrician failed to perform a Caesarean section to prevent brain damage to their newborn. It was the state's highest malpractice award against an obstetrician. Mark and Julie Robinson of Cabin Creek, about 15 miles east of Charleston, said Dr. Kanoj K. Biswas, a Charleston obstetrician, should have performed the Caesarean section on July 31, 1987, after their son, who weighed more than 10 pounds, became stuck in the birth canal. Instead, the couple said Biswas used forceps to remove the baby, causing fetal asphyxia and a brain hemorrhage. The doctor's lawyer had argued that the child had an abnormal heart and the his treatment during birth was not the cause of his medical problems. ``We're working scared,'' Sandhu said. ``Malpractice awards are skyrocketing. There should be some reasonable compensation to victims, but they shouldn't be made millionaires overnight.'' Sandhu and at least seven other Charleston obstetricians have decided not to take new patients, he said. Some are leaving to practice in neighboring states with lower insurance costs and limits on medical malpractice awards. The decline in obstetricians has worsened in the state in recent years, said Dr. Bruce Berry, chairman of West Virginia's section of the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology. Berry said the state now has 65 registered obstetricians, down from 135 five years ago. Twenty-one family practioners also deliver babies, but the state hasn't been able to recruit new physicians, Berry said. There were 23,045 babies born in West Virginia last year, according to state figures. West Virginia has been troubled by problems keeping physicians of all kinds. Last year, the state had 152 doctors per 100,000 residents, 37th among the states, according to the American Medical Association. Some counties have no doctors at all. Berry said he quit practicing obstetrics 14 months ago in Charleston mainly because of the high cost of malpractice insurance. West Virginia Medical Association officials are trying to determine how other obstetricians are reacting to the malpractice award, said Executive Director George Rider. Dr. Paul Fulcher of Charleston, who also stopped taking new pregnant patients because of the recent case, said such malpractice awards leave him ``virtually uninsured.'' Fulcher said most obstetricians carry a minimum $1 million malpractice insurance. The maximum coverage is $10 million, Berry said. West Virginia physicians pay about $63,000 in liability insurance annually, sometimes twice as much as doctors in Virginia and Kentucky, Rider said. He said he is uncertain why malpractice insurance costs more in West Virginia. High insurance costs are making it harder for pregnant women to find a physician, Fulcher said. ``The main thing is we want to ensure the availability of health care and provide our expertise without our personal and family assets being on the line,'' Fulcher said. ``I want to continue practicing in this state, but I won't make my family liable.'' Berry said the average delivery costs $1,200 to $1,500. Patients would have to pay $500 more to cover liability insurance if an obstetrician took out a $10 million policy, he said. The medical association has been unsuccessful in attempts to cap malpractice awards; other states' caps have been declared unconstitutional, officials said. Instead, Fulcher said, some obstetricians have proposed a reserve fund to cover large malpractice awards. But he said another $15 million award would wipe out the fund. Del. Bobby Hatfield of Kanawha, chairwoman of the House Health and Human Resources Committee, said the state will consider legislation establishing excess insurance funds to help physicians. Obstetricians said they need help soon. ``I love my job and delivering babies, but I want better protection,'' Sandhu said. ``They may just quit delivering babies in this state.''

DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles Harbor Closed by Cargo Ship's Propane Leak
DOC.TEXT: Busy Los Angeles Harbor was closed to ship traffic while authorities pondered how to remove a leaking canister of propane gas from a cargo ship today without sparking an explosion or fire. The harbor was closed to incoming and outgoing vessels about 11:30 p.m. Thursday after officials discovered propane leaking from a canister in the cargo hold of the Evergroup, said Coast Guard spokeswoman Elizabeth Fleming. No evacuations from nearby ships and no injuries were reported. Crew members who left the ship when the leak was discovered reboarded the vessel at Berth 229 ``to shut down all the ship's systems ... anything that might cause a spark,'' Ms. Fleming said. ``The gas is not poisonous, but it is flammable,'' said Coast Guard Petty Officer Robert Beals. ``They're thinking about flooding it with (carbon dioxide) in the moring, to prevent a fire or explosion in the port.'' Coast Guard and city fire officials planned to huddle this morning to determine the safest way to remove the canister, said Fire Capt. Craig Fletcher. Fire officials first began receiving reports about a strange smell in the harbor late Wednesday, but were not able to discover its source until late Thursday, Fletcher said. ``It was really hard to find because the winds kept changing,'' he said. Fire officials initially dispatched a fire boat, six engine companies and hazardous materials team to the scene, said Fletcher. Firefighters were released overnight, but are expected to be sent back when the canister is removed from the ship, he said. The harbor, located about 25 miles south of downtown, is the nation's second busiest port.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Navy Warning Vessels To Keep Away From Burning Tanker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to ADD quotes from shipping official saying explosion apparently occurred above waterline, ruling out mine. ADDS conditions of injured unknown and that dead to be returned to U.S. Pickup 15th, `The U.S....
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Navy today told vessels to steer at least four miles clear of a burning Kuwaiti tanker while an army of salvage boats worked around the clock to keep its volatile cargo from exploding again. The U.S.-flagged Surf City was loaded with naphtha and diesel fuel for Italy on Thursday when a blast ripped through it in the Persian Gulf, 20 miles off the United Arab Emirates coast. The ship was still billowing smoke today. Its American captain and first mate were killed, but the 23 other sailors, all Americans but one, were rescued by U.S. warships. Four were hospitalized, but their conditions were not known. Officials ruled out sabotage or a floating mine as the cause and said a short circuit may have sparked the blast aboard the ship, which was owned by the Kuwaiti Oil Tanker Co. It had been reflagged for U.S. protection during the Iran-Iraq war. ``The explosion according to our reports occurred above the waterline,'' said C. Miles Sheldon, head of Chesapeake Shipping Inc., the subsidiary used by the Kuwait Oil Tanker Co. to operate its American-owned tankers. The huge blaze that burned through the night on the ship was contained, but the ship's condition was uncertain, Sheldon told a news conference in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates. He said the Surf City was listing three degrees as a result of the loss of cargo. The lost cargo was only naphtha, which burns easily and evaporates, causing minimal pollution, he said. U.S. Navy officials told ships in the area to stay at least four miles away from the ship, which was being monitored by the USS Simpson, a missile frigate. ``The accommodation quarters are still smoldering, and the heat could blow up the cargo, which would be a major disaster,'' said a shipping source in the southern Persian Gulf, who spoke on condition on anonymity. Two salvage tugboats from the Kuwaiti Oil Tanker Co. joined half a dozen others from the United Arab Emirates overnight, dousing the tanker with foam and water to fend off a more serious explosion, the shipping sources said. The source said the front part of the ship was only about two feet above water. The tugboats were trying to keep it from sinking. Because the explosion occurred halfway near the Iranian island of Abu Musa, it provoked speculation that it might have been caused by an Iranian mine or other explosive. The Iranian Revolutionary Guards used the island as a base for ship attacks during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. Capt. Ron Wildermuth, chief spokesman for the Central Command in Florida which oversees the U.S. naval forces, said initial reports indicated the explosion was caused by an internal accident. Abdul-Fattah al-Bader, the chairman of the Kuwait Oil Tanker Co., told reporters in Kuwait that he ruled out sabotage, attributing the fire to a short circuit. The U.S. Navy identified the dead as Derrick F. Linardich, the 38-year-old captain of Norfolk, Va.; and Steven P. McHugh, the 34-year-old first mate from East Bridgewater, Mass. Sheldon said the bodies had been recovered and would be sent home after formalities were completed in Dubai. The U.S. Navy has a 10-unit Middle East Force in the gulf, and monitors movement of U.S.-flagged ships in the gulf from a distance. It officially ceased the regular escorts it used to conduct at the height of the Iran-Iraq war, mainly from Iranian threats. Kuwait, whose tankers were a primary target of the Iranians, re-registered 11 of its tankers in the United States to give them the right to the U.S. Navy protection. A few months after the U.N. cease-fire halted the 8-year Persian Gulf war in August 1988, Kuwait deflagged six of the tankers. Surf City was one of the five still flying the U.S. flag, with the Kuwaitis geared to discuss their de-registration this month.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois Crude Oil Spill 16 Times Greater Than First Estimated
DOC.TEXT: Shell Oil Co. said a pipeline accident this week spilled an estimated 672,000 gallons of crude oil, 16 times more than the company first estimated. The new figure stunned state environmental officials. ``This came as a tremendous shock,'' Will Flower, a spokesman for the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, said Thursday. ``We knew the (42,000 gallon) figure was conservative, but to find out that it was (672,000 gallons) was quite a shock.'' An underground pipeline connecting two crude oil storage tanks burst Monday, spewing crude oil above the ground near the tanks at a Shell refinery across the Mississippi River from St. Louis. Shell spokesman Tony Canino defended the delay in reporting the larger estimate, saying the company wanted to be ``absolutely firm'' about any figures released. ``We think it's perfectly reasonable not to release a number until it's firm,'' Canino said. ``We would rather be right than fast.'' Canino also said that Shell has not determined yet what caused the underground pipeline to rupture in this southwestern Illinois town. On Wednesday, the Illinois EPA called for a study of the refinery to discover the cause of recurring spills, emissions and fires, and come up with ways to prevent them. ``In pipeline leaks alone, there has been more than a million gallons of product loss since mid-December,'' said Flower. The cleanup of the spill was continuing, Flower said, with company crews picking up all liquid crude oil on the ground. ``In our last inspection, the oil didn't get into a nearby retention pond, but the rain today moved the oil toward the retention pond,'' said Flower. He said Shell deployed absorbent booms to collect oil in the pond. State EPA officials and representatives from Illinois Attorney General Neil Hartigan's office were scheduled to discuss the spill with Shell officials this afternoon. Hartigan filed a lawsuit in September against Shell, seeking $1.2 million in penalties for various environmental mishaps.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Leader To Meet With Chairman Of Largest Mining Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with anti-apartheid march. Pickup 11th pvs, `Relly has...
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela met today with parliamentary opposition leaders, and aides released details of what will be his first trip abroad since leaving prison _ an 18-day, four-nation trip starting next week. Aides also confirmed that Mandela, who has endorsed the nationalization of South Africa's mines, planned to meet Monday with the chairman of the country's largest mining conglomerate. Gavin Relly, whose Anglo American Corp. is the world's No. 1 gold producer, accepted an invitation to visit Mandela's house in the black township of Soweto, the company said. In a demonstration of racial solidarity, hundreds of blacks joined thousands of whites in a march and rally today organized by the main white anti-apartheid party, the Democratic Party. Jackson Tembu, a black leader of the United Democratic Front anti-apartheid coalition, joined Democratic Party co-leader Zach de Beer on the podium at the rally and praised the party as ``the only voice of reason'' in white politics in recent years. De Beer was one of three Democratic Party leaders to meet with Mandela earlier today at his home. His party represents anti-apartheid whites in Parliament. Also at the meeting was the Reb. Allan Hendrickse, leader of Parliament's mixed-race chamber. Mandela's African National Congress has urged boycotts of elections for the mixed-race and Asian chambers of Parliament, saying their creation was part of an effort to entrench the exclusion of blacks. But Hendrickse said after the meeting that the ANC and the Labor Party, which controls the mixed-race chamber, would be able to work together. Denis Worrall, one of the Democratic Party leaders, said his delegation and Mandela agreed on the need for universal voting rights, but differed over the ANC's support for guerrilla violence, economic sanctions and nationalization. Since his release Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison, Mandela has reaffirmed his support for the ANC's economic policies, which call for nationalization of mines, banks and monopoly industries. Mandela, whose last trip abroad began with a clandestine border crossing in 1962 shortly before his imprisonment, plans to fly Tuesday to Lusaka, Zambia. There, he will meet leaders of several African countries and confer with the ANC's exiled leadership. He then plans to spend three days in Zimbabwe and six days in Tanzania before flying to Sweden on March 12 to visit ANC President Oliver Tambo, who is recovering from a stroke in a Stockholm clinic. Relly has spoken out frequently against apartheid, and his corporation _ although occasionally at odds with black unions over wage disputes _ espouses relatively liberal employment policies. In 1985, when the government was condemning all contact with the ANC, Relly was among a group of South African businessmen that traveled to Lusaka for talks with the movement's leaders. Another member of that delegation, Tony Bloom, also is scheduled to meet Mandela on Monday. Bloom formerly was chairman of the Premier Corp., one of South Africa's biggest food companies, but he left the country in 1988 to work in London. Mandela and the ANC contend that some degree of socialism is needed to help reduce the enormous gap between white wealth and black poverty. Several business leaders have conceded that some redistribution of wealth is needed but say this can be done better without nationalization.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Stock Market Has Fifth-Largest Drop In History
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0546 to CORRECT to 2nd Ld-Writethru. UPDATES with yen losing ground against other major currencies, stocks dropping on Hong Kong and London markets; edits throughout to tighten. A version moved on the financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Computerized selling and interest-rate jitters pushed stock prices into a tailspin today, causing the fifth-worst loss in history on the world's largest exchange. The fall comes two days after the Tokyo market's third-largest decline and puts the Nikkei index of 225 selected issues down 2,569.35 points _ or nearly 7 percent _ for the week. The government acknowledged confusion over arbitrage trading and today directed the securities industry to report on their arbitrage activities, said a Finance Ministry official on condition of anonymity. The Nikkei lost 935.87 points, or 2.61 percent, in light trading to end the week at 34,890.97. It was the first time the Nikkei has fallen below the 35,000-point level since Oct. 17, 1989. Meanwhile, the dollar rose against the Japanese yen, closing at 146.47 yen, up 1.24 yen from Thursday. The yen also lost ground against other major currencies, including the West German mark. In Hong Kong, stock prices reacted to the drop in Tokyo, with the Hang Seng Index losing 33.61 points to close at 2,894.31. Stocks in London also stumbled. By midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was off 30.6 points, or 1.3 percent, at 2,238.6. The Nikkei index, which on Wednesday lost 1,161.19 points, or more than 3 percent, won back 92.51 points on Thursday. But it quickly began sliding when trading began today. Declines in the futures market triggered a wave of program selling in the afternoon, pushing the Nikkei down to a four-month low. Institutional investors, primarily foreign trust funds, sold a large volume of index-related shares in the spot market through program trading, analysts said. Securities and trust fund companies were hesitating to increase their holdings for fear of reporting losses at the upcoming end of the fiscal year, said Michio Katsumata of Nomura Securities Co. Most Japanese companies close their annual accounts at the end of March. Securities companies often cash in some of their holdings at that time to offset earlier losses. Extremely thin volume accentuated the decline. ``The market is extremely vulnerable right now to such selling because of the low volume of stocks being traded and small number of investors taking part,'' Katsumata said. ``Most major players remain on the sidelines.'' Volume in the morning session was estimated at a low 430 million shares, about half the usual amount. Dealers said anticipation that the Bank of Japan would hike the discount contributed to the Nikkei's decline. Higher interest rates tend to discourage stock investment. Officials at the central bank, whose official discount rate now stands at 4.25 percent after three increases last year, have said they are still monitoring economic conditions and have not decided on another increase. Rising inflation in recent months and strong growth in the economy and the money supply led analysts to predict a discount rate increase. Rumors about the possible emergence of a stock scandal, following last year's Recruit scandal, also discouraged many investors, dealers said. One rumor suggested a major governing party politician may be arrested for illegal stock dealings, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Testimony Gives Little Aid to Poindexter Defense, Experts Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 11th graf, At the, with White House no-comment
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan's videotaped testimony gives little support to the defense in John M. Poindexter's upcoming Iran-Contra trial and could undermine it in several important ways, observers say. Reagan steadfastly maintained that Poindexter and other White House aides were not breaking the law when they advised the Nicaraguan Contras during a congressional ban on U.S. aid to the rebels. The former president said he was in ``total agreement'' with a letter Poindexter sent to Congress in July 1986 denying that the National Security Council staff was giving the rebels covert military assistance. ``If I had written it myself, I might have used a little profanity,'' Reagan said of the letter, which prosecutors charge was a false statement to lawmakers by Poindexter. Former Iran-Contra prosecutor Michael Bromwich said it the ``one line that dramatically helps the defense'' during eight hours of testimony. ``The president sees this letter and says it looks fine to him,'' Bromwich said. ``I think it has a psychological effect on the jury.'' But Reagan's confusion and lack of knowledge about the participation of Poindexter and White House aide Oliver L. North in the Iran-Contra affair is damaging, said Bromwich, a member of the team of lawyers that successfully prosecuted North last year. ``Reagan seems to have very little idea of what was going on so he certainly didn't authorize or approve of what North or Poindexter was doing based on full knowledge of the facts,'' said Bromwich, now in private law practice in Washington. Also damaging are Reagan's statements that he didn't authorize any of the actions Poindexter took that prosecutors allege violated the law, Bromwich said. ``On the ultimate question, `Did you authorize? Did you approve?' the answer is `No, No, No,''' Bromwich said. At the White House today, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We have no comment'' on Reagan's testimony. The transcript of Reagan's eight-hour pre-trial deposition, given last week behind closed doors in Los Angeles, was released Thursday by U.S. District Judge Harold Greene. The public was allowed to view the videotapes of Reagan's testimony in the courtroom where Poindexter is scheduled to go to trial March 5 on charges of obstructing congressional inquiries into the Iran-Contra affair. Reagan testified he ``never had any inkling'' that North was providing strategic advice to the Contras. The former president steadfastly maintained that ``no one has proven to me'' that profits from the U.S.-Iran arms sales were diverted to buy arms for the rebels. Nor did he know that North had sought help from arms dealers Albert Hakim and Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force major general, in arming the Contras. Both have pleaded guilty to charges arising from their roles in the Iran-Contra affair. Only when prosecutor Dan Webb produced a copy of the report by the Tower Commission, which Reagan appointed to investigate the Iran-Contra affair, did the former president acknowledge that the diversion must have occurred. ``This is the first time that I have ever seen a reference that actually specified there was a diversion,'' Reagan told Webb. Asked if he expected Poindexter to report the diversion to the president, Reagan said: ``Yes, unless maybe he thought he was protecting me.'' In fact, Poindexter told Congress in 1987 that he didn't tell Reagan about the diversion. Reagan admitted to Webb that he never authorized his former national security adviser to obstruct congressional inquiries into the Iran-Contra affair by destroying documents or making false statements. This testimony ``takes away one of the defenses that Admiral Poindexter was asserting,'' said Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., who was a recipient of one of Poindexter's letters when he chaired the House Intelligence Committee. ``That defense was that he was specifically authorized to do what he did,'' Hamilton said. Paul Rothstein, a Georgetown University law professor, said Webb may have ``made a lot of mileage'' by getting Reagan to say he didn't authorize the specific acts by Poindexter that prosecutors say violated the law. The defense probably will focus on the claim that Reagan's fervent support for the Contras ``created a certain environment or climate in the White House that gave the signal or the impression to Admiral Poindexter that he could do what he did,'' Hamilton said. Reagan's testimony may give some support here because the former president was so firm in his criticism of Congress for tying his hands when he was trying to help the Contras, Bromwich said. ``There is throughout this deposition, a clear suspicion of Congress that comes out loud and clear,'' Bromwich said. The former president's testimony also makes clear that ``Reagan viewed himself in a war with Congress on Contra aid,'' Bromwich said. ``He made very clear to all his subordinates that he felt very strongly on the issue.'' But Webb used written answers that Reagan gave to the Iran-Contra grand jury in 1987 ``to cut his legs out from under him'' when his testimony conflicted with the prior statements, Bromwich noted. Reagan testified that he didn't know which White House official told him that a C-123 transport plane that was shot down over Nicaraguan on Oct. 5, 1986, was not connected with any U.S. government effort to help the Contras. But Webb produced Reagan's written answers in which he specifically stated that it was Poindexter who gave him those assurances.

DOC.HEAD: Czech Playwright-President Gets Warm Reception from PEN-pals, Officials
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Havel's caretaker...', to CORRECT that Czech agency said Havel arrived home sted Vienna en route home.
DOC.HEAD: LaserColor NY13
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak president Vaclav Havel dashed around Manhattan, receiving a hero's welcome from writers and artists, hobnobbing with punk rockers and meeting a ``legend'' _ Paul Newman. ``I've been in the presence of some great artists and I've been in the presence of some great statesmen, but I've never before been in the presence of a great artist-statesman,'' Newman said Thursday at a reception for Havel. With the wit and self-deprecation that typified the comments he made in broken English in his one-day whirl around the city, Havel called Newman ``such a big legend that I didn't believe he physically exists. Now I'm standing here with him.'' The Czechoslovak Parliament elected Havel president a few weeks after a peaceful revolution in December that led to the ouster of a hard-line Communist government. That regime had jailed Havel for five years for his satirical plays and other activism. After receiving the Spirit of Freedom award from the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Thursday, Havel told an audience of several thousand: ``I'm sorry I had no opportunity to write my speech because I was not today two hours in prison.'' Some of Havel's works were produced in the solitude of incarceration. Havel's caretaker government is preparing for parliamentary elections in June. He left for home early this morning, and arrived in Czechoslovakia later in the day, the Czechoslovak state news agency reported. His first taste of the Big Apple in a generation began late Wednesday in lower Manhattan's East Village. His boyhood schoolmate, filmmaker Milos Forman, took him on walks to places Havel visited in 1968. They dropped in on CBGBs, one of the first punk rock clubs, and rock hangout The Bitter End. ``People were recognizing him in the streets,'' Forman said. ``Their faces were lighting up.'' At a concert in Havel's honor Thursday, playwright Arthur Miller said, ``I welcome him as the world's first avant-garde president.'' Among the other artists who spoke at the concert at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine was actor Ron Silver, who said: ``Vaclav Havel has shown the world that art matters.'' Addressing Havel, he added: ``Help us overcome our cynicism and let us bask in the glory and joy of an artist leading us.'' Earlier Havel received an honorary doctor of law degree from Columbia University, where Forman teaches film. Columbia President Michael Sovern told the playwright: ``We are especially pleased to award you a degree because as a young man you and many other promising leaders of your generation were deliberately prevented from earning one by the oppressive regime.'' Havel breakfasted with Mayor David Dinkins and theater producer Joseph Papp, who announced his intention to produce Havel's play ``Slum Clearance.'' Papp had invited Havel to New York in 1968 with an invitation to see the Public Theater's production of his play, ``The Memorandum.'' Havel told reporters Thursday that as a playwright, he never could have conceived a plot in which he would become president. Like many tourists, Havel's agenda included the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he viewed 20th-century works. Havel also met with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. The concert at the cathedral featured performances by Paul Simon, James Taylor, Roberta Flack, opera star Placido Domingo, and the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Zubin Mehta. Classical offerings included selections from Czech composer Antonin Dvorak's ``New World Symphony'' and Mozart's ``Don Giovanni,'' which premiered in Prague. A dozen actors and writers _ including Gregory Peck and Saul Bellow _ read from Havel's speeches and letters and paid tribute to his achievements. Forman, the filmmaker, summed up their sentiments by saying: ``If a playwright makes us laugh or cry, ... he's an artist. But if a playwright succeeds to orchestrate the overthrow of a communist dictatorship without one bullet fired, it's a miracle.'' On Wednesday, Havel addressed Congress in Washington, D.C., and said the United States could best help Czechoslovakia by helping the Soviet Union stay on the road to democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Commander Well, But Weather Forces Postponement Of Saturday Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with launch postponed until at least Sunday, CORRECTS spelling of spokesman Buckingham. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Because of...'.
DOC.TEXT: NASA today postponed for a third time the flight of Atlantis on a secret military mission, saying its commander had recovered from an illness but the threat of storms still prevented the launch. NASA managers ordered the delay until at least Sunday, blaming a weather front that moved into the area this morning, packing rain and brisk winds and bringing the threat of thunderstorms. The forecast for Sunday is much better with an 80 percent chance of favorable conditions. The postponement came just hours after doctors pronounced Atlantis commander John O. Creighton fully recovered from a respiratory infection that, along with the weather, forced two earlier postponements. NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham said today that after doctors decided Creighton was healthy enough to fly Atlantis, the astronaut and a crewmate spent part of the morning flying practice landings in the space shuttle training aircraft. Atlantis originally was scheduled for launch early Thursday, but Creighton became ill. Hopes of launching this morning instead were dashed when physicians recommended Creighton be given another 24 hours to recover. That slipped the launch to early Saturday, and then the weather forecast today put it back another 24 hours. Sources said Atlantis will deploy a spy satellite during a four-day mission.
