Creighton's illness, described formally as an infection of the upper respiratory tract, developed suddenly on Wednesday. He received unspecified therapy and by Thursday afternoon NASA said he was on the mend. Because of the military secrecy of Atlantis' flight, NASA has not announced a precise launch time, saying only that it would come between midnight and 4 a.m. The countdown is kept secret until the final nine minutes before the rockets ignite. Once Atlantis fades from the view of launch observers, progress of the mission will be blacked out. NASA will not release the air-to-ground communications, as is done with most shuttle flights, or give reports on the astronaut activities. The blackout will be lifted just an hour before Atlantis returns to Earth for a landing at Edwards Air Force Base in California. Creighton's illness came as a surprise. All five of Atlantis' crew members were found to be healthy during a routine medical examination on Tuesday. The next day, the astronaut complained of a sore throat. NASA doctors enforce a strict isolation for the astronauts seven days before a launch. The system requires most people working within six feet of the astronauts to wear masks. A NASA spokesman claimed on Wednesday that an astronaut illness had never before forced a mission postponement. But, after a bit of file-checking on Thursday, the agency said that the Apollo 9 flight in 1969 had been delayed three days because the crewmen developed upper respiratory infections. In 1970, astronaut Thomas K. Mattingly was taken off the crew of Apollo 13 doctors learned he had been exposed to the measles. He was replaced on the crew by back-up pilot John Swigert and the launch was not delayed. NASA officials said there were no plans to replace Creighton. Creighton's four crewmates on Atlantis are Air Force Capt. John H. Casper, Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane, and Navy Lt. Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot. Atlantis, according to sources who asked not to be named, is to carry into space a 37,300-pound, $500 million spy satellite called AFP-731. The device is said to be capable of taking high-resolution reconnaissance photos and of eavesdropping on electronic communications around the world. The satellite is to be placed into a high inclination orbit that will cover more of the Earth than satellites previously launched by the shuttle. This orbital path will carry it over most of the Soviet Union, including areas far to the north. Atlantis' flight will be 34th space shuttle mission and the sixth secret military mission.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Traffic Fatality Rate Lowest Ever in 1989
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 9th graf, The highest, with highest-ever fatality rate.
DOC.TEXT: The 1980s ended with the lowest annual traffic death rate ever, capping a decade in which many Americans declared war on drunken driving and began using long-neglected safety belts, federal officials say. The 1989 fatality rate was 2.2 deaths per 100 million miles traveled, down from 2.3 the previous year and one-third lower than the 1980 rate of 3.3, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration reported. Fatalities in 1989 are estimated at 45,500, compared with 47,093 in 1988. Final numbers for last year are still being tallied but are unlikely to change significantly, officials said. ``The reduction in traffic deaths during the 1980s reflects our national resolve against drunk driving, increased safety belt use and a generally heightened awareness of highway safety,'' Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said Thursday. The death rate probably will continue downward in the 1990s, even if more miles are driven, as the government expands safety regulations and the automobile industry makes vehicles more crashworthy, officials said. ``This means that American motorists are less at risk than ever before,'' NHTSA administrator Jerry R. Curry said. The fatality rate is the most widely accepted measure of highway safety trends, Curry said. It takes into account changes in miles driven from year to year, and even a slight increase or decrease can reflect a difference of thousands of lives. If last year's rate were the same as in 1980, for example, the number of deaths would have been 69,800 instead of 45,500. The highest fatality rate on record is 24.1 deaths per 100 million miles in 1921, the first year the government attempted to establish a rate, NHTSA spokesman Tim Hurd said. By 1940, when statistics were more reliable, the rate had fallen to 10.9 deaths per 100 million miles, still far higher than recent years. Joan Claybrook, NHTSA administrator during the Carter administration who criticized the agency's performance in the Reagan years, also hailed the improved fatality rate. But it resulted in part from standards the federal government adopted grudgingly, she said. ``Even when Reagan was saying get the government off our backs, state legislatures were continuing to pass these safety requirements with these incredibly high payoffs,'' said Ms. Claybrook, now president of Public Citizen, a public interest group founded by Ralph Nader. Thirty-three states and the District of Columbia have enacted mandatory seat belt laws since 1984. The total fell from 34 last fall when North Dakota voters rejected by referendum a bill that had cleared the state legislature. Seat belt use has increased from 10 to 15 percent in the early 1980s to around 47 percent, said Jeffrey Miller, deputy NHTSA administrator. A regulation that took effect in September requires all cars made in the United States to have air bags or automatic safety belts. ``That will save thousands of lives every year,'' Ms. Claybrook said. ``It's the most important health standard in America.'' Meanwhile, all states now require child restraint seats and have established 21 as the minimum drinking age. Alcohol-related highway deaths have fallen from about 28,000 in 1980 to 23,500 in 1988, a 17 percent decline. The number of teen-agers involved in such crashes fell by one-third between 1982 and 1986, Miller said. ``The numbers are still obviously high but we're making some noticeable inroads,'' he said. State drunken driving laws were toughened across the nation during the 1980s, while police and prosecutors became more adept at handling impaired driving cases, Miller said. Public tolerance waned, spawning designated driver programs and awareness campaigns. Curry, appointed by President Bush last year, has promised to quicken his agency's consideration of new safety regulations. He said Thursday that new side-impact standards, the subject of fierce debate for more than a decade, will be established this year. ``There's a lot of emotion involved ... a lot of money involved for the manufacturers,'' he said. ``It's going to be expensive.'' The new standards will envision a 10 to 15 percent reduction in side-impact deaths, which total one-third of all fatalities in passenger cars, said Barry Felrice, associate NHTSA administrator for rulemaking. But Curry voiced concern about overburdening automakers, with tough clean air and gas mileage requirements pending in Congress. ``The automobile industry is fragile and we have dumped an awful lot of safety regulations on them in the last 12 months,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ariane Rocket, Shuttle's Competitor, Explodes After Takeoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with investigative panel to study cause of explosion, adds details of explosion, background on American program, CORRECTS when Ariane launches began. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An unmanned Ariane rocket carrying two Japanese communications satellites exploded just after liftoff, prompting the competitor to the U.S. commercial launch industry to suspend future flights. The Ariane 44-L rocket, powered by four strap-on boosters, blew apart Thursday less than two minutes after takeoff, apparently because of a fire in the propulsion system, Arianespace President Frederic D'Allest said at the launch site late Thursday. ``All Ariane flights are suspended until we discover the reasons of this accident,'' he said. ``We are going to analyze this failure and explain the catastrophe of this flight as rapidly as possible.'' The Ariane rocket, carrying two telecommunications satellites for the Japan Broadcasting Corp. and Space Communications Corp., exploded over the Atlantic Ocean about 7{ miles from the launch pad at the Ariane space center in Kourou, French Guiana, on the northeast coast of South America. It was the first such failure after 17 consecutive successful Ariane launches. One of the boosters powering the 582-ton vehicle experienced a sudden drop of pressure just 6.2 seconds after the end of the countdown, Arianespace officials said. Two other boosters tried to prevent the rocket from tipping but were unable to stabilize the flight. At 90 seconds, technicians realized the mission would have to be abandoned, and the explosion took place 11 seconds later, officials said. Arianespace had planned at least eight more launches this year, but all have been suspended until the fault can be discovered and fixed, D'Allest said. In the meantime, Arianespace will continue to manufacture and prepare rockets to be ready to resume launches. Speaking to reporters today, D'Allest said Arianespace was eager to reassure customers of its reliability and would establish a special investigative panel next week to determine the reason for the rocket's failure. Customers will be given all the details of the findings ``so they can ... be comfortable that we can resume flights safely,'' he said. Japanese officials said they would continue to cooperate with Arianespace, despite the loss of the two satellites that were insured for more than $200 million. Witnesses who saw the flight on the video monitors at launch headquarters in Evry, France, said flames appeared to break out in the first stage of the rocket before it was due to detach at 2 minutes, 30 seconds into flight. Technicians said the rocket appeared slightly off course and passed unexpectedly close above the support scaffolding as it rose, with flame from one of the boosters burning the structure. However, there was no indication this caused the explosion. Technicians who replayed videotapes Thursday night suggested a turbo-pump failure might have contributed to the blast. Debris from the vehicle rained over the coast, but no injuries were reported. Winds carried a cloud of the fuel back to land, forcing the launch staff and the 12,000 residents of Kourou indoors until it passed. Some residents complained of burning eyes and sore throats. French police and soldiers, using a helicopter, searched today for debris along the coast. Arianespace, a consortium of European companies, took over the commercialization of the Ariane program from the European Space Agency in 1980. It is responsible for building, operating and marketing launch services. Ariane shots have become routine, with successful missions about once a month. The reliability of the program has made Arianespace the world's leading provider of commercial launch services. Four other Ariane rockets have exploded in flight. Thursday's was the first explosion since May 31, 1986, and the first of the No. 4 rocket series. The 44-L is the most powerful in the series. The launch was the 36th Ariane mission since the first flight in the unmanned space program, overseen by the European Space Agency, was held Dec. 24, 1979. The United States depended on its space shuttles to launch commercial satellites until the Challenger exploded on Jan. 28, 1986. Since then, three major American aerospace companies, Martin Marietta, McDonnell Douglas and General Dynamics, have been developing and launching commerical satellites. But with its early start, Ariane has captured about 50 percent of the market, and it drew business from the American program after the Challenger explosion. For Thursday's launch, the BS-2X satellite was built by General Electric's aerospace division to direct broadcasting for Japan's national NHK television network. In Tokyo, Yoshiro Nakamura, chief technician for the network, said the failure was very disappointing but NHK's staff would continue to cooperate with Arianespace. The second satellite, the Superbird B built by Ford Aerospace, was owned by Mitsubishi's subsidiary, Space Communications Corp. The BS-2X was insured for $150 million to $180 million, Arianespace said, while the Superbird B was insured for about $60 million. Jungi Inoue of the Space Communications Corp. put launch and insurance costs at $600 million.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Soldiers Recapture Strategic Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to ADD newspaper report on Vietnamese allegedly in Cambodia. Pickup 4th pvs, `Cambodia's official...
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Sihanouk
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian government forces today retook a strategic northwestern town from guerrillas in the first major victory of the Communist government's counteroffensive. The outcome of the battle was reported by a guerrilla commander, Gen. Dien Del, and confirmed by the radio of Cambodia's Vietnamese-installed government. Dien Del, deputy commander of the non-Communist Khmer People's National Liberation Front guerrillas, charged that Vietnamese soldiers were involved in the attack, although Vietnam claimed it withdrew all its troops in September. Captured soldiers told of 700 Vietnamese at two bases near Svay Chek. The New York Times today quoted Eastern European diplomats as saying several thousand Vietnamese troops and military advisers returned to Cambodia in October to help government troops defend Battambang and Sisophon, two important cities. It quoted the diplomats, who were not identified, as saying about 5,000 Vietnamese soldiers were still in Cambodia. Cambodia's official radio said government troops ``succeeded in completely recapturing Svay Chek. We are now in full control of this area.'' The fighting came three days before peace talks are to begin in Indonesia between the Vietnamese-installed government in Phnom Penh and the three guerrilla groups led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk. The guerrillas have made major gains in the west bordering Thailand since September. The Sihahouk guerrillas seized the strategic town of Thmar Puok, while the Khmer Rouge guerrillas took the gem-mining town of Pailin. The fighting had been at a relative lull in more recent weeks. In the past, it has intensified just before peace talks as the government and guerrillas try to strengthen their bargaining positions. Dien Del, interviewed in the key Thai border town of Aranyaprathet, said Svay Chek was heavily shelled by tanks and Soviet-made, multiple-rocket launchers during the final assault, four days after the counteroffensive began. He said the 600 guerrillas defending the town fled in confusion after they failed to receive word that a front-line position had fallen earlier. They regrouped in three towns north of Svay Chek, he said. The general had no reports on casualties. The liberation front had taken Svay Chek Dec. 5 after three major assaults. The guerrillas' brief control of Svay Chek allowed them to attack Sisophon, a government military operations center 13 miles to the south. Svay Chek is near the Thai border and in the province of Banteay Meanchey. The guerrillas will not immediately try to retake Svay Chek because of shortages of Chinese-supplied ammunition, Dien Del said. Guerrilla sources also reported that Chinese-supported Khmer Rouge guerrillas on Thursday night attacked a major government military garrison at Sophy, which is south of Svay Chek. Details were not immediately available. The Khmer Rouge, another member of Sihanouk's coalition, were in power in Cambodia in 1975-1978. During that time, hundreds of thousands of Cambodia's 8 million people died from Khmer Rouge executions, famine and civil unrest.

DOC.HEAD: White House Spokesman Needles Lawyers
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's press secretary gave a light-hearted tongue-lashing today to the nation's lawyers, saying they ``deserve all the criticism they can get.'' Marlin Fitzwater made his comment at his regular daily briefing when a reporter asked when Bush felt that lawyers were guilty of seeking excessive awards in malpractice cases. Bush, in a speech Thursday, had said the government would help ``restore common sense and fairness to America's medical malpractice system.'' Fitzwater, who is not a lawyer, said, ``Lawyers certainly deserve all the criticism they can get.'' Asked if Bush, also a non-lawyer, shared his feelings, Fitzwater laughingly said: ``Those are universally held feelings by everyone who's ever dealt with the legal establishment ... I'm sure all my good friends who are lawyers understand.'' Fitzwater, who is divorced and recently closed on a new house, did not explain the basis of his feelings.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Damages U.S. Bank in Argentina
DOC.TEXT: Two bombs caused minor damage today at a U.S. bank and a meatpacking company owned by a multinational corporation. A leftist group claimed responsibility. Elsewhere, police stepped up security outside supermarkets in several provinces after looting occurred, apparently by people outraged over the nation's economic problems and unemployment. The early morning blast at Citibank damaged the entrance to the building in Lomas de Zamora, 12 miles southwest of the capital. Windows and storefronts in neighboring buildings were shattered, police said. The blast at Tres Cruces meatpacking company occurred in Villa Devoto, a residential neighborhood in Buenos Aires, and caused similar damage. The company is owned by the Brazil-based Bunge y Borne group, one of Latin America's largest multinationals. There were no reports of injuries in either blast. A leftist group called the Che Guevara Brigade claimed responsibility. In a communique left at an independent news agency, the group said: ``We cannot stand by, arms crossed, to the rape by monopolies. Citibank and the meatpacker Tres Cruces were struck this morning ... because (the brigade) considers them responsible ... for aggression against the people.'' In Santa Fe, 300 miles north of the capital, about 50 people ransacked a grocery. Police Chief Carmelo Rolon told the government news agency Telam that a dozen false alarms about trouble eslewhere in the city were called in beforehand to disperse his forces. Twenty people were arrested, including six children and four women, Telam reported, and quick police action stopped another attempting looting nearby. In a separate incident, 50 people looted a food store in San Miguel de Tucuman, capital of the province, the news agency Diarios y Noticias reported. In Rosario, the biggest city in Santa Fe province, several stores and delivery trucks were looted Wednesday and Thursday, prompting patrols by provincial and federal police, and paramilitary border guards. Rosario, a city of 1 million located 185 miles north of Buenos Aires, was the center of food riots in May in which at least 16 people died, nearly 200 were injured and more than 1,700 arrested. A provincial governor, Pedro Salvatori, told Telam today the situation in his area ``is very alarming....There is a (economic) paralysis, high unemployment and hyperinflation.'' Police patrols of supermarkets in Resistencia, the capital of norther Chaco Province, were stepped up today. The national government insists the looting is isolated and caused by leftist agitators. President Carlos Menem today called such agitators ``individuals who live in an atmosphere of violence.'' The Che Guevara Brigade communique exhorted Argentines to ``sack ... supermarkets, defend ... state companies, resist hunger-level salaries and unemployment and the closing of factories.'' Since Menem took office in July he has imposed three steep hikes in public service rates and pledged to sell state companies and cut public spending in an effort to narrow a huge deficit and curtail inflation. Unemployment is running about 20 percent, and inflation has soared 8,124 percent during the past 12 months.

DOC.HEAD: 1950s Rock 'N' Roll Precursor Suffers Liver Failure, `Very Critical'
DOC.TEXT: Singer Johnnie Ray, whose string of hits in the early 1950s served as a precursor to rock 'n' roll, was in critical condition in a coma today after suffering liver failure, a hospital spokesman said. Ray, 63, was not expected to live, according to a statement issued late Thursday by Alan Eichler Associates, a public relations firm. Ron Wise, spokesman at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, said he did not know know what caused Ray's liver failure or when he was admitted. Ray's first major record release, ``Cry,'' with ``The Little White Cloud That Cried'' on the flip side provided him the No. 1 and No. 2 songs in the country in 1950. His emotional singing style, punctuated with real-sounding sobs, were the subject of jokes and skits by impersonators. With the release of his follow-up record, ``Please Mr. Sun'' and ``Brokenhearted,'' Ray's songs occupied the top four positions in the charts kept by the entertainment newspaper Variety, a feat listed in the Guinness Book of Records, the Eichler release said. Ray's songs blended rhythm and blues, country and gospel, helping to create rock 'n' roll. Other top songs included ``What's the Use,'' ``Somebody Stole My Gal,'' ``Who's Sorry Now,'' and ``Yes Tonight Josephine.'' In 1954, he co-starred with Ethel Merman, Dan Dailey, Marilyn Monroe, Donald O'Connor and Mitzi Gaynor in ``There's No Business Like Show Business.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Die in Fire at Atlanta Senior Citizens Apartment Building
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4-5th grafs, `Their identities...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with identities of victims, detail on injuries. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Chamberlin said...'.
DOC.TEXT: Fire broke out in a senior citizens' high-rise building early today, killing a man and a woman who leapt to her death from the burning 11th floor apartment, officials said. The blaze was quickly extinguished by firefighters from a next-door fire station who were alerted by people yelling. Deputy Fire Chief D.M. Chamberlin Sr. said a man was found dead in the apartment where the fire started, and a woman was killed when she jumped from the burning apartment. Fire department officials identified the victims as James Loughridge, 58, who lived in the apartment, and 28-year-old Patricia Almond of Atlanta, who was visiting him. Four residents taken to Grady Memorial Hospital for treatment of smoke inhalation and minor lacerations, said spokesman Jim Driscoll. None was expected to be admitted, he said. Chamberlin said about 60 residents were evacuated from the 13-story Juniper-Tenth high-rise. The cause of the blaze was not immediatly known. An arson inspector was on the scene, which Chamberlin said was routine for fatal fires. Firefighters heard people yelling shortly after 1 a.m., Chamberlin said. He did not know if the shouts came from people in the building or on the street. While firefighters battled the fire, others knocked on doors to awaken sleeping residents and direct them to safety. The fire spread to adjacent apartments on the 11th floor, Chamberlin said. The Atlanta Housing Authority apartment building for the elderly is located in Atlanta's Midtown section.

DOC.HEAD: Former Justice Minister Acquitted of Passing Secrets to Husband
DOC.TEXT: The former justice minister who was forced to resign amid allegations she disclosed secret government information to her husband was cleared of wrongdoing today. A Supreme Court jury said evidence did not support prosecution claims that Elisabeth Kopp violated official secrecy laws, a crime punishable by up to three years in prison. But the court said Mrs. Kopp had lacked ``the required care.'' The five-member court convicted Kopp's former personal assistant but imposed no penalty. It acquitted another former Justice Ministry aide. The case involved a government investigation in 1988 into laundering of drug money and its scrutiny of the currency dealing firm Shakarchi Trading A.G. Mrs. Kopp's husband, Hans. W. Kopp, resigned as vice president of the firm Oct. 27, 1988, the day he received a phone call from his wife urging him to break ties with the company. No charges have been filed against Shakarchi, and the company denies wrongdoing. Several dozen supporters cheered when Mrs. Kopp, smiling broadly, left the Supreme Court building in Lausanne today. Mrs. Kopp admitted in court that she made the phone call to her husband, a businessman and lawyer, but said she thought the information she gave to him had come from banking circles, not from government secrets. Mrs. Kopp's personal assistant at the time was Katharina Schoop, who told her boss of the probe involving Shakarchi. Ms. Schoop said she learned of it from Justice Department documents shown to her by another ministry aide, Renate Schwob. Ms. Schoop said that when she told Mrs. Kopp her husband's firm was under suspicion, the source of information was never mentioned but that she was convinced Mrs. Kopp knew it came from inside the government. After Mrs. Kopp called her husband, she told him to call Ms. Schoop for more information. The court convicted Ms. Schoop of giving details to Mr. Kopp but did not impose a penalty, saying Ms. Schoop was acting on her bosses' orders and was not aware she was breaking the law. Ms. Schwob was acquitted. All had been charged with violating official secrecy laws, an offense carrying a maximum three-year prison term and fines of up to $27,000. Mrs. Kopp was Switzerland's only female government minister and was in line to be the country's first woman president, a largely ceremonial post. She resigned over the affair in January 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Murderer Granted Temporary Furlough, Goes To Funeral Home
DOC.TEXT: A convicted murder was taken to a funeral home today to pay respects to his mother after the state correction commissioner set aside a state law adopted in reponse to the Willie Horton case. The decision Thursday is the first time an inmate serving a life sentence for first-degree murder has been granted a non-medical emergency furlough since Massachusetts adopted the statute. The law was approved after Horton, a convicted murder, fled while on furlough from Massachusetts and assaulted a Maryland couple. President Bush used the issue in his campaign in 1988 against Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. The state statute prohibits emergency furloughs, except for medical reasons, to inmates serving life sentences for first-degree murder. Following a series of court decisions, Correction Commissioner George Vose agreed to allow Philip Pennellatore to be taken under guard for a private viewing of his mother, Nettie Pennellatore, before today's funeral. Pennelatore made the visit at about 7 a.m. Mrs. Pennellatore died Tuesday of pancreatic cancer. She was 61. Her son, 29, was convicted of first-degree murder for the 1981 killing of an 80-year-old retired librarian and is serving a life sentence. John Reinstein, legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union in Boston, said Pennellatore was pleased with the decision but added, ``He wishes this issue had been resolved before she died so he could have seen her.'' The ACLU had sought a court injunction to permit Pennellatore to visit his mother Feb. 5, but she died before a ruling was made. Pennellatore then requested permission to attend the funeral, but a Superior Court judge ruled against it Wednesday. Vose granted the emergency furlough after a state appeals court judge ordered the Correction Department to consider the request, said department spokeswoman Kathy Robertson.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Outlines Terms for Normal Ties With Sandinistas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 5 grafs of Lugar, Weinstein comment after 7th graf, A consensus
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III says he will impose stiff conditions on normalizing relations with Nicaragua even if the leftist government is returned to power on Sunday in a free and fair election. Baker ruled out normal ties on Thursday unless Nicaragua refrains for a ``sustained period'' after the election from supporting leftist rebels in El Salvador. In addition, he said, the administration must be satisfied that the Sandinista government will not shut down the democratic opening which President Daniel Ortega has given to opposition groups during the campaign. Asked about U.S. policy during a hearing of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Baker said it is normal for those who believe in democracy to respect the results of a free and fair election. But, he said, the U.S. government will make its own judgment about the fairness of the election, suggesting that he will not take at face value the assessments of the hundreds of international observers who will be in Nicaragua on Sunday. The administration has provided assistance to opposition candidate Violeta Chamorro in her campaign to end Ortega's 10{-year grip on power. A consensus has emerged among State Department officials that Mrs. Chamorro has the votes to defeat Ortega but that the Sandinistas will devise a way to rig the outcome in their favor. At the White House today, Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., and Allen Weinstein, president of the Center For Democracy independent monitoring organization, also cited a possibility for fraud in the Nicaraguan election. The two, who met with Vice President Dan Quayle, said the Nicaraguan system of taking vote counts off official tally sheets and relaying them by Telex to Managua leaves open opportunities for meddling with the results out of the view of official observers. ``The chain of observation has been broken,'' said Lugar. Weinstein also said that delegations from Costa Rica and Honduras were told they could not join his observer group. Lugar said President Bush should ``go slow'' in improving ties should Ortega win the election, until it can be determined if the process was fairly conducted. In discussing the possibility of a Sandinista victory, Baker said Thursday, ``I don't think we should assume this at all.'' Most recent polls show Ortega with a comfortable lead but officials here believe that many Nicaraguans, fearing retaliation, are not inclined to be honest with pollsters. The administration has highlighted perceived campaign abuses by the Sandinistas, but former President Jimmy Carter has described most such complaints as ``highly exaggerated.'' Carter heads the observer delegation of the Council of Freely Elected Heads of Government, which has made a number of trips to Nicaragua. Although U.S. military aid to the Contra rebels was suspended two years ago, U.S.-Nicaraguan relations are far from normal. A trade embargo imposed by the United States in 1985 remains in effect and the respective embassies of the two countries have not been represented at the level of ambassador since 1988. It is assumed that if Mrs. Chamorro wins on Sunday, the thousands of Contra rebels now assembled at border camps in Honduras will return to Nicaragua in peace. The fate of the Contras in the event of a Sandinista victory is less clear. U.S. officials, without being specific, have told Contra leaders that the United States will not abandon them regardless of the outcome Sunday. A $49.5 million U.S. humanitarian aid program expires at the end of the month. The level of suspicion between the United States and Nicaragua remains high. The Sandinistas reject Washington's assertion that U.S. aid to the Contras is limited to food and other humanitarian items, charging that U.S. logistical support is being provided as well. Although an informal cease-fire was suspended late last year, the fighting has been no more than sporadic. The Bush administration has its own list of grievances against the Sandinistas. Chief among them is the administration contention that Nicaragua continues to arm and train the Salvadoran rebels in violation of a pledge Ortega has made in writing to other Central American presidents. Nicaragua also maintains close ties with Cuba, reinforcing U.S. concerns that the Sandinistas are intent on exporting their revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Says Publicity on Marriage Troubles Helps Business
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one grafs after 12th, `All Mrs. ..'. to ADD Mrs. Trump reportedly seeing analyst. Picks up 13th graf, `On Thursday...'. A longer version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Tycoon Donald Trump, who usually delights in media attention, says he hates the splashy publicity about his breakup with wife Ivana but believes it has a silver lining: It's good for business. Trump said in an interview Thursday that the screaming tabloid headlines and talk-show jokes about his marital travails actually have benefitted his multibillion-dollar casino, hotel and airline empire. ``The business has never been better,'' he said, ``but because it's a private company most people don't know about it. Unfortunately, for all the wrong reasons, the last two weeks it's been even better yet.'' Trump said business has been up at his two hotel-casinos in Atlantic City, N.J., the Plaza Hotel and the Trump Shuttle, which links New York with Washington and Boston, since the breakup first hit the headlines two weeks ago. Still, he said having his name splashed over the media has taken a toll. ``It's horrible. I hate it. I hate the publicity,'' Trump said in his glitzy 26th-floor office commanding a view of Central Park and the Plaza Hotel, one of his properties. ``It's been on a personal basis difficult because I happen to like Ivana. ... But it's something you have to go through and in many cases a lot of people have to go through it. People grow apart.'' Under an agreement Ivana is contesting, she would receive $25 million and the couple's home in Connecticut as well as custody of their children. Trump's holdings are estimated to be worth up to $4 billion. Although Trump insisted the publicity was a business plus, some marketing analysts said the headlines could hurt an empire built the developer's name. ``He's becoming a joke,'' said Jack Trout, president of Trout & Ries, a marketing consulting firm in Greenwich, Conn. Mrs. Trump declined through spokesman John Scanlon to comment on her husband's remarks. ``All Mrs. Trump wants is a fair and equitable share of the fortune that they accumulated together while they were married,'' Scanlon said. ``We're disappointed that Mr. Trump is prepared to offer his wife and children less than 1 percent of his accumulated wealth. We really expected better of him.'' The Daily News in New York reported today that Mrs. Trump's friends said she was seeing an analyst ``several times a week'' in an effort ``to keep a grip on her emotions and help her through the rough spots.'' The newspaper did not identify the friends, nor did the report indicate whether Mrs. Trump had ever consulted an analyst before the breakup. On Thursday, meanwhile, Trump accepted the ``Outstanding New Yorker Award'' from the New York Society of Association Executives. He appeared unflustered by the media's microscope until city Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman praised his achievements and listed those which have brought him and New York acclaim. ``And to me one of the most important things is his love affair,'' she said, pausing several seconds while she knocked on the wooden podium. Then she added ``with the city.'' There was laughter throughout the crowd and then Trump's face became red for at least a full minute.

DOC.HEAD: Store Clerk Kills His Second Robbery Suspect
DOC.TEXT: A store clerk has shot and killed a robbery suspect for the second time in seven months, this time an unarmed man who had his hands in his pocket as if he had a weapon, police say. Du ``Jack'' Nguyen, 28, told police that the suspect, Frederick B. Henderson, demanded money after entering the Happy 7 Food Mart on Thursday, saying, ``You want to do this the hard way or the easy way?'' Nguyen said he handed over an undisclosed amount of money, then pulled out a 9mm handgun and told Henderson to freeze, said police investigator Dennis Waldron. Nguyen said he fired one shot when the suspect turned with his hands in his pockets. Although Henderson never threatened the clerk, Nguyen said he believed his life was in danger, Waldron said. Last July 19, Nguyen shot and killed Calvin Lee Watts, 29, who entered the store with a pistol and demanded money, investigators said. Waldron said the state attorney's office will be asked to investigate the latest shooting. ``It appears at this point that (the shooting) is well within the law, but the investigation is ongoing,'' he said. ``The law says you can use whatever force is reasonable for protection of yourself or others if someone threatens to harm you.'' It marked the fourth time that shots have been fired at the convenience store in Pensacola's middle-class East Hill district in the last 18 months. Other clerks fired shots at robbery suspects twice in 1988, but no one was wounded in either case.

DOC.HEAD: Parts of Alabama, Georgia Declared Disasters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Edits throughout to UPDATE with disaster areas declared, new quotes on Mississippi flooding, conditions of tornado victims; and to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Waterlogged portions of Georgia and Alabama were declared federal disaster areas today and residents of low-lying sections in Mississippi stacked sandbags in preparation for more flooding this weekend. President Bush declared nine northwestern Georgia counties to be eligible for disaster assistance in the wake of last week's heavy rains and tornadoes, and federal officials in Alabama added a dozen counties to the six that already had been declared disaster areas there. The declarations will make federal money available to people whose homes or businesses were damaged in storms that have pounded the Deep South since Feb. 10. Another round of thunderstorms and tornadoes passed through the region on Thursday, causing some serious damage in portions of Mississippi and Alabama and injuring at least 30 people. Heavy thunderstorms or rain showers were reported Thursday from Florida to Michigan. The wet weather was the result of low pressure that was pulling moisture northward out of the Gulf. The new storm raised the threat of more flooding in Mississippi, Alabama and Georgia, but the fears were largely unrealized. Some residents of low-lying areas of southern Mississippi expect flooding this weekend, however, as water rises in the Pascagoula River from rainfall that occurred earlier upstream. ``Looks like Saturday and Sunday will be the two worst days down here,'' said Hank Turk, director public safety in Mississippi's Jackson County, where water was as much as 2 inches deep on 20 to 30 roads. Turk said there had been no mass evacuations and ``the people involved have had experience with this sort of thing before. They have already made preparations and they know when it is time to get out.'' While high water problems continued to plague the Gulf Coast, an end to the heavy rain allowed other flood-damaged areas of southern and eastern Mississippi to continue cleaning up. Disaster relief teams toured flood-damaged areas this week, and Gov. Ray Mabus is expected to request federal disaster assistance. Tornadoes touched down Thursday along Mississippi's Gulf Coast and in several places in rural Alabama. A powerful blast of wind also swept through Columbus, Ga., but weather officials were uncertain whether it was a tornado. The twisters struck first at the Gulf Coast town of Pass Christian, Miss., damaging at least 30 homes. They then struck Opp, Ala., and at least two sections of rural Alabama, the National Weather Service said. Four people were seriously injured in Pike County, northwest of Opp, when a twister ripped apart three mobile homes. The condition of an 86-year-old woman was upgradged from critical to stable today, and a 64-year-old man also was listed in stable condition, said Edge administrator Burton Whitaker. ``They're improving. I think they're going to be OK,'' he said. Two other storm victims originally listed in critical condition, a 67-year-old man and a 44-year-old woman, were transferred from Edge to Baptist Medical Center in Montgomery, where a spokeswoman said they were listed in serious condition today. Thursday's storm was accompanied by record high temperatures, but forecasters said a sharp cold snap would follow. In Augusta, Ga., the temperature reached a record 79 degrees Thursday, but was expected to slide into the 20s by the weekend. Cherry Blossom Festival officials in Macon, Ga., worried the cold would freeze buds on their trees, which were breaking into bloom early because of the warm weather. ``We'll definitely lose some in the freeze,'' Bibb County Extension Agent Frank Funderburk said.

DOC.HEAD: Union and Government Reach Pay Deal on Ambulance
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators reached agreement today on a pay raise of about 17 percent for ambulance workers to end a dispute that has disrupted emergency service across Britain for six months. Some ambulance drivers said they would vote against the deal because it did not put them on the same footing as police and firefighters by including a formula for future wage increases tied to inflation. But Roger Poole, chief negotiator for the five unions involved, called the pay deal ``simply staggering'' and said the ambulance unions had ``driven a coach and horses'' through the government's policy on curbing wage hikes. The accord, covering the period from March 1, 1990 until March 31, 1991, was reached after 20 hours of talks between union officials and managers of the National Health Service. Poole said it gives ambulance workers a 17.6 percent pay increase, while the Health Service put the package at 17 percent. There is an option for local ambulance companies to add another 2 percent. The salaries of ambulance workers would rise from $17,259 to $18,812 on March 1 and to $20,298 on Oct. 1. Crew members would also receive a lump sum payment of $1,454, and there would be extra allowances for staff with specialized training. Poole said he was confident the 22,500 ambulance workers and control room staff would overwhelmingly approve the settlement and return to their jobs after a vote is taken around March 13. In the Liverpool area, branch secretary Ray Clayton of the National Union of Public Employees said he was dismayed there was no pay formula to link wage increases with inflation. ``I don't think the strike will be called off,'' he said. Andy Lawrence, an ambulance workers' spokesman in west Sussex, called the deal ``an insult to our intelligence.'' Job actions began Sept. 7 when ambulance drivers started refusing to work overtime. In October, emergency crews stopped using their radios or in some cases answering calls from control rooms. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government ordered police and army ambulances to answer emergency calls starting Nov. 8. It was the first time they had been used for civilian ambulance calls since the ``winter of discontent'' of 1978-79 when a series of public service strikes hit a Labor Party government. Some health authorities hired taxis and asked relatives to drive non-emergency cases to hospitals. In some cases, ambulance crews suspended for joining the dispute carried out their own unofficial service, accepting emergency calls direct from hospitals or members of the public but not from ambulance control rooms.

DOC.HEAD: Funeral of Kenya's Foreign Minister Ends in Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf to CORRECT day of disappearance.
DOC.TEXT: The funeral of the slain foreign minister ended in violence today as riot police beat back a huge crowd of wailing, stone-throwing mourners with nightsticks and tear gas. Scores of people were injured by rocks and sticks, and reporters said they saw police club and arrest dozens of others before the spontaneous demonstration of grief and rage was brought under control. Cabinet ministers, leading politicians and foreign envoys were caught up in the melee, which erupted moments after President Daniel arap Moi left the grounds of the Valley Road Pentecostal Church in his official limousine. No deaths were reported. Thousands of people had gathered outside the church, about a mile from downtown Nairobi, for the service for Robert Ouko, whose charred body was found with a bullet hole through the skull near his farm in western Kenya on Feb. 16. The crowd was largely quiet until the first mourners inside the church began to file out, many of them weeping. As the crowd outside joined in the moaning and crying, police began to move it back. A group of young people, thought to be university students, shouted, and a hail of rocks, sticks, bottles and other missiles was let loose. Riot squads charged into the demonstrators, chasing them through a nearby park and into the city's center. Hours later, police and government paramilitary units were still on Nairobi's streets, dispersing demonstrators and bystanders. Several cars were stoned and windows smashed in some sections of the city. University students demonstrated in Nairobi for four days earlier this week demanding an impartial investigation into Ouko's death. The demonstrations were halted on orders of campus administrators Wednesday night. Ouko was the fourth leading political figure to die violently since Kenya gained independence in 1963. None of the three previous murders was solved and in each case the government of former President Jomo Kenyatta was accused of a coverup. Moi's government has released only sketchy details of its investigation, but has called in three Scotland Yard detectives and a British pathologist to assist it. They began work Wednesday. Ouko appeared to be more popular in death than he was in life. Although considered one of the most articulate and able members of Moi's cabinet, he was largely out of the domestic political limelight as foreign minister, a post he had held since 1979. He had barely retained his parliamentary seat in the face of a strong challenge in his western Kenya constituency in an election in 1988. Following the funeral service, Ouko's body was to be flown to Kisumu, a major trading center near Lake Victoria in western Kenya, where his coffin was to be displayed at a sports stadium. From there, the body was to be taken to his nearby family home in Koru for burial Saturday. Ouko's partly burned body was found in heavy brushland about four miles from his family farm three days after he left home before dawn on Feb. 13 without notifying employees or relatives.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Says He Has Approved Palestinian Participation in Peace Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUB grafs 12-14, `Rita Hauser...December 1988' to add that letter received by fax. Pickup 15th, `Shortly after...
DOC.TEXT: PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat said in a letter released today that he has approved the participation of Palestinians from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip in peace talks with Israel. It was the first formal statement by the PLO leader that he has approved terms for Israeli-Palestinian talks, although there have been hints from Cairo that he was moving in that direction. Arafat said in the letter that the PLO would prefer an international peace conference and ``guarantees that can only be provided by the great powers and the United Nations.'' But he added: ``The PLO once more leaned over backward and approved the idea of a dialogue between representatives of the Israeli government and representatives of the Palestinian people in the occupied territories and the diaspora.'' He said that such talks would have to be part of a process ``aimed at a comprehensive and final settlement'' and that its agenda ``could cover all the conceptual ingredients of that process, including the elections and the 10 Egyptian points.'' The ``10 Egyptian points'' were recommendations put forward by Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak to try to get a concensus with Israel on preliminary peace talks. Mubarak, backed by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, has offered to host an initial Israeli-Palestinian dialogue aimed at reviving stalled Middle East peace efforts. Those talks are expected to help clear the way for Israeli-proposed elections in the occupied territories leading to limited autonomy of the areas' 1.7 million Palestinian residents. Hundreds of Palestinians and more than 40 Israelis have been killed in the Palestinian uprising in the territories. Efforts to get the talks under way have been stalled by Israeli concerns over the composition of the Palestinian delegation and the agenda. Israeli, which refuses to deal with the PLO as a ``terrorist group,'' has not yet agreed to participate in the prelimintary talks urged by Mubarak. Arafat's letter was sent to a meeting in Jerusalem by Jewish peace activists called the Special Emergency World Jewish Leadership Peace Conference, which concluded Thursday. Rita Hauser, a New York peace activist who attended the conference, told reporters that the letter was received ``through a circuitious manner, via fax'' on Thursday but that conference leaders had been unable to ``get it fitted in'' amid the conference's heavy schedule. It was presented at a board meeting today of the Tel Aviv-based International Center for Peace in the Middle East, which sponsored the conference. Ms. Hauser, an attorney and head of the center's American branch, met with Arafat in Stockholm in December 1988. Hauser said she had been in fax contact with the PLO since that meeting. Shortly after their meeting, Arafat made a series of historic announcements recognizing Israel's right to exist and renouncing terrorism. Those statements led, in turn, to the United States resuming contacts with the PLO for the first time since 1975. Arafat's letter to the Jerusalem meeting of Jewish peace advocates was dated Feb. 17 and came from Tunis, where the PLO is headquartered. There was no explanation for the delay in its transmittal to Jerusalem. In the letter, Arafat repeated the PLO's call for creation of an independent Palestinian state in the occupied territories, which were captured by Israel from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. ``We remain deeply convinced that the only real security guarantee for Israel lives in a peaceful settlement based on the termination of the Israeli occupation of the Palestinian and Arab territories and the acceptance of the two-state principle,'' he wrote. Arafat noted that Israel has been fearful of dealing with the PLO, and said that Palestinians had similar concerns about dealing with the Jewish state. ``Watching the convoluted maneuvers the Israeli government has engaged in and the massive obstacles with which it has littered the path to peace, the Palestinian people are not filled with confidence in the good intentions of the Israeli leaders,'' Arafat wrote. He continued: ``To them, the only guarantee of their own security and their political future lies in the full participation of the PLO in all stages of the peace process.'' Such a role has been ruled out by Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. In an interview published today in The Jerusalem Post, Shamir was asked what the PLO could do to make itself an acceptable negotiating partner. ``The only thing it should do is dismantle itself,'' Shamir replied. ``Because its minimal demand is a Palestinian state, and a Palestinian state cannot co-exist with Israel.''

DOC.HEAD: 88 Percent Of Chinese Women Practice Birth Control
DOC.TEXT: Birth control is practiced by 88 percent of Chinese married women of child-bearing age, but poor-quality contraceptives lead to a high rate of unplanned pregnancies, a State Family Planning Commission official said. Zhu Yaohua said 46 percent of the 164 million women practicing contraception used intra-uterine devices, the China Daily reported Friday. Female sterilization, or tubal ligation, and vasectomies were the next two most common forms of preventing births, she said. Figures on other methods were not listed. State Planning Commission figures for 1988 showed IUDs accounted for 41.1 percent of contraception, female sterilization for 36.1 percent and male sterilization for 11.4 percent. Oral pills, at 5.8 percent, and condoms, at 4 percent, were far less popular. Zhu said structural faults in the Chinese-made IUDs and insertion problems resulted in a high number of unplanned pregnancies. U.N. Population Fund officials in Beijing have said there is a 10 percent failure rate for the IUDs, a major reason why there were 12.68 million abortions in China in 1988, more than one for every two live births. China adheres to a strict one-child-per-family policy, and women who become pregnant outside the state plan are often pressured to have abortions.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Guide Might Make Victorian Blue Blood Run Cold
DOC.TEXT: The names of illegitimate children of British aristocrats have been printed for the first time in a famous guide to bluebloods. It's something of a revolution for ``Debrett's Peerage and Baronetage,'' the weighty reference book that first came out in 1769 and appears every five years. ``We have put them in at the request of those families who wanted the names of natural children to appear,'' said editor Charles Kidd at the launch of the latest edition Thursday night. ``Across the country, about one in every four children is born out of wedlock. If parents agree, we believe that Debrett's should record illegitimate issue to ensure the book is comprehensive, although these children still cannot inherit a title,'' he said. Kidd said about 200 names had entered the huge book as a result of changing social attitudes, but he has not helped readers by printing a list. ``You'll have to search them out,'' he said. It takes some searching and will have to be done by someone who knows plenty about the offspring of the upper classes. There are 2,300 families in the book involving tens of thousands of names. But Lady Elizabeth Berkeley gave permission for her entry to be publicized. Her composer-husband, the late Sir Lennox Berkeley, was the son of an illegitimate member of the Earl of Berkeley's family and was barred from Debrett's. Although the earldom is extinct, five Lennoxes have gotten into the book as a result of the policy change, and Lady Elizabeth said: ``I am delighted. My only regret is that my husband did not live to see it.'' ``He could never have the title or the family castle, but what really hurt him was that his father had no existence in Debrett's,'' she said. Other entries of the illegitimate include offspring of the 24th Earl of Erroll, a premier peer of Scotland whose family motto is ``Bear the yoke.'' ``At the beginning of the 18th century, fathers always claimed their illegitimate children, and put them in the parish registers. It was only Victorian prudery that swept them all under the carpet,'' said Frances-Jane French, a specialist on the Anglo-Irish aristocracy. ``There's no reason at all why Debrett's should take a moralistic line. A lot of our aristocrats sprang from the mistresses of King Charles II,'' said jovial Ian McCorquodale, chairman of Debrett's Peerage Ltd. The new Debrett's also includes adopted children for the first time, although they also cannot inherit titles. ``We are simply keeping abreast of changing social fashions,'' said Kidd's co-editor, David Williamson. Among hundreds of other, legitimate new entrants in the book is film actress Jamie Lee Curtis, who starred in ``A Fish Called Wanda,'' and entered the aristocracy by her 1984 marriage to the Hon. Christopher Guest, a relative of Viscount Wimborne. Actor Nigel Havers is also in, because his father, the former Sir Micahel Havers, was given a life peerage after being forced by ill-health to resign the lord chancellorship in 1987 after holding it for four months. The 169th edition of ``Debrett's Peerage and Baronetage'' weighs nearly 5 pounds and contains 2,400 pages, including 96 pages of advertisements for antique shops, schools, hotels and charities such as the International League for the Protection of Horses, and the Indigent Gentlewomen of Scotland. It costs $205, a whopping price for a book, and between 6,000 and 7,000 copies will be sold worldwide, the company says.

DOC.HEAD: Harold L. Goodwin, Adventure Writer, Government Official, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Harold L. Goodwin, a retired government official who wrote science adventure, oceanology and space stories, has died at age 75. Goodwin, a retired deputy director of the National Sea Grant Program, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home. Goodwin began writing the Rick Brant series of science adventure stories under the pen name John Blaine in 1947 based on his world travels as a government official. One is to be published this year. He wrote books for children and adults on the oceans and space under the names Blake Savage and Hal Gordon. Goodwin served as a Marine officer and combat correspondent in World War II. He was responsible for the first Navy broadcast from New Caledonia on the war in the South Pacific and received a medal and presidential citation for combat missions over Iwo Jima and Guadalcanal. In 1961, he worked as special assistant to the administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and in the 1950s as director of Operation Deep Freeze in the Navy. He also was director of operations for the Civil Defense Administration. Born in Ellenburgh, N.Y., Goodwin was raised in Baltimore and Springfield, Mass. Goodwin is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Swensk, three sons, three grandchildren and a brother. Funeral services were scheduled for Friday in Bethesda.

DOC.HEAD: Group Breaks Into Synagogue, Right-Wing Attacks Reported
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Removes 2nd graf and subs last two grafs to CORRECT that newspaper did not report attack in Bacua.
DOC.TEXT: Vandals broke into a synagogue in a northwestern city and destroyed furniture and religious objects, a Jewish organization reported today. In the city of Oradea, 330 miles northwest of Bucharest, unidentified assailants smashed windows and broke down the doors of the synagogue on the night of Feb. 15-16, said Teodor Blumenfeld, general secretary of the Federation of Romanian Jewish Communities. They tore apart the building, apparently in search of gold and silver objects, he said. They did not find any but destroyed prayer books and prayer shawls, Blumenfeld said. He estimated the damage at 30,000 lei, or $1,500 at the official exchange rate. No one had been arrested, he said. Romania's chief rabbi, Moses Rosen, said last week that he feared a surge of anti-Semitism in the more open climate following the December revolution that ended Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's 24-year rule. He said groups like the Iron Guard, Romania's former Nazi-allied fascist movement, could be reborn. Rosen, who has been chief rabbi for 41 years, met last week with interim President Ion Iliescu and asked for a ``guarantee of existence'' for his community, which has been reduced from some 850,000 on the eve of World War II to 20,000 today. Half of Romania's Jewish community was wiped out in the Holocaust, and 400,000 were allowed by Romania's Communist authorities to settle in Israel after the war. Blumenfeld said security guards and alarm systems were being provided for synagogues around the country. Nonetheless, he called the attack in Oradea an isolated incident. The independent national daily Romania Libera, which published news of the attack in today's editions, condemned it as a ``grave act of vandalism.'' The newspaper, the most widely read daily in Romania, also contained what appeared to be a report of an attack by a right-wing group on government headquarters in the city of Bacau, 190 miles northeast of Bucharest, that left a man dead. The Bacau police chief, Gheorghita Toader, said in a telephone interview that no attack had occurred, and the report apparently was describing a hypothetical situation.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Defends Negotiations with Exxon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of `spokesman' in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department today defended its negotiations with Exxon Corp. about settling possible criminal charges from the Alaskan oil spill, saying any deal will not compromise the state's legal rights. Department spokesman David Runkel, responding to criticism of a possible deal by environmental groups and Alaskan officials, said the Justice Department was ``puzzled by comments which have been reported by persons who appear to have little grasp of what is actually involved in this case.'' Runkel said the discussions involve ``a number of complicated legal and factual issues.'' ``No actions taken by the federal government in the enforcement of federal criminal laws will compromise the State of Alaska's ability to pursue the violations of its criminal laws or appropriate civil remedies,'' Runkel said. ``Nor will the rights or private parties, including the environmental groups and Alaska residents, to pursue appropriate civil claims be adversely affected by any actions of the federal government in the criminal law area,'' Runkel said. He declined to discuss the specific items of the plea negotiations, which sources say have been going on for several weeks. ``As in most cases of this type, there have been discussions with attorneys for Exxon as to the admissible parameters of appropriate penalties and appropriate corrective measures in the event of a guilty plea to any criminal charges that might be brought,'' Runkel said. Runkel also declined to say whether any negotiated settlement would cover civil claims the federal government could bring against Exxon. His comments were in response to statements by environmentalists and Alaskan officials that criticized what they understood to be the proposed deal. Alaska Attorney General Douglas Baily, speaking Thursday in Juneau, accused the Justice Department of trying to get the state to issue ``a hasty endorsement'' of an inadequate draft proposal. ``Under the proposed agreement, the federal government would abandon its commitment to Alaska to assist with its civil claims against Exxon,'' Baily told reporters. He said he hoped the agreement would be revised to make it more acceptable to the state. ``We are being asked to accept a pig in a poke. ... And that pig smells awfully bad,'' he said. ``From all accounts the Bush administration is giving Exxon a wink and a nod ... a mere slap on the wrist,'' added Jay Hair, president of the National Wildlife Federation. Sources said the draft agreement calls for Exxon to pay up to $500 million into a natural resources restoration fund over the next seven years and possibly a significantly smaller amount in direct criminal penalties to the U.S. Treasury. The agreement, if made final, would allow Exxon, whose tanker spilled more than 11 million gallons of oil into Alaska's pristine Prince William Sound in March 1989, to avoid an embarrassing criminal trial and possible criminal prosecution of individual corporate officials. The criminal laws used by federal prosecutors in oil spill cases allow fines of up to double the cost of the cleanup. Exxon has said it has spent nearly $2 billion to clean up the oil spill. Exxon attorneys, in the negotiations with the Justice Department, have tried to limit the amount of money to be paid to the U.S. Treasury as criminal penalties, preferring to pay most of the money into the restoration fund, sources said. But one government source suggested Exxon might have to pay only about $150 million initially, and subsequent annual payments over seven years would be open to Exxon challenges. Environmental lawyers said that money paid for restoration under the criminal settlement could be tax-deductible as an ordinary cost of doing business and could be used to reduce future assessments against Exxon under various civil proceedings. Criminal penalties could not be deducted from future assessments, nor would they be tax-deductible. No criminal charges have been filed in federal court against Exxon as a result of the Alaska spill, pending the outcome of the plea-bargaining. State officials last year agreed that the federal government would handle criminal charges against Exxon while the state focused on civil litigation. Although details of the proposed agreement remained sketchy, the process brought attacks from environmentalists and Alaska state officials. Eleven environmental groups filed papers in U.S. District Court in Anchorage asking that any out-of-court settlement between the Justice Department and Exxon be reviewed in an open court hearing. Mike Matz, chairman of the Alaska Coalition, a group of environmental and civic organizations, said the Bush administration was moving too quickly to settle with Exxon. He characterized the reported settlement as ``little more than a slap on the wrist.'' Michael Fischer, executive director of the Sierra Club, accused the Bush administration of ``being too eager to forgive Exxon'' by trying to reach ``a quick and dirty settlement'' with the oil company. Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., also criticized the Justice Department bargaining with Exxon, saying the agreement ``may not provide full damages'' and might jeopardize the rights of other parties seeking damages from the oil company.

DOC.HEAD: Be Hunted: Grow Bigger, Live Longer
DOC.TEXT: The threat of being eaten prompts some snails to grow bigger and live longer, two zoologists report. That doesn't mean that France is facing any danger from giant escargot. But it does suggest that controlling snail populations may not be a simple matter of sending predators after them, say Todd A. Crowl and Alan P. Covich in Friday's edition of the journal Science. Crowl and Covich discovered that the widely distributed freshwater snail Physella virgata virgata lives longer and grows larger when it's being hunted by crayfish than it does when it's left alone. Snails living in streams without crayfish grew rapidly to a shell length of about 4 millimeters (0.16 inch), at which time they stopped growing and began reproduction. They lived between 3 and 5 months. But snails living in streams where crayfish preyed on them continued growing until they reached the length of 7 millimeters (0.27 inch) to 11 millimeters (0.43 inch) before starting to reproduce. And these snails lived 11 to 14 months. At first the researchers wondered if they had simply encountered different types of snails in different streams, or if they were the same type and somehow responded to being hunted by crayfish. To find out, they treid raising snails in four types of stream water. Regardless of their origin, snails were small and lived shorter lives when raised in water that had been exposed only to snails, water that had been exposed only to crayfish and water that had been exposed to snails and crayfish separately, the researchers found. But raising the snails in water that had been exposed to crayfish who were hunting and eating snails resulted in snails that grew larger and lived longer, they reported. ``Our results suggest that snails are capable of detecting a chemical cue that results from crayfish actively foraging snails,'' concluded Covich and Crowl. Crayfish eat lots of juvenile snails, but the prey rate declined as snail size increased, they found. ``Thus, by delaying the onset of reproduction and growing to a larger size, snails decrease mortality due to size-specific predation,'' they observed. Rapid responses of this type may be more important than genetic changes in avoiding being eaten, they concluded. Plus, the reactions of the snails ``suggest that the application of simple predator-prey models to biologically control snail populations may be of limited use.'' Changes in life history in response to being preyed upon have been observed in some plants and invertebrates, but the reaction is ``novel'' for snails, they report. Covich is with the Department of Zoology at the University of Oklahoma. Crowl, formerly with that department, is currently affiliated with the Department of Fisheries and Wildlife at Utah State University and the Department of Zoology at Otago University, Dunedin, New Zealand.

DOC.HEAD: Sihanouk Returns to Live in Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, once Cambodia's ruler and now a guerrilla leader, returned from 11 years of exile Friday to live in a ``liberated zone'' until his entire country is free. As Sihanouk entered the country, one of the three guerrilla groups in his alliance said they had lost a strategic town to soldiers of the Vietnamese-sponsored government in Phnom Penh. Gen. Dien Del, deputy commander of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, told reporters the army retook Svay Chek on Friday with the the aid of Vietnamese troops. Vietnam says it withdrew all its soldiers in September after 11 years of occupation, but the guerrillas claim some remained. Sihanouk told about 100 reporters brought in by bus for the homecoming: ``All Cambodians want to live in Cambodia and die in Cambodia. I am 68 years old and I feel more and more I could die on foreign soil, even if it is friendly foreign soil like China or North Korea.'' With him were his wife, Monique, and their platinum-white poodle, Mickey. Sihanouk, who has lived in exile since the Vietnamese invasion in December 1978, will be 68 on Oct. 21. Armed guerrillas and civilians chanted ``Long live his Royal Highness!'' as the smiling prince's party crossed by car from Thailand to a parched field about 100 yards inside Oddar Meanchey. After the ceremony, the prince drove farther east into Cambodia. Sihanouk's guerrilla alliance includes his own group, the Liberation Front led by Sonn Sann and the Khmer Rouge, the strongest faction, which governed Cambodia from April 1975 until the Vietnamese invasion ended its brutal rule. The guerrillas had scored major victories in Oddar Meanchey and other northwestern regions in the past few months, but Premier Hun Sen's government recently began a counteroffensive. The capture of Svay Chek was its first victory. Phnom Penh radio said the army ``succeeded in completely recapturing Svay Chek. We are now in full control of this area.'' All the guerrilla factions went on the attack after the Vietnamese withdrawal in late September. Sihanouk's group took strategic Thmar Puok and the Khmer Rouge captured Pailin, a gem-mining center. The government's campaign broke a lull of several weeks. An article in Friday's editions of The New York Times quoted two senior Eastern European diplomats as saying several thousand Vietnamese troops and military advisers returned to Cambodia in October to help government troops defend Battambang and Sisophon, two important cities in the northwest. It quoted the diplomats, who were not identified further, as saying about 5,000 Vietnamese soldiers were in Cambodia. Cambodian and Vietnamese officials deny there are Vietnamese troops in Cambodia or that any returned. Since fleeing the Vietnamese invasion, Sihanouk has lived in palaces and luxury hotels in China, North Korea, Thailand, France and other countries that support his guerrilla movement and have provided him with a comfortable life. In northwestern Cambodia, he will live in a one-room village house without running water or regular electricity, said Ek Sereywath, Sihanouk's spokesman in Bangkok. His staff will consist of cooks and two personal assistants, the spokesman said, and food and supplies will be brought in fron Thailand. Ek Sereywath said Sinhanouk would divide his time between two newly captured villages that have been renamed Sereipheap, or ``Freedom,'' and Ekareach, or ``Independence.'' The exact locations of the villages were not revealed. The prince said he would not lead his guerrilla army from the villages, but would concentrate on helping supply food, medicine and clothing to civilians. He said the hundreds of thousands of refugees in camps in Thailand were welcome to follow him home if the Thai government would allow it. Sihanouk ascended the throne in 1941 and led Cambodia to independence from France in 1953. He was overthrown in a 1970 military coup after resisting U.S. attempts to draw Cambodia into the Indochina war. He spent 1975-78 under house arrest by the Khmer Rouge, who embarked on a radical agrarian revolution that resulted in at least 1 million deaths by execution, starvation or disease. On Wednesday, Sihanouk met in Bangkok with Hun Sen, the premier installed by Vietnam. They agreed on the need for a U.N. presence in Cambodia and formation of a ``supreme national body'' that was not defined. A new round of peace talks involving the guerrillas, Hun Sen's government, Vietnam, France and Southeast Asian countries are to begin Monday in Jakarta, Indonesia.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Corps Coming to Poland, Eagleburger Continues Talks
DOC.TEXT: The first Peace Corps program in Poland was established Friday as U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger continued talks with Polish officials on American aid for economic reforms. Eagleburger, appointed by President Bush to coordinate aid to Poland, also heard Poland's demands that its western border be assured before German reunification. The two-day trip that began Thursday was described as a ``working visit'' by U.S. officials, with a series of closed-door meetings between Polish finance officials and the U.S. delegation, which included Deputy Treasury Secretary John Robson. Under the Peace Corps program, about 60 volunteers will begin arriving this summer, mainly English teachers to train Polish instructors. Earlier this month, the Polish Education Ministry announced that Russian study would no longer be required in schools. But officials said the introduction of Western languages to the schools would be slowed by the lack of qualified teachers. The Peace Corps has launched similar language training in Hungary, but U.S. officials said the Polish effort may be expanded to include agricultural assistance and other Peace Corps programs usually offered to developing nations. Eagleburger also met with President Wojciech Jaruzelski and leaders of the Roman Catholic church, which is distributing some U.S. aid. Economic help for Poland, especially to lighten the weight of Poland's $40 billion debt to the West, was to be the key agenda topic. Prime Minister Taduesz Mazowiecki used the visit to press Poland's views on Germany. ``We talked also about the most topical matter at present, that is the unification of Germany and the Polish presence at internatinal negotiations to that effect,'' Mazowiecki told the official PAP news agency after meeting with Eagleburger on Thursday. Poland is pressing for a seat at reunification talks planned by the two Germanys and the four World War II occupying powers: the United States, Soviet Union, France and Britain. On Wednesday, Mazowiecki called for drafting a ``peace treaty'' establishing the border during the talks. About one-third of Poland is comprised of lands forfeited by Germany after the war to compensate Poland for an even larger eastern territory annexed by the Soviet Union. East Germany and West Germany individually have signed agreements recognizing the border. But West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, some of whose political supporters still consider the lands part of Germany, has said he cannot make promises about the border on behalf of a reunified Germany. ``Taking advantage of the presence of the representatives of the U.S. administration, I presented the Polish point of view on this issue, which was included in a letter to President Bush,'' Mazowiecki said. The United States has so far not endorsed Poland's demand to take part in the six-nation talks on reunification, and Eagleburger said he would not take a stand on ``this very complicated issue.'' Eagleburger said he expected Mazowiecki would discuss the question with Bush when he visits Washington in March. In the econmic arena, Polish Finance Minister Lesek Balcerowicz said the talks were not expected to yield any immediate announcements, the official news agency PAP said. Balcerorwicz, who shaped the dramatic drive to reshape the economy as a market-driven system, said the Eagleburger delegation showed ``much understanding'' for his request that Poland be able to start drawing on a $45 million U.S. enterprise fund after the first quarter of 1990. Also on the Polish agenda for the meetings with Eagleburger was the foreign debt, more than $3.1 billion of which is owed to the United States, and obtaining new credits. The Polish side also is seeking assistance in the agricultural sector, including preferential sales of grain and foder, investments in environmental projects and help rebuilding the infrastructure, especially modernizing telecommunications, the Polish press reported.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Board Says Gulf Of Mexico Pipelines Pose Hazard to Fishing Boats
DOC.TEXT: The federal government should correct the danger posed to thousands of fishing vessels by poorly buried on unburied pipelines in the Gulf of Mexico, safety officials said Friday. The National Transportation Safety Board, in its investigation of an October fishing boat fire that killed 11 crewmembers, urged the Transportation and Interior departments to identify, inspect, maintain and protect the more than 18,000 miles of underwater pipeline along the gulf's outer continental shelf. The boat, the Northumberland, snagged and ruptured a 16-inch natural gas pipeline about a half mile offshore near Sabine Pass, Texas. The gas ignited, and within seconds the vessel was engulfed in flames, killing all but three of the 14 people aboard. Investigators determined that portions of the high-pressure pipeline had been exposed for up to 10 years. The board said at least 20 other incidents of ships damaging offshore pipelines have occurred in the gulf in recent years. The most serious before the Northumberland accident was in 1987, when the fishing vessel Sea Chief struck and ruptured a natural gas pipeline in Louisiana water, resulting in a fire that killed two crewmembers. The continental shelf lies under shallow waters of from nine to 12 feet in spots, where the law requires that pipelines be at least three feet below the sea bottom. But many older pipelines were never buried, the board said. In letters to Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan and Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner, the safety officials called upon the two departments to cooperate in protecting ships that may operate outside established sea lanes. Up to 35,000 shrimping vessels, as well as other fishing boats, operate in the gulf's shallow waters over a web of pipelines, the board said. It quoted officials of the U.S. Geological Survey as saying that coastal erosion can be severe along the gulf coast. ``Winter storms, hurricanes and the placement of man-made structures such as jetties can accelerate the erosion and subsidence rates and lead to the removal of sediment covering a pipeline,'' the board said. ``Marine vessel operators cannot presume that offshore pipelines in water depths less than 12 feet are buried and their vessels, therefore, are protected,'' said the letter signed by Board Chairman James L. Kolstad. The board said that, although the number of reported incidents remains small, it may be a growing problem. The board called upon federal authorities to determine the extent of pipelines in the gulf and set up a system for inspecting them. No regulations exist to ensure that pipes remain buried, the letter said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Company Involved in Purchase of Minor League Baseball Team
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with background and comment from Japanese company. No pickup. A version moved on sports wires.
