DOC.TEXT: A minor-league baseball team affiliated with the Chicago White Sox has been sold to a major Japanese brewery, and the new owners say they don't plan any major changes for the successful farm club. The new owners of the Birmingham Barons are Martin Kuehnert, an American, and a new holding company formed by Suntory International. The New York-based company is the U.S. subsidiary of Suntory Limited, a Japanese multinational food, beverage and restaurant company. Kuehnert, 43, who spent the past 20 years as a sports entrepreneur and broadcaster in Japan, will be the Barons' new president and chief executive officer. Suntory spokesman Takafumi Kashiwagi said in Tokyo that there would be no other changes in team management and that Suntory would not employ any of its executives with the team. No financial details of the sale were disclosed. However, Asahi Shimbun, a national newspaper in Japan, estimated the price at more than $3 million. The brewery, which recently began sports and music businesses in Japan, plans to expand its entertainment operations. He said the company had no intention of buying a Japanese baseball team. ``When it comes to entertainment, America is an advanced country, and we are hoping to learn a lot from the Barons,'' Kashiwagi said. Baseball is a national sport in Japan, and former American baseball players regularly play for Japanese teams. A Japanese major league team recently offered to buy the Durham Bulls in North Carolina after some of its officials saw ``Bull Durham,'' the movie about the minor league club, but the team president said it wasn't for sale. Art Clarkson, the Barons' principal owner, will remain with the organization as general manager and chief operating officer. ``We have 100 percent control,'' said Kuehnert, who returned to the United States in October and has bought a house in the Birmingham area. ``Suntory is the majority owner and I'm the minority owner.'' The Barons play in the Class AA Southern League and the sale is expected to be approved by league directors. Some minor-league teams in the United States are owned by major-league teams, others are privately owned. The privately owned teams work under agreements with the major league teams to train its players. Suntory International imports wine, beer and other beverages into the United States and is a soft drink bottler. It also owns Chateau St. Jean Winery in Sonoma, Calif., and restaurants in Boston, Chicago and Honolulu.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Declares Disaster in Georgia
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed papers Friday to speed disaster assistance to nine Georgia counties hard hit by storms and tornados earlier this month. The state of emergency declaration affects the counties of Carroll, Chattooga, Cobb, Douglas, Fannin, Gilmer, Gordon, Murray and Walker. The declaration opens the way for a variety of federal assistance efforts, including funds for local governments to repair public facilities as well as grants and loans to individuals and businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Rooney to Return to 60 Minutes Soon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with source casting doubt on reports, picking up 4th graf, `The network ...'. SUBS last graf with 2 grafs to CLARIFY that calls were counted last week, add detail on letters. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Andy Rooney is expected to return to ``60 Minutes'' before his three-month and suspension is up, perhaps as early as next week, according to reports published today. But a source familiar with the situation cast doubt on the reports. ``Absolutely nothing has been determined,'' the source said in response to the reports in today's editions of The Wall Street Journal and New York Newsday. The newspapers said Rooney and CBS News President David Burke held talks this week about Rooney's return. ``Burke is trying to review this thing and reach a conclusion,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``But no decisions have been reached. None.'' Rooney told the Journal that ``there was a chance I could have come back on Sunday,'' but those plans collapsed. The newspaper said he could be back as early as March 4. In The Washington Post, Rooney was quoted as saying he could be back ``within a month.'' Newsday cited unnamed sources as cautioning that CBS was still figuring how and when to lift the Feb. 8 suspension, but said the commentator could be back on the air as early as next week. The network suspended Rooney without pay for three months for racial remarks he was quoted as making in The Advocate, a gay magazine based in Los Angeles. Rooney has denied making the remarks. The possible lifting of the suspension coincides with a slight drop in the ratings of ``60 Minutes.'' The program has fallen from fifth place among network programs when Rooney last appeared three weeks ago, to 10th place two weeks ago and to last week's 11th place ranking, according to figures compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Co. Burke called Rooney earlier this week and arranged a meeting Wednesday at the CBS News Broadcast Center, Newsday said. Rooney said that he and Burke ``had a very pleasant conversation and he conceded that there was nothing personal. I like him fine.'' Burke declined to comment on Rooney's situation, the Journal said. Rooney, in anticipation of an early return, prepared a piece on his civil rights record for this Sunday's edition of ``60 Minutes,'' but it was not scheduled to be aired until at least the following week, according to the reports. As of last Friday, CBS had received 5,133 calls about Rooney's suspension, with 5,061 supporting him, said CBS News spokesman Roy Brunett. CBS also has received about 1,800 letters about the matter, but there has been no breakdown of how many supported Rooney and how many praised his suspension, Brunett said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Kohl to Discuss `Where Things Going' on German Reunification
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl joins President Bush at Camp David, Md., this weekend to discuss ``where they think things are going'' in the surging drive toward German reunification. Both U.S. and German officials are promoting the meeting, away from the formalities of Washington, as symbolizing a personal relationship between Bush and Kohl, both proponents of reunification. Kohl, just back from a visit to Moscow, was flying to Washington and on to the presidential retreat Saturday to go over the recent Ottawa agreement for reunification, face to face. The two presidents will discuss such questions as when implementation meetings should begin among East and West Germany and the agreement's four other parties _ the United States, France, the Soviet Union and Great Britain _ said one official. They will also discuss the future of U.S. troops in Europe. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the two leaders would discuss ``the full range of issues related to changes in Eastern Europe,'' including reunification, a U.S. proposal on reducing conventional forces in Europe, and the future of NATO and the Warsaw Pact. ``We don't anticipate any new agreements or announcements,'' Fitzwater said. He characterized the weekend, when Bush will be accompanied by Secretary of State James A. Baker III, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and Chief of Staff John Sununu, as ``an opportunity for the two leaders to discuss the status of events, where they think things are going.'' Fitzwater said West Germany's newly announced plans for a one-to-one currency exchange with East Germany probably will be one topic. Kohl also will give Bush a firsthand account of his meeting with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, who is talking now of a slower approach to reunification. The Camp David agenda could also include an issue that has caused consternation on the part of at least one of Germany's neighbors. Poland is worried that a reunified Germany might become aggressive about retaking territory that was part of Germany before the World War II victors carved new boundaries. The Poles seek a public statement by German leaders and the four other countries to respect the postwar boundaries. On Wednesday, Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki stepped up the pressure by calling on the two Germanys to sign a treaty guaranteeing Poland's current borders. Kohl, who has not made a public statement about the matter, is under pressure from West German conservatives who want to regain the territory. The separate states of East Germany and West Germany recognized Poland's boundaries under the 1975 Helsinki Act on European Security and Cooperation signed by 35 nations. Asked about the matter last month, Bush said, ``We have recognized under Helsinki existing borders, and I have no problem reiterating that.'' But he said he had ``no judgment'' on whether there should be multilateral action to reaffirm the borders. Coming on the heels of Kohl's Moscow trip and the Germany reunification agreement reached Feb. 13 in Ottawa, Kohl's visit with Bush highlights ``a very important historical turning point for Germany and Europe in general,'' said a U.S. official, commenting only on condition of anonymity. West German government spokesman Hans Klein said it showed ``the close friendship and responsible partnership between Germans and Americans.'' Bush called Kohl twice on the day Baker was in Ottawa working on the unification document. That accord called for the two Germanys to develop a plan and meet with the four other powers to approve it and work out larger security issues. Kohl's visit also comes shortly before the March 18 elections in East Germany that will foretell the direction of a new government to replace the current caretaker leadership containing both Communist and opposition members. Kohl, embattled on his own home front, is looking also to the possibility of reunification with an eye toward picking up support for his party after the two Germanys are one. Elections in West Germany are Dec. 2. The Social Democrats have shown increasing strength against Kohl's Christian Democrats. Some observers predict that unification could occur in time to make the Dec. 2 election one covering the new unified country. Kohl, in traveling to Moscow and the United States, continues to put himself forward as the leader of the unification drive. As far as the U.S. role, administration officials have said the Germans themselves must take the lead on unification. However, Bush and Kohl are in agreement that U.S. troops should remain in the western part of Germany, and not move into the East. Both also believe that a united Germany should be a member of NATO.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-abortion Bill Defeated in Indiana Senate; Michigan Governor Vetoes Bill
Precede INDIANAPOLIS
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Michigan governor vetoing abortion bill. Picks up 5th graf, `The Indiana ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Pro-choice forces won two battles when the Indiana Senate defeated legislation to ban abortions in public hospitals and Michigan Gov. James Blanchard vetoed a bill requiring minors to obtain permission for an abortion. Abortion rights activists in Indianapolis clapped in the Senate gallery and hugged in the hallway when senators turned back the public hospital ban on a 26-23 vote Thursday evening. It followed a two-hour debate. ``We're not going to be debating this issue again in the Indiana Senate during this session,'' said Dinah Farrington, a lobbyist for Planned Parenthood Inc. ``Attempts will be made to bring it back, but I really don't think we're going to see it on the Senate floor again for a vote.'' Today, Blanchard announced his veto of the Michigan bill, which would have required minors to get permission either from their parents or a court. The governor said he supported parental involvement in such decisions, but the bill ``takes a woman's right to help herself away from her.'' The actions marked the latest swings in the see-sawing fortunes of abortion legislation around the country. Earlier in the week, legislatures in South Carolina and Michigan had given final approval to bills requiring parental consent for teen-agers seeking abortions. The veto of the measure in Michigan leaves only one question in the abortion dispute in the state _ whether abortion foes will make a doomed override attempt or head straight to the voters. Barbara Listing, president of Right to Life of Michigan, had said Thursday that the group's executive committee would wait until Blanchard vetoed the bill before deciding its plan of attack. ``It's likely that we would simply begin as soon as possible with an initiative petition drive,'' Listing said. Blanchard's counterpart in South Carolina, Gov. Carroll Campbell, has not taken action on the parental consent bill passed there this week but has said he supports it. The Indiana legislation would have prevented doctors in public hospitals or clinics from performing abortions except in cases of rape, incest or when the life or health of the mother is threatened. Under current law, no public money can be used for abortions, but some public hospitals perform the procedure by using private donations and fees. The measure also would have required doctors to perform viability tests before performing abortions after the 20th week of pregnancy. Doctors failing to conduct the tests could have been jailed. The U.S. Supreme Court in July gave states more power to restrict abortions. The ruling upheld a Missouri law that banned abortions in public hospitals and stopped public employees from counseling women about abortions. It also required doctors planning to perform abortions to first test any fetus over 20 weeks to determine if it could live outside the womb.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Confirms Asian Troop Cuts; Soviets Not Impressed
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced Friday the Pentagon wants to bring about 12,000 U.S. troops home from Asia, but a ranking Soviet official said the plan was nothing to ``brag about.'' Cheney, ending a two-week visit in the Pacific Rim with a major policy address before the National Press Club, said that during his tour he discussed a range of cuts ``on the order of 10 percent, scattered about the region.'' He said the first phase could take three years. Gennady Gerasimov, head of the Soviet Foreign Ministry's Information Department, criticized the proposed reductions as ``small-scale'' when compared to Soviet efforts. ``The plan is not much to brag about,'' said the Soviet official, who is in Tokyo to wrap up an Asian tour of his own. ``It was the natural result of fiscal policies and modernization.'' Both superpower officials arrived in Tokyo from Manila. Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said Gerasimov is a guest of Kyodo News Service, not the government, and the ``simultaneous visits are simply accidental.'' Final decisions on the troop reductions will be made after further discussions with the military commanders and Congress, the U.S. secretary said. Congress has pressed Cheney to slash his defense budget and reassess the reasons for keeping 120,000 U.S. troops in Asia. Cheney, however, said it would be a mistake to reduce the U.S. presence in Asia just because of eased tensions in Europe, and America must ``look at the region on its own terms.'' He also said that despite calls from some lawmakers for 20 percent to 30 percent cuts, he believes Congress will maintain ``a major U.S. presence in the Pacific.'' ``In the future, if there are solid indications that regional stability will not be threatened, we may _ in consultation with our allies _ make other adjustments that would be appropriate,'' he said. However, Cheney said a total U.S. pullout would open ``a vacuum'' in the region, leading to destabilizing arms races, regional tensions, ``and possibly conflict.'' Cheney, who toured South Korea, the Philippines and Japan, said the Soviet Union hasn't acted to reduce tensions in Asia as it has in Europe, and called on Moscow to help calm the region's flashpoints. But Gerasimov, speaking to reporters at the National Press Club just hours after Cheney, argued that Moscow has already made substantive reductions, including the mothballing of 50 ships in its Pacific Fleet and the recent withdrawal of aircraft from Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam. ``Our presence in Cam Ranh Bay will be replaced by mosquitos and grasshoppers,'' he said. ``Such large reductions as we have carried out were the product of new thinking ... and cannot be explained by modernization'' as American military officials have charged, he said. Gerasimov dismissed American calls for the Soviets to help increase stability on the Korean peninsula by exerting more pressure on North Korea. ``North Korea is an independent country, it is not our satellite,'' he said, pointing out that while there is no foreign military presence in the North, the U.S. maintains 43,000 troops in the South. ``North Korea has made several proposals for peaceful reunification (with South Korea), including tearing down the wall along their border,'' he added. ``Some people say the wall doesn't exist, but I have seen it from Panmunjom. This is a time for tearing down such walls.'' The Soviet diplomat said Moscow is not considering returning to Japan the disputed Southern Kurils _ small islands off the coast of Hokkaido that have been occupied by the Soviets since the end of World War II. Japanese officials, following daylong discussions Thursday with Cheney, called plans for reducing the 50,000 U.S. troops here ``prudent and appropriate.'' While in Tokyo, Cheney also sought increases in Japan's $2.4 billion annual support toward the $7 billion cost of the American deployment in Japan. But no specific figures were discussed or agreed upon, officials said. The secretary, who leaves for the United States Saturday, said that Japan has ``significantly increased'' its spending for U.S. forces here. ``We think that is a very positive trend,'' he said, adding that he hoped such increases would continue.

DOC.HEAD: Party Newspaper Cites `Dog Mayor' to Criticize U.S.
DOC.TEXT: The People's Daily isn't known for its sense of humor, as it proved Friday with a scathing front-page report that U.S. democracy is going to the dogs. The Communist Party newspaper said the town of Sunol, Calif., had elected a dog as mayor. The joke, however, may be on the newspaper. ``Western `democracy' has reached such a peak of perfection that not only can one talk of `democracy' between people, but `democracy' between dogs and people,'' the newspaper said with heavy sarcasm. ``There is no distinction between people and dogs. ... No wonder some people prostrate themselves in worship of Western democracy.'' The dog election ``can be seen as a wake-up tonic for those kindhearted people who are naive and ignorant and blindly worship Western democracy,'' the paper said. ``In the final analysis, Western nomination systems are a very limited kind of `democracy.' Sunol is an unincorporated area of about 400 people in Alameda County 40 miles southeast of San Francisco. Some of the local residents jokingly refer to a beloved black Labrador named Bosco as the hamlet's ``mayor'' following a mock election more than 10 years ago when the pooch supposedly beat two human rival candidates. The town actually is governed by the Alameda County board of supervisors. Local media have been known to do periodic stories on Bosco. The People's Daily published the story one day after the Foreign Ministry lashed out at U.S. criticism of its human rights record. It also carried articles Friday about the spread of AIDS and drug use in the United States, bolstering the official image of the United States as an anarchic and degenerate society.

DOC.HEAD: Life of Salvadoran President
With Obit-Duarte
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of the life and career of President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador, who died Friday in San Salvador: Nov. 23, 1925: Born in San Salvador. May 1948: Graduates as civil engineer from the University of Notre Dame, South Bend, Ind. Aug. 14, 1949: Marries a childhood friend, Ines Duran. November 1960: Co-founds Christian Democratic Party. March 1964: Elected to first of three terms as mayor of San Salvador. Feb. 20, 1972: As he is winning the presidential election, the vote count is stopped by the military. Duarte is arrested, severely beaten and expelled from the country. October 1979: Returns from exile after coup by reformist-minded military officers. March 3, 1980: Named member of third military-civilian junta, after two previous juntas disbanded amid discord. Dec. 13, 1980: Named president of fourth junta. U.S. aid _ cut off by Carter administration 10 days earlier because of human rights abuses _ is reinstated. March 25, 1984: Wins plurality in presidential elections. May 6, 1984: Wins presidential runoff against rightist candidate Roberto d'Aubuisson. June 1, 1984: Assumes presidency. Oct. 15, 1984: First round of peace talks with leftist rebels held in the northern town of La Palma. March 31, 1985: Christian Democrats win majority in legislative elections. Sept. 10, 1985: His daughter Ines, 35, is kidnapped by leftist guerrillas. Oct. 24, 1985: Ines Duarte and 23 kidnapped mayors are released in exchange for 22 rebels imprisoned by government and 100 wounded guerrillas given safe conduct out of country. June 1, 1986: Proposes new peace talks with rebels. Proposal accepted. Sept. 14, 1986: Travels to town of Sesori in northeast El Salvador for talks with guerrillas. Rebels, saying government forces have militarized the town, refuse to attend. Duarte says insurgents don't want peace. Oct. 10, 1986: Major earthquake devastates San Salvador. An estimated 1,500 people killed, thousands left homeless. Oct. 14, 1987: During White House ceremony, Duarte leaves speakers platform to kiss U.S. flag. Though applauded in Washington, he is criticized at home for subservient attitude. March 20, 1988: Christian Democrats defeated by rightist Republican Nationalist Alliance in legislative and municipal elections. May 27: Government says he is suffering from bleeding ulcer, will go to United States for treatment. May 31: Duarte, before leaving for Washington, says his ailment is ``of a malignant nature.'' Delegates presidency to Vice President Rodolfo Castillo Claramount. June 1: Castillo confirms that Duarte has stomach and liver cancer. Calls him a ``man on the verge of death.'' June 2: Duarte vows to fight his cancer and urges countrymen to ``never lose the liberty they have now.'' Feb. 23, 1990: Dies in San Salvador.

DOC.HEAD: Take a Moment and Bash a Lawyer
DOC.TEXT: Anyone who hates lawyers has a friend in the White House. ``Lawyers certainly deserve all the criticism they can get,'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater declared Friday. ``Those are universally held feelings by everyone who has ever dealt with the legal establishment.'' Fitzwater made his comments at a press briefing when a reporter asked about President Bush's speech Thursday, in which he promised government help to ``restore common sense and fairness to America's medical malpractice system.'' Fitzwater did not explain the basis of his feelings but said, ``I've never had any personal problem with lawyers, you understand.'' He said he was sure that ``all my good friends who are lawyers'' would appreciate his position. After his briefing, Fitzwater declined an opportunity to back off his attack. ``Everyone ought to take every opportunity to blast lawyers. It's so easy to bash lawyers,'' said Fitzwater, who works for a government that employs thousands of lawyers and has its own attorneys in the White House. The American Bar Association said it was disappointed with Fitzwater's comments. ``I hope that he wasn't serious,'' said ABA President L. Stanley Chauvin Jr. of Louisville, Ky. ``And if he was, it was because he wasn't aware of all the things lawyers do to protect peoples rights.'' Moreover, he said the ABA was involved in projects such as drug education and protecting the rights of the elderly and children. ``Most of the people I talk to ... feel that their lawyer is honest, competent, capable, reasonable and interested in their welfare,'' Chauvin said. ``It's the one on the other side who's shifty-eyed.'' Chauvin offered to stand up for Fitzwater's rights if his remarks get him in trouble. ``If anybody chastises him I'll protect him and his rights,'' he said, adding with a laugh, ``I'll send him a big bill for it. I'm expensive. I'll get him out of it, even if it takes every nickel he has.''

DOC.HEAD: US Decides Against Imposing Sanctions on South Korea, Europe
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Friday that it would not retaliate against the 12-nation European Community and South Korea regarding trade barriers imposed against U.S. telecommunications firms. Instead, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said, the administration will extend for a year the current round of talks aimed at settling the dispute. ``There is much additional work to be done before we obtain the full market openings we should have, but a decision to end our negotiations now could halt the momentum we have achieved and jeopardize future prospects for liberalization,'' Hills said in announcing the decision. South Korea and the European Community were accused by the administration a year ago of erecting unfair barriers that discriminate against the sale of U.S. telecommunications products and services. Under the 1988 trade law, U.S. negotiators had a year in which to try to get the other countries to remove the offending barriers. If the talks proved unsuccessful, the administration could then have retaliated by imposing higher tariffs on imports from the European Community and South Korea. Hills said the administration decided to exercise the option to extend the negotiations for another year on the grounds that substantial progress had been made in the talks. Hills cited several areas where both the European Community and the South Koreans had liberalized their trade laws concerning telecommunications equipment. ``The Koreans are taking steps to open their market to U.S. equipment manufacturers,'' Hills said, citing particular progress in the areas of government purchases, setting standards for foreign equipment sales and liberalizing tariffs on telecommunications equipment. In 1988, the European telephone equipment market was estimated at $22 billion while the telephone services market was more than $50 billion. The South Korean equipment market was put at $1.5 billion. ``U.S. telecommunications companies are among the best in the world. Given the opportunity to compete fairly, they could achieve a much larger share of the telecommunications markets,'' Hills said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Wins Right To Keep Jail in Armory for Now
DOC.TEXT: A sheriff who seized a National Guard armory because he said there was no other place to put prisoners won the right today to keep a makeshift jail there for at least two weeks. At a hearing in Hampden County Superior Court, Judge George Keady approved an interim order that was submitted by attorneys for both the county and the state. ``The parties have worked very hard on this and we will continue to work on a final solution,'' said Edward McDonough, representing Hampden County Sheriff Michael Ashe. The order allows Ashe to remain at the armory, continue cooperating with the National Guard and report back in court on March 12. Ashe took over the armory a week ago, telling stunned brigade officials that he was empowered to seize their facility by 17th Century statutes ordering him to keep the peace. The regular county jail was overcrowded, and the sheriff said he needed more space or he would have to start releasing inmates. Four more inmates were moved to the armory Thursday, bringing the total to 19. The inmates say they back the sheriff. ``It's all right here. It's open,'' said 24-year-old Wilfredo Lopez, who said he liked the more rural setting of the armory, which is near a park. ``I like it better here because it's not close to the highway,'' said 29-year-old Donald Blake of Springfield, who has two months to go on a charge of breaking into a car.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Former Salvador President Dead of Cancer
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Combines pvs. Adds that Duarte died at home. Adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: Jose Napoleon Duarte, who became El Salvador's first democratically elected president in 50 years but was unable to end a civil war that battered his nation, died today of cancer, his doctor said. He was 64. The ex-president's personal physician, Jose Luis Saca, said Duarte died at 11:50 a.m. at home, in the fashionable San Benito neighborhood on the south side of San Salvador. In May 1988, doctors at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington diagnosed the cancer and removed 60 percent of Duarte's stomach, but the cancer had spread to his liver. At that time, they gave him from six to 18 months to live. Duarte governed from 1984 until June of 1989, when his Christian Democrats lost control of Congress and he had to turn the presidency over to Alfredo Cristiani, leader of the rightist Arena party supported by the oligarchy that Duarte fought so long. Duarte, who was once arrested, beaten and exiled for his fidelity to democracy, called his inauguration in 1984 ``a light in the long night of horror,'' and he likened himself to Moses delivering a people from their tribulations. Duarte was crucial to the replacement of an authoritarian, semi-feudal system with incipient democracy. But he finished his term, and his life, burdened by failures, compromises, frustration and dashed hopes. The war with the leftist Farabundo Marti Liberation Front continues after 10 years. Poverty remains endemic in this small Central American nation of 5 million, where the staggering economy is dependent on U.S. aid. ``He didn't work miracles,'' said a high-ranking U.S. diplomat who served in El Salvador for most of Duarte's term. ``But he must be credited with instituting the democratic system itself. His great legacy is the transition (of government). The rest pales by comparison.'' Duarte's opponents criticized his bombast and messianic complex. Some of his top aides were accused of corruption. His supporters hailed his idealism and fighting spirit. But adversaries and fans agree Duarte played a historic role in El Salvador. ``One must acknowledge President Duarte's democratic vocation,'' said Cristiani just before he took over on June 1. ``He has, with his aptitude and positions, promoted the advance of democracy. But I wouldn't go so far as to call him the father of Salvadoran democracy.'' Duarte was born in San Salvador Nov. 23, 1925, the second of three sons to a tailor father and dressmaking mother. The father later turned to candy making, a business good enough to put all three boys through college. In 1944, Duarte, who had been a Boy Scout and remained active in the organization for life, went to Notre Dame in South Bend, Ind. He graduated as a civil engineer and came home to marry his childhood friend, Ines Duran, work in her family's construction business and raise six children. The barrel-chested, blue-eyed engineer joined a half dozen other Roman Catholic professionals in 1960 to found the Christian Democratic Party. They were mostly young liberals who hoped they could put the church's social doctrine into practice through government. He served three terms as mayor of San Salvador, gathering a political following that revered him through years of exile and trouble. He ran for president in February 1972 and was winning handily when the army stopped the count and declared its candidate the winner. A few weeks later, a dissident military faction attempted a coup that Duarte supported. When the coup failed, he was arrested, beaten and told he would be shot. He was instead allowed to leave the country. He spent more than seven years in Venezuela and returned to construction, but kept active in politics and indulged his hobby of oil painting. He came home after a 1979 coup by reformist minded military officers intent on dismantling the semi-feudal economy that had made a very few Salvadorans very wealthy while leaving the vast majority poor and illiterate. Duarte joined the ruling junta in 1980 and became its president in December that year. The army and police embarked on a course of brutal repression that left tens of thousands of civilians dead, many by officially sanctioned or tolerated death squads. Duarte was criticized for presiding over terror, but he said things would be worse were it not for his presence. In an effort to deprive the guerrillas of an issue, the junta began what was envisioned as a radical land reform, expropriating _ with compensation _ most of the country's biggest farms and turning them into cooperatives. The reform was a partial political success, but it eventually bogged down because of organizational and production problems. Duarte, popularly elected in 1984, promised his presidency would bring peace and, with it, prosperity. But in three attempts at negotiations with the rebels he did not budge from the demand that they lay down their arms and join the political process _ something they are now considering in talks with the Cristiani government. But at the time the rebels contended conditions for democracy were absent in El Salvador. Duarte, who was fond of weather metaphors, compared the war to a ``typhoon'' in a 1987 interview with The Associated Press. Mainly because of the war, the economy crumbled. The decline was hastened by droughts and a 1986 earthquake that killed an estimated 1,500 people and left tens of thousands homeless. U.S. economic and military aid reached nearly $2 million a day. Duarte's ability to impress foreign leaders, particularly members of the U.S. Congress, and elicit aid was universally recognized. But his opponents on both right and left decried what they called subservience to U.S. influence. Even his supporters cringed when Duarte, at a White House ceremony before dozens of TV cameras, kissed the U.S. flag. As he was being treated for cancer in Washington in June, 1988, his state-of-the-republic address was read to the legislature. Aware of the gravity of his disease, Duarte offered an evaluation of his term. ``The will of my people has caused me to navigate seas each day more stormy and more dangerous because of cross-currents. The absence of fair winds and persistent adversity all along the route have joined to prevent us from bringing about our high aims,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Norwegian Premier Proposes North American-European Security Conference
DOC.TEXT: Norwegian Prime Minister Jan P. Syse proposed Friday a 35-nation, North American-European security conference. ``Today, our task is to link the countries of Europe, all of them, and North America so closely together that a return to the quarrels of the past can never take place,'' he said in a speech to the National Press Club. He predicted that ``there will be the unavoidable call in some European quarters for the dissolution'' of the North Atlantic Treaty Alliance and the Warsaw Pact. ``And there will be the calls on this side of the Atlantic for bringing the troops home _ not some of them, but all. Both views are equally dangerous. ...'' He also said that intensified economic competition and the declining military threat ``could tempt us to focus more on what divides us and less on what unites us.'' He suggested that the 12 countries of the European Economic Community join with Norway and the five others that belong to the European Free Trade Association to set up what he called a European economic space. It could be a model for future relations between eastern and western Europe, he said. Earlier, Syse met privately for 30 minutes with President Bush at the White House. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said that the two leaders discussed East-West relations, maintaining the strength of NATO, German reunification, arms control and European troop reduction.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Delays Launch for Third Day
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis' commander got over his cold Friday but the weather remained bad, forcing NASA to postpone for the third time the launch of the shuttle on its secret military mission. Shuttle managers slipped the launch 24 hours to Sunday morning after weather forecasters predicted high winds and thunderstorms in the hours leading up to a Saturday launch. The forecasters said the cold front causing the problems would move out by Sunday and there was an 80 percent chance of favorable weather at the scheduled liftoff time of about 1 a.m. That's the best outlook so far for the shuttle mission, which was originally scheduled for liftoff Thursday. The heavy rains and high winds would have prevented crews from pumping propellant into Atlantis' fuel tank for the four-day mission to put a spy satellite in orbit. The craft requires more than a half-million gallons of fuel. ``Weather conditions continue to be unacceptable for (fueling) which would be required for a Saturday morning launch attempt,'' NASA said. A mobile launch structure will remain around the shuttle to protect it from thunderstorms, the space agency said. Despite the threatening weather, Atlantis commander John O. Creighton, a Navy captain, and the shuttle's pilot, Air Force Col. John Casper, flew a training aircraft Friday. Flight surgeons earlier in the day declared Creighton fully recovered. Creighton and the four other crew members were found to be healthy during a routine medical exam Tuesday, but the commander complained of a sore throat the next day. His illness, along with predicted thunderstorms, prompted NASA to postpone Thursday's launch. The agency decided on another 24-hour hold the next day for similar reasons, but delayed Saturday's launch solely due to weather. Each day's delay costs $247,000 in labor and materials. That does not include expenses at other NASA centers supporting the mission. The exact time of liftoff has not been announced by NASA because of the clandestine nature of the mission, although the agency has said the shuttle will go up between midnight and 4 a.m. The countdown will be kept secret until the final nine minutes before the rockets ignite. Sources report liftoff should occur about 1 a.m. Reports on the progress of the mission will be blacked out throughout the flight. The silence will be lifted an hour before Atlantis returns to Earth for a landing at Edwards Air Force Base in California. The shuttle will be carrying a spy satellite said to be capable of taking high-resolution reconnaissance photos and of eavesdropping on electronic communications around the world, according to sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. Atlantis will be the 34th space shuttle mission and the sixth secret military mission.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Suggest Change in Tax Law for Upper-Income Earners
DOC.TEXT: Democratic leaders said Friday that Congress may consider cutting income taxes on ``upper-middle-class'' families but raising taxes on the richest Americans. However, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., and Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, acknowledged there is little Congress can do to make the tax law more equitable unless President Bush goes along. ``There's not going to be a Democratic light-cavalry charge on that (tax) issue,'' Mitchell told reporters. Foley said he thinks Congress will consider ways to remove a feature of the 1986 tax law that imposes a lower marginal tax rate on the wealthiest people than is paid by those with somewhat less income. The marginal rate is the rate paid on the next dollar earned. For example, under the new law a person with $150,000 income would pay $330 tax on a $1,000 pay raise while a person with $1 million income would pay $280 on the same raise. Adjusting the tax system to get rid of that quirk ``does not constitute necessarily a raising of taxes,'' Foley said. That presumably means it would not violate Bush's pledge not to raise taxes. ``Within a revenue neutrality (that is, without affecting the federal deficit) you could perhaps provide a more equitable balance between tax rates paid by what I would call upper-middle-class-income taxpayers and the very highest-income taxpayers,'' Foley said. ``I don't think the (top) bracket will be raised above 33 percent,'' he said. Mitchell added: ``For the first time in American history since the income tax was introduced, the marginal rate at which income is taxed declines as income rises above a certain level.'' Winners in any such tax change would be single people with taxable incomes (after exemptions and deductions) between roughly $45,000 and $93,100, and couples between $75,000 and $155,300. Higher taxes would be paid by singles above $93,000 and couples above $155,000. Foley and Mitchell emphasized their irritation that Bush and his predecessor, Ronald Reagan, have convinced the public that they will not accept higher taxes. The best evidence of Reagan's political skill, Mitchell said, was that he ``proposed, supported and signed into law 13 tax increases ... (yet) convinced everyone in America that he was against all of them.'' ``President Bush has got the words down right, but it remains to be seen if he has the political skill to pull off the same result,'' Mitchell said. Mitchell noted that Bush approved a $6 billion net tax increase last year, and in the budget he sent to Congress last month proposed tax increases totaling $15.7 billion, though no general increase in income taxes. Bush wants ``new taxes by anybody's definition,'' Foley said. Mitchell said that despite a big tax cut in 1981, federal taxes are about the same as 10 years ago and the butden has shifted from high-income to middle-income people. ``It is that which we believe should be corrected,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Funeral For Foreign Minister Ends in Riots
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people rioted Friday following the funeral for Kenya's foreign minister, attacking police with stones and smashing windows in the worst outbreak of violence since a 1982 coup attempt. Scores of people were injured and dozens arrested as Nairobi police dispersed a huge crowd of wailing, stone-throwing people mourning the mysterious death of Robert Ouko. Violence also was reported in the western city of Kisumu, his home, where dozens were injured, including at least three people shot by police. By nightfall, police and paramilitary units had dispersed demonstrators in Nairobi and Kisumu, but were bracing for more trouble at Ouko's burial outside Kisumu on Saturday. In Nairobi, Cabinet ministers, leading politicians and foreign envoys were caught up in the melee, which erupted moments after President Daniel arap Moi left the church service. Thousands of people had gathered outside the suburban church for the funeral service for Ouko, whose charred body was found shot in the head on Feb. 16. He had been missing from his western Kenya home for three days. The crowd was largely quiet until the first mourners inside the church began to file out, many of them weeping and ululating. As the crowd outside joined in the moaning and crying, police began to move it back. The police action brought a hail of rocks, sticks, bottles and other missiles from the crowd. Riot police, on hand in anticipation of trouble, charged into the mourners, chasing them through a nearby park and for nearly a mile to the city's center. As the disturbance spread into the heart of the capital, most of the stone throwing and taunting of police seemed to be taken up by large gangs of mostly young people, many of them apparently unemployed day laborers. Cars were stoned and windows smashed throughout the city. Some minor looting was reported. From Nairobi, Ouko's body was flown to Kisumu, a city on Lake Victoria that he represented in Parliament. There his casket was displayed on a low bier in the middle of a sports stadium on the outskirts of town. Thousands of mourners, mostly from Ouko's Luo tribe, had been gathering outside the stadium since early morning. When his body arrived in the afternoon, they filed by the bier single file. ``The trouble is that most of them did not get to see the body,'' said a ranking police officer, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``When the first ones came out, they incited the others.'' Roads in Kisumu were blocked, vehicles and buildings were set afire, shop windows were smashed and cars were stoned. Ouko, 58, was the fourth leading political figure to die violently since Kenya gained independence in 1963. None of the three previous murders was solved and in each case the government of former President Jomo Kenyatta was accused of a coverup. Ouko also was the highest-ranking politician from the Luo tribe, one of four major ethnic groups in Kenya that share and jockey for power in the single-party government and engage in rivalries that go back centuries. The other groups are the Kikuyu, the Luya and the Kalengen. University students in Nairobi began mostly peaceful demonstrations early in the week, demanding an impartial investigation into Ouko's death. The country was abuzz with rumors, some linking the slaying to tribal rivalries. Moi's government called in three Scotland Yard detectives and a British pathologist to assist the investigation in what was seen as an attempt to allay fears of a coverup. Only sketchy details of the inquiry have been released. Ouko appeared to be more popular in death than in life. Although considered one of the most articulate and able members of Moi's Cabinet, he kept largely out of the domestic political spotlight. Burial was to be near his family farm in Koru, about 40 miles from Kisumu.

DOC.HEAD: DX AH NOTE
BuRec Says New ``Call'' May Be Issued On North Platte Water
DOC.TEXT: Ranchers have been warned that unless mountain snowpacks improve significantly, the Bureau of Reclamation may issue an order for regulation of North Platte River water in April. But State Engineer Jeff Fassett said the ``call,'' which his office would have to approve, likely would have little effect on North Platte irrigators because it probably would last just a month. Fassett also added that his office could authorize irrigators this spring and summer to rotate or exchange water allocations in order to make the most of it. Officials with the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation are being pressured by downstream irrigators with rights to water from BuRec projects to order the call on the water, the engineer said. ``There's no doubt the word `call' on the river has come up,'' Fassett told a meeting of the Upper North Platte Water Users Association. Last winter Fassett and the BuRec issued another call on the water, the first time such an order had come in the winter in the history of state regulation on the river. Issuing a similar call this April can only be avoided if the area receives ``huge, above-average snowpacks'' that will fill downstream reservoirs,'' Fassett said at the meeting Wednesday. He noted that this year marks the second-lowest carryover of stored water in the North Platte drainage in the last 35 years, and the area is going into its fourth straight dry year with snowpacks of just 70 percent to 80 percent. But Fassett said BuRec officials aren't likely to decide whether to issue the call until after the March snowpack and streamflow predictions are available. He also noted that the call cannot extend beyond May 1 because of stipulations included in the North Platte decree _ a 1945 U.S. decision that established provisions for use of North Platte flows in Nebraska, Wyoming and Colorado. If a call is made this year it will be to regulate other river water users in favor of the 1904 water rights tied to Pathfinder Reservoir and the downstream irrigation districts the federal project serves. That would mean all water usually claimed for junior water rights _ those dated after the agreement _ would first have to go to fill the Pathfinder right. Looking ahead to the summer, Fassett said North Platte irrigators may have to face the prospect of borrowing water, but so far state officials are not encouraging such loans. Fassett noted that the BuRec would require extensive environmental evaluation before allowing the loans. Last year water loans to irrigation districts generated heated controversy over state's rights and led to a lawsuit filed against the BuRec by the state of Wyoming, the Goshen Irrigation District and the Casper-Alcova Irrigation District.

DOC.HEAD: Time Out of Whack in Britain's Fifth-Warmest Winter
DOC.TEXT: Daffodils are blooming and fruit trees are budding as England enjoys the warmest February since the American Revolution, and the fifth-warmest winter on record. Friday's high of 65 degrees Fahrenheit tied a record for the date, and the coldest temperature all winter was 37 degrees on New Year's Day. ``If you ask me if there is a greenhouse effect _ it hasn't been proved to my satisfaction, but if this is what it's like, then I'm all for it,'' said Ken Graves, secretary of the Royal National Rose Society. Outside Graves' office in the quiet cathedral town of St. Albans, 20 miles north of London, buds are forming on a Gloire de Dijon rose, and a bit of color is already peeking through. Those who believe that global warming has arrived will note that last winter was even warmer in England. Skeptics might note that the winter of 1686 was just as warm, and that Thursday's high temperature was matched in 1961. The average temperature in central England this month has been 45 degrees, 7 degrees warmer than normal and the hottest February since 1779, when the average was 46 degrees. There have been but four warmer winters since England started keeping records in 1659, said Barry Parker of the Meteorological Office. This winter's average temperature of 43 degrees since Dec. 1 has been exceeded only in 1834, 1869, 1975 and 1989. ``I would much prefer a good hard frost for several days,'' Parker said. ``There will be plagues of things going around my garden in the summer.'' Warm winters have brought a boom in the population of garden pests. Graves knows all about the anxieties of gardeners after a second straight winter without ice. ``We get no end of correspondence at this time of year, and over the telephone _ `Oh dear, oh dear, my roses have made all these long new shoots, what shall I do?' ``Prune as normal, and forget the new growth,'' Graves advises. The mild winter has thrown time out of whack. ``Daffodils, that come before the swallow dares, and take the winds of March with beauty,'' as Shakespeare had it in ``The Winter's Tale,'' are already blooming in some gardens. ``There are some varieties flowering rather precociously,'' said Jim Pearce, president of the Daffodil Society. ``There's a variety named `February gold' _ I think it was rather optimistically named, because this is only the second time anyone can remember it flowering in February,'' he said from his home in Colchester in eastern England. Warm weather may be a problem for some of the hundreds of flower shows held around the country, usually in April, Pearce said. ``If they are entirely daffodils, they're not on a safety streak, are they?'' The Royal Horticultural Society has an early show April 3-4, and its main daffodil show on April 25. ``It certainly looks as though the early show is going to be the main even this time _ subject, of course, to a debacle in the present climatic conditions,'' Pearce said.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Will Ask Supreme Court to Review Flag-Burning Decision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 7, I believe, with reaction.
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said today it will ask the Supreme Court to review a federal judge's finding that a law Congress passed last year to ban flag burning is unconstitutional. Chief spokesman David Runkel said the Justice Department would file a notice in Seattle federal court today of its intention to appeal Wednesday's ruling by a judge there. Runkel said the government will then have 30 days to file its brief in the high court. The law that forbids desecretion of the flag provides for a direct appeal of its constitutionality from federal district court to the Supreme Court. While the Bush administration has in the past supported a constitutionalamendment to ban flag burning, Runkel said the Justice Department now has a duty to defend the law enacted by Congress. The law was passed after the Supreme Court last year struck down a Texas statute that provided criminal penalties for flag burning. ``I believe the Supreme Court will reaffirm that the principles for which the flag stands include the freedom to dissent,'' said David Cole, an attorney who represented defendants in the Seattle case. Backers of a constitutional ban on flag burning say Wednesday's ruling shows Congress didn't go far enough when it outlawed flag desecration. But opponents of writing the prohibition into the Constitution said the real test would come when the case goes to the Supreme Court. ``I wouldn't get too worked up about a district court ruling,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. ``It's what we all expected.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said he remained convinced the law would be upheld by the Supreme Court. ``Whatever the outcome is, I do not favor a constitutional amendment,'' Foley said. ``I believe it would be wrong to amend the First Amendment.'' U.S. District Judge Barbara Rothstein in Seattle ruled Wednesday the new federal law against flag desecration is unconstitutional and dismissed flag-burning charges against four people. She said the right to destroy the flag was as protected as the right to wave it. The case involved four people who challenged the flag-protection law immediately after it went into effect last October by burning a U.S. flag outside a Seattle post office. Lawyers for three other flag-burners argued before a federal judge in Washington on Thursday that she should follow Rothstein's lead. That case involved defendants who burned a flag in a protest on the steps of the U.S. Capitol. Attorneys for Congress likened the law to the ban on burning draft cards, which was upheld by courts during the Vietnam War. Charles Tiefer, deputy counsel for the House clerk's office, said flag-burning ``was not mere speech.'' Democrats in Congress used the statutory ban to head off efforts by Republicans and the Bush administration to pass a constitutional amendment. The debate followed last summer's ruling by the Supreme Court striking down as unconstitutional a Texas law that banned flag desecration. Supporters of the constitutional route promised to renew their efforts. ``This decision vindicates those of us who wanted to fix this thing and have the states take up the question of protecting the flag properly,'' said Rep. Chuck Douglas, R-N.H. ``The way to do it is by a constitutional amendment, and there is nothing short of that.'' The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., said he still believed the Supreme Court would uphold the 1989 law as constitutional. ``The fact remains that the flag protection law is constitutional until the Supreme Court says that it is not,'' Biden said. ``I can assure these Seattle flag-burners that if they will just go and live in Tehran, Iran, my Kentucky constituents will be glad to buy them one-way airline tickets,'' Rep. Carroll Hubbard, D-Ky., told a nearly empty House chamber. He denounced ``malicious flag-burning by those who hate the United States, but enjoy living here.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Gather to Welcome Havel Home
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people gathered in downtown Prague on Friday to welcome President Vaclav Havel home from his trip to the United States. Havel, addressing the crowd from a balcony over Old Town Square, said he considered his visit successful. ``Dear friends, I would like to tell you that we have just arrived from America. We did not go there to take some rest or watch the sea and skyscrapers, we went there to do some work,'' Havel said. ``And I think we have achieved far more than we had expected.'' He drew laughter from the crowd when he said: ``Somewhere in New York I saw a poster saying `Havel to the White House.''' ``I thought about it and I realized that one small country in a state of moderate derangement will be enough for me,'' he joked. Havel said he found himself in the role of ``messenger boy'' between two important houses: the White House and the Kremlin. While in Washington, Havel addressed Congress and met with President Bush. On Monday, he travels to Moscow where he is to hold talks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He is also expected to sign an accord on the total withdrawal of some 73,500 Soviet troops from Czechoslovak territory. At a subsequent news conference, Havel refused to elaborate on what message he might be bringing to Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Bonn Official Says East Germany May Choose Immediate Union
DOC.TEXT: East Germany may be too divided after the March elections to agree on a government and could opt for immediate union with West Germany, a Cabinet minister said in a newspaper report published Friday. Die Welt of Bonn said Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble expressed his theory to U.S. officials. Ministry officials confirmed the account. East Germany's economic crisis has accelerated in recent weeks, forcing the government to end food subsidies and prompting speculation it is near bankruptcy. German reunification, and the economic and political questions it poses, are expected to dominate discussions this weekend when Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany meets with President Bush at Camp David, Md. According to Die Welt, Schaeuble told Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, that East Germany's first free elections may not produce a leadership that could agree on an economic rescue plan. ``It is conceivable that there will be no more (East German) government after March 18,'' he said. Several recent polls, however, have indicated East Germany's Social Democrats will win more than 50 percent of the vote. Communist candidates are expected to fare badly because of the once-omnipotent party's role in creating the economic crisis. Premier Hans Modrow, the most trusted Communist politician, has not decided whether to lead the party ticket. Pro-democracy opposition parties are numerous, poorly organized and inexperienced, which has led to a near-takeover by sister parties in West Germany. The 400-member parliament to be elected March 18 vote is supposed to choose a government to succeed Modrow's transitional administration. If the seats are spread too broadly among the many parties, members may be unable to agree on a leadership that could work with Bonn on an economic recovery plan. Schaeuble said he considered an inconclusive vote the ``more probable'' outcome of the elections, Die Welt said. Interior Ministry spokesman Willi Hausmann, who confirmed the account, said Schaeuble outlined several possible unification plans during a visit to Washington. Die Welt said he met with Baker and Scowcroft to discuss anti-drug policies, but the U.S. officials were more interested in discussing German reunification. One of the most critical decisions will be the exchange rate of East German marks for the West German currency. Kohl has offered to make the Deutschmark the official currency of both nations in return for capitalist reforms, effectively creating a single economy. Economic experts are discussing how the West German mark should be made legal tender for both, but no decision on monetary union can be made until after the East German elections. A 1-to-1 conversion rate probably would cause rampant inflation because of the unusually large savings of East Germans, who have had few goods to buy. Dieter Vogel, the West German government spokesman, discounted a newspaper report Friday that Bonn had decided on 1-to-1. He said a committee studying economic union still was the ``fact-finding stage.'' The newspaper said Schaeuble explained to the U.S. officials that Article 23 of the West German Constitution, known as the Basic Law, allows the legislature of any German region to decide to merge with West Germany. ``Article 23 doesn't envision the involvement of West Germany'' in the decision on merging, Schaeuble said. No referendum in either German state would be necessary if Article 23 was used, Die Welt said. A parliamentary vote soon after the elections to join West Germany probably would outpace the ``two-plus-four'' negotiations proposed by the World War II Allies. The two Germanys plus the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France agreed last week in Ottawa, Canada, to negotiate ``external aspects'' of German unity soon after the East German elections. Schaeuble gave Washington what was tantamount to an assurance Bonn does not seek to regain territory lost to Poland and the Soviet Union after World War II, the paper indicated. It quoted him as saying a transitional legislature would have to be created after any decision by East Germany to merge, and that body could recognize the Polish border. Recognition of the boundary between with Poland has become a major issue because Kohl has not committed himself to the current frontier, which follows the Oder and Neisse rivers. About one-third of Poland was German territory before World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Arianespace Rushes to Reassure Customers After Rocket Blast
LaserPhoto LON2
DOC.TEXT: The president of Arianespace said Friday a panel of experts will be named to determine why an Ariane rocket exploded shortly after takeoff and to reassure customers of its reliability. Frederic D'Allest, head of the European consortium, said he hoped the failure Thursday of the unmanned Ariane 44-Lor would not destroy customer confidence in Arianespace, which holds more than half the world's commercial satellite business. While the investigation is under way, all Ariane launches will be suspended, D'Allest told a news conference at the space center in Kourou, French Guiana. The news conference was also relayed to reporters at Arianespace headquarters in Evry, near Paris. Twelve to 15 experts will be named to investigate the incident and issue a report within two months giving ``all the details of our findings so they (clients) can ... be comfortable that we can resume flights safely,'' D'Allest said. ``If the cause is clear and precise and the problem corrected, we should rapidly regain the confidence of our clients,'' he said. The rocket was carrying two telecommunications satellites for the Japan Broadcasting Corp. and Space Communications Corp. when it exploded over the Atlantic Ocean about 7{ miles from the launch pad at Kourou. The investigative panel, to be appointed early next week, must determine why one of four strap-on boosters that power the rocket experienced a sudden drop in pressure just 6.2 seconds after the end of the countdown. The automatic pilot then ordered two of the other boosters to increase power to compensate for the one that failed. But at 30 seconds, the pressure plummeted in a motor in the body of the rocket adjacent to the booster. At 90 seconds, technicians realized the rocket was out of control, and 11 seconds later the rocket blew apart. Debris from the vehicle rained over the coast and the Iles du Salut just off shore, but no injuries were reported. Winds blowing from the east carried a cloud of the fuel back to land, forcing the launch staff and the 12,000 residents of Kourou indoors until it passed. Some residents complained of burning eyes and sore throats. French police and soldiers conducted an air search Friday along the beach for debris from the rocket. Witnesses who saw the flight on the video monitors at Evry said the rocket appeared slightly off course from the start and passed unexpectedly close above the support scaffolding as it rose, with flame from one of the boosters burning the structure. Officials said the rocket may have touched the scaffolding, but there was no indication this caused the explosion. France's space minister, Paul Quilles, said the explosion should cast no shadows over the Ariane program, which he noted had had an ``exceptional'' run with 17 successful flights in a row. Arianespace competes with the U.S. commercial launch industry. The United States depended on its space shuttles to launch commercial satellites until the Challenger exploded on Jan. 28, 1986. Since then, three major American aerospace companies, Martin Marietta, McDonnell Douglas and General Dynamics, have been developing and launching commercial satellites. But with its earlier start, Ariane has captured more than 50 percent of the market, and it drew business from the American program after the Challenger explosion. The launch was the 36th Ariane mission since the first flight in the unmanned space program, overseen by the European Space Agency, was held Dec. 24, 1979. It was the first explosion since the 18th Ariane flight on May 31, 1986, and the first of the 4 series. After the explosion in 1986, Ariane suspended all launches for 15 months to correct a basic design problem. D'Allest said he had confidence that there is no fundamental design problem with the rocket's engines and he hoped that launches could resume quickly. Since the last failure, flights had become almost routine. Successful missions have been held on the rate of about one per month, with 43 satellites launched since the commercial program got under way in 1981. Another 32 are scheduled with a contract value of $2.36 billion. The Thursday night launch of the two communications satellites marked the first time an Ariane mission carried an all-Japanese payload. One, the BS2K, was built by U.S. company General Electric's aero-space division to direct broadcasting for Japan's national NHK television network. The second, built by Ford Aerospace, was owned by Mitsubishi's subsidiary Space Communications Corp. to channel telephone, telegraph and telex messages. The BS2K satellite was insured for $150 million to $180 million, Arianespace said, while the Superbird B was insured for about $60 million. In Tokyo, Yoshiro Nakamura, chief technician for NHK, said the failure was very disappointing but NHK would continue to cooperate with Arianespace.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Clint Eastwood has sued a weekly supermarket tabloid, alleging that it falsely claimed extremists threatened to kill him for refusing to speak at a convention of white racists. The lawsuit, filed Thursday in federal court, alleges the Jan. 2 article in The Globe, headlined ``Nazi Thugs Put Bounty on Clint _ But Dirty Harry Won't Lay Low,'' was false, inflammatory, and constituted invasion of privacy. The story, attributed to unidentified sources ``close to the actor,'' reported that Eastwood became a target after turning down a speaking invitation by the Aryan Nation. Eastwood ignored the threats, saying, ``I've never shied away from a fight and I won't start now,'' according to The Globe. Court papers filed on behalf of the 59-year-old actor and filmmaker say he never received such an invitation, never received any death threats and never uttered that quote. Eastwood is asking for $2 million in general damages and $20 million in punitive damages for intentional and negligent infliction of emotional distress through incitement to violence and for invasion of privacy.

Impressionist Rich Little is seeking custody of his 1-year-old daughter, whose mother is fighting him over child support. Little's lawyer, Gerald Z. Berkowitz, says he succeeded in having the child support argument heard in Delaware, where the mother, Lalette Cottrell, and child, Lindsay, live, rather than in California, where the comedian lives. Little is willing to pay support but wants an amount ``consistent with the needs of the child,'' his lawyer said. If the case were heard in California, Little would have to pay from $5,000 to $10,000 a month, he said. ``I don't think the Delaware courts would give her that,'' Berkowitz said. ``And I don't think a child needs $5,000 to $10,000 a month.'' Little, of Los Angeles, also filed for custody because Cottrell has ``resisted permitting him to visit his daughter,'' Berkowitz said. Cottrell and her lawyer, Daniel F. Kelleher, would not comment.

Comedian Redd Foxx was paid $500,000 for his role in the movie ``Harlem Nights'' and spent $373,000 of it on ``wine, women, song and gambling,'' the Internal Revenue Service says. Such expenditures make it unlikely the IRS can reach agreement with Foxx on his tax troubles, IRS attorney Rollin Thorley told a federal bankruptcy judge Thursday. Foxx, who gained fame playing a junk dealer on the TV show ``Sanford and Son'' and currently performs at a Las Vegas resort, filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy law in 1983. He owes the IRS more than $900,000 in taxes, penalties and interest. The earnings on the recent movie were revealed as Foxx appeared in court to try to block a public auction of more than 400 items of personal property seized in an IRS raid in November. The items, including his Las Vegas home, several cars and jewelry, were to be sold last month. The sale was delayed while a federal judge tried to decide whether the IRS or the bankruptcy court had first claim on the property. Bankruptcy Judge Clive Jones ordered the property seized by the IRS to remain ``in limbo'' for 60 days while lawyers try to reach agreement. Foxx failed in bids to block the IRS from seizing his paychecks for back taxes.

Dancer Judith Jamison told 60 children from 35 countries Friday that she achieved what she has by following the advice of her parents _ to love life. Speaking at a Black History Month celebration at City Hall in her honor, she said, ``You don't have to be a dancer, but enjoy what you love to do and be committed to it.'' The artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater was given a proclamation by City Council President Andrew Stein who said, ``She proves that with a dream _ and lots of hard work _ you can be anything you want to be.'' Ms. Jamison said her key to success was to do ``what my mom and dad told me to do. `Love it. Dedicate yourself to it. Be committed to it. Know where your gifts are coming from _ and, please, have a sense of humor.'' She said one way to grow in life is through dancing. ``That can be your road map, a discipline you can take into any area of responsibility,'' she said. ``You can study dance and be an architect ... a doctor ... a dentist. Anything you wish. It opens up large, large areas of your life _ of enjoyment, of being around people, of working for the same goals,'' she said. The children attend a public school that specializes in teaching children from abroad.

Tammy Faye Bakker has renewed her South Carolina driver's license, a right reserved for state residents, but refuses to say whether she is moving back from Florida to the state where PTL was based. Mrs. Bakker told reporters she did not want to talk about why she got the license renewed Thursday. The state requires that a person get a license within 30 days after moving to South Carolina, but it must be returned if the person establishes another residence. Mrs. Bakker has been conducting a ministry in Orlando, Fla. Her husband, Jim, is serving 45 years at a federal prison in Rochester, Minn., for fraud in his raising funds at the PTL television ministry in nearby Fort Mill.

DOC.HEAD: American Cinema Editors Announce Nominations For Best Edited Films, TV
DOC.TEXT: ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' the documentary ``Roger & Me'' and the television special ``Roe vs. Wade'' are nominees in the 40th annual Eddie awards for editing from the American Cinema Editors. Steven Spielberg was declared filmmaker of the decade for his ``prestigious efforts to enhance the art of film editing,'' the honorary professional association announced Thursday. The awards ceremony will be held March 24 at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills. Here is a list of the Eddie nominations for best editing: Feature film: ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' David Brenner and Joe Hutshing; ``Field of Dreams,'' Ian Crafford; ``Glory,'' Steven Rosenblum. Documentary: ``Gary Cooper _ American Life, American Legend,'' Murray Jordan; ``The Great Dinosaur Hunt,'' John Soh; ``Roger & Me,'' Wendy Stanzler and Jennifer Beman. Television special: ``Howard Beach: Making the Case for Murder,'' Byron ``Buzz'' Brandt; ``Roe vs. Wade,'' Joe Ann Fogel and Elodie Keene; ``My Name is Bill W.,'' Paul Rubell and John Wright. Episode from a television mini-series: ``Lonesome Dove, Part 3,'' Corky Ehlers; ``Around the World in 80 Days,'' Les Green and David Beatty; ``War & Remembrance, Part 10,'' Peter Zinner and John Burnett. Episode from a television series: ``L.A. Law (His Suit is Hirsute),'' Paul Dixon; ``In the Heat of the Night (These Things Take Time),'' Buford ``Bud'' Hayes and Victor Lackey; ``Murder She Wrote (Night of the Tarantula),'' John C. Horger.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega: Underneath New Image, Old Fires Simmer
LaserPhoto MGA3
DOC.TEXT: On the campaign trail, President Daniel Ortega comes across like a combination rock star, game show host and evangelical politician. It is a dramatic change in image for a man so serious, so earnest about his country, his revolution and his job that even close friends say he can be boring. But behind the slick new facade still simmer the old class resentments, the anger and the hunger that carried Ortega to the pinnacle of Nicaraguan power. Ortega the candidate has swapped his trademark olive-drab uniforms for flashy sports shirts and his owlish glasses for contact lenses. He dances at campaign rallies with beauty queens and tosses baseballs. He kisses babies and poses for photos. He presses flesh and dispenses on-the-spot patronage with a boldness that could shame even a seasoned Chicago pol. This new style reflects, in part, a man more confident of his own hold on power and more comfortable with crowds than the scruffy, strident young revolutionary who marched in Managua more than a decade ago. But it is also the product of slick celebrity packaging. The Sandinista campaign sells Ortega, 44, the way Madison Avenue pitches the latest youth-oriented commodity, emphasizing the contrast with his main challenger, the white-haired publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, 60. His picture adorns T-shirts, billboards and posters bearing slogans such as ``Daniel, President of the Young'' or ``Daniel is Love.'' The image is one thing. The words are another. Ortega's rhetoric is harsh and his campaign speeches hammer on the Sandinista's main challenger, the United National Opposition, like a power drill. UNO, Ortega insists, is one and the same as the hated and feared National Guard that defended Anastasio Somoza's dictatorship until it fell in the 1979 revolution in which the Sandinistas took power. GN-UNO, he says, uniting the Spanish acronym for the long defunct guard and the coalition, ``is death, is treason.'' Its leaders, he says, represent the affluent class that put up with the Somoza family dictatorship for 45 years, lining their pockets in the process. He got so wound up in a recent speech that he threatened to confiscate Mrs. Chamorro's house and turn it into a child center and shut down her daily La Prensa, the only opposition newspaper in Nicaragua. At moments like this, the tough, angry kid who was running anti-military street gangs and marching in anti-Somoza demonstrations when he was in his early teens shows through. His common-law wife of 12 years, the flamboyant poet Rosario Murillo, told The Miami Herald recently that Ortega has never shed his revolutionary asceticism. ``He's like a monk,'' said Murillo, who refuses to discuss rumors they will split up after the election. Ortega grew up steeped in anti-American resentments forged by the nearly continuous Marine occupation of Nicaragua between 1921 and 1933 and by the U.S. role in installing the Somoza family dictatorship. Both parents served time in jail for anti-Somoza activities. In an interview last year with The Associated Press, Ortega said his greatest achievement in a decade of power was fending off U.S. attempts to topple the Sandinista revolution. The cost of the war with U.S.-backed Contra rebels and the economic embargo, he said, had been immense, but ``the reality is that the revolution is here.'' Ortega became a Sandinista when he was 18, leaving law school to join the tiny, clandestine Marxist movement in 1963. By 1966, he had had six months of guerrilla training in Cuba and was masterminding bank robberies to raise money for the cause. By 1967, he was in prison for killing a National Guard officer, lamenting in a now-famous poem that he never got to see Managua when miniskirts were in style. He was freed after seven years when Sandinista commandos kidnapped a group of prominent citizens. The hostages were traded for 25 jailed Sandinistas who were flown to Cuba. Ortega came home from Cuba in 1975 and when Somoza fell in 1979, he became head of the ruling junta that took over. He became president in 1984 elections and rose to a dominant position in the Sandinista leadership. That position is shored up by his brother Humberto, who serves as defense minister. Mrs. Chamorro, the widow of Somoza's most outspoken critic, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, served with Ortega on the junta but resigned after nine months. Later, she said the Sandinistas had betrayed their promise of a pluralistic, democratic Nicaragua. Those old promises haunt Nicaragua, and should Ortega lose Sunday's election, his word will be put to the test anew. ``Daniel Ortega could become a real historical figure if he were to peacefully hand over power to Dona Violeta; he could go down in the history of Latin American revolutionary movements,'' said Alfredo Cesar, Mrs. Chamorro's chief strategist. ``We have lots of guys in Latin America who refuse to hand over power. If he didn't he'd be just one more little dictator. But he has a chance to make history.'' Ortega shows no sign he plans to confront defeat. ``The people have already voted,'' he tells his audiences confidently. ``I speak to you as the president-elect.''

DOC.HEAD: Trooper Was Surprised At Finding No Drunks On Exxon Valdez
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with today's testimony, CORRECT spelling of Moussy drink, add background on legal classification of 0.5-percent-alcohol brew. Picks up 13th graf, `The defense...'.
DOC.TEXT: In an interview tape recorded just hours after the nation's worst oil spill, tanker captain Joseph Hazelwood denied drinking heavily, but said he had a ``phony beer'' on the ship and ``a real beer'' before he sailed. Hazelwood's interview with a state trooper the morning after his ship ran aground was played for jurors in a hushed courtroom this morning. His words were muffled because of the tape quality, but jurors were given a typed transcript to follow along. Also today, the trooper heard on the tape, Michael Fox, testified that he found more than 100 empty bottles of a brand of a very-low-alcohol beer on the ship after the grounding. On the tape, Hazelwood described how the accident occurred and was asked by Fox whether he had been consuming alcohol. ``Well, I had one of these phony beers, `Moussy,' and I'd been ashore. I had lunch with Captain Murphy, drank iced tea,'' Hazelwood replied. The trooper asked whether Hazelwood had anything to drink before going back to the ship. The skipper said he stopped to pick up pizza for other crew members, and later had ``a beer with a piece of pizza.''
