Hazelwood, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with second-degree criminal mischief, a felony; and three misdemeanors: reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. The Exxon Valdez leaked nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil, blackening hundreds of miles of rocky coastline and killing countless birds, fish and wildlife. Exxon has spent some $2 billion trying to clean up the mess. On the tape, Hazelwood was asked whether he stopped at any bars in Valdez during his time ashore, and said, ``We went by the Pipeline to see if anybody off the ship was in there, if we knew anybody.'' But he said he drank nothing there. Several witnesses have testified that Hazelwood drank vodka at the Pipeline Club that afternoon, but there is a dispute about how much he drank and when. Earlier, Fox testified he found empty bottles of Moussy, a brand of brew with 0.5 percent alcohol, on the Exxon Valdez when authorities returned to search the tanker about a week after it ran aground. There were ``a lot of them, over 100,'' he said. Fox said he went to the ship to look for evidence of hard liquor in the captain's quarters, but didn't find any. He told jurors he also went through ``a lot of trash _ it would fill this room.'' A product like Moussy with a half-percent or less of alcohol is categorized under the law as ``non-alcoholic''; in fact, manufacturers are not even allowed to call the products beer but must describe them as a ``brew.'' Regular beer has between 3.5 and 4 percent alcohol by volume. Other witnesses have said that the very-low-alcohol beer was allowed aboard ships by Exxon, which forbids any other alcohol. On Thursday, Fox testified that he boarded the grounded Exxon Valdez expecting to stop a drunken brawl and found instead a dark, quiet ship where ``everyone was gazing out the windows.'' ``They said the captain was drunk and they wanted me to take care of it,'' Fox testified at Hazelwood's criminal trial in state court. But when he met the skipper, he said, Hazelwood didn't seem intoxicated. He said Hazelwood, 43, was napping when he arrived about four hours after the tanker hit a reef. They met about an hour later for the first time. ``I said, `Well, what the heck is the problem?''' Fox said, and Hazelwood replied with his much-quoted comment, ``You're looking at it.'' The defense is expected to contend that the smell some witnesses detected on Hazelwood's breath was the low alcohol beer and that he drank it after the accident. Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Thomas Falkenstein testified Thursday that he smelled alcohol on Hazelwood's breath when he met the skipper, adding, ``It was an obvious smell.'' But his testimony was challenged by Hazelwood lawyer Michael Chalos who played for jurors a videotape of Falkenstein's remarks on television. ``I never talked to him face-to-face like we're talking,'' he told Connie Chung of CBS during an interview. ``It was side-by-side and staring out at the pilot house across the deck. We were close, 2{ feet, and I smelled alcohol in and around the area.'' The prosecutor, Deputy District Attorney Brent Cole, asked whether anyone else was in the area when Falkenstein smelled liquor. He answered no. Chalos asked whether the captain appeared impaired or intoxicated. ``That was the first time I had met Capt. Hazelwood,'' said the witness. ``I saw no signs of impairment.'' Jurors also watched a section of the TV show in which Falkenstein described Hazelwood's mood after the disaster. ``He was lucid but sullen like a man who'd seen his career go down the tubes,'' Falkenstein said.

DOC.HEAD: ^Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: A cat is avenging her species. Goldie, a tiger cat, is so tough she has every dog in the neighborhood on the run. So her owner, Kenneth Mercure, posted a sign soon after Goldie came to stay that warns: ``Dogs _ Beware Of The Cat.'' ``I was afraid she would attack a nice dog _ a valuable one _ and I don't want a lawsuit,'' said Mercure, 69. Mercure has seen wise dogs cross the street well before reaching his house and cross back well after they've passed it, he said. ``Maybe the dogs can read the sign, I don't know,'' he said. Other dogs suffer for their ignorance. One hapless canine followed a letter carrier into the yard and Goldie chased it away, Mercure said. ``I guess he didn't get the hint because he came back,'' Mercure said. ``She went around the side of the house and got him. He doesn't follow the mailman anymore.'' Goldie adopted the Mercures after her former owners moved out of a nearby house and left her behind. Mercure guessed she was about 4 years old. Not all dogs attract Goldie's ire. Three small dogs live next door and are quite friendly with the feline. ``They sometimes touch noses through the fence,'' he said. Terrorizing strange dogs, however, seems almost a mission. ``We've had lots of cats, but I've never seen a cat like her,'' Mercure said. ``I don't know why she's like this. Maybe she was abused.''

When U.S. Sen. Bob Graham sent Georgia pecans to his 99 colleagues for Christmas, the thank-you cards proved a mixed bunch. The Florida Democrat said he sent boxes labeled ``delicious Georgia pecans'' grown on a Graham family farm near Albany, Ga. ``Thanks ever so much for sending the walnuts,'' wrote back Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H. ``They arrived in time for our office Christmas party, so I shared them with the staff.'' ``Thank you for the chestnuts. It was very kind of you to do that, Bob,'' replied Minority Leader Alan Simpson of Wyoming. Sen. Slade Gorton, R-Wash., offered the Florida senator his ``sincere thanks for the wonderful box of almonds.'' John Glenn got the nuts right, but not their origin. ``Thank you very much for sending your holiday greetings and for sending the sampling of Wisconsin products, too,'' wrote the Ohio senator.

DOC.HEAD: Housewife Candidate Thrust Into Political Spotlight
LaserPhoto MGA4
DOC.TEXT: Young Violeta Barrios wanted to learn to type and be a secretary when she grew up. Instead, she married a man who became one of Nicaragua's revolutionary heroes, and as a steel gray-haired widow of 60 she finds herself the political symbol at the center of an electoral storm. Despite a rocky start, a broken knee and political naivete, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has run for president with gusto and a common touch. She has managed, despite her handicaps, to lead the strongest challenge to President Daniel Ortega and his leftist Sandinista party in their 10 years of rule. ``I am nothing,'' Dona Violeta, as she is called even by Ortega, said in an in interview. ``But in this life, you can learn anything.'' An elegant woman with graceful manners, Mrs. Chamorro's two main strengths are her martyred husband and her lack of alignment with any one political party. That was enough to qualify her as a candidate for the disparate and fractious United National Opposition, a coalition of 14 parties known as UNO. The memory of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro has been used by all sides, even by Mrs. Chamorro's four children, two of whom support Ortega. ``My father's enemies are within UNO,'' wrote Mrs. Chamorro's eldest daughter, Claudia. The phrase was used in Sandinista campaign graffiti throughout Nicaragua. Mrs. Chamorro's late husband, whose father started what is today Nicaragua's sole opposition newspaper, La Prensa, was shot down by assassins in January 1978. The slaying, believed to have been ordered by dictator Anastasio Somoza, ignited the popular revolt that brought the Sandinistas to power in July 1979. Mrs. Chamorro, who still publishes La Prensa, became a member of the junta that took over from Somoza but quit after nine months. She has bitter memories of what she considers the Sandinistas' betrayal of her husband's democratic goals and her own faith in the revolution. ``I'm not praising Somoza's government; it was horrible, but the threats that I've had from the Sandinistas _ I never thought they would repay me in that way,'' she said. Her pain as a widow, strong religous convictions and loyalty to Chamorro's memory _ she pays weekly visits to his grave to leave fresh flowers _ made her a symbol of dissatisfaction with the Sandinistas. But there have been many drawbacks. Even after months of campaigning, she stumbled over speeches and made baffling blunders. Last year, during a trip to Europe, she was asked about UNO's government program. ``It's a secret,'' she replied. The Sandinistas have tried to paint Mrs. Chamorro as an empty-headed figurehead; a pro-government newspaper runs a daily column where nearly every joke portrays her as slow-witted. Perhaps responding to this, Mrs. Chamorro told a rally early in the campaign, ``I am not a dummy.'' One of her top advisers is her eldest son, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, who returned from exile in Miami, where he had been a director of the U.S.-backed Contra rebels who tried to topple Ortega's government by force. The son feared his mother would be manipulated by vice presidential candidate Virgilio Godoy and top aide Alfredo Cesar, two strong-willed politicians. Mrs. Chamorro, the eldest daughter of a landowning family, was sent to U.S. finishing schools to learn English. ``I love math, I wanted to be a secretary, learn to type,'' Mrs. Chamorro said. With her father's death in 1948, she returned to the family home in the southern town of Rivas and married Chamorro. Her political awakening came after years of being a housewife and mother. On one of the various occasions Chamorro was imprisoned by Somoza, Mrs. Chamorro blew up at being kept in the dark. ``There had been something political and they threw him in jail,'' Mrs. Chamorro said. ``I asked Pedro what was going on. Then I told him, `Look, let's make a deal. From today on, you're going to tell me all that's happening, so I won't be caught unaware.''' She has played the role of presidential candidate with gusto. Hampered by a cast on her fractured knee, she was at ease being before crowds in her wheelchair under a sun tent in back of a pickup truck. Beaming smiles at peasants, Dona Violeta was familiar and neighborly, calling people ``papito'' and ``mamita.'' ``I try to help, to do good things for the country,'' Mrs. Chamorro said. ``I am what I am.''

DOC.HEAD: White House Urged to `Glow Slow' in Relations With Nicaragua
With AM-Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: The White House was urged Friday to ``go slow'' on normalizing relations with Nicaragua in the event of a Sandinista victory, with two prominent observers citing the possibility for fraud in Sunday's election. Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., and Allen Weinstein, president of the independent monitoring organization, the Center for Democracy, said Nicaragua is using a teletype system to transmit voting results that opens opportunities for the Sandinistas to engage in fraud. Weinstein also complained that the leftist Sandinista government has blocked delegations from Honduras and Costa Rica that were to join the center's observation efforts at the Sunday election. In addition, Weinstein said the government has barred observers from the center from going in and out of precincts to watch the vote count; has denied visas for additional staff members in the Center's Managua office and has denied visas for two dozen U.S. Democratic and Republican political leaders to join its monitoring operation. The center montored elections in Panama and the Philippines and has been in Nicaragua since April at the invitation of both the Sandinista government and the main political opposition group. Lugar was named by President Bush to head a bipartisan congressional team of election observers, but Managua denied them entry on the grounds that they represented a government that supports the opposition. Lugar said he has ``no idea'' whether the election process has been free and fair, and that he is ``not confident at all'' that the monitoring process will be adequate to insure that outcome. ``The chain of observation has been broken'' because there will not be monitoring of the transfer of voting results to teletype centers that will relay them to Managua, he said. ``The president's got to make some tough decisions on what occurs here,'' Lugar told reporters after he and Weinstein met with Vice President Dan Quayle. ``My advice would be to go slow in the process. We're going to have to sift out a good bit of what occurs.'' U.S. officials have said that if Ortega won a free and fair election, the Bush administration would consider normalizing relations with Managua, as long as other conditions are fulfilled as well. Those include cessation of exporting arms to leftist guerrillas in El Salvador and honoring human rights. Secretary of State James A. Baker III told a congressional committee Thursday he would require a ``sustained period'' of refraining from support for the Salvadoran rebels and would impose stiff conditions before agreeing to normalized relations. Quayle on Friday said the administration ``will be paying very close attention to the fairness of the election.'' He reiterated administration criticisms of Nicaragua for denying visas to Bush's observer delegation and other would-be observers. ``Obviously Daniel Ortega has been very selective on who he has allowed into the country,'' Quayle told reporters. ``If you have a viewpoint perhaps not entirely sympathetic to Daniel Ortega you are denied entry into Nicaragua.'' But he added, ``We will reserve judgment until all the information is in.'' Besides Weinstein's group, other observer teams allowed into Nicaragua include one headed by former President Carter, and two under the auspices of the United Nations and the Organization of American States. Meanwhile, the executive committee of the Inter-American Dialogue, a panel of prominent hemispheric leaders, called for normalization of relations if Sunday's elections are honest. If there is an undisputed Sandinista victory, the panel said the United States should assist in the repatriation and resettlement of the Contra rebels, lift the U.S. trade embargo against Nicaragua and join multilateral aid efforts. The group's co-director, former Ambassador Sol Linowitz, told a news conference that if the election is not free and fair, ``this calls for a wholly different approach.'' On Capitol Hill, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said the administration ``should find ways to recognize'' the new government as long as, if Ortega wins, he shows commitment to ``maintaining the spirit of a free election and permitting the normal, accepted political activities to continue in the country.''

DOC.HEAD: Fat Substitute Is Better, But Don't Pig Out On It
DOC.TEXT: First the good news: A creamy concoction that lowers the fat in frozen desserts is healthier than ice cream loaded with butterfat. But nutritionists warn that a fat substitute isn't a magic elixir. It won't let consumers obsessed with diet and weight-control indulge their sweet tooth free of worry. ``Don't get carried away thinking you can eat this stuff for lunch. Fat-free ice cream is not a substitute for apples or broccoli,'' said Bonnie Liebman, director of nutrition for the Center for Science in the Public Interest. ``I want to make sure that people don't go overboard thinking these new foods are nutritious,'' she said Friday. ``Basically, we're talking about junk food without the fat. It's less harmful than what it's replacing, but it's still junk food.'' Simplesse, made from egg whites and milk, was spooned out Thursday as the first fat substitute to win approval from the Food and Drug Administration. NutraSweet Co., a subsidiary of Monsanto Co., plans to market it in seven flavors of a frozen dessert called Simple Pleasures. A 4-ounce serving has 1 gram of fat and 120 calories, compared with 5 grams of fat and 130 calories in regular ice cream and 15 grams of fat and 250 calories in super-premium ice creams such as Haagen-Dazs. ``Simplesse means we can now enjoy all the rich, creamy taste of foods ... without the fat, without the calories, without the worry and without the guilt,'' said Robert Shapiro, NutraSweet's chairman and chief executive. But experts are concerned that imitation ice cream with less fat could encourage people to eat more portions or load up on other foods high in fat rather than food with vitamins, minerals and fiber. ``It sounds like the perfect answer, but it's not,'' said Marion Nestle, professor of nutrition at New York University and managing editor of the surgeon general's recent report on health and nutrition. ``Putting a substance in ice cream doesn't address the underlying issue: People don't eat enough fruits, vegetables and grain,'' she said. ``I don't think this is going to reduce America's dietary intake of fat. This isn't about nutrition. It's about improving the financial health of Monsanto.'' Financial experts predict Simplesse could fetch $500 million a year for Monsanto. It cannot be used in frying or baking, however, because it congeals at higher temperatures. Nutritionists say the new product might follow trends of artificial sweeteners. They were touted as a way to reduce sugar consumption, but sugar intake has increased to 132 pounds from 118 pounds per person per year since 1975, and four times as many sugar substitutes were consumed in the same time, according to the Center for Science in the Public Interest. ``Will fat substitutes be a substitute for fat, or will people just eat more double-scoop ice cream cones,'' said Lisa Lefferts, a staff scientist for the public watchdog group. ``It's one step in the right direction, but it's only a step,'' said Dr. Scott Grundy, director of the Center for Human Nutrition at the University of Texas. Fat tops every nutritionist's list of things to reduce in the diet. Americans now get an average of 37 percent of their calories from fats, and most experts recommend lowering that to no more than 30 percent. The surgeon general's report said its top priority is lowering the intake of saturated fat from such foods as hamburgers, steak, cheese, butter, pastries and french fries. Too much fat causes obesity, increases the risk of heart diseases and may increase the risk of breast and colon cancers, according to reports by the American Heart Association, the American Cancer Society and the National Cholesterol Education Program. ``Fat is the single worst thing about the average American's diet,'' said Ms. Liebman. ``For the average person, you couldn't possibly get too little fat if you tried.''

DOC.HEAD: Security Stepped Up Amid Fears for Sunday Rallies
DOC.TEXT: The Interior Ministry said Friday it was placing one-third more police on duty nationwide to keep order amid widespread fears of violence at weekend street protests, but organizers rejected an appeal to call off their ``peaceful February revolution.'' Teachers warned children to stay off Moscow streets on Sunday, when the rallies are scheduled, and doctors who normally have the day off were told to report to work, capital residents said. The official news agency Tass said meetings were held at Moscow businesses Friday to emphasize the need to prevent destabilization. Rumors of impending violence swept the country in advance of Sunday's planned pro-democracy rallies and counterdemonstrations, but spokesmen for the Interior Ministry and KGB security police said they had no reason to believe them. Some groups, however, responded by canceling rallies. The nationwide demonstrations grew out of the success of a protest Feb. 4, when tens of thousands of people paraded through Moscow demanding the Communist Party give up its grip on power. Three days later, led by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the party Central Committee voted to renounce its constitutional monopoly on power, paving the way for a multiparty democracy. Organizers Yuri Afanasyev and Gavriil Popov, both parliamentarians, said in leaflets distributed Friday on Moscow's Pushkin Square that Sunday's rallies for ``radical democratic changes'' are in line with public protests that have led to ousters of more than a dozen local party chiefs nationwide. ``A peaceful February revolution, started by a half-million-strong manifestation Feb. 4 in Moscow, is continuing,'' the leaflets said. Sunday is the anniversary of the February Revolution, the 1917 popular uprising that drove Czar Nicolas II from the throne. For many Russian progressives opposed to the Communist Party, it marks the short-lived triumph of Russian democracy, since the Bolsheviks seized power eight months later. Andrei Protsenko of the People's Front in the southern Russian city of Rostov-on-Don said his group had planned a rally Sunday but authorities outlawed it. The group decided to cancel because it feared government provocations and being blamed for any violence, he said. Leningrad People's Front leaders said they would not take part in an officially sanctioned rally Sunday because they also feared provocations, either from the government or right-wing groups dominated by Russian nationalists who favor orthodox Communism. In Azerbaijan, where a state of emergency was imposed following bloody ethnic attacks on Armenians and an army assault to dislodge nationalists from the capital of Baku, Yusis Samed Oglu of the People's Front said no rallies were planned out of fear that soldiers would use force. The Soviet Interior Ministry, which includes riot squads and police, has canceled days off Sunday for many of its workers and 17,000 of them will be on duty in Moscow alone, said spokesman Arkady Bronin. He estimated that nationwide, one-third more Interior Ministry workers than normal will be on duty. He did not have the total figure. The government launched a massive campaign to head off trouble. State-run media throughout the day repeated a Communist Party appeal for Soviets to avoid ``chaos'' during the rallies, and two members of the ruling Politburo spoke out. In a special prime-time TV broadcast, Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov said the government understood the people's frustrations because ``they can't live normally,'' but emphasized law and order were vital. ``We are not only concerned but we are taking, and will take, very strict measures to keep order in the limits of the law. Everyone must answer in accordance with the law,'' Ryzhkov said. The Cabinet that Ryzhkov heads, the Council of Ministers, issued an order instructing police and governing bodies to prevent ``extremist and criminal elements'' from provoking disorder. Politburo member Alexander N. Yakovlev told the government daily Izvestia that rallies were not the way to press for change. ``To elect authority on the streets is not democracy but arbitrary rule, ignoring the people,'' Yakovlev said. Afanasyev told a news conference the Sunday rally in Moscow was designed to broaden democracy. The organizers rejected an appeal from creative labor unions that urged the rallies be canceled because of potential danger. ``The situation is very tense, and any skirmish, any street incident might lead to unpredictable consequences,'' the unions said in a statement read at a news conference by Elem Klimov, head of the Filmworkers Union. The statement said citizens should voice their opinions not at rallies but at the polls. Elections to republican Supreme Soviet legislatures are scheduled March 4 in the Russian federation, the Ukraine and Byelorussia, and will be held Saturday in Lithuania. Officials of Moscow's Frunze district told administrators of one school to warn children to stay off the streets Sunday, and a doctor at Moscow's Children's Clinic No. 3 said all staff were told to report to work Sunday, residents said. ``Chronicle,'' a newsletter posted in a Moscow pedestrian underpass, said the KGB was bracing for an attack Sunday on its headquarters. Asked about the report, KGB spokesman Sergei Zakatov laughed. He said he was aware of rumors of trouble but that ``it's too early to speak about a danger to state security because it depends upon the streets on Sunday.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Secretary Calls Unflattering Report `Hypercritical'
DOC.TEXT: Air Force Secretary Donald Rice said in a letter released Friday that a congressional report contending his service had grossly understated the costs of major weapons was ``hypercritical and inflammatory.'' ``The ... report offers a narrow, CPA's view of the information needed for defense decision-making that has limited relationship to the real problems of defense management,'' Rice said in an angry three-page letter to the head of the General Accounting Office, Charles Bowsher. For his part, Bowsher told a Senate committee Friday that the Air Force's accounting system fails to provide accurate cost data for almost 80 percent of its weapons, inventory and equipment. ``We roughly estimate that equipment and missiles are misstated by billions of dollars and aircraft and inventories are misstated by tens of billions of dollars,'' he told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee. Bowsher testified as the GAO released its 109-page audit of the Air Force's accounting and financial management system. The Associated Press and other news organizations had reported the GAO's findings Thursday based on a draft of the report. Testifying at the hearing, called after the draft became public, Bowsher said the Air Force has resources totaling about $275 billion and receives about $90 billion in annual appropriations. The GAO concluded that the Air Force had understated the cost of the B-1 bomber by $7.1 billion, the F-15 fighter by $6.8 billion and the F-16 fighter by $6.3 billion. In addition, the Air Force made billions of dollars in adjustments that could not be explained or supported by the service officials, the GAO said. In one instance, the Air Force tinkered with its accounts when the balance for the Space Systems Division differed from other records by $2.4 billion, making the change without determining why the records did not agree. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio and chairman of the panel, noted that the GAO chose to audit the Air Force because it is the only armed service to develop financial statements that are in accord with accounting practices elsewhere in the federal government. ``If the Air Force does indeed have the best financial management system among the services, then the audit results are an indictment of the financial management systems of the whole Department of Defense _ the Army, the Navy, as well as the Air Force,'' Glenn said. The Ohio Democrat also used the hearing to question Bowsher about Rice's previously unreleased Feb. 15 letter to him. Although the Defense Department, in its official response to the GAO report, concurred wholly or in part with all 26 recommendations in the audit, Rice was highly critical of the report. The Air Force secretary wrote that the service volunteered to work with the GAO on the audit and ``in return, the GAO writes a hypercritical and inflammatory report.'' ``I urge you to send your team back to the drawing board with instructions to prepare a report that fairly evaluates the pros and cons of GAO's approach and which uses Air Force data only as a test case for a new approach,'' Rice said. Asked about Rice's complaint, Bowsher said his agency audited the Air Force using a financial system for federal agencies agreed upon in 1986 by himself, former Treasury Secretary James Baker III and former White House budget director James Miller. Rice also argued in his letter that even if the type of financial information from standard accounting systems were useful, ``Why do I need it at a penny-wise level of accuracy that a CPA would judge `auditable?''' Bowsher responded: ``We're not talking about penny accuracy. We're talking about billions of dollars of errors.''

DOC.HEAD: Accord Reached in Lawsuit Over Art Museum Funds
DOC.TEXT: One group of Occidental Petroleum Corp. shareholders has settled a dispute with the company over the use of $86 million in Occidental funds to build Chairman Armand Hammer's art museum. But another group will oppose the proposed settlement of a class-action lawsuit when it comes up for approval by Vice Chancellor Maurice Hartnett of the Delaware Chancery Court on April 4. The shareholders have opposed Occidental's support for the Armand Hammer Museum and Cultural Center, which is being built beside the company's headquarters in the Westwood section of Los Angeles. Hammer, 91, decided in 1987 to build the museum after a falling out with the Los Angeles County Museum of Art over its plans for his collection. The proposed deal allows Occidental to spend $86 million to build and run the museum. But it limits other spending on the project, puts some limits on Occidental contributions to Hammer-related charities, grants $1.4 million in fees to the plaintiffs' lawyers and ensures that Occidental's name as well as Hammer's will appear on the museum. ``We don't think it is fair, reasonable or adequate,'' said Deputy California Attorney General Susan Henrichsen, the attorney for California's huge public employee pension fund, part of the shareholders group that plans to object to the deal. That group filed a separate, similar class-action lawsuit last year to force Occidental to sell the museum.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department to Appeal Ruling Supporting Flag-Burning
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said Friday it will ask the Supreme Court to overrule a federal judge's finding that a law banning flag burning is unconstitutional. Spokesman David Runkel said Justice Department attorneys would file a notice in Seattle federal court of the government's plan to appeal Wednesday's ruling by U.S. District Judge Barbara Rothstein. The judge dismissed criminal charges against four people arising from a flag-burning incident, saying the law passed last year by Congress violated constitutional free-speech protections. Congress enacted the law after the high court last year threw out a similar Texas statute on the same constitutional ground. President Bush proposed a constitutional amendment to ban flag burning but allowed the bill passed by Congress without signing it. Despite the administration's preference for a constitutional amendment, the Justice Department has a duty to defend the law, Runkel said. David Cole, an attorney for the Center for Constitutional Rights who argued the Seattle case, predicted the high court would not overturn Rothstein's ruling. ``I believe the Supreme Court will reaffirm that the principles for which the flag stands includes the freedom to dissent and will therefore uphold Judge Rothstein's ruling,'' Cole said. The law provides for direct appeal of rulings on its constitutionality from federal district court to the Supreme Court. The prospect of another Supreme Court ruling has renewed calls in Congress for a constitutional amendment to ban flag burning. ``This decision vindicates those of us who wanted to fix this thing and have the states take up the question of protecting the flag properly,'' said Rep. Chuck Douglas, R-N.H. ``The way to do it is by a constitutional amendment, and there is nothing short of that.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Declares Red Cross Month
DOC.TEXT: President Bush went to the national headquarters of the Red Cross on Friday to sign an annual proclamation designating March as American Red Cross month. In a speech to Red Cross employees, he noted that the service organization had an especially busy year. He praised it for mobilizing disaster relief for Hurricane Hugo and the Northern California earthquake last fall and for providing emergency food, clothing and medical aid to new refugees in Eastern Europe. Bush called the Red Cross ``a star of hope across the globe'' that has cast ``a glow of love and caring.'' ``For 109 years that star has shone anytime there has been a need, anywhere there is a need. And today, it dazzles still,'' he said. And, on a more lighthearted note, Bush told his audience: ``What a pleasure to address the Red Cross. One reason is that if my speech is a disaster, relief is close at hand.''

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Says Any Settlement Would Not Affect Other Claims
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said Friday that any settlement with Exxon Corp. over possible criminal charges from the Alaskan oil spill won't compromise civil claims by the state or its citizens. Spokesman David Runkel delivered a statement in response to criticism from environmentalists and Alaskan officials that the department was trying to force the state to go along with what it considered an inadequate settlement of the federal case. ``There are a number of complicated legal and factual issues involved in this matter and we are puzzled by comments which have been reported by persons who appear to have little grasp of what is actually involved in this case,'' Runkel said. An early draft of a possible settlement called for Exxon to pay up to $500 million to finance a natural resources restoration program over the next seven years, according to sources familiar with the negotiations. But U.S. government sources, speaking on the condition of anonymity, stressed that there was no agreement with Exxon, although discussions were continuing with attorneys for the oil company. The department is seeking an agreement under which Exxon would be assessed for additional cleanup costs if expenses exceed those in the original estimate, said one source. A resolution in the discussions, which have been going on for several months, is expected soon, according to the environmentalists and the state officials. A federal grand jury is meeting in Alaska in connection with the investigation by the department's environmental crimes section. The grand jury could conceivably return an indictment if the Justice Department and Exxon do not reach a settlement of the case. Federal criminal laws in oil spill cases provide for fines up to double the cost of a cleanup. Exxon has spent nearly $2 billion to clean up the oil spill, according to Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner. On Thursday, Alaska's attorney general, Douglas Baily, accused the Justice Department of trying to force the state to make a ``hasty endorsement'' of the draft proposal. ``Under the proposed agreement, the federal government would abandon its commitment to Alaska to assist with its civil claims against Exxon,'' Baily told reporters. ``We are being asked to accept a pig in a poke. ... And that pig smells awfully bad.'' Similar criticism was voiced by representatives of environmental groups, who charged that the Justice Department was prepared to let Exxon off easy for the massive oil spill when the tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground in Prince William Sound. Runkel declined to discuss the specifics of the negotiations, beyond stating, ``There have been discussions with attorneys for Exxon as to the admissable parameters of appropriate penalties and appropriate corrective measures in the even of a guilty plea to any criminal charges that might be brought.'' ``No actions taken by the federal government in the enforcement of federal criminal laws will compromise the state of Alaska's ability to pursue violations of its criminal laws or appropriate civil remedies,'' Runkel said. He also rebutted criticism that any settlement would impair the ability of ``environemntal groups and Alaska residents to pursue appropriate civil claims.''

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Says PLO Accepts Idea for Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: PLO chief Yasser Arafat said in a letter released Friday by a Jewish group that his organization would support peace talks with Israel involving Palestinians from the occupied territories. It was believed to be the first time Arafat has approved of such talks. In his letter, Arafat also repeated the PLO's demand for a separate state and for full participation in all peace talks, which Israel rejects. ``The PLO once more leaned over backward and approved the idea of a dialogue between representatives of the Israeli government and representatives of the Palestinian people in the occupied territories and the diaspora,'' said the letter, which was sent to a meeting of Jewish activists called the Special Emergency World Jewish Leadership Peace Conference. Rita Hauser, an attorney and the head of the center's American branch, said the six-page letter was received ``through a circuitous manner, via fax'' on Thursday, but that conference leaders chose not to publicize it until Friday. Avi Pazner, an aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said the letter would not influence Israel. ``We are absolutely not interested in what Arafat's position is,'' he said. ``We want to go forward with the peace process, not with Arafat, but without Arafat.'' Pazner accused the Palestine Liberation Organization of trying to ``insert itself through the side door'' to gain entry to peace talks while Foreign Minister Moshe Arens was out of the country. Arens, whose right-wing Likud bloc has ruled out PLO participation in talks, met in Washington on Friday with Secretary of State James A. Baker III to discuss ways of restarting the Middle East peace process. Baker has been trying for months to arrange a three-way meeting with Arens and Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid to decide on the composition of a Palestinian delegation to preliminary peace talks. Friday's meeting with Arens failed to accomplish that, Baker said. In his letter, Arafat said peace talks would have to be part of a process ``aimed at a comprehensive and final settlement'' of the Palestinian situation and that the agenda ``could cover all the conceptual ingredients of that process.'' ``We remain deeply convinced that the only real security guarantee for Isael lies in a peaceful settlement based on the termination of the Israeli occupation of the Palestinian and Arab territories and the acceptance of the two-state principle,'' he wrote. Arafat noted that Israelis have been fearful of dealing with the PLO and said Palestinians have similar concerns. ``Watching the convoluted maneuvers the Israeli government has engaged in and the massive obstacles with which it had littered the path to peace, the Palestinian people are not filled with confidence in the good intentions of the Israeli leaders,'' Arafat wrote. ``To them, the only guarantee of their own security and their political future lies in the full participation of the PLO in all stages of the peace process,'' he said. The preliminary talks Baker has tried to set up would be to clear the way for Israeli-proposed elections in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The elections would give limited automony to the 1.7 million Palestinian residents of the territories. Efforts to get the talks under way have been stalled by Israel's concerns over the makeup of the Palestinian delegation and the agenda. The Israeli government wants the agenda limited to the election plan. Pressure has been increasing on Likud to accept some compromises to get the talks started. The left-leaning Labor Party demanded the Cabinet agree to a Palestinian delegation that would include some deportees. Likud opposes having deportees in the delegation. On Thursday, Likud threatened to leave the coalition government if the compromise was not accepted. The letter was dated Feb. 17 and came from Tunis, where the PLO is based. There was no explanation for the delay in its transmission to Jerusalem. Ms. Hauser met with Arafat in Stockholm in December 1988. Shortly after that, Arafat made a series of historic announcements in which he recognized Israel's right to exist and renounced terrorism. Those statements led to the opening of a dialogue between the United States and the PLO.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister to Form New Government
DOC.TEXT: Caretaker Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson said Friday he is forming a new government to end Sweden's political crisis and quell the labor strife and inflation that have beset the economy. Carlsson said the government would consider opening Sweden to workers from the Soviet Baltic republics to alleviate an inflation-boosting labor shortage and would seek to mediate labor disputes. Carlsson's Cabinet resigned Feb. 14 when the legislature rejected his emergency economic program. He was asked to form a new government Thursday after the centrist opposition parties failed to unite on a common policy. Thage G. Peterson, the speaker of parliament, informed the 349-member Riksdag that he had asked Carlsson to lead another Cabinet. ``I hereby propose to parliament to appoint as prime minister Ingvar Carlsson, who intends to form a government of members of the Social Democratic Party,'' Peterson said, immediately adjourning the session. A vote on the new Carlsson government was set for Monday, with the small Communist Party expected to support it and the Center Party to abstain. The new Cabinet would be installed Tuesday, Swedish radio said. The program Carlsson outlined shifted the government's attack on economic problems from greater regulation to liberalizing the labor market. ``This is a proposal of measures of how we shall conduct a sound economic policy, ... take responsibility for the nation and quickly solve the crisis,'' Carlsson said. The platform dropped a controversial proposal for a two-year wage freeze and for compulsory arbitration of labor disputes, while it maintained a price freeze for an indefinite period. It included a proposal to appoint a state mediator whose task would be to dampen wage demands in a national agreement to be negotiated this spring. The government also would tighten rules to prevent wildcat strikes. The political crisis began in January with a series of labor conflicts that closed all banks for three weeks and threatened to paralyze public services and transport in major cities. The government said the labor strife was symptomatic of pressures that had caused a wage-cost spiral. Some economists have blamed Sweden's full employment policy, which has limited unemployment to about 1 percent, for fueling inflation approaching 9 percent, or twice that of most of its trading partners. To offset the labor shortage, Carlsson said the government will investigate whether young workers from the Soviet Baltic republics will be given the opportunity to work in Sweden. It also would give Swedes the choice of working two years beyond the retirement age at 65, and working through two of the six-weeks vacation to which each Swedish worker will entitled by law as of next year.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Army Protests in Lithuania, Moldavia
With AM-Soviet-Rallies
DOC.TEXT: About 30 young men turned in their military identification cards in the Lithuanian capital Friday and in Moldavia youths burned a military uniform in protests on Soviet Army Day. The demonstrations reflected the anger at the Soviet military that has surfaced in outlying republics that were incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940. The national holiday marks the 72nd anniversary of the Red Army. In Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, the youths turned in their I.D. cards to a nationalist group, saying they refused to serve in an ``occupation army.'' Lithuania is trying to secede from the Soviet Union and on Saturday holds parliamentary elections aimed at opening negotiations with the Kremlin for full independence. The young men filled out declarations in Lithuanian and Russian saying the 1940 Red Army occupation of their country was illegal and therefore under the Geneva convention they had no obligation to serve. The demonstration was peaceful, with no interference by police. There were about 150 onlookers. ``What do we need an army for?'' asked one of the young men, Janavicus Vidmant. The official Soviet news agency Tass said an official Soviet Army Day celebration in the Moldavian capital, Kishinev, was accompanied by an unsanctioned protest. A group of ``extremist-bent youth'' carried anti-Soviet signs and chanted anti-army slogans in a march through the city, Tass said. They picketed a military garrison and then went to Kishinev's central square, where they burned an officer's uniform and military identification cards, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Crown Prince Celebrates Birthday Bash, But Still No Bride
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of friends attended a birthday bash for Japan's Crown Prince Naruhito, who turned 30 on Friday, but one guest was prominently absent _ a royal bride. According to the prince, there might not be one by his side for some time to come. ``I may have met my ideal woman, and I may not have,'' he coyly told reporters. ``That's all I have to say.'' Four years ago, Naruhito, the eldest son of Emperor Akihito and first in line to the Chrysanthemum Throne, said he hoped to marry by the age of 30. The comment has haunted him since, and has created intense competition in Japan's media to be the first to name the bride. The 30 deadline also put pressure on palace officials, who have said they would like to see the prince wed as soon as possible, but who are having trouble helping him find a suitable mate. Even so, in a pre-birthday news conference earlier this week, the prince said he doesn't feel rushed. ``I know how to operate a washing machine without getting covered in bubbles, and I know how to handle an iron,'' said Naruhito, who is preparing to set up his own residence at the Akasaka Palace in downtown Tokyo. Aside from two years at Oxford, the prince has lived most of his life with his parents. ``I will be going about it at my own pace, without hurry,'' he said, adding, ``I don't feel guilty (about being single).'' Excerpts of the conference were broadcast Friday on major TV networks and carried in most newspapers. Foreign reporters were not invited. Speculation about Naruhito intensified when it was announced in August that his younger brother, Prince Aya, had already proposed to Kiko Kawashima, a 23-year-old graduate student with no royal background. Many palace conservatives resisted the idea of Aya, 24, marrying before his brother, and palace watchers wondered if Naruhito was not going to surprise them with an announcement of his own. But with Aya's wedding scheduled for late June, and a series of coronation celebrations planned for November, it is now believed that Naruhito won't be able to marry until sometime next year. During the news conference, Naruhito stressed he wants to choose his own spouse, although his wedding won't be an entirely private matter. Under Japanese law, male members of the royal family must receive government approval before getting married, and palace officials generally make up a list of princess candidates. Noble descent was a must until Naruhito's father wed Empress Michiko, the daughter of a wealthy businessman. ``It is not a question of what her position is, but rather what kind of person she is,'' Naruhito said when asked if he, too, would consider a commoner. ``Her ability to adapt to the palace does not depend on her background.'' Naruhito said his position has made the search difficult, as he is not able to pick and choose freely. The demands of life in Japan's often secluded, tradition-conscious palace are also enough to scare many women away. The prince said he has not lost hope. ``I want to decide for myself ... I am not at all pessimistic.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Business Group Heading to Panama
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met Friday with a group of U.S. business executives who are heading to Panama to help revive the Central American nation's wrecked economy. The group, which leaves for Panama City on Saturday, hopes to develop contacts between U.S. and Panamanian business interests in a variety of areas. Panama is suffering from years of corruption under deposed dictator Gen Manuel Antonio Noriega, along with two years of U.S. economic sanctions against the Noriega government and the devastation of the U.S. invasion last Dec. 20. ``It looks to us like we can get that place going in a hurry,'' said Fred Zeder, president of the Overseas Private Investment Corp. ``We're looking forward to a quick start-up down there.'' OPIC is federally-owned agency that sells insurance to Americans investing overseas. Zeder is leading a group of 26 business people who want to do business in Panama. Among them are representatives of American Express, AT&T and GTE Spacenet International. Bush's former chief of staff, Craig Fuller, is going as a representative of Strategic Resources Corp., which wants to set up an investment fund. Fuller said the Panamanians told the group that among their chief economic needs are the port of Panama City where equipment is needed for rebuilding, the health care system that was gutted by Noriega's regime, and telecommunications. He said the Japanese and South Koreans already have been laying groundwork for business opportunities there, so American firms will face competition. ``We're looking for new opportunities, growth opportunities,'' Lamont Godwin of American Express told reporters outside the White House after their closed meeting with Bush. ``We want to know what has changed'' since the ouster of Noriega, he said. Zeder said Panama's economy is ``like an automobile that's been left out to rust,'' during the Noriega years.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli, U.S. Officials Still Apart on Formula For Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens failed Friday to arrange an opening round of Mideast peace negotiations, but left the impression of eventual success. ``It was a very constructive and hopefully a very productive meeting,'' Baker said after talking to Arens for 90 minutes. Arens agreed, saying ``we had a good, constructive conversation.'' He then flew to New York, planning to go on to Jerusalem on Saturday at the end of the Jewish Sabbath. He will brief Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and the Israeli Cabinet on Sunday. On Monday, Arens is due in Warsaw to oversee a resumption of diplomatic relations with Poland after a 23-year lapse. The positive statements by Baker and Arens indicated they had made some headway to negotiations, with the next move up to the Israeli Cabinet. But when Baker was asked if he had been able to set up a three-way meeting with Arens and Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid _ the first step in a drawn-out U.S. plan for negotiations _ he replied: ``No, we have not agreed today on the timetable for a trilateral meeting.'' Baker told Arens about his talks in Moscow with Soviet officials on two issues of keen interest to Jerusalem: rising anti-Semitism and Soviet unwillingness to implement an agreement for direct Aeroflot flights of Jewish refugees to Tel Aviv. Arens said he had thanked Baker for his efforts. Their meeting was held against a backdrop of U.S. impatience and mounting political pressure in Israel for concessions. Israel's majority Likud Party, of which Arens is a senior member, is under pressure from the minority Labor Party to accept an Egyptian formula for starting the talks or face dissolution of the coalition government in Jerusalem. The chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasser Arafat, said, meanwhile, in a letter released by peace activists in Jerusalem that he had approved the composition of a Palestinian delegation that would include delegates from the West Bank and Gaza. Baker has tried for months to arrange a three-way session here with Arens and Abdel-Meguid. It would be followed by talks between Israel and Palestinians in Cairo.

DOC.HEAD: Bushes `Saddened' Over Duarte Death
DOC.TEXT: Former Salvadoran President Jose Napoleon Duarte brought ``a message of hope'' to all of Latin America, the White House said in a statement Friday. Durate died Friday after a two-year battle with cancer. ``President Duarte was the father of Salvadoran democracy, a dedicated servant to the people of El Salvador and a firm friend of the United States,'' the White House said in a statement issued by presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``His wisdom and dedication to the growth of democracy in Central America will be long remembered. President Duarte was also a strong supporter and exponent on behalf of human rights and social justice and has left a strong legacy in this area.'' President Bush and his wife, Barbara, ``are deeply saddened'' by the death, the statement said, noting that Bush and Duarte ``enjoyed a warm, close working relationship.'' Bush visited Duarte last fall when the former Salvadoran president was at Walter Reed Army Medical Center here for treatment. Deputy White House press secretary Alixe Glen said it had not been decided who would represent the United States at Duarte's funeral. Bush admired ``the courage he (Duarte) exhibited in building the foundation of democracy in El Salvador and the message of hope he brought to all of Central America,'' the statement said. ``The American people join the people of El Salvador in mourning their loss.''

DOC.HEAD: Bushes Attend Funeral of Staff Kin
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, on Friday attended the funeral of the father-in-law of Susan Porter Rose, the first lady's chief of staff. A. Chapman Rose died Saturday at the age of 83. The funeral was held a block from the White House, at St. John's Church across the street from Lafayette Park. As they emerged from the service, the Bushes were applauded by several dozen onlookers. One man carrying a sign criticizing Bush on human rights yelled repeatedly, ``Love thy neighbor.'' The president did not seem to notice.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Says Soviets Can Buy Another Million Tons of Wheat
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union will be able to buy an additional 1 million metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Undersecretary Richard T. Crowder said the wheat will be made available under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. The new amount is in addition to 12,950 tons Moscow had remaining under a previous allocation announced Dec. 19. The Soviet Union is committed to buy minimum quantities of wheat and corn under a long-term grain agreement, which began its seventh year on Oct. 1 and will expire Dec. 31. Moscow has bought nearly 2.8 million tons of wheat for delivery in 1989-90, according to USDA records. Nearly 11 million tons of corn have been sold for 1989-90 delivery, along with soybeans and soybean meal. In 1988-89, the sixth under the agreement, the Soviet Union bought about 5.4 million tons of wheat and more than 16.3 million tons of corn, plus soybeans, soybean meal and grain sorghums. A metric tons is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The EEP arrangement allows private exporters to sell wheat and other designated commodities to specified countries at reduced prices in order to meet foreign competition. The exporters then collect free government surpluses of grain or other products as bonuses, or subsidies. Since EEP began in 1985, more than $2.69 billion in subsidies has been paid to exporters to ship a variety of commodities to overseas customers. As of Feb. 22, sales totaled 92.7 million tons of grain, including 69.7 million tons of wheat. The Soviet Union, as the largest EEP beneficiary, has bought more than 20.3 million tons of wheat. China is second at 14.2 million tons of wheat.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Announces Pizza Topping Recall Because of Broken Glass
DOC.TEXT: A Hutchinson, Kan., company has issued a nationwide recall of approximately 106,000 pounds of frozen pork pizza topping because it may contain light bulb fragments, the Agriculture Department said Friday. The product was made by Doskocil Sausage Co. and was sold exclusively to food service facilities, including restaurants and carryouts, the department said. It is not available in packages sold directly to consumers. Products include ``Leprino Foods Pizza Topping Mix'' with the code NOV13891131, and ``Pizzano Cooked Italian Style Pizza Topping'' with a code of NOV13891548 or NOV20891548. Lester M. Crawford, administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service said both products were shipped in cartons containing five-pound bags. The establishment number 623 was stamped on the cartons and bags. Crawford said distributors and food service operators who have any of the suspected products should return them to suppliers. The company began the recall after receiving four complaints, one on Jan. 15 and three on Feb. 13, about broken glass in pizza topping, Crawford said. There have been no reports of contaminated products being consumed. Jim Greene, an agency spokesman, said the products went to some 60 distributors ``from California to Pennsylvania'' but that he didn't have any further details on locations. Consumers with questions about the recall were advised to call the USDA's toll-free meat and poultry hotline at 1-800-535-4555, which operates from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. EST Monday through Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Sutherland Daughters to Meet U.N. Chief, Present Petitions
Retransmitting to fix cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: The daughters of Thomas Sutherland, who has been held hostage in Lebanon since 1985, will take petitions signed by 18,000 Colorado residents to the United Nations on Monday. Kit and Joan Sutherland have been told they can meet for about 15 minutes Monday with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, said Anne Stoddard, spokeswoman for the U.S. mission at the United Nations. The petitions call on the international body to intervene in seeking the release of Sutherland, who was on leave from Colorado State University and acting as dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut when he was abducted by gunmen on June 9, 1985. ``We're very excited about it,'' Kit Sutherland said of the New York visit. ``We're looking forward to showing the U.N. that there are still people who are concerned.'' Wil Huett, a radio talk-show host who led the petition drive, said it had yielded 18,015 signatures. The petition was drafted by University of Denver International Law School professor Ved Nanda and some of his students. Nanda said he expects the document to be forwarded to the U.N.'s Commission on Human Rights, which is meeting in Geneva. The petition may serve to ``remind'' Perez de Cuellar of a promise to use his office in an effort to free hostages held in Lebanon, Nanda said. Most of the 18 Westerners held hostage in Lebanon are believed in the hands of extremist Shiite Moslem factions. Eight are Americans; the longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was abducted March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Observer Group in Nicaragua Relegated to `Outsider' Role
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
LaserPhoto MGA7
DOC.TEXT: The red carpet is out for sympathetic celebrities invited to observe the general election, but on Friday observers from the most conservative group still were waiting for visas from the leftist Sandinista government. The Washington-based Center for Democracy, which acted for the U.S. Senate in observing the 1986 Philippines elections and the 1989 Panamanian elections, says it has become an outsider in the monitoring process. Insiders include people like actor Ed Asner, a longtime critic of U.S. policy in Central America, and British singer Billy Bragg, whose latest album is ``Workers' Paradise.'' ``It would be our job, if we were satisfied with the results and the procedure, to go back and do our best to counteract the negative media that continually occurs vis-a-vis the Sandinistas in the United States,'' Asner said as he trotted toward a bus in the sweltering afternoon heat. Asner, a former president of the Screen Actors' Guild; Bragg, singer Jackson Browne and actor Robert Foxworth had just finished an hourlong meeting with Vice President Sergio Ramirez and were late for a meeting with the interior minister. But Allen Weinstein, president of the Center for Democracy, could only gaze out his window across the street to the Foreign Ministry, which hasn't issued visas for 25 Americans on the center's team. The center learned Thursday that visas for three Costa Rican congressmen in its delegation had been denied. ``There they are, right across the street. But they won't answer our calls, they won't answer our letters,'' Weinstein said. Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Mercedes Borge said the ministry didn't know anything about the visas and referred inquiries to the Supreme Electoral Council. The council spokesman was not available for comment, a secretary said by telephone. Weinstein has issued a statement saying the ``integrity of the entire international observer process'' has been jeopardized by the visa problems and electoral council refusal to let his observers watch the votes being counted. He had been hoping to field 100 observers but will end up with fewer than 30. Sunday's election will still be one of the most closely watched in history, with one observer for about every 850 voters. Every morning, hordes of observers spill out of the doors of the Intercontinental Hotel, a pyramid-shaped Managua landmark. They clog restaurants and roam the aisles of the dollar store, virtually the only place in Nicaragua for supermarket-style provisions, Ray-Bans and Reeboks. The Sandinistas expect a favorable verdict from voters and count on the observers to give the election a credibility the Bush administration cannot ignore. President Daniel Ortega, whose main challenger is publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, says he will propose a political truce with the opposition and the United States, which has financed the Contra rebels and kept an economic embargo on Nicaragua. The government has worked closely with the three main observer missions: the United Nations, the Organization of American States and former President Jimmy Carter's Council of Freely Elected Heads of Government. The three will deploy more than 700 people in all and they will issue the definitive verdicts on the election. All three groups have said they believe conditions exist for a free and fair election. The Center for Democracy was one of the first groups invited here and has been monitoring the campaign since last fall, as have the three major observer groups. But things went sour when it blamed the Sandinistas for a riot after an opposition rally in Masatepe in December in which one person died and scores were injured. The center issued a critical report, then held a news conference during a Central American summit in Costa Rica. Weinstein flew back to Washington and told reporters there Friday the White House should go slow on normalizing relations with Nicaragua in the event of a Sandinista victory. Among his charges: that Nicaragua is using a teletype system to transmit voting results that opens opportunities for Sandinista fraud. The vast majority of the smaller observer groups are either critical of U.S. policy in Central America, sympathetic to the Sandinistas or both. The U.S.-based Veterans for Peace, for example, will have 59 observers, more than Carter's group. Accredited observers also are here from pro-Sandinista solidarity groups, leftist parties, labor groups and pacifist organizations. Other observers include those from national election tribunals in Central and South America, universities, embassies, parliaments and religious organizations. The Supreme Electoral Council has accredited 2,000 observers for the elections; 1.75 million people are registered to vote.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Other Parties Running In Nicaraguan Elections
With AM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Eight parties other than the ruling Sandinista party and the United National Opposition are running in Sunday's elections. They may not gather many votes, but the constitution guarantees one seat in the National Assembly to each defeated party with a presidential ticket. Here is a brief look at the eight: _Social Christian Party: Probably the third-place finisher. The Social Christians are supported by Eden Pastora, better known as Commander Zero, a former Sandinista guerrilla leader who switched sides and fought with the Contra rebels. Yatama, the native Indian organization, recently gave its support to UNO's presidential ticket but remained allied with the Social Christians in other races. Candidates: Erick Ramirez, president; Rina de Taboada, vice president. _Revolutionary Unity Movement: The movement's presidential candidate, Moises Hassan, is the son of a Palestinian immigrant and is a graduate in nuclear physics from North Carolina State University. Hassan has been mayor of Managua, construction minister and vice minister of the interior under the Sandinistas. The ultraleft Hassan now claims the Sandinistas betrayed the true revolution. _Social Conservatism Party: The party's leader and presidential candidate, Fernando Aguero, was once the foremost opposition figure. He was discredited after signing a power-sharing pact with dictator Anastasio Somoza following a massacre during an anti-Somoza demonstration he organized. _Central American Unionist Party: The party believes in regional unification because of a common historical past shared by Nicaragua and other Central American countries. Its presidential candidate is Blanca Rojas, a university professor. _Democrat Conservative Party: The party president, Clemente Guido, is a vice president of the National Assembly and the recognized leader of the Conservative bloc, made up of several splinter parties. The party is running Eduardo Molina as its presidential candidate. _Marxist-Leninist Popular Action Movement: A small party that still advocates classic Marxism-Leninism. Its presidential candidate is Isidro Tellez. _Revolutionary Workers' Party: Another small, far-left party. Presidential candidate: Bonifacio Miranda. _National Unity Liberal Party: A splinter group from the Independent Liberals of UNO's vice presidential candidate Virgilio Godoy. Presidential candidate: Rodolfo Robelo.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Resolution Splinters American Bar Association
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT reference to D'Alemberte to he, sted she. Pick up 5th graf, `Treasurer Joseph ...'
DOC.TEXT: A pro-choice resolution approved by the American Bar Association's governing body is dividing the lawyers group and testing its members' capacity for professional detachment. Despite opposition from the ABA's president, president-elect, secretary and treasurer, its governing body last week approved a resolution endorsing a woman's right to an abortion. ``Some of the very best people in the ABA are in agony over this resolution, and I'm sorry for that,'' said Sandy D'Alemberte, a supporter of the measure who probably will become ABA president next year. Among the ``best people'' he referred to are: _ Treasurer Joseph Nolan, who resigned from the Chicago-based ABA, saying he could not reconcile his Roman Catholic beliefs with a resolution ``that advocates abortion on demand.'' _ Secretary Tony Palermo, who said he will seek the resolution's repeal at the ABA convention in August on the grounds that abortion is a personal and political issue, not a legal one. If he fails, he may quit. _ President-elect John Curtin, who says he will not sign his name to ABA friend-of-the-court briefs in abortion cases. _ Texas Bar Association President Darrell Jordan, who hints that his and other state groups might pull back from the ABA. _ Pennsylvania Bar Association President-elect John Carpenter, who said Friday he had resigned from the national group's governing body, the ABA House of Delegates. The resolution also was criticized by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who contended that it raises questions about the ABA's ability to honestly render advisory opinions on the professional competence of judicial nominees. The resolution says the ABA ``opposes legislation or other government action that interferes with the confidential relationship between a pregnant woman and her physician or with the decision to terminate the pregnancy at any time before the fetus is capable of independent life.'' As a result of the resolution's passage, ABA groups will be able to file briefs in abortion cases and work against proposed state laws that would restrict abortion rights. But Richard Collins, an ABA spokesman, said abortion has not yet been added to the association's list of legislative priorities. So far, the resolution's greatest impact has been on the ABA itself. ``Even lawyers don't like contentiousness among themselves,'' said Estelle Rogers, who helped engineer the resolution's passage. At least 40 members of the 365,000-member organization have resigned, and this week Palermo predicted ``a massive withdrawal'' of lawyers if the resolution is not repealed. Many ABA members have written the national office to ask what the resolution says and what it means. When they find out, Nolan predicted, many will demand change or follow him out the door. ``It looks like a snowball,'' he said. This week, law professors at the University of Notre Dame in South Bend, Ind., voted to end the school's payment of their $1,900 ABA dues to protest the resolution. Law Dean David Link said the decision among professors at the Roman Catholic university was primarily based on a professional, not a religious, objection. ``We're not saying they should have taken the opposite position,'' Link said. ``They just shouldn't be in this when you think of the division that still exists among members of the bar association and in the courts.''

DOC.HEAD: CBS, CNN Plan Shuttle Coverage
With AM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: Cable News Network and CBS News planned live coverage of the launch of the space shuttle Atlantis, scheduled for about 1 a.m. Sunday, spokesmen said Friday. NBC News and ABC News would be prepared to go live with the launch but had no firm plans to do so, spokesmen said. Bad weather and a crew member's cold have delayed the liftoff since Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Increased Security for Immigrating Soviet Jews
DOC.TEXT: Israel has increased security for Jewish immigrants en route from the Soviet Union because of warnings that Arab guerrillas may be planning attacks, newspapers reported Friday. President Chaim Herzog suggested that Israel censor reports about immigration and the travel routes of those arriving. ``During all the years of great immigrations, governments of Israel imposed censorship, in agreement with the media, on all related to reports on immigration, numbers, countries of origin and travel routes,'' he said on Israel radio. Imposing total censorship would be difficult, but previous governments found ``the golden path between the need to explain the issue to the Jewish people ... and the necessity to avoid providing ammunition to our enemies,'' Herzog said. Friday's Jerusalem Post said a ``reliable source'' confirmed that security was tightened after warnings were received that unspecified guerrilla groups planned to attack immigrants from the Soviet Union. Security officials would not confirm or deny the reports. Concern over the safety of immigrants grew after Arab protests about the arrival of thousands of Soviet Jews in the past few months. Palestinian groups fear Israel will encourage the new arrivals to settle in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip. The government has denied any such plan and only about 200 of last year's 12,000 Soviet immigrants settled in the territories. Bassam Abu Sharif, political adviser to chairman Yasser Arafat of the Palestine Liberation Organization, told reporters Wednesday in Tunis: ``We consider the settlement of Soviet Jews in the West Bank is an act of war against the Palestinian people and the Arab nation. Such an act can only cause similar action on our part, that is to say acts of war.'' Zeev Schiff, a respected Israeli military commentator, wrote in the daily Haaretz that such Palestinian statements ``create the background for acts of terror against immigrants en route to Israel or in Israel itself.'' ``Such attacks may be expected in order to terrify, to make immigration harder and to ignite the international community for using pressure against Israel,'' he said. Schiff said Palestinian guerrillas may interpret Western condemnations of the settling of immigrants in the occupied lands as ``justifying violent acts against the immigrants and the Israelis accompanying them.'' ``Israel's security mechanisms will now have to invest thought and resources in protecting the movement of immigrants to Israel, coming from various directions,'' he wrote. One Palestinian attack on Jews leaving the Soviet Union has been reported. In September 1973, two guerrillas of the Saiqa group based in Syria attacked a train carrying 37 Soviet Jews near the Austrian border, taking three emigrants and an Austrian hostage. Austria negotiated the hostages' release, but closed the Schoenau center near Vienna, then the main transit point for Soviet Jewish emigrants. Soviet Jews were immigrating to Israel at a rate of more than 2,500 a month at the time. Arab states protested that Moscow was providing the Jewish state with manpower. Most Soviet Jews now go to Hungary or Romania and are flown to Israel. The number of Soviet Jews arriving in Israel has increased rapidly because of eased Soviet emigration policies. In 1988, about 2,000 Soviet Jews came to Israel, but the number grew to 12,000 in 1989 and more than 8,000 have arrived so far this year.

DOC.HEAD: Former Defense Executive Pleads Guilty in Pentagon Case
DOC.TEXT: A former executive of a United Technologies Corp. division pleaded guilty Friday to conspiring to illegally obtain inside information about a Pentagon competition for a lucrative Navy contract. Roger K. Engel, 49, a former vice president of the company's Norden Systems division in Norwalk, Conn., pleaded guilty to conspiracy to defraud the government. Engel, who agreed to cooperate with the Justice Department's investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud called ``Operation Ill Wind,'' could receive a five-year sentence and fined up to $250,000. U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton in Alexandria, Va., scheduled Engel's sentencing for May 11. Engel is the third former Norden Systems executive to plead guilty to participating in the conspiracy to obtain inside bid information abou a $150 million contract to build a battlefield air traffic-control system for the Marine Corps. A former senior vice president of Norden, James E. Rapinec, 54, and C.J. (Jack) Richardson, a former marketing executive, pleaded guilty in December and are also cooperating with prosecutors. The three men have all admitted they arranged in 1988 for Norden to pay defense consultant Thomas E. Muldoon $49,500 to get information about the Navy's contract competition from his contacts in the Defense Department. Muldoon was paid $27,500 before the ``Ill Wind'' investigation was publicly disclosed in June 1988, when FBI agents searched the offices of a number of defense contractors, including Norden Systems. Norden then withdrew from the Pentagon's competition for the radar command and ground-control system, known as ATACC. Muldoon, who was sentenced last week to 27 months in prison for participating in an unrelated scheme to bribe a Pentagon procurement official, obtained the information with the help of another defense consultant, Mark Saunders. Saunders obtained information about Norden's ranking in the competition from George Stone, then a senior Navy procurement official. Neither Saunders nor Stone has been charged. According to court papers, Muldoon told Richardson that his ``contact'' in the government was responsible for Norden being kept in the competition. Norden's president, Edwin Decker, approved the consulting arrangement with Muldoon, according to court papers. But Norden spokesman Scott Brinckerhoff said it was standard practice for Decker, who has since retired, to approve consulting contracts. ``He certainly did not approve illegally obtaining any kind of information,'' Brinckerhoff said.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Wins Two More Weeks at the Armory
DOC.TEXT: After a weeklong standoff with the state, a sheriff with an overcrowded jail won permission to keep a makeshift prison at a National Guard armory for at least two more weeks. A Superior Court judge endorsed a temporary settlement between the state, which owns the armory, and Hampden County Sheriff Michael Ashe, who seized part of the building Feb. 16. Ashe, whose action sparked a war of words with the state and drew support from many citizens, said he had just decided to ``go out and do what I have to do.'' The sheriff was under a federal court order forbidding him from holding more than 500 prisoners in the 102-year-old Hampden County Jail, which is designed to house 279. On Friday, 19 inmates were held at the temporary lockup at the armory, in a large room with a concrete floor and a volleyball net stretched between the walls. ``This is a victory for the people,'' Ashe said after the hearing in which lawyers for county and state agreed to let him keep using the armory until March 12. On that day, both sides are supposed to report back with a permanent solution, or a hearing will be held on the sheriff's request for an injunction allowing him to keep using the armory. Under the settlement approved by Judge George Keady, Ashe agreed to allow the National Guard to keep operating out of the building. ``I think what we wanted to do is keep it on the front burner but turn down the heat,'' said Lawrence Fletcher-Hill, assistant state attorney general. The sheriff shocked state officials when he moved on the armory, telling guardsmen that he was seizing the property under a 17th century statute ordering him to keep the peace. The sheriff said his only other choice was to turn prisoners out onto the streets. State officials at first reacted angrily. Secretary of Public Safety Charles V. Barry, who has jurisdiction over the armories, issued a statement saying he would press criminal trespass charges against the sheriff. The state had argued that the sheriff, as a county official, doesn't have any right to take state property. But early in the week, the sheriff won a temporary restraining order allowing him to stay at the armory. That, along with widespread support from residents, local officials and even prisoners, turned the focus to working out a compromise spot for the prisoners. ``We're putting the issue of the sheriff's actions to the side,'' Fletcher-Hill said at a news conference after Friday's hearing. ``It's more important that we find a solution.'' Officials declined to specify what locations they are considering for overflow prisoners. A new jail is scheduled to be built in nearby Ludlow, but that is at least two years away. Money for the temporary solution will come from funds set aside for overcrowding problems, state prison officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Lifts Some South African Sanctions
DOC.TEXT: Britain lifted restrictions Friday on investing and promoting tourism in South Africa, acting alone after the rest of the European Community refused to ease any sanctions. ``It is now entirely for the private sector to decide'' on new investment, ``but we do feel very strongly that President de Klerk has done more, and more quickly and with greater courage, than any other South African president,'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said. She has argued that international sanctions should be lifted to reward de Klerk and his white government for political reforms and the release of black leader Nelson Mandela on Feb. 11. Britain's action, announced in statements to the House of Commons by Trade Secretary Nicholas Ridley and Employment Secretary Michael Howard, means the government will ``no longer discourage'' investment or tour promotion, officials said.
