The organization that represents major British companies operating in South Africa said it believed ending the non-binding investment restrictions would make no immediate difference. ``Overseas capital is going to be very sensitive to political developments there,'' said Tim Bird, spokesman for the British Industry Committee on South Africa. ``For long-term investment, you need long-term confidence.'' The committee represets about 30 British companies with big South African interests, including ICI, Shell and British Petroleum. It is unclear whether lifting the tourism restrictions will make a marked difference. Brochures for South African vacations are not prominently displayed in most travel agencies. Opposition Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock, opening the headquarters of the Wales Anti-Apartheid movement in Cardiff, said the government move was ``pathetically premature.'' The general secretary of the South African Council of Churches, the Rev. Frank Chikane, who arrived Friday on a visit, also said Mrs. Thatcher had moved too fast. ``When we have reached the stage where the dismantling of apartheid is irreversible, we will blow the whistle,'' he said. By law and custom, apartheid establishes a racially segregated society in which the 28 million blacks have no vote in national affairs. The 5 million whites control the economy and maintain separate residential districts, schools and health services. Asked about her isolation on South Africa, Mrs. Thatcher said: ``It is a pretty cozy isolation, pretty crowded, judging by the numbers of foreign statesmen who are talking to us.'' She was speaking at a news conference with Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, who paid a one-day visit to discuss German unification. Andreotti said de Klerk ``has taken some extraordinary steps ... and should be supported,'' but Italy, like the rest of the 12-nation European Community, refused a British appeal to lift the non-binding investment and tourism restrictions. They were among measures imposed in 1986 by the European Community, including binding bans on import of iron, steel and gold coins that remain in effect. British investment has dropped from nearly $4.6 billion in 1984 to $3 billion in 1987, the latest government figure available, but Britain remains the single largest foreign investor in South Africa. South Africa's biggest trading partners are West Germany, Italy, France, Britain, United States and Japan. Mainly because of pressure from anti-apartheid groups, several big British corporations, like hundreds of U.S. companies, have withdrawn from South Africa in recent years and sold out to local companies. It is also unclear if lifting the tourism restrictions will make a marked difference. Brochures for South African vacations are not prominently displayed in most travel agencies, but they are available and South African Airways advertises in British newspapers.

DOC.HEAD: Hezbollah Leader Says Hostages Should be Freed
DOC.TEXT: The spiritual leader of Hezbollah, believed to be an umbrella organization for groups holding hostages, said Friday the 18 Western captives in Lebanon should be freed. ``We have to think of finding realistic and humanitarian means to free the foreign hostages,'' Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah said in a sermon at Friday prayers in Bir el-Abed, a district in the Shiite Moslem slums of south Beirut. ``This problem has been widely exploited by Western forces to distort the image of Islam and Moslems,'' he said. Hezbollah, or Party of God, is allied with Iran. The English-language Tehran Times, which is close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani, said Thursday the hostages should be freed because they had become a propaganda tool of Iran's enemies. The editorial was the first known statement by an Iranian newspaper in support of freeing the hostages. Shiite kidnappers are believed to hold most of the hostages, who include eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman. Held longest is Terry A. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. In his first comment on the hostages of 1990, Fadlallah said: ``There should be a new study of this problem in order to to be able to bring about a political and humanitarian solution that guarantees the freedom of the captives and the rights of Moslems. ``We want to approach this issue, which is used by the international media and as a means of pressure, on a new basis to reach a solution that will close this case altogether and enable the Islamic struggle to pick up new momentum.'' Fadlallah visits Iran frequently and was in Tehran earlier this week for talks with Iranian leaders. On Thursday in Damascus, Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa told Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, that the Tehran Times editorial was ``a good sign'' and he would be going to Iran soon to persue the hostage issue. Al-Sharaa said he would ``work intensly with the top Iranian leaders'' and ``I hope we will be able to arrive at good results.'' He said Syria had told Iran's leaders ``it is their interest to work with us in gaining the release of the hostages.'' Syria has good relations with Iran. It was the only major Arab country to support Iran in the eight-year war with Iraq that ended in August 1988. Mrs. Say said of Fadlallah's statement: ``This is another encouraging sign in a complicated situation. ... It seems most of the parties are working toward a resoluton.'' She is on a tour with an Associated Press delegation to seek the release of Anderson and the others. She has met with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Pope John Paul II and Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

DOC.HEAD: Disasters Declared in Two States; Residents Brace for Floods
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-one storm-battered counties in Alabama and Georgia were declared federal disaster areas on Friday, and Mississippi and Indiana residents piled sandbags in low-lying areas where they expect floods this weekend. Forecasters said the Deep South's big soaking appeared to be over for the time being, however, and drier cold air began to replace the soggy warm air that has drenched the region for the past two weeks. ``We're getting back to normal,'' said Mayor J.L. Nolen of Opp, Ala., where a tornado on Thursday snapped trees, ripped the roofs off buildings and sent 10 people to the hospital. ``We're just extremely lucky no one got killed.'' Damage from the recent storms was estimated at more than $30 million in Mississippi and Georgia alone. Alabama was hardest hit by the most recent storm, but emergency officials there have not set a figure on the loss. The American Red Cross said some 2,800 Alabama families have been victimized by floods, tornadoes and other severe weather since Feb. 10. Rowland Faust, a spokesman for the Federal Emergency Management Agency, said a dozen of Alabama's 67 counties had been added to an earlier disaster declaration signed by President Bush, who originally authorized aid to six counties. Bush declared nine northwestern Georgia counties to be disaster areas on Friday because of the tornadoes and floods, and Mississippi Gov. Ray Mabus asked for federal disaster assistance for 32 counties. The disaster declarations make federal relief money available to individuals, businesses and local governments. In Simpson County, Miss., officials estimated that as many as 100 bridges were lost to flooding, and other counties have said numerous bridges must either be repaired or replaced. In Jackson County, high waters from the upper Pascagoula Basin were encroaching and civil defense officials said they offered sandbags to residents whose homes were in the floodway. ``It's at my back door even as we speak,'' Harold Morris, a computer programmer in Escatawpa. ``In a few hours it will start coming into the bottom part of my house.'' While high water problems continued to plague Mississippi's Gulf Coast, an end to the recent heavy rains was allowing other flood-damaged areas of the South to clean up. Further north, however, lowland portions of Indiana were flooding, prompting road closings, evacuations and sandbagging. A psychiatric hospital in West Lafayette was surrounded by flood waters and emergency workers in Fort Wayne were called to rescue a pair of youths stranded when their canoe capsized, officials said. In Fort Wayne, the area hardest hit by rainfall Wednesday and Thursday, about 30,000 sandbags were distributed and residents helped seal off neighborhoods. ``When the water comes up, this is what you do,'' said Elizabeth Batcha, who spent Friday morning throwing bags from a truck to her Fort Wayne neighbors. ``Last June, we had water up to our front steps.'' The recent spate of soggy weather has been accompanied by record high temperatures, and although more records fell on Friday, forecasters said the balmy period was coming to an end. Bitter cold Arctic weather was poised to make a descent into the eastern half of the nation. Forecasters warned of low temperatures Sunday that would dip into the 30s in Florida's panhandle, in the 20s in northern Georgia and below zero in states along the Canadian border.

DOC.HEAD: Hilary Foretich Located
DOC.TEXT: Seven-year-old Hilary Foretich, the subject of one of the longest parental visitation disputes in the nation's history, has been located in New Zealand, television station WRC said Friday. The girl was found at a motel with her grandparents, the station said. District of Columbia police spokesman Quintin Peterson said that police were attempting to confirm that Hilary was in New Zealand. But, the detective investigating the case in New Zealand city of Christchurch, Sgt. Russell Hawks, said she had been living in the city ``for some time.'' ``She's fine, in a healthy state, no problems there at all,'' Hawks said in a telephone interview with the station. Another police official, a Sgt. Peyton, told The Associated Press that the case was already before a family court judge and that the girl was in the custody of the grandparents. He declined to be specific about the case, and would not confirm that the girl in question was Hilary. The girl's mother, Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, spent 25 months in jail for civil contempt of court rather than disclose the girl's whereabouts. She maintained that Hilary's father, Dr. Eric Foretich, had sexually abused the girl. On those grounds, she refused to give him court-ordered visitation rights. Foretich has strongly denied ever abusing the child. Morgan, Foretich and both of their attorneys were not immediately available for comment. There was no answer at the homes of Morgan and Foretich and their attorneys did not immediately return telephone calls. A reporter for Radio New Zealand, Jill Gallop, told the television station that police confirmed Hilary and the grandparents, Morgan's parents, had been in Christchurch for three years. The grandparents last year sought permission to live in New Zealand permanently, she said. The girl's identity was revealed when New Zealand authorities checked with U.S. officials to determine if there were any outstanding court orders pertaining to the child, Gallop reported. Morgan was released from jail in Washington in September after President Bush signed a law limiting civil contempt in District of Columbia child abuse cases to 12 months.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Issues Bayonets To Control Demonstrations
DOC.TEXT: The government has issued bayonets and dogs to security forces and is moving additional police to Bucharest to control demonstrations, Interior Minister Mihai Chitac said Friday. The announcement came at a session of the ruling Provisional Council of National Unity, which was discussing a decree that would limit demonstrations. Also Friday, more than 500 people knelt and prayed at an open-air Romanian Orthodox Mass in downtown Bucharest, the first such celebration in decades. The new security measures followed actions last Sunday by hundreds of anti-government demonstrators, who assaulted and briefly occupied government headquarters at Victory Square. The interim government had been reluctant to use force against demonstrators following the bloody uprising by protesters and army troops that ended the 24-year reign of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Chitac told the council Bucharest lacked officers and additional police would be brought to the capital from other areas. He said about 4,500 new positions for police would be established in the ministry. Soldiers stood aside last Sunday when demonstrators shattered windows at government headquarters and occupied the building for three hours. The troops said they had no orders to fire. At the Provisional Council's meeting Friday, seveal opposition leaders accused the interim government of having secretly staged the violent demonstration itself, so it could justify limiting political demonstrations. State-run television on Friday showed thousands of people demonstrating against the government the previous evening in Timisoara, the western city where the uprising against Ceausescu began last December. Demonstrators condemned communism and the leadership of interim President Ion Iliescu. In downtown Bucharest on a sunny Friday, people crowded University Square, some clutching candles, for the Mass celebrated by a priest who was jailed and exiled for his opposition to the Ceausescu regime. ``May God allow us to raise churches on our land in order to have Jesus born again here,'' said the Rev. Gheorghe Calciu, who returned this week from the United States. The crowd knelt silently to remember the revolution's victims, then followed Calciu in a procession through the square to flower-bedecked memorials. About a dozen police in long blue coats patrolled the square but did not interfere. Calciu, 64, a human rights activist, was imprisoned by the Communist regime for 21 years. Expelled from Romania in 1985, he has been serving at Holy Cross Church in Alexandria, Va., and has been spiritual leader of the Romanian World Congress exile organization. Religious practice was discouraged under Ceausescu, and the Romanian Orthodox Church, to which most of the population belongs, was kept on a tight rein. Masses took place only in religious buildings and believers were often persecuted. In Oradea in northwest Romania, unidentified assailants smashed windows and broke down the doors of a synagogue on the night of Feb. 15-16, said Teodor Blumenfeld, general secretary of the Federation of Romanian Jewish Communities. They tore apart the building, apparently looking for gold and silver objects, he said. They did not find any, but destroyed prayer books, shawls and kits, Blumenfeld said. He estimated damage at nearly $1,500. No one was arrested, he said. Romania's chief rabbi, Moses Rosen, said last week he feared a surge of anti-Semitism in the more open climate following the December revolution. He said groups like the Iron Guard, Romania's former fascist movement allied with the Nazis, could be reborn. Blumenfeld said security guards and alarm systems were being provided for synagogues around the country. But he called the Oradea attack an isolated incident. An announcement appeared Wednesday in the Bacau newspaper Desteptarea announcing establishment of an extremist right-wing organization, the Anti-Communist Army-Archangel Michael Legion, national newspapers said Friday. It declared that the group would ``not give up until all Communists, socialists and other left- wing elements are liquidated.'' The notice said if the newspaper did not print the warning, ``we will strike against you.'' It was signed ``Heil Hitler.'' Police said soldiers and police were guarding the newspaper offices.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Plagues Atlantic States, Record Highs Set
DOC.TEXT: Rain moved across many of the Atlantic states Friday, and 21 storm-torn counties in Alabama and Georgia were declared federal disaster areas after two weeks of drenching. Before skies clouded over and temperatures dropped, record highs were recorded from Georgia and South Carolina to Portland, Maine. Rain and thunderstorms extended from Florida across eastern New York state and much of New England. Parts of Kansas, Arkansas and Missouri also received rain, while the upper Great Lakes states got snow. Snow fell in portions of Michigan, Wisconsin, Illinois and Iowa. Drier, cold air began to replace soggy warm air in the Deep South, where a dozen Alabama counties were added to an earlier emergency relief declaration because of recent storms. Nine Georgia counties were declared disaster areas because of tornadoes and floods. High water continued to threaten Mississippi's Gulf Coast, and residents in lowland Indiana helped seal off neighborhoods from flood waters with sandbags. Mooreville, N.C., and Savannah, Ga., received some damage from thunderstorm gusts. Charlotte, N.C., had gusts up to 70 mph, the National Weather Service said. Boston's high of 63 degrees broke the date's previous record of 59 degrees, set in 1976, and Providence, R.I., broke a 57-year-old record by one degree with a reading of 61. Portland, Maine, recorded a high of 58, breaking the record of 52 last set in 1981. A high of 80 degrees in Columbia, S.C., shattered a record 79 that had stood since 1897. Helena, Mont., had a high of 55, which broke the old mark of 54 set in 1881. The high temperature in the Lower 48 states was 88 degrees in Sarasota and Bradenton in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Ed Gray Questioned
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee questioned a former top thrift regulator Friday in an investigation of five senators who intervened with banking officials on behalf of Lincoln Savings and Loan. Edwin J. Gray, former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said he met with the committee for four hours behind closed doors and ``they might choose to invite me back.'' The ex-regulator declined to discuss his testimony because, ``The committee asked me to hold confidential'' any discussions of Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., John McCain, R-Ariz., Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. and John Glenn, D-Ohio. All five have denied wrongdoing. The committee's investigation is still in its preliminary stage. Sources familiar with the overall investigation said the committee appears to be exploring all possible relationships between the senators and Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr., the former head of Lincoln, based in Irvine, Calif. These sources, speaking only on condition of anonymity, said the committee is ranging beyond a 1987 meeting between four senators and Gray _ and a session a week later between all five senators and San Francisco-based regulators. The senators asked for the meetings at the request of Keating, who complained that he was treated unfairly. Keating, his family members and associates contributed some $1.3 million to the campaigns and causes of the five senators. The government ousted Keating and took control of the failing Lincoln on April 14, 1989, and the cost of protecting depositors at the thrift may exceed $2 billion, believed to be the biggest of the many losses in the nation's S&L debacle. Gray testified last November that four of the senators asked him, in a private meeting on April 2, 1987, to drop a proposed regulation that would have curtailed risky investments by Lincoln. In return, he told the House Banking Committee, the four would get ``their friend'' Keating to make more home loans. Gray identified the four as DeConcini, Glenn, Cranston and McCain, and described the offer as ``a quid pro quo.'' Those senators and Riegle met a week later to discuss the case with the San Francisco examiners, who were investigating Lincoln and recommending its seizure by the government. One source said, ``It appears the committee is going to go beyond the meetings into a full recounting of the relationship between Keating and the senators.''

DOC.HEAD: Rooney, CBS Mum on Reports He'll Return Early
DOC.TEXT: Humorist Andy Rooney, who usually has a lot to say, was unavailable Friday to discuss reports he may return early from a three-month suspension from the CBS ``60 Minutes'' show. Rooney, who was suspended by CBS News President David Burke after a newspaper attributed a racist remark to him, could return to the show as early as next week, The Wall Street Journal and New York Newsday reported. The Washington Post said he could return as early as March 4 from the 90-day suspension imposed Feb. 8. Burke's spokesman, Tom Goodman, said CBS wouldn't comment on whether Rooney, who met earlier this week with Burke, would return early. Rooney didn't return phone calls. A source familiar with the situation, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Burke was reviewing the matter, but had yet to reach a decision. Rooney was suspended without pay after a gay magazine, The Advocate, attributed to him a racial slur. Rooney denied making the remark. Advocate writer Chris Bull, who interviewed Rooney, has said he stands by his story. Burke never has made public any specific reason for suspending Rooney. Rooney earlier drew fire from homosexual activists for a Dec. 28 CBS special in which he said ``many of the ills which kill us are self-induced,'' and then listed ``homosexual unions'' as among those ills. As of last Friday, CBS had received 5,133 calls about Rooney's suspension, with 5,061 supporting him, said CBS News spokesman Roy Brunett.

DOC.HEAD: Balladeer Johnnie Ray in Coma With Liver Failure, Condition Grave
DOC.TEXT: Fifties balladeer Johnnie Ray, known as the ``Prince of Wails'' for his vocal histrionics on such songs as ``Somebody Stole My Gal'' and ``Just Walkin' in the Rain,'' was in a coma Friday with liver failure. Ray, 63, was not expected to live, according to a statement issued late Thursday by Alan Eichler Associates, a public relations firm. Ray, whose condition deteriorated steadily since he entered Cedars-Sinai Medical Center Feb. 16, slipped into a coma Thursday with total liver failure, said hospital spokesman Ron Wise. The spokesman described his condition as grave. The once slender, boyish singer was credited with revolutionizing popular music in the early 1950s with his unique blend of rhythm and blues, country and gospel punctuated with real-sounding sobs. Some said his raw and emotional style opened the door to a new type of music that later became rock 'n' roll. Ray's first hit record was ``Cry,'' followed by ``The Little White Cloud That Cried,'' ``Please Mr. Sun,'' ``Brokenhearted, '' ``What's the Use,'' ``Somebody Stole My Gal,'' ``Who's Sorry Now,'' and ``Yes Tonight Josephine.'' His unusual singing style quickly became the butt of jokes and a prime target of impersonators. At various times he was dubbed ``The Prince of Wails,'' ``The Howling Success,'' ``The Nabob of Sob,'' `The Song Wringer,'' ``The Cry Guy'' and the ``Master of Misery.'' ``Of course the days are gone of the screaming teen-agers _ and nobody had them screaming more than I did,'' Ray recalled in a 1984 interview with the Associated Press. ``But even in those days I had the same kind of audience I have now _ the elderly, the middle-aged and the young kids,'' he said. ``I don't have a TV series, I've had no hit records. Ray was born Jan. 10, 1927, in Dallas, Ore., a tiny town near Salem. It was there he saw his first movie when he was 3 or 4. ``It was Edna Mae Oliver in `Murder on the Blackboard,' and from then on I wanted to be a movie star,'' he told the AP. In 1954, Darryl F. Zanuck offered him a seven-year contract with 20th Century Fox and he co-starred with Ethel Merman, Dan Dailey, Marilyn Monroe, Donald O'Connor and Mitzi Gaynor in ``There's No Business Like Show Business.'' Ray's movie career ended when Zanuck resigned to become an independent producer. ``The new head of Fox was Buddy Adler, and a Johnnie Ray fan he was not,'' Ray said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Meets Opposition Leaders of Parliament
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela met Friday with liberal white and mixed-race members of Parliament who have been shunned by some black militants because they take part in a legislative body that excludes blacks. Aides to Mandela, meanwhile, said the African National Congress leader will leave next week on an 18-day, four-nation trip, his first abroad since his release Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison. He plans to fly Tuesday to Lusaka, Zambia, to meet leaders of African countries and confer with the exiled leadership of the ANC. He then will spend three days in Zimbabwe and six days in Tanzania, aides said. On March 12 he will fly to Sweden to visit ANC President Oliver Tambo, who is recovering from a stroke in a Stockholm clinic. Mandela said Friday in an interview with British Broadcasting Corp. television that the ANC was willing to compromise with the government and that democratic elections must precede negotiations on the future of the country. He was interviewed at his home in Soweto and the program was broadcast in Britain. Mandela said nationalization of industry was a basic ANC policy, but he added: ``If we decide to negotiate, then we must be open to compromise. If you are not prepared to compromise, then you don't negotiate. Once we commit ourselves to negotiation, then we admit the possibility of compromise.'' He said the only way of determining who will be involved in the talks on South Africa's future is through democratic elections. He also said the ANC did not claim to be the only voice of black South Africans. ``But we are confident that we can lead the struggle for change in the country,'' he said. Mandela met at his home Friday with the three co-leaders of the Democratic Party, which represents anti-apartheid whites in Parliament. The party has tried to build alliances with black groups in recent years with some success. But some militants have refused to deal with the Democrats because they remain in Parliament, which has houses for whites, Asians and people of mixed-race, but excludes blacks. Democratic co-leader Denis Worrall said his delegation agreed with Mandela on the need for universal voting rights, but differed over the ANC's support for guerrilla violence, economic sanctions and nationalization. Mandela has reaffirmed his support for ANC economic policies, which call for the nationalization of mines, banks and monopoly industries. He and other ANC officials have sought to reassure white business people, however, saying economic issues should be subject to negotiation and compromise. Mandela also met the Rev. Allan Hendrickse, leader of Parliament's mixed-race chamber. The ANC has urged boycotts of elections for the mixed-race and Asian chambers of Parliament. But Hendrickse said after meeting Mandela that the ANC and the Labor Party, which controls the mixed-race chamber, would be able to work together. Mandela's aides said the black leader plans to meet Monday with Gavin Relly, chairman of the Anglo American Corp., the world's No. 1 gold producer. Relly has spoken out frequently against apartheid, and his corporation espouses relatively liberal employment policies. Also Friday, an ANC delegation led by one of the group's leaders, Walter Sisulu, met with church leaders in Natal Province to discuss ways of resolving a 4-year-old black factional struggle that has claimed about 3,000 lives. Mandela is to join the delegation Sunday for a huge rally in the port city of Durban. In Johannesburg, hundreds of blacks joined more than 1,000 whites in a march organized by the Democratic Party in support of peace and democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Judge to Allow Confessions in Jogger Rape Case
DOC.TEXT: Incriminating videotaped and written statements from five teens accused in the gang rape and near-fatal beating of a jogger in Central Park are admissible as evidence at their trial, a judge ruled Friday. Six teens are accused of being part of a band of roving youths who attacked an investment banker as she jogged through the park the night of April 19. Admission of the statements was critical to the prosecution's case because the victim has no memory of the attack and cannot testify against her alleged assailants, and because there is no physical evidence that conclusively links the suspects to the attack. The woman, now 29, was raped, beaten and left for dead, but has since made a recovery doctors call remarkable and returned to work. Of six teen-agers charged with attacking the woman, five gave statements to the police that were videotaped. One of them, Antron McCray, 16, said, ``We took turns getting on top of her.'' He said he punched and kicked the jogger and another defendant, Yusef Salaam, 15, hit her with a pipe. McCray, according to a third defendant, Kevin Richardson, 15, ``had sex with her.'' The six are charged with with rape, sodomy, assault and attempted murder. Four other youths are charged in attacks on male joggers that night. Attorney Jesse Berman, who is defending one of the youths, complained after the ruling that Judge Thomas Galligan suppressed ``next to nothing.'' The only exception to the ruling was a comment made by one of the teens to a police officer at a precinct stationhouse. After the officer told the teen-agers, ``You should be out with your girlfriends instead of being out beating people,'' the youth replied, ``I got mine,'' the policeman has testified. Galligan gave no reason for the exception. Another defense attorney, referring to the judge's ruling to suppress suspects' statements in another murder case in which the victim was black and his alleged attacker white, suggested that racism tainted Galligan's decision. ``There is a double standard,'' said attorney Colin Moore. ``We came in expecting nothing, and that's what we came away with.'' The teen-agers charged in the case are black.

DOC.HEAD: Will This Day Never End?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 7: ``The rotatational,'' to note 1982 loss made up; ADDS one graf to note other causes of slowing.
DOC.TEXT: If it seems like some days will never end, it may not be your imagination. A government scientist confirms that the day got longer recently. The Earth's rotation slowed slightly during a 10-day period in January, causing the length of a day to increase by five-ten-thousandths of a second, reports Dr. Dennis McCarthy of the U.S. Naval Observatory. The change occurred starting Jan. 24 and has been associated with a series of westerly bursts of wind blowing out of Asia across the Pacific Ocean, McCarthy reported. Minute changes in the Earth's rotation are most often associated with such weather, he explained, because of the force of the winds acting on the planet's surface. The last time the planet slowed significantly was during the 1982-1983 El Nino event, when it decreased by two-ten-thousandths of a second. While climatologists reports that there are signs of a new El Nino developing in the Pacific, McCarthy said in a telephone interview that it is too soon for that to affect the planet. The rotational speed lost in the 1982-1983 event was gradually regained, but it remains to the seen if the January loss will be made up, he said. An El Nino is a series of changes in ocean water temperature and air pressure that has been known to alter weather conditions worldwide. The 1982-83 occurrence was considered the most severe of its type in at least a century. Changes in the Earth's speed of rotation are calculated by precise observations of the apparent movement of stars and planets in the sky. The January and 1982-1983 slowdowns are not connected with the much more gradual retardation of the earth's rotation caused by the moon. To compensate, from time to time ``leap seconds'' are added to the calendar, such as the 61st second that came at the end of the last minute of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Letters, Fund Bolster Carol Stuart Relatives
DOC.TEXT: A brother of Carol Stuart said Friday his family remains angry about her killing, but letters of support and contributions to a scholarship fund set up in her name have restored their faith in people. ``There are times when the whole situation angers me,'' Carl DiMaiti said. ``That so many lives can be so disrupted and shattered in such a short period of time for no real reason, or no reason that I can see or reason that I can understand.'' It was DiMaiti's first formal interview since his brother-in-law, Charles Stuart, apparently committed suicide Jan. 4 after investigators learned he made up a story about he and his wife being shot by a black gunman. DiMaiti spoke the day after the FBI began a preliminary inquiry into the Boston Police Department's investigation of the case. The inquiry is focused on allegations that police intimidated and coerced several people into implicating William Bennett, who is black, in Carol Stuart's slaying last Oct. 23. The Suffolk County grand jury met Friday for the fourth time since Charles Stuart apparently jumped off a bridge into the Boston Harbor. Three of his siblings, Neysa Porter, Shelley Yandoli and Michael Stuart, reportedly appeared before the grand jury. Charles Stuart originally told investigators that he and his pregnant wife were shot by a mugger while leaving a childbirth class. Mrs. Stuart, 30, died of her wounds and the couple's son, delivered prematurely by Caesarean section, died 17 days later. Stuart's story about the black gunman touched off a massive manhunt during which minority residents allege their civil rights were violated. DiMaiti, 37, a former high school teacher who now runs the family pizza dough business, said his family has found new hope in the Carol DiMaiti Stuart Foundation formed last month. The foundation was established to award scholarships to residents of the Mission Hill neighborhood, where Charles Stuart originally told police the bogus holdup occurred. Contributions to the fund totaling $253,000 have poured in from around the country, the latest a check for $5,122.40 from New England Baptist Hospital. Letters of support have poured in. Many are addressed simply to ``DiMaiti Family, Medford, Mass.,'' DiMaiti said. And many letters are from people who also experienced the loss of a loved one, he said. ``They said the pain will ease,'' DiMaiti said. ``They say it's something you never get over but it does get better.'' DiMaiti described his mother as still ``devastated'' by her daughter's death, but said the letters and contributions from as far away as California and overseas have helped restore her faith in people. DiMaiti would not comment on the FBI's inquiry into the manner in which Boston police handled the case. The investigation, undertaken at the request of U.S. Attorney Wayne Budd, will examine ``allegations that individuals were coerced or intimidated into making statements implicating Willie Bennett,'' said a statement issued Thursday by FBI Special Agent Thomas Hughes. Bennett, who is black, was named by police as a suspect after Carol Stuart's shooting, but he was cleared after Charles Stuart's apparent suicide.

DOC.HEAD: Tugs Struggle to Cool Down Crippled Tanker
DOC.TEXT: A flotilla of salvage tugs worked Friday to prevent a flareup of fires that could touch off another blast aboard a U.S.-flagged Kuwaiti tanker crippled by an explosion. U.S. Navy warships warned other vessels to keep at least four miles away from the fire-ravaged Surf City. The U.S.-flagged tanker was en route to Italy loaded with naphtha and diesel fuel when a blast ripped through it Thursday in the Persian Gulf, 20 miles off the United Arab Emirates coast. U.S. military officials identified the two people killed in the explosion as the ship's master, Derrick F. Linardich, 38, of Norfolk, Va.; and the first mate, Steven P. McHugh, 34, of East Bridgewater, Mass. The other 23 crew members scrambled to lifeboats as flames raced across half of the 700-foot ship. The crewmen, including four with minor injuries, were rescued by the American missile frigate USS Simpson. Spokesmen at U.S. Central Command in Tampa, Fla., the headquarters responsible for U.S. operations in the Gulf, said they were told that the Surf City's chief engineer was ``British-Canadian,'' but others said all 25 crewmen were American. One survivor, 27-year-old Wayne Cohen of Boston, said the captain and first mate were in an area where work was being done on a cargo tank when ``the whole ship blew up.'' The 81,283-ton tanker is one of five Kuwaiti tankers still sailing under protection of the U.S. flag 19 months after the end of the Iran-Iraq war. C. Miles Sheldon, head of Chesapeake Shipping Inc., told a Dubai news conference that the bodies of the captain and first mate were recovered and would be sent home from Dubai. Chesapeake Shipping is the subsidiary set up by the Kuwait Oil Tanker Co. to operate the U.S.-flagged ships. Sheldon said that although the fires had been contained and the tanker was no longer in immediate danger of sinking, its condition remained unpredictable. He said the ship and cargo together were worth more than $30 million. In Kuwait, the chairman of Kuwait Oil Tanker Co., Abdul-Fattah al-Bader, said the blast most likely had been caused by a short circuit. He agreed with U.S. military officials who had discounted the possibility of Iranian sabotage or a drifting mine. The Surf City was described by witnesses as sharply down by its bow and listing, as a result of water pouring through a huge hole in its side. Smoke still billowed from the ship Friday, leaving a streak in the sky visible from shore. Gulf-based shipping sources said about eight tugboats were on the scene, some dousing the tanker with water and fire-smothering foam to reduce chances of another explosion in its volatile cargo. ``The accommodation quarters are still smoldering, and the heat could blow up the cargo, which would be a major disaster,'' said one source, speaking on condition of anonymity. Al-Bader said there would be no pollution problem even if the tanker should sink, because the oil would evaporate. Eleven Kuwait-owned tankers reflagged by the United States in mid-1987 to afford them naval escorts as protection from attacks by Iran, which was targeting the shipping of countries supporting Iraq. Six of the tankers reverted to Kuwaiti registry a year ago, while the other five have continued to sail under the U.S. flag. They are manned by American crews.

DOC.HEAD: British Journalist Held in Sudan
DOC.TEXT: Authorities in Sudan detained a British journalist after he interviewed the military government's chief of security, an editor of the Financial Times said Friday. Julian Ozanne, 25, has been held at security headquarters in Khartoum since Wednesday, said Jurek Martin, the newspaper's foreign editor. Ozanne is the Financial Times' East Africa stringer based in Nairobi, Kenya. He arrived in Khartoum on Sunday on assignment for the Sunday Correspondent, another London newspaper. Ozanne was questioned by a military official Tuesday and ordered to report the following morning to security headquarters. His hotel room was searched and notes and papers were taken, said Martin. The British ambassador to Sudan visited Ozanne on Thursday and Friday and reported him in good health, Martin said. But there was no word on his release. The London-based International Press Institute protested the detention and appealed to Sudan's leader, Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, to release the reporter. The institute said Ozanne was detained after interviewing Col. Bakri Hassan Saleh, Sudan's head of security. Martin said he did not know why Ozanne was being held, but he said there were several sensitive issues he was likely to be writing about, including the Sudanese civil war and the outcome of the trial of terrorists who bombed a hotel in Khartoum, killing two British aid workers.

DOC.HEAD: Army Deserter `Threw 30 Years Away' in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: An Army deserter who spent 30 years in East Germany said Friday he was only there a few weeks before he realized he must try to escape that country's grim conditions and danger. ``I feel like I threw 30 years of my life away,'' Arnold Kephart, 53, said in an interview here at the home of his brother-in-law, Arlo Dunbar. Speaking with a heavy German accent, Kephart said the country he's returned to is ``a different world'' and he never thought he would see anything like the rapid liberalization of Eastern Europe. ``It was like you were locked up all the time. I never really ever felt at home,'' he said. As an Army private in 1959, Kephart wrecked an Army truck and, fearing punishment, fled to East Germany. While there, Kephart said, he had 14 or 15 jobs, married twice and had four children, including a son he brought back with him. When he returned to the United States last month, Kephart was arrested at the airport before upset relatives who had been waiting for the reunion. A week later, the Army granted him an other-than-honorable discharge. A deal for a television movie of Kephart's life has just been closed, according to his attorney, James Martin Davis. He wouldn't reveal details. Kephart, who earned his living as a truck driver in East Germany, said he regretted his spur-of-the-moment decision to go absent without leave a few weeks after settling in Schmalkalind, the town where he lived for 30 years. Travel restrictions were so tight that only two opportunities to escape come along before East Germany opened its borders last year. The first attempt came in 1973 or 1974, Kephart said. His first marriage _ which produced a daughter, Kitty _ had ended in divorce. Kephart said he met two men ``in a beer joint'' who asked him if he wanted to get out. ``Maybe we had too many beers, but this one said he knew where there was a hole in the fence,'' Kephart recalled. He and his companions set out. He said he doesn't remember where they were headed, except that it was out of town. One of the men was walking near the border about five minutes ahead of Kephart and the other man when Kephart heard a noise. ``We thought maybe he stepped on a mine,'' Kephart said. ``We just turned around and headed back to town. ``Two or three days later, I heard that they'd found a person on the border _ dead,'' Kephart said. ``There's no way that couldn't have been the guy we were with.'' Before the second attempt 1975, Kephart drank ``enough beer to get my courage up and so I'd have an excuse if I got caught,'' he said. Kephart said three guards grabbed him as he approached the border, beat him, and sent him back to town. ``After that, I didn't think about trying the border again,'' he said. He met his second wife, Brigitte, a year after he was beaten. She is the mother of Frankie, now 12 and in the United States with his father, and Kephart's 8-year-old twin daughters, Katharina and Kathleen. The family lived in a small house, Kephart said. Their diet was meager: bread with some bologna-like meat for breakfast, soup and potatoes for lunch. Dinner was a reprise of breakfast, he said. ``You could seldom get eggs,'' said Kephart, who added that he is enjoying foods he sorely missed in East Germany. ``I always loved chili,'' he said. ``And pork and beans. They just don't have anything like that over there.''

DOC.HEAD: California S&L, Big in Junk Bonds, Seized
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS six grafs with four available names of other S&Ls taken over
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators on Friday seized the savings and loan industry's second largest holder of junk bonds, a California institution that worked closely with indicted financier Michael Milken. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision turned Imperial Savings Association, San Diego, over to the Resolution Trust Corp., a federal agency created in August to dispose of insolvent S&Ls. At the end of the year, Imperial had $9.7 billion in assets, the thrift office said. High-yield, high-risk bonds represented more than 10 percent of its portfolio. The institution was $60.1 million in the red, regulators said. Also seized on Friday was Mercury Savings and Loan Association, Huntington Beach, Calif. It had $2.16 billion in assets and was $33 million in the red, the thrift office said. Mercury operated more traditionally than Imperial, but had invested in several large hotel projects that went sour. Like several other large institutions before it, Imperial ran afoul of provisions in last summer's savings and loan bill requiring it to value its securities at market value rather than the purchase price. It was forced to recognize $200 million in junk bond losses in the last quarter of last year and had indicated it expected to take a writedown of at least $50 million more in the current quarter. At the end of September, Imperial was the 16th largest S&L in the nation and had the second biggest junk bond portfolio, behind only Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif., according to Sheshunoff Information Services. Of the top four junk bond holders in the S&L business, only Columbia, with $4.1 billion of the bonds, remains out of the government's control. Analysts speculate, however, that it may be one of the next takeovers. Its debt has been downgraded by Moody's Investors Service and regulators have restricted its activities since November. ``I think that Columbia has to be real close to the margin,'' said Bert Ely, an Alexandria, Va., financial institutions analyst. ``I wouldn't be surprised to see Columbia popped (into the RTC) fairly soon.'' CenTrust Bank of Miami, No. 3 in junk bonds, was seized earlier this month, and City Federal Savings Bank of Bedminster, N.J., No. 4, toppled in December. The seizures make the government, through the RTC, the largest owner of junk bonds. Imperial, the chief subsidiary of Imperial Corp. of America, had 80 branch offices in California, which will remain open during normal business hours. It had $7.6 billion in deposits in 387,000 accounts, the RTC said. All accounts up to the $100,000 federal insurance limit are guaranteed. Founded in 1950, Imperial grew as it helped finance the post-World War II housing boom in California. However, under former Chief Executive Kenneth J. Thygerson and investor Victor Goulet, it took advantage of California's liberal regulations to venture into risky investments. It became a major customer of Milken, who was head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s junk bond operation in Beverly Hills, Calif. Junk bonds have declined 15 percent to 20 percent on average since the summer. Earlier this month, Drexel Burnham's parent company sought protection under federal bankrupcty laws. Thygerson, who had joined the thrift in 1985, resigned last July. His successors were trying to save the institution by shrinking it to half of its peak size of $12 billion and returning it to more traditional practices. But the thrift office said in a statement, ``There was no possibility of replenishing capital without federal assistance.'' In addition to junk bonds, Imperial had purchased a troubled portfolio of car loans from Grand Wilshire Finance Corp., a now-bankrupt Los Angeles-area firm. It was also suffering from problem loans it made to a now-bankrupt New Jersey firm that sold Yugo automobile dealerships in the United States. Spokesmen for Imperial did not immediately return telephone calls seeking comment. All told, regulators seized 12 S&Ls on Friday, including First Atlantic Savings and Loan Association of Plainfield, N.J., with $1.3 billion in assets. The RTC has more than 330 S&Ls under its control with about $180 billion in assets. Though 12 S&Ls were seized, by Friday night the names of only seven had been released. The other four for which the Resolution Trust Corp. was appointed receiver: _Provident Federal, Casper, Wyo., with $263 million in assets. _Frontier Federal Savings and Loan Association, Walla Walla, Wash., $166 million. _Texasbank Savings FSB, Conroe, Texas, $381 million. _Nowlin Savings Association, North Richland Hills, Texas, $227 million.

DOC.HEAD: United Nations Approves Global Plan to Fight Drugs
DOC.TEXT: The General Assembly approved a plan Friday to combat worldwide drug abuse and the illicit narcotics trade, but a U.N. official said more money is needed to win the battle. The measures put together during the world body's four-day special session on narcotics focused more on eliminating demand through reduced consumption than previous U.N. anti-drug plans. The plan also emphasized promoting economic development and the importance of increased foreign trade to aid countries under siege by powerful drug producers and traffickers. It urges tighter controls of chemicals and equipment used to manufacture illegal drugs, and recommends steps to prevent the international banking system and other financial institutions from being used for laundering profits from the illicit drug trade. The plan calls for increased efforts to develop alternative incomes, such as crop substitution, for drug-producing countries. It also urges increased law enforcement cooperation and stresses the importance of treatment and rehabilitation for drug users. The plan says countries can receive help in eliminating demand through several U.N. bodies, such as the U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, the U.N. Children's Fund and the World Health Organization. The coordinator of U.N. drug programs, Margaret Anstee, said, ``I'm afraid that if we're not ready to put all the resources in, then I think we might lose the war against drugs.'' She told a news conference that if the financially strapped United Nations does not receive more resources to strengthen its anti-drug campaign, there may be increased calls for legalization of narcotics. ``I'm not in favor of legalization, but we might end up in a situation where legalization would take place simply because we have not even barely fought the first battle on this matter,'' she said. U.N. officials have estimated that the United Nations needs an additional $33-$35 million during the next two years for drug programs already in place. The new programs recommended by the plan, adopted by consensus, would require even more money, but the level of funding necessary has not been determined, Mrs. Anstee said. Some countries, including the United States, have said the enhanced drug programs can be funded by diverting resources from other areas within the United Nations. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar stressed in his opening speech before the session that the anti-drug fight is an exceptional situation requiring budget increases.

DOC.HEAD: Interior Minister Reinforces Police Patrols
DOC.TEXT: Interior Minister Richard Sacher will reinforce weekend police patrols to avert a possible disruption of pro-democracy rallies, the official news agency CTK reported Friday. It said the decision was made because of concern over disruptive action by ``dark forces'' still active in Czechoslovakia, which was ruled by a hard-line Communist regime until a peaceful revolution in November. It did not elaborate. Police patrols will be augmented by Interior Ministry troops, the agency said. Until this year, Feb. 25 was celebrated as the anniversary of the Communist takeover in 1948. The Civic Forum, a loose opposition movement governing in coalition with the Communists and other parties, is sponsoring a rally in downtown Prague on Saturday in memory of Jan Zajic, who burned himself to death Feb. 25, 1969, to protest the presence of Soviet military forces. Soviet troops have been stationed in Czechoslovakia since a Warsaw Pact invasion crushed the ``Prague Spring'' liberalization of 1968. President Vaclav Havel travels to Moscow on Monday and is expected to sign an agreement on the withdrawal of the 75,000 Red Army troops in Czechoslovakia.

DOC.HEAD: Jimmy Stewart Returns to Princeton to Receive University's Highest Honor
LaserPhoto TN3
DOC.TEXT: More than 60 years ago, James Stewart arrived at Princeton University with an accordian and an ambition to become an engineer. The engineer dream, the famed actor recalled Friday, was dashed after just a year at the Ivy League school. ``College algebra,'' Stewart, 81, recalled with a smile, ``was like a death blow.'' But Stewart, who on Saturday will receive the school's highest alumni honor _ the Woodrow Wilson Award _ said his prowess on the accordian helped him gain his first parts in the school's Triangle Club theater productions. ``Then the parts got a little bigger,'' Stewart said at a news conference. ``I guess you could say I started in the acting business through my accordian.'' Stewart later stalled plans to study architecture in graduate school to join Princeton classmate Joshua Logan in a summer stock company, and one of America's most fabled acting careers was launched. He starred in such films as ``Mr. Smith Goes to Washington,'' ``The Philadelphia Story,'' ``Harvey,'' ``Rear Window,'' and his personal favorite, ``It's a Wonderful Life.'' Stewart, an Academy Award winner for his acting, holder of medals for his service during World War II, and recipient of the nation's highest civilian award, the Medal of Freedom, said being honored by his alma mater ``is one of the most important events of my life.'' ``I was a terrible student,'' said Stewart, who graduated in 1932. ``I started out with the idea that I wanted to become an engineer because I was interested in aviation. After my first year, every teacher, every man that I had anything to deal with, said the same thing: `You're in the wrong racket. Engineering is not for you.'''

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Captain Gets Honorable Discharge; Spy Case Closed
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force captain targeted by a spy investigation was honorably discharged Friday and the investigation was closed, the Air Force announced. Capt. John Vladimir Hirsch, 34, never was charged, but was brought back from a West Berlin post to Kelly Air Force Base in July because of the probe. ``The investigation did not substantiate espionage, and the case was closed,'' 1st Lt. Joe Wiggins, a spokesman for the Electronic Security Command headquarters at Kelly, said Friday. Hirsch, an electrical engineer, voluntarily applied to leave the Air Force and was granted an honorable discharge under an early release program, Wiggins said. The case was handled by the Air Force Office of Special Investigations, Wiggins said. The investigation of the Czechoslovak-born officer began in July when polygraph examiners decided Hirsch wasn't telling the truth in a routine security update. He was assigned to a communications unit of the secretive Electronic Security Command, which collects intelligence on Warsaw Pact radar and communications. A search of his apartment turned up records of $120,000 in bank accounts, photographs of NATO military installations and classified documents, according to Pentagon officials who spoke on condition of anonymity. He then was reassigned to the 6968th Alteration and Installation Squadron at Kelly, where his duties didn't involve classified projects. Hirsch was born in Prague, Czechoslovakia, became a U.S. citizen in 1971 and joined the Air Force in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian Sues For Damages From Invasion
DOC.TEXT: A Panamanian citizen who claims his small plane was destroyed by gunfire during the U.S. invasion of Panama sued the government for damages Friday, an attorney said. The lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court on behalf of Luis Alvarado claims his single-engine Cessna was destroyed when a U.S. Army C-130 indiscrminately sprayed .50-caliber bullets Dec. 20 at Paitilla Airport in Panama City. Alvarado, an employee of the Panama Canal, and other Panamanians were invited by the U.S. Army to file claims after the invasion, said his attorney, Michael O'Kane. Alvarado did file, but the Army denied his claim, saying the damages resulted from an ``act of war,'' the attorney said. ``In the Noriega case, the government claims that its actions in Panama were not an act of war,'' O'Kane said, referring to the federal drug-trafficking prosecution of deposed Panamanian ruler Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``But when it comes time to pay, they tell a different story.'' The U.S. attorney's office in Miami didn't return phone calls about the case Friday. O'Kane also represents Daniel Miranda, one of Noriega's co-defendants in the Miami drug-trafficking case. Miranda, 36, is accused of flying $800,000 in drug profits from Fort Lauderdale to Panama in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: VP Going to South America for Chilean, Brazilian Inaugurals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, Quayle also, to restore Endara's name; SUBS last graf to conform
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle will travel to South America for presidential inaugurations in Chile and Brazil next month. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., will join the delegation going to Chile. Quayle also is expected during his March 9-16 trip to stop in Argentina, Paraguay and Barbados to continue U.S. efforts to overcome Latin resentment lingering from the U.S. invasion of Panama in December. Many Latin countries still have not given formal diplomatic recognition to the U.S.-installed government of President Guillermo Endara. Quayle and Kennedy will attend the inauguration of Patricio Aylwin on March 11 in Chile. Brazil holds its inauguration March 15, installing Fernando Collar de Mello. Elected Dec. 20, Collor de Mello recently made a pre-inaugural trip to Washington, where he met with both Quayle and President Bush. Kennedy, who has long been interested in Chilean affairs, will go only on that part of the trip. The Massachussetts senator, before meeting with the vice president on Thursday, said he was delighted to be part of the delegation. Chile's Dec. 14 elections marked a return of democracy to the last South American nation still ruled by the military. This will mark Quayle's fourth trip to Latin America as vice president. He traveled early this month to Panama to show support for Endara's government, and to Jamaica and Honduras, where he met with several heads of state.

DOC.HEAD: Police Capture Two More Joliet Escapees
DOC.TEXT: Police raided a South Side apartment Thursday and captured two convicted murderers who escaped earlier this month from the Joliet Correctional Center, authorities said. Acting on an informant's tip, police arrested James Allen, 40, of Chicago, a three-time convicted killer serving a natural life sentence, and Daniel Johnson, 24, of Burns, Tenn., who is serving an 80-year sentence for murder, said spokesman Nic Howell of the Illinois Department of Corrections. Allen and Johnson were among six inmates who escaped Feb. 11 in the largest breakout in the history of the state prison system. Two of the inmates have already been captured and two others remain at large. ``We've been working on this case 24 hours a day ever since these guys got out,'' Howell said. ``It's fine that they're off the street and we're after the other two now.'' About 35 Chicago police officers and three fugitive-apprehension specialists from the Corrections Department took part in Thursday afternoon's raid on the two-flat apartment building. ``Allen was arrested in the living room, and Johnson was walking out the back door,'' Howelll said. The men were not armed and there was no resistance, the spokesman said. Allen and Johnson were being held at a Chicago police station and were to be returned to Joliet later Thursday, Howell said. The two inmates still at large are convicted murderer Dave Rodriguez, 21, of Chicago, and burglar Ronald Roach, 20, of Wyoming, Ill. Authorities had believed Allen and Johnson might have fled Illinois. On Wednesday, the FBI announced it had entered the case at the request of local authorities to help search for the fugitives outside the state. On Friday, a jail guard, William Smith, 46, of Joliet, was charged with aiding in the escape. Prosecutors said he gave inmates a hacksaw blade used to cut cell bars.

DOC.HEAD: Former Salvadoran President Dies of Cancer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 8th pvs, `In Washington...' to ADD that Quayle to lead delegation at funeral. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `Secretary of...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY27,29,30; LaserColor NY25
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jose Napoleon Duarte, whose quest for democracy in a society ruled by the privileged few was thwarted by a disastrous civil war, died Friday of cancer. He was 64. Duarte died at his home in the capital's fashionable San Benito neighborhood, said Dr. Jose Luis Saca. Doctors at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington diagnosed the cancer in May 1988 and removed 60 percent of Duarte's stomach, but the disease had spread to his liver. They gave him from six to 18 months to live. Duarte was president from 1984 to June 1989, when he was succeeded by Alfredo Cristiani of the rightist Arena party, who was supported by the oligarchy Duarte so long had fought. Nearly a generation ago, Duarte was arrested, beaten and exiled for his fidelity to democracy. He called his inauguration in 1984 ``a light in the long night of horror,'' and likened himself to Moses delivering his people. His role in replacing an authoritarian, semifeudal system with the beginnings of democracy was critical, but he finished his term, and his life, burdened by failure, compromise, frustration and dashed hopes. The war with the leftist Farabundo Marti Liberation Front is 10 years old. Poverty remains endemic in this small Central American nation of 5 million people, whose economy depends on U.S. aid. In Washington, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater issued a statement saying, ``President Duarte was the father of Salvadoran democracy, a dedicated servant to the people of El Salvador, and a firm friend of the United States.'' The White House said Vice President Dan Quayle will fly to El Salvador to lead the U.S. delegation at Duarte's funeral Sunday. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said, ``There could be no more fitting tribute to his memory than for his countrymen to follow his lead and to ensure that human rights and democratic institutions grow and strengthen in the country he loved so deeply and to which he gave so much.'' A high-ranking U.S. diplomat who served in El Salvador during most of Duarte's term said of him: ``He didn't work miracles, but he must be credited with instituting the democratic system itself. His great legacy is the transition. The rest pales by comparison.'' Opponents criticized Duarte's bombast and messianic attitude; supporters praised his idealism and fighting spirit. Both agree his role in El Salvador was historic. ``One must acknowledge President Duarte's democratic vocation,'' Cristiani said just before taking office June 1. ``He has, with his aptitude and positions, promoted the advance of democracy.'' Duarte was born in San Salvador Nov. 23, 1925, the second of three sons. His father was a tailor and his mother a dressmaker. Later, his father started a candy-making business that became prosperous enough to put all three boys through college. Jose Napoleon became a Boy Scout and remained active in the organization throughout his life. He was graduated from the University of Notre Dame in 1948 with a degree in civil engineering, married childhood friend Ines Duran, and worked in her family's construction business. They had six children. The barrel-chested engineer joined half a dozen other Roman Catholic professionals in 1960 to found the Christian Democratic Party. Most were young liberals hoping to put the church's social doctrine into practice through government. After three terms as mayor of San Salvador, Duarte ran for president in February 1972. He was winning handily when the army stopped the count and declared its candidate the winner. A few weeks later, he supported a coup by a dissident military faction. It failed. Duarte was arrested, beaten and told he would be shot. He was allowed to leave the country instead and spent more than seven years in Venezuela. Reform-minded military officers seized power in 1979 and Duarte returned. He joined the junta in 1980 and became its president. Civil war began and the army and police embarked on a brutal repression in which tens of thousands of people were killed, many by ``death squads'' officially sanctioned or tolerated. Duarte was criticized for presiding over terror, but he said things would be worse were it not for his presence. In an effort to deprive the guerrillas of an issue, the junta began what was envisioned as a radical land reform to break up large farms and turn them into cooperatives. The reform was a partial political success, but eventually bogged down because of organizational and production problems. When he was popularly elected in 1984, Duarte promised to bring peace and prosperity. In three attempts at negotiations with the leftist rebels, however, he did not budge from the demand that they lay down their arms and join the political process. The guerrillas refused, but now are considering it in talks with the Cristiani government. Mainly because of the war, the economy crumbled. The decline was hastened by droughts and an earthquake in 1986 that killed an estimated 1,500 people. U.S. economic and military aid reached nearly $2 million a day. Opponents decried what they called the president's subservience to the United States. Even his supporters cringed when Duarte kissed the U.S. flag at a White House ceremony. In a speech in June 1988, Duarte gave this assessment of his presidential term: ``The will of my people has caused me to navigate seas each day more stormy and more dangerous because of crosscurrents. The absence of fair winds and persistent adversity all along the route have joined to prevent us from bringing about our high aims.''

DOC.HEAD: Carnegie Commission Honors 19 Heroes
DOC.TEXT: A retired funeral director who pulled a man in a stalled wheelchair out of the path of a train in Oregon was among 19 Americans and Canadians recognized Thursday by the Carnegie Hero Commission. ``I'm kind of elated. I've never been called a hero before,'' said Dale R. Layton, 65, of Canby, Ore. Layton is among 7,424 people honored by the commission since its founding by Pittsburgh industrialist Andrew Carnegie in 1904. More than $18.3 million has been awarded in one-time payments and pensions to the heroes or their survivors. Five of those honored Thursday died in their rescue attempts. Layton had pulled into a coffee shop's parking lot on Nov. 17, 1988, when he heard a train whistle blowing non-stop. He turned and saw the train bearing down on Lawrence Supnet, 28, of Portland, whose battery-powered wheelchair had become stuck in the track at a crossing. ``I turned and ran just as fast as I could run,'' Layton said in a telephone interview. ``I just gave the chair one yank and tilted it back. I bet it wasn't five heartbeats from the time I grabbed it and the time the train was there.'' Also recognized Thursday were 15 other Americans and three Canadians: _Garry W. Proffit, 34, of Hollywood, Md., who drowned trying to pull a man from a water storage tank in Lusby, Md., on Sept. 15, 1988. _Michael G. Martinez, 40, of Hialeah, Fla., who died of a heart attack after saving an unidentified woman from drowning in the Atlantic Ocean at Miami Beach, Fla., May 29, 1989. _John K. Aiena, 44, of Beaumont, Texas, who died trying to save a man from drowning in a Port Arthur, Texas, marina May 26, 1989. _Betty B. Lamb, 69, of Sacramento, Calif., who died trying to save her 3-year-old grandson from drowning in the Pacific Ocean July 12, 1989, in Jenner, Calif. The child also died. _Keith A. Jensen, 33, of New Denmark, New Brunswick, who died trying to save his parents from their burning home Jan. 31, 1988, in New Brunswick. _James K. Webb of Fishkill, N.Y., and Richard Gustin of Lagrangeville, N.Y., both 25. They helped rescue three men from a burning car in Buchanan, N.Y., on April 11, 1989. _Anthony J. Vaca, 23, of Antioch, Calif., who pulled three men from two vehicles that caught fire after colliding in Antioch on March 23, 1989. _Donald L. Dobson, 31, of Reading, Pa., who dragged a woman from a burning apartment in Spring City, Pa., on May 26, 1988. _Denise Boczek, 31, of Camarillo, Calif., who helped save a 7-year-old boy from drowning in the Pacific Ocean at Oxnard, Calif., on June 22, 1989. _James J. Stack III, 30, of Chicago Ridge, Ill., who subdued a man who attacked two men on a bus with a knife March 14, 1989, in Bloomington, Ill. _David E. Kamerath, 47, of Salt Lake City, Utah, who rescued a 6-year-old girl from the second floor of her burning home April 21, 1989. _John M. Mattson, 24, of Pickering, Ontario, who struggled with a man who stabbed a store owner during a robbery in Pickering on Aug. 15, 1989. _Jeffrey A. Jones, 33, of Cathedral City, Calif., who pulled an injured man out of his pickup truck March 4, 1989, as a train approached in Coachella, Calif. _Marc Branch, 27, of Paquetville, New Brunswick, who rescued a 16-year-old girl from an overturned burning car Oct. 14, 1987, in Paquetville. _Donald L. Reed, 51, of Moscow, Idaho, who saved two women from drowning after their boat sank in the frigid Snake River April 15, 1989, in Pullman, Wash. _Karen A. Caylor, 29, of Pittsburgh, who pulled a woman from a car that was sinking in a canal May 16, 1989, in Naples, Fla. _Christopher M. Rumbaugh, 27, of Orlando, Fla., who pulled a woman out of a burning car June 8, 1989, in Tavares, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Chattanooga Sues to Halt Showing of `Oh! Calcutta!'
DOC.TEXT: It's the second longest-running musical in Broadway history, but if city officials get their way, ``Oh! Calcutta!'' won't have even one performance in Chattanooga. The city filed suit Thursday in Hamilton County Chancery Court to block the showing of ``Oh! Calcutta!'' at the Tivoli Theater on grounds it violates the state's obscenity law. The 10-page suit also claims the musical violates state and local laws against indecent exposure and a local ordinance against lewd and indecent conduct. A New Jersey promoter wants to stage the play May 2 or May 6 at the Tivoli, but the theater is run by the city's Memorial Auditorium Board, which last week voted against bringing in the production. ``The auditorium board just wants to do what it feels is best for the community and have shows that are in tune with community tastes,'' said City Attorney Randy Nelson. The city is seeking judicial support for its action because the Tivoli is publicly owned and can only deny use if an event violates local laws or business criteria. With 5,959 performances, the revival of ``Oh! Calcutta!'' was the longest-running musical on Broadway when it closed Sept. 24, although it has since been passed by ``A Chorus Line.'' The musical is now on a six-month tour of more than 90 cities, including Nashville. Al Stewart, a press agent for the musical's promoter, Singer Entertainment Consultants Ltd. Inc. of Port Murray, N.J., said the play is art, not obscenity. ``Something that has been around for 21 years and has played in 15 countries before 60 million people, I wouldn't go that far ... to say it is obscene,'' said Stewart. ``It is done in art. It's theater.'' No member of the Memorial Auditorium Board has seen the play, said Tivoli Manager David Johnson, but they have read the script. ``The board felt the play violated local and state ordinances on nudity and obscenity,'' Johnson said. The lawsuit contends the play's depiction of complete nudity and simulated intercourse and other sexual acts would be obscene under the state definition regarding community standards and offensive sexual conduct. The lawsuit also says the nudity would violate state and local laws against indecent exposure and the simulated sexual acts would violate a city law against lewdness. In 1975, Chattanooga tried to stop production of the nude musical ``Hair,'' but the U.S. Supreme Court struck down the ban, saying the procedure by which the performance was halted fell short of constitutional standards.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Rejects Claim Stevie Wonder Stole Song
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to include writethru designation. LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from Wonder, plaintiff's lawyer, details. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `Chiate contended...
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury Thursday rejected a $25 million claim that pop star Stevie Wonder's Oscar-winning 1984 song ``I Just Called to Say I Love You'' was stolen from another songwriter. The plaintiff, Lloyd Chiate, claimed Wonder's song, part of the movie soundtrack for ``Woman in Red,'' was stolen from a song he co-wrote titled, ``I Just Called To Say.'' ``I knew the truth in my heart all along,'' said Wonder, who attended the two-week trial and testified on his own behalf. ``I'm very sorry a lot of people had to spend a lot of precious time in this courtroom. But I do appreciate and respect justice.'' Wonder offered to try to smooth over the dispute by writing a song with Chiate and Lee Garrett, co-author of ``I Just Called To Say,'' and donate the proceeds to charity. ``Then we all really win,'' Wonder said. ``It is far easier to love than to hate.'' Chiate, 40, sued Wonder in 1985 under the superstar's real name, Steveland Morris, for copyright infringement, claiming that Wonder pilfered ``I Just Called To Say,'' co-written by Lee Garrett, after Wonder heard the song in 1977. Wonder, 39, denied stealing the song, which won an Academy Award in 1984. He said he wrote ``I Just Called to Say I Love You'' long before hearing the Chiate-Garrett composition and without any influence from the song. Chiate wasn't present when the jury announced its verdict. His attorney said his client was wronged by a star-struck jury and a biased judge who had originally dismissed the lawsuit but was overruled by an appeals court. ``I don't think that Mr. Chiate ever got a fair trial,'' said lawyer Herbert Dodell. ``The result was inevitable, a terrible miscarriage of justice.'' Jury foreman Robert Apfelzweig, 39, a research scientist from Pasadena, said the jury didn't find any evidence that Wonder had access to the Chiate-Garrett song and the two songs were ``quite dissimilar.'' ``Mr. Chiate's case started weak and got weaker,'' said Apfelzweig. Chiate contended that Wonder first had access to Chiate and Garrett's music during the summer of 1977, when Garrett played Wonder a tape recording of his music after the latter had talked Garrett out of committing suicide one night. Garrett and Wonder are boyhood friends. Garrett originally was named as a plaintiff in the suit, but he dropped out and testified for Wonder. Wonder testified in the courtroom of U.S. District Judge David W. Williams that he wrote much of ``I Just Called to Say I Love You'' on July 16, 1976, while being driven from his mother's San Fernando Valley home. It was at least a year, perhaps two, before he heard the song Chiate and Garrett wrote, he said. Wonder said that he later polished and recorded ```I Just Called to Say I Love You,'' which became a big hit and also won a Grammy.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Saved After 12 Hours on Reef
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details of sinking, quotes. Picks up 8th graf pvs, ```They didn't...' No pickup. This stands for the item listed as AM-Dive Boat on the AM-News Advisory.
DOC.TEXT: Nine people were rescued from a shallow reef early Thursday, 12 hours after their dive boat rolled over and sank in stormy seas. Rescuers said their survival was a tribute to cool heads and warm wet suits. The six passengers and three crew members aboard the 28-foot Diamond Girl were dumped in 70-foot-deep water at 5 p.m. Wednesday. A Coast Guard patrol boat picked them up in darkness. The nine were left clinging to a webbed-bottom flotation ring and said they propelled the raft through four miles of six- to eight-foot waves to the barrier reef they knew lay ahead, said Chief Petty Officer Charles Kemnitz. No one was injured. One of the passengers, Dave Kirkham, 29, of Ringwood, N.J., said he and dive master Graham Green, 22, were underwater when they spotted the boat sinking. ``Then we saw a scuba tank and then there's the boat about 50 to 60 feet away,'' he said. ``We bolted to the boat to see who could be in it.'' They grabbed life vests, a first-aid kit and a strobe light before heading for the surface. Coast Guard Petty Officer Alex Worden said the crew thought the vessel began taking on water when packing around the propeller shaft came loose. The craft then rolled over when it was hit by a big wave, he said. ``It went down very, very quickly,'' said Diamond Girl Capt. Craig Eubank, 28. The Coast Guard began a search after getting a call about 8:30 p.m. Wednesday from a passenger's girlfriend, who said the boat was overdue. A patrol boat spotted them at about 5 a.m., bobbing on the wave-swept reef about five miles from Key West. The water over the reef was about two feet deep, but waves six feet high swept through, periodically lifting the castaways off their feet, officials said. ``They didn't have time to get a (distress) call out,'' said Kemnitz. ``They were all divers, so they were all probably cool-headed people to begin with. They had a dive master with them, plus an experienced captain.'' The six passengers and a crew member all wore wet suits, which retain body heat and protect against coral cuts, Kemnitz said. ``I'm sure that helped a lot,'' he said. ``Two of the people, the only two who didn't have wet suits, were in the raft while the rest were in the water holding on to its side.''

DOC.HEAD: Bottles Of Cyanide Wash Up On British Coast
DOC.TEXT: Police roped off beaches and warned the public to stay away on Thursday after six plastic bottles of deadly potassium cyanide were found washed up on the southern English coast. The affected area stretches from the holiday resort of Brighton to Newhaven, 15 miles to the east. The bottles, along with 10 more containing harmless chemicals, are thought to have been washed overboard from a ship buffeted by recent heavy storms in the English Channel. The first bottles were discovered Wednesday. In a statement to news media, Brighton police warned the public: ``Don't go anywhere near the containers. You won't get a second chance if one is leaking.'' Potassium cyanide can kill if inhaled at close range. As police and a coast guard helicopter patrolled the shoreline looking for more of the nine-inch-long white bottles, firemen in protective clothing and breathing apparatus began clearing those already found. Police roped off all holiday beaches on the stretch of coast where the bottles were found and told the public to stay clear while the search and recovery operation continues. Martin Fitzgerald, a spokesman for East Sussex county council, said the bottles containing potassium cyanide bear the chemical's symbol, KCn, and its United Nations identification code, 1680. News reports quoted John Vass, secretary of a chemical company, BDH Ltd., of Poole in southwest England, as saying labels on the bottles indicated they came from there. The London Times quoted Vass as saying the company believed the six bottles were part of a shipment to Saudi Arabia that left England in late January and was due to arrive in Saudi Arabia March 2. Vass was quoted as saying his company's total potassium cyanide shipment had been 16 of the 1.1-pound bottles for use in laboratory testing.

DOC.HEAD: British Petroleum Submits Final Cleanup Plan
DOC.TEXT: British Petroleum officials on Thursday presented the Coast Guard with a plan for finishing clean-up of 12 miles of Southern California beach tarred by a spill of crude oil from a tanker. Company spokesman Jim Marino refused to provide details of the plan, which he said sets a ``preliminary timetable'' for reopening beaches closed by the Feb. 7 spill of 400,000 gallons of oil from the tanker American Trader. City, state and federal authorities must approve the plan before it is put into effect, Marino said.
