Even as oil was being cleaned from the beaches, state attorneys planned legal strategy for recovering damages from the tanker's owner and operator. An official with the state attorney general's office said both British Petroleum, which chartered the American Trader, and American Trading and Transportation Co., which owns the vessel, could be held liable for damages caused by the spill off Huntington Beach south of Los Angeles. ``We've yet to decide who to sue, but under state law both the transporter and the owner of the oil are liable for damages,'' said deputy attorney general Sylvia Cano Hale. Hale said she expected local officials to provide their damage assessments by April. How much money will be sought from the companies had yet to be determined, she said. Investigators believe the tanker was punctured by its own anchor as it maneuvered in shallow water two miles offshore to discharge its cargo into a submerged pipeline that leads to a refinery on shore. British Petroleum demonstrated two sand cleanup technologies intended to eliminate residual oil that may have penetrated beaches above the high-tide line along six miles of coast. One device, dubbed a ``beach sanitizer,'' resembles a Zamboni ice-rink grooming machine, except that it lifts and sifts sand, Marino said. The other employs a drag line that unearths sand beneath the surface so workers can remove buried oil residue. Clean-up crews continued to use pressurized warm water to clean rock faces at Bolsa Chica State Beach and the Newport Bay jetties. In all, 370 workers continued cleanup along 14 miles of coast, British Petroleum said. The 811-foot American Trader arrived in San Francisco Thursday, where it will undergo repairs to the damaged hull, said Coast Guard Lt. Jay Ellis said.

DOC.HEAD: Demo Opponents Spar Over Alleged Ethnic Remark
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: State Treasurer Ann Richards on Thursday accused Democratic gubernatorial opponent Jim Mattox of planting an article in a Hispanic-oriented newspaper that alleged she used an ethnically derogatory term. Tiempo, a Waco-based weekly, published an article Thursday alleging that Ms. Richards referred to illegal aliens as ``wetbacks'' in a speech text written during her successful campaign for Travis County commissioner in 1976. Ms. Richards, whose no-holds-barred oratory drew wide attention at the Democratic National Convention in 1988, denied using the term. ``Mattox has always got other people to do his dirty work when he could,'' Ms. Richards told The Associated Press. Mattox' press secretary, Kelly Fero, denied that the campaign had any connection with the article. ``We did not plant this story with anybody. We know nothing about this story. And that's all we have to say about it,'' Fero said. Recent polls have shown Ms. Richards leading the Democratic primary field and Mattox running third behind former Gov. Mark White in the race to the March 13 primary election. Mattox and Ms. Richards, however, have run a particularly heated campaign against each other. Republican Gov. Bill Clements isn't seeking a another term. Ernesto Fraga, publisher and author of the article, said he personally supports Mattox but that had nothing to do with the story. ``If any other candidate had written something like this, I would have printed it,'' Fraga said. Fraga made available to the AP a facsimile copy of the two-page, handwritten speech text on which he based his article, but declined to say how he had obtained it. Above the text is what appears to be Ms. Richards' letterhead. A sentence in the text said: ``If it takes a man to hire non-union labor, cross picket lines and work wetbacks then I say thank God for a woman or anyone else who is willing to take over.'' Shown a copy of the Tiempo story and the paper's reproduction of two sentences from the handwritten text, Ms. Richards said that the opening sentence of the text was her handwriting, but the sentence containing the word ``wetbacks'' wasn't. ``I can't tell you any more than what you can see here, that there are obviously two handwritings and that Jim Mattox's supporters put that out,'' Ms. Richards said. Ms. Richards came under similar criticism after a debate in Houston earlier this month, when she was heard by some to say, ``No legislator, no judge and no bureaucrat has any business in determining whether a white woman has an abortion or not.'' Ms. Richards has insisted she was misunderstood, that she said ``why a woman'' rather than ``white woman.''

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Premier Says Talks Encouraged Peace Process
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen said Thursday his talks with guerrilla leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk may have produced a basis for a peace settlement soon. The two leaders met in Bangkok Wednesday for talks sponsored by Thai Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan. ``We can regard this meeting as a success,'' Hun Sen told reporters before leaving for home. ``Because of the existence of such a basis, we will have some light of hope for peace in the near future.'' Hun Sen's remarks were translated into English by an aide. He did not elaborate or take questions from reporters. His government, installed by Vietnam after a late 1978 invasion of Cambodia, is fighting a coalition of three guerrilla groups led by Sihanouk, former ruler of the country. A joint communique issued Wednesday hinted at some progress in the talks but was vaguely worded and did not appear to contain any new concessions. On Thursday, the Khmer Rouge guerrilla group cited what it said were three recent battlefield operations it launched ``in cooperation with'' Sihanouk guerrillas. Sihanouk, criticized for his ties with the fanatical group, has denied any such cooperation existed. The Khmer Rouge killed hundreds of thousands of people in agrarian revolution when it ruled Cambodia before Vietnam invaded and installed another government. The Khmer Rouge army radio, monitored in Bangkok, said the two forces cooperated in attacking government positions in northwestern Siem Reap province in one operation on Feb. 14 and two operations on Feb. 15. It did not specify the nature of the cooperation in the strikes, but said 15 government soldiers were killed, war materiel was seized or destroyed, and villages were ``liberated.'' The Hun Sen-Sihanouk communique said a U.N. presence ``at appropriate levels in Cambodia is essential and should be encouraged.'' It did not say how far they accepted an Australian proposal for the United Nations to administer the country pending a national election. It also said they wanted a ``supreme national body'' that would symbolize national unity, but gave no details. Both leaders dodged the question of whether the body would include the Khmer Rouge, the largest guerrilla group, whose future role has been the major stumbling block in negotiations. Hun Sen and Sihanouk agreed to meet again in coming months, and expressed hope that wider peace talks next week in Indonesia will make enough progress to allow resumption of the international conference on Cambodia in Paris. That conference has been suspended since last August. Sihanouk will not go to Jakarta. Instead, he will cross into northwestern Cambodia on Friday to end a decade of exile and live a guerrilla-controlled zone in the northwest until a political settlement, his spokesman said. The Khmer People's National Liberation Front, which is allied with Sihanouk's forces, has reported a large-scale government counteroffensive since Monday against positions taken by guerrillas in recent weeks. Fighting was fierce as government forces on Wednesday attacked a Liberation Front base in the northwestern district of Sisophon, the guerrilla radio said. Resistance officials and Thai military officers said government forces also struck Monday and Tuesday near Svay Chek, a gateway to Sisophon. Ok Serei Sopheak, a spokesman for the Liberation Front high command, said the 1,300 attacking soldiers were backed by rocket launchers, heavy artillery and at least six Soviet-made T-54 tanks. He said the guerrillas held onto Svay Chek, killed 49 soldiers and wounded 20.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS to UPDATE with Speier obit; picks up Lasky obit. An AMs separate on Lasky moved as a0651. A separate on Craddock moved on the sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Hans Speier, who was the last living founder of the University in Exile of the New School for Social Research, died Saturday while vacationing in Sarasota Fla. of heart failure at age 85. Speier lectured on political sociology at the College of Politics in Berlin. At the New School, he was a professor of sociology. He emigrated from Germany in 1933 where he joined the University in Exile of the New School for Social Research in New York City and recruited many of the refugee scholars who made up its faculty. During World War II, he was section chief and later acting chief of Foreign Broadcast Intelligence Service. He also served as a propaganda adviser to the overseas branch of the Office of War Information. After the war, he worked for the State Department's Occupied Areas Division. He joined the RAND Corp. in 1948 and was in charge of its social science division until 1960. He was a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the World Academy of Art and Sciences. His latest book was ``The Truth in Hell and Other Essays,'' published last year. Other books he wrote included ``From the Ashes of Disgrace'' and ``Divided Berlin.''

Victor Lasky, who covered World War II in Europe for Stars & Stripes, the soldiers' newspaper, died Thursday of cancer at age 72. After the war, he joined The New York World-Telegram and helped write a Pulitzer-Prize-winning series on Communist infiltration of American institutions. He covered the trial of former State Department official Alger Hiss and co-authored a book about the case, ``Seeds of Treason.'' He wrote several biographies, including ``J.F.K: The Man and the Myth,'' ``Robert F. Kennedy: The Man and the Myth'' and books about Supreme Court Justice Arthur Goldberg, actor George Murphy, Jimmy Carter and Henry Ford II. In 1952, a documentary he wrote for MGM, ``The Hoaxters,'' was nominated for an Academy Award. In his later years, he was critical of journalistic misconduct and wrote for Accuracy in Media, a watchdog organization. He is survived by his wife, Patricia, of Washington and two sisters.

Albert W. Hampson, an artist who worked for The Saturday Evening Post, Look magazine and book publishers, died Monday of a heart attack at age 79. Hampson painted bank presidents, prominent doctors and the late Philadelphia mayor James H. Tate, whose 1974 portrait hangs in the City Hall Annex in Philadelphia. Hampson was 25 when he painted his first cover for the Post as a freelancer in 1935. Hampson was an art director and freelance commercial artist for various advertising agencies in New York and Philadelphia. He was a life member and for eight years a member of the board of directors of the Philadelphia Sketch Club.

Edward F. Owen, a longtime Omaha steel executive and philanthropist, died Thursday while vacationing in Naples, Fla. at age 73. The cause of death was not disclosed. Owen spent much of his life at the helm of Paxton & Vierling Steel Co., the family owned business he took over from his father, Fred Owen. At his death, Edward Owen was chairman of Owen Industries Inc., a parent company formed to manage Paxton & Vierling and other holdings. He also devoted much of his energy to charitable causes as diverse as the Henry Doorly Zoo, the Boys' Clubs of Omaha and the Omaha Community Playhouse.

Bruce Craddock, the head football coach of Western Illinois University for the past seven years, died Thursday after a 10-month battle with liver and intestinal cancer at age 46. He compiled a 41-35-1 record with the Leathernecks and was named Gateway Conference Coach of the Year in 1987 and 1988. His 65-54-1 overall mark included four years running the program at his alma mater, Northeast Missouri State. He was an assistant coach at the University of Vermont and NE Missouri before becoming head coach at his alma mater in 1979. Craddock was hired at Western Illinois in December 1982. His best season was 1988 when the Leathernecks were 10-2 overall, including 6-0 in winning the Gateway. He was inducted into the NE Missouri's Hall of Fame for athletes.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President Spends Whirlwind Day In New York
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `Havel met...,' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with details of concert. Picks up 14th graf pvs, `In receiving...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY21
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel sampled New York City's attractions Thursday while meeting with politicians, religious leaders, American writers and some pint-sized compatriots. Breakfast with Mayor David Dinkins was the first stop on a busy schedule that included meetings with the Council on Foreign Relations, Czechoslovak-Americans and U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar and stops to pick up academic and religious honors. All that followed a tour of some East Village hangouts Wednesday night shortly after his arrival with Czechoslovak-born filmmaker Milos Forman. During his visit Thursday morning to Gracie Mansion, the mayor's official residence, Havel met writers Kurt Vonnegut, Edward Albee and Arthur Miller. Afterward, he spoke with reporters about the ``extremely strange and extraordinary'' circumstances that resulted in his being elevated from dissident playwright to president. But, he added, it was not a job he coveted. ``I didn't want to be a president. But I was raised to the post by public pressure,'' he said. Havel was elected president Dec. 29 by the Czechoslovak Parliament a few weeks after a peaceful revolution that led to the ouster of a hard-line Communist government. Elections are scheduled for June. The breakfast meeting proved fruitful, professionally and personally, after producer Joseph Papp announced he was going to produce Havel's play ``Slum Clearance'' and the president received an invitation from Dinkins to come back to New York when he can spend more time. ``I like New York very much. I hope soon I will not be a president and accept Mr. Mayor's invitation,'' said Havel. Havel's last visit was in 1968 for opening night of one of his plays. Havel's next stop was the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he was greeted by two dozen flag-waving, cheering kids from the Czechoslovak School for children of Czechoslovak diplomats. ``For us the changes in our country are very exciting. But we're so far from home. This is our way of keeping in touch, with him and with our countrymen,'' said teacher Lida Husek. Havel met with religious leaders at the residence of Roman Catholic Cardinal John O'Connor's. He received an honorary degree from Columbia University and later attended an evening concert in his honor at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Paul Simon and Roberta Flack sang, and Zubin Mehta conducted the Brooklyn Philharmonic. There were readings, some from Havel's own speeches, by about a dozen actors and writers including Ellen Burstyn, Gregory Peck and Saul Bellow. Many speakers expressed joy and wonder that a playwright and former political prisoner now leads a nation. ``Vaclav Havel has shown the world that art matters,'' said actor Ron Silver. ``Help us overcome our cynicism and let us bask in the glory and joy of an artist leading us.'' In receiving the honorary degree, Havel recalled giving a speech at Columbia in 1968, when the Vietnam protest movement was in full swing in this country. Though the students were on strike, they attended the speech, Havel said, adding that experiencing the America of the late 1960s was part of his political education. ``The atmosphere of that time very much inspired me, influenced me,'' Havel said. At a pre-concert reception, Havel marveled at meeting actor Paul Newman, president of the Actors Studio, which last year performed the Havel play, ``Audience.'' ``Mr. Newman, whom I know many years from movies, who is such big legend that I didn't believe he physically exists,'' he said. ``Now I'm standing here with him.'' The Czechoslovak president and his wife, Olga Havlova, arrived in the United States on Monday. He addressed Congress and met with President Bush twice before traveling to New York on Wednesday. He was to return home Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Charles Defends Traditional Architecture.
DOC.TEXT: Eds: tops with 8 new grafs to update with dinner remarks, pickup 2nd graf pvs: Emerging from etc.

Britain's Prince Charles told leading American architects Thursday night that ``much of the commercial building of today bears as much relations to architecture as advertising slogans bear to literature.'' The 41-year-old heir to the British throne urged planners, developers and designers to remember that buildings exist primarily for human beings. ``The time has surely now arrived when we must learn to work with rather than against nature, when we can once again make places in which to live and work which are more than machines,'' he said. Charles laid down his challenge at a black-tie, $250-a-plate awards dinner of the American Institute of Architects where he was the star attraction. A sold-out audience of 1,200 architects, members of Congress, diplomats and Hollywood celebrities heard him warn that the world's cities are becoming ``the epitome of the throwaway society.'' ``If that comes about ... then I shall be proud to be considered old fashioned, reactionary, antediluvian, anachronistic,'' he continued. The architects came to the glittering National Building Museum anticipating some sharp barbs from Charles about the state of modern architecture. He did not disappoint them, noting that their welcome might be a sign that ``an epidemic of masochism (is) sweeping the ranks of the AIA.'' Earlier, after lunching with President Bush, the prince attended an architectual exhibit where he was hailed as ``Our Knight in Shining Armor'' because of is support for traditional architecture. Emerging from his limousine on the steps of the historic Octagon House, the Prince of Wales was obviously delighted to be met by a cluster of placards whose slogans included: ``Hurrah Prince Charles,'' and ``Humane Architecture _ Happy People.'' ``He saw the sign, `Shining Knight in Armor,' and he said, ``Gee Whiz,'' said Thomas J. Eyerman, a member of the Board of Regents of the American Architectural Foundation, one of the sponsors of the event. ``He was absolutely shocked that in America that people would have signs talking about architecture, calling him a shining knight in armor,'' Eyerman said. The pro-prince demonstrators told reporters they represented organizations that fought a long and ultimately unsuccessful fight to save Washington's historic Rhodes Tavern from demolition. The prince's objective at Octagon House, used as a temporary executive mansion by President James Madison after the British army burned the White House in 1814, was to view an exhibit commemorating the design of London's St. Paul's Cathedral by the leading British architect of the 17th century, Sir Christopher Wren. Octagon House, built in 1800, is now a museum of the American Institute of Architects. Charles married his wife, Diana, in St. Paul's in 1981. The prince reacted to the layout of architectural renderings and models with animation, looking at each exhibit closely, pointing out details and asking questions of one of his guides, Eric Evans, dean of St. Paul's. The works on display have never before been assembled as a unit and the prince was quoted by architects with whom he spoke as hoping they also could be shown in London. As the prince was inspecting the exhibit, America's leading architects gathered at a glittering black-tie gala for a royal critique of their work. On a chill, drizzly day, the 41-year-old heir to the British throne dined in the White House family quarters with Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle. The other luncheon guests included Secretary of State James A. Baker III, White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft, British Ambassador Sir Antony Acland and Henry Catto, U.S. ambassador to London. Bush escorted Charles down a red carpet to his Rolls-Royce limousine after lunch and shook hands with the prince, who wore a dark gray, double-breasted pinstripe suit. The busy schedule for Charles' one-day Washington visit also included an embassy reception for alumni of the Marshall Scholars program, under which the British government pays all costs for exceptional American students to spend two or three years at British universities. Later, Charles was the star attraction at a sold-out awards banquet for 1,200 architects, members of Congress, diplomats, Supreme Court justices and Hollywood celebrities at the National Building Museum. The prince's dinner speech gave him another opportunity to criticize the worst examples of modern architecture and appeal to his audience to design more attractive, comfortable buildings that are scaled to human needs and respect the surrounding landscape. Back home, Charles has angered some architects but won the applause of much of the British public with his contention that the London skyline has suffered more damage from architects, city planners and developers than from German bombers in World War II. In ``A Vision of Britain,'' a book he published last year, Charles accused some modern architects of creating ``Frankenstein monsters, devoid of character, alien and largely unloved.'' He says some new buildings in London remind him of word processors or nuclear power plants. Honored at the banquet was architect Fay Jones of Fayetteville, Ark., a former pupil of Frank Lloyd Wright who won the AIA's prestigious Gold Medal. Bush presented the award to Jones at a White House ceremony after the lunch for Charles. The prince will end a weeklong U.S. tour on Friday, when he meets with American environmental experts at the British Embassy before he returns to London. Charles began his visit last weekend by playing in two benefit polo matches at Vero Beach, Fla. He met Wednesday with 100 corporate executives in Charleston, S.C., to promote private investment in poor urban neighborhoods and plead for business cooperation in protecting the environment.

DOC.HEAD: Church Officials Condemn Ordination of Gay Priest
DOC.TEXT: After two months of official silence, the Episcopal Church's presiding bishop said a Newark colleague was wrong to ordain a practicing homosexual who later made embarrassing remarks about Jesus Christ and Mother Teresa. The Rev. Edmond L. Browning, who has refrained from comment on the ordination of J. Robert Williams, released a statement to church officials critical of the ordination handled by Newark Bishop John S. Spong. In the statement made public this week, Browning, the top Episcopal official in the United States, said he and his Council of Advice ``disassociate'' themselves from the ordination, but not from ``the many members of our church who are gay and lesbian.'' Williams raised controversy five weeks after his Dec. 16 ordination by belittling church teachings on celibacy and monogamy in a speech. He has told reporters he believed Christ had a gay lover and has implied that Mother Teresa would be better off if she had sex. Williams, 34, told a Detroit church panel in January that monogamy and celibacy are ``unnatural'' and made the remark about Mother Teresa, a Roman Catholic nun who has received a Nobel Prize for her work with the poor, in response to questions from a church official. The remark about Christ was made to a church group in Texas. Conservative church critics have demanded Spong's resignation, saying he violated a church resolution against admitting practicing homosexuals to the clergy. Until Williams' controversial remarks, Spong had defended the ordination as a way to make the church more inclusive. But after the remarks were publicized, Spong asked Williams to keep silent and refrain from functioning as a priest while the diocese investigates whether Williams misrepresented his views during the lengthy ordination process. National church spokesman Jim Solheim said the bishops objected to the way Spong heralded his intention to ordain an openly gay priest, thus polarizing the church community as a result. ``Practicing gays have been ordained before, but very quietly. The objection to Spong is to his style, it's to the way he did it,'' Solheim said. Spong, who is on sabbatical until March 1, was unavailable for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Carlsson Ready To Form New Swedish Government
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson, head of Sweden's caretaker Cabinet, is ready to lead a new government to replace the one which resigned last week, the national news agency TT reported Thursday. Earlier Thursday, the Social Democratic leader informed Parliament Speaker Thage G. Peterson he was ready and able to present the government to the legislature for approval. He was expected to get active support from the small Communist Party and passive support for the comeback by the middle-of-the-road Center Party. His previous government resigned on Feb. 15 when the Communists joined other opposition parties to defeat a bill for a two-year wage and price freeze.

DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles Files Own Suit Against Medfly Spraying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th, `The city...,' to UPDATE with governor meeting with city officials, quotes.
DOC.TEXT: Legal challenges to the state's urban pesticide spraying program cropped up like pesky Medflies on Thursday as officials in Los Angeles, Burbank, Glendale and Pasadena moved to stop the rain of malathion. Under orders from the Los Angeles City Council, City Attorney James Hahn filed a Superior Court lawsuit seeking an immediate halt to the helicopter missions to eradicate the Mediterranean fruit fly. The lawsuit, filed jointly with the cities of Burbank and Glendale, seeks a court order halting the spraying missions. It names Gov. George Deukmejian, the state Department of Food and Agriculture, department director Henry Voss and the County Board of Supervisors as defendants. It alleges the malathion missions violate residents' civil rights because the public has a right to be free of toxic chemical risks to their health. Agriculture officials maintain the pesticide is safe and warn that the Medfly, if established, could produce annual losses of $200 million to the state's agricultural industry. The lawsuit also contends that the agriculture department has violated pest eradication statutes requiring that non-pesticide alternatives be used before officials resort to spraying. In addition, the chopper sorties violate public nuisance regulations by creating excessive noise and damaging property, the suit alleges. The city of Pasadena planned to file an amicus brief supporting the lawsuit. Deukmejian met in Pasadena on Thursday with Pasadena and Glendale city officials, but the discussion yielded no agreements on the pesticide program or on a provocative new Pasadena ordinance prohibiting low-level helicopter flights at night. The Republican governor said he was confident the cities' suits would fail, adding,``The courts have consistently supported the position taken by the state.'' Meanwhile, the private Natural Resources Defense Council and a host of state legislators filed a second Superior Court action challenging Deukmejian's state of emergency decree enabling officials to spray the Medfly-killing pesticide over 400 square miles of Los Angeles and Orange Counties. Helicopters were to take to the skies again Thursday night to blanket a 30-square-mile area of the Verdugo hills in Burbank and Glendale as part of the state's $30 million Medfly eradication campaign. In Pasadena, City Attorney Victor Kaleta said he was awaiting a police report that could enable him to file criminal misdemeanor complaints against six helicopter pilots who conducted a spraying mission over the city early Thursday. The private pesticide sortie entered city air space at 12:55 a.m. Thursday. It was tracked flying at 500 feet, violating a new city ordinance that bans helicopterr flights below 700 feet. A police helicopter pilot contacted the formation, informed its pilots they were violating the ordinance, and ordered them to cease and desist. The pilots acknowledged they were in violation but continued spraying. The police pilot flew to the helicopter base at El Monte and informed the pilots that police would seek the complaints, said Lt. Gregg Henderson. With sufficient evidence, Katela said his office could file complaints possibly next week. The maximum penalty for violating the ordinance is a $1,000 fine and a year in jail. But the Federal Aviation Administration has said that only it can enforce laws regarding civil air traffic, and attorneys from the agency have met with Katela, said FAA spokeswoman Elly Brekke. ``We told him it was our interpretation that their ordinance was preempted by federal law,'' said Brekke, citing the supremacy clause of the U.S. Constitution. She said that under rules regarding crop dusting aircraft and aircraft for hire, ``There is no minimum altitude at which they must fly. The rules say the pilot must fly the helicopter in such a way that if there were an emergency aboard the aircraft, the pilot would be able to land the aircraft safely,'' said Brekke. ``The bottom line is that the altitude is at the pilot's discretion,'' she said. In addition to the Los Angeles lawsuit, the Orange County cities of Garden Grove, Huntington Beach and Westminster have sued in Superior Court. A judge refused their request to stop spraying immediately, but ordered the state to provide more information on malathion. The Legal Aid Society of Orange County filed suit in federal court, arguing the spraying violates the civil rights of homeless people who are unable to take health precautions if they are doused with pesticide. The Medfly lays its eggs in more than 250 varieties of fruits, vegetables and nuts grown in California. The crops are destroyed when the larvae hatch and growing maggots eat their way out.

An Ariane rocket carrying two Japanese communications satellites exploded just after liftoff, prompting the competitor to the U.S. space shuttle to suspend future flights. The unmanned Ariane 44-L rocket, powered by four strap-on boosters, blew apart Thursday, apparently from a fire in the propulsion system, Arianespace President Frederic D'Allest said at the launch site. ``All Ariane flights are suspended until we discover the reasons of this accident,'' he said. ``We are going to analyze this failure and explain the catastrophe of this flight as rapidly as possible.'' The failure came after 17 straight successful launches of the Ariane. The two satellites alone were insured for more than $200 million.

The 1980s ended with the lowest annual traffic death rate ever, capping a decade in which many Americans declared war on drunken driving and began using long-neglected safety belts, federal officials say. The 1989 fatality rate was 2.2 deaths per 100 million miles traveled, down from 2.3 the previous year and one-third lower than the 1980 rate of 3.3, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration reported. Fatalities in 1989 are estimated at 45,500, compared with 47,093 in 1988. Final numbers for last year are still being tallied but are unlikely to change significantly, officials said. ``The reduction in traffic deaths during the 1980s reflects our national resolve against drunk driving, increased safety belt use and a generally heightened awareness of highway safety,'' Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said Thursday.

A record medical malpractice award is causing some West Virginia obstetricians to turn away new patients and consider leaving the state, where their ranks already have been halved in five years. ``Some will probably leave if they get a chance. I would leave,'' Dr. Ujjal Sandhu said Thursday. ``I don't want to worry about losing my shirt. The patients will have to go out of state just like the doctors are leaving.'' A county jury in Charleston last week awarded a couple $15.25 million after they claimed their obstetrician failed to perform a Caesarean section to prevent brain damage to their newborn. It was the state's highest malpractice award against an obstetrician. Mark and Julie Robinson of Cabin Creek, about 15 miles east of Charleston, said Dr. Kanoj K. Biswas, a Charleston obstetrician, should have performed the Caesarean section on July 31, 1987, after their son became stuck in the birth canal.

Czechoslovak president Vaclav Havel dashed around Manhattan, receiving a hero's welcome from writers and artists, hobnobbing with punk rockers and meeting a ``legend'' _ Paul Newman. ``I've been in the presence of some great artists and I've been in the presence of some great statesmen, but I've never before been in the presence of a great artist-statesman,'' Newman said Thursday at a reception for Havel. With the wit and self-deprecation that typified the comments he made in broken English in his one-day whirl around the city, Havel called Newman ``such a big legend that I didn't believe he physically exists. Now I'm standing here with him.'' The Czechoslovak Parliament elected Havel president a few weeks after a peaceful revolution in December that led to the ouster of a hard-line Communist government. That regime had jailed Havel for five years for his satirical plays and other activism.

DOC.HEAD: For Gospel There's Only One Place: Bourbon Street
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Up the street a barker holds open the door for a peek at the nude dancer grinding away on a table top. Another show is advertised as the French Orgy, and the sign at the female impersonators' club says, ``boys will be girls.'' Music blasts from the bars and the T-shirt shops. Tourists dance in the street, drinks in hand. Bourbon Street is in full swing, and so is the Gospel and Blues Tent where Sherman Washington and the Zion Harmonizers are raising their voices in tight harmony while the crowd raises theirs in approval. ``It's wonderful. The people really get into it. They shout and carry on. It's a real joy,'' said Washington. After years in churches and concert halls, gospel has found a new home in a cabaret setting on Bourbon Street. The same people who pay to hear Dixieland and Cajun pay to hear the traditional black religious music. ``It's sure not church, but I think everyone has a good time listening to us,'' Washington said. Accompanied by a guitar and drums _ and sometimes keyboards, tambourine and base _ the Zion Harmonizers sing the same songs you can hear in black churches and tents across the United States. The hand-clapping music, an integral part of New Orleans' musical heritage, includes many of the standards such as ``Closer Walk,'' but other numbers are less well known. ``We have our own way of singing; our own style of harmonizing. You can't listen to it long without clapping your hands. It's what you would call an upbeat sound,'' Washington said. The introduction of gospel to rowdy Bourbon Street was made this winter by Ian Hardcastle, a white Canadian who doesn't sing it and didn't even know about it a decade ago. ``I'd never seen a gospel group. Then in 1972 I visited the Jazz Fest and heard it for the first time. That alone made me want to move to New Orleans,'' Hardcastle said. A real estate developer who restored historic buildings in Canada, Hardcastle moved south to live part-time in 1987. He now divides his time between the French Quarter and Toronto. Hardcastle's love of gospel produced the Blues and Gospel Tent on the site of the old Pete Fountain club. For a $3 cover, fans can listen to gospel from 8 p.m. to 10 p.m., and to the blues from 10 p.m. to midnight. The tent, which is actually a large enclosed courtyard, serves mixed drinks but no food, although a Sunday gospel brunch is being added. ``It might seem a little funny to some people to have us singing gospel in a place like Bourbon Street, but, who knows, maybe it gets a different kind of spirit into folks. The Lord works in mysterious ways and I don't think he minds us making music whereever we are,'' said Washington. Although Washington, 63, developed his music in church and the Zion Harmonizers were started by a Baptist minister, their performances and those of the other groups that play at the tent are strictly that _ performances. Washington knew the potential: He is one of the organizers of the gospel tent, the always crowded arena at the annual New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. Three New Orleans gospel choirs rotate at the club. ``It's not religious. I don't have a pulpit up front. I don't think people come here for religion. I think they come for the music, but what they get out of it is up to them,'' Hardcastle said. After 10 p.m., such groups as the Zion Harmonizers give way to singers such as Irma Thomas and Marva Wright and the blues. ``It's an easy transition,'' Hardcastle said. ``I think both are sort of the roots of American music.'' And if tourists feel more comfortable with the blues when they start out, gospel seems to be gaining ground with them. ``I see them being sort of stiff when we start out, but before you know it everybody is moving and tapping their feet with us. Their bodies just start in doing it before they know what's going on,'' said Washington.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv

DOC.HEAD: Sondheim and the British Put ``Sunday in the Park'' Together
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf of b0278, sent Feb. 22, bgng `Sondheim promised...' to CORRECT that he made remarks in a lecture, not an interview. Pickup 5th graf, `The New ...'
DOC.TEXT: ``Bit by bit, putting it together, bit by bit, only way to make a work of art.'' These lyrics, from Stephen Sondheim's ``Sunday in the Park With George,'' have a special resonance in London these days, as the Royal National Theater puts together the British bow of one of the most haunting and innovative musicals of the 1980s. ``Sunday in the Park'' dared to dramatize the artist's imagination in a show that couldn't be more removed from mainstream Broadway fare. It won the 1985 Pulitzer Prize for drama, a rare accolade for a musical. Sondheim promised that the British version will be very different. The composer-lyricist was recently in Britain, where he talked about the new production with students at Oxford University. The New York show starred Mandy Patinkin as Georges Seurat, the French pointillist master whose 1884-86 painting, ``A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte,'' is the musical's centerpiece. Australian performer Philip Quast inherits the part in London, opposite Maria Friedman as Seurat's mistress, Dot, a role originated by Bernadette Peters on Broadway. Its Broadway director, librettist James Lapine, has turned to movies, so the show, which opens March 15 at the National's Lyttelton auditorium, is being staged by Steven Pimlott, a Cambridge graduate best known for directing opera and the classics. In an interview before starting rehearsals, Pimlott said his task was ``to embrace on the one hand Seurat's painting and on the other the traditions of the Broadway musical.'' He and designer Tom Cairns flew to the United States in October to see the canvas at the Art Institute of Chicago. He did it for the creative stimulus. ``I'd have felt very odd doing this piece not having seen the painting,'' Pimlott said. ``It's a fabulous picture, a fun picture not least because the Chicago Art Institute makes so much of it. I think (Seurat's) `Bathers at Asnieres' is at least as good a painting, but we don't make quite as much of a fuss at the National Gallery.'' The first act of the musical takes place over a series of Sundays from 1884 to 1886 as Seurat works on his painting, using his distinctive style of dabbing dots of color onto the canvas so that when viewed from a distance they will form a picture. It ends with a memorable theatrical flourish as the actors position themselves like the figures on the canvas. The second act, set in present-day New York, invents a great-grandson for Seurat, an artist also named George, suffering the double burden of an imposing ancestry and creative blockage. Trying to emulate his great-grandfather's genius with color and light, George invents a ``chromolume,'' a bizarre contraption that ricochets laser-beams around the theater. This second act was problematic _ ``the infamous second act,'' jokes Pimlott _ because some Broadway audiences weren't sure whether this experiment in high-tech pointillism was a serious artistic statement or a joke. So Pimlott has turned his George into a performance artist working with humans, not machines. He has hired Martin Duncan, a well-known actor-director in British ``fringe'' theater, to stage a brief performance piece involving four actors. It is the third musical produced at the 26-year-old National, one of Britain's two flagship state-subsidized theaters. The first, ``Guys and Dolls,'' was a hit that went on to the commercial West End. But the second, Marvin Hamlisch's ``Jean Seberg,'' directed by Peter Hall, was a critical and financial flop. ``Sunday in the Park'' will run for 16 weeks, playing a full eight performances a week. This is unusual for a repertory theater. Its top ticket price of 20 pounds (about $33) is a record high for the three-theater complex. It is the second of three Sondheim shows to be seen in London this year. A commercial revival of ``A Little Night Music'' closed Feb. 17 on the West End. ``Into the Woods,'' his most recent Broadway show, opens Sept. 25 and will star Julia McKenzie.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv

DOC.HEAD: Frank Zappa on the Financial News Network?
DOC.TEXT: And now, for something completely different. Frank Zappa, the rock star whose heart belongs to Dada, tonight begins a three-day stint as guest host of a TV show _ on cable's Financial News Network. His forum: FNN's ``Focus'' series. But the topics won't be the state of rock, his 25 years of innovation and playful experiments in music, or any kind of music at all. They are, however, in the Zappa tradition: eclectic. Tonight's show concerns four opportunities for U.S. business in the Soviet Union. He taped the segments during a trip five weeks ago to Moscow, Paris and Czechoslovakia, where he met the country's new president, Vaclav Havel. One segment, he says, details how Tass, the official Soviet news agency, has begun an operation that could be a Soviet TV news store, offering Western TV outlets its reports from the U.S.S.R., Eastern-bloc countries and elsewhere. ``They're trying to find Western consumers for the product of their audio-visual department,'' Zappa says. And, he says, ``they'll shoot your story to order. Tell them what you want, they'll shoot it.'' Tuesday's show will be a chat with the owner of Manhattan's Le Cirque, a restaurant where Robin Leach's kind of people dine. On Wednesday, Zappa will interview former CBS newsman Daniel Schorr, now a comentator on National Public Radio, about news as a business. Zappa, who once described himself as a `composer-slash-businessman'' despite his rock roots and such gonzo classics as ``Weasels Ripped My Flesh,'' concedes some may think it weird he's appearing on FNN. ``I think part of the reason people think it's so odd is the name of the venue,'' he says of FNN, which says it is seen in 33 million homes and offices. ``Financial News Network sounds pretty gray and corporate.'' He cheerfully admits high finance is not his bag: ``All I know of the stock market is that it's all voodoo, and that the best thing that's happened in this part of the 20th century is that Drexel Burnham self-destructed.'' But FNN, he says, is starting to offer programming in the evening hours that aims at a broader audience than tunes in for its daytime reports on Wall Street and world finance. He cites ``Focus,''whose host, Bob Berkowitz, is off on a book tour, as such a broader-audience program. He says he first appeared on it two months ago, talking about doing business with the Soviet Union. Despite his recent non-musical expeditions, Zappa, 49, is still busy with his music and says he's working on two new albums. He also has overseen the transfer of his 50 other albums to compact discs for release this year. And he has written his first television score, for ``Outrage at Valdez,'' a Cousteau Society special on the Exxon Valdez oil spill. Ted Turner's TBS cable network will show the program March 25. After Wednesday, Zappa plans to return home to North Hollywood, Cal., and finish editing the tape he shot in Czechoslovakia, where he has a cult following, during that nation's joyous process of liberalization. The footage, he says, will be made into a one-hour show that Great Britain's ITN network has bought for showing on London's Channel Four in June, just before Czechoslovakia's presidential elections. His show will be part of a six-hour extravaganza called ``An Evening of Revolutionary Entertainment,'' he says. Like his music videos, Zappa's Prague program eventually will wind up for sale, distributed by a Chicago company called MPI Inc. His TV marketing company has a somewhat more interesting name. It's called Honker Home Video, he says, solemnly explaining: ``It's named after my nose.'' __ Elsewhere in television ... HAVEL FETED: Vaclav Havel, the Czech playwright-turned-president, will be saluted by New York's leading artistic figures in a PBS special airing Thursday night. The special was taped last week. Performers on the saluting schedule include Dizzy Gillespie, Paul Simon, Placido Domingo and the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra.

DOC.HEAD: Demand for Efficiency Drives Costs of Snow Removal
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Ignatius Balistrieri, a city sanitation worker for 31 years, remembers the days when Milwaukee's snow-covered streets were plowed using horses and buggies. ``The men would stand in back and fan the sand mixture onto the road,'' he says. But while snow falls the way it always has, the methods for removing it have evolved into a high-tech multimillion-dollar enterprise stretching across the northern United States. Cities in the Midwest, Northeast and mid-Atlantic each winter spend millions of dollars keeping streets and walkways clean. Advancing technology has made the job easier. Improved snowplows have reduced the number of workers needed to clear roads. Hydraulic-powered plows on road salt trucks can be operated by one person, for example, while the older plows required at least two workers to maneuver. And road trucks sanding slippery roads now use salt-sand mixtures and chemicals like liquid calcium chloride, which speed up the melting process, in place of traditional sand. But the new technology also has made the task more expensive. Milwaukee spent $4 million to plow and salt 1,400 miles of road in 1988, compared with $2 million in 1984, even though the city received 13 more inches of snow in 1984 than 1988, Balistrieri said. Milwaukee averages about 49 inches of snowfall each winter, and city officials always are prepared to clear at least that much. But erratic winters in Washington, D.C., which budgets about $2.5 million annually for snow removal, have made it hard to forecast what's needed, said Tara Hamilton of the Public Works Department. ``After the 1987 winter, when we got 20 inches of snow in four days, we pretty much made up our minds that we were going to be a snow city and invest in the resources needed for that,'' she said. But since November, less than 13 inches has fallen, according to the National Weather Service. ``It's hard to have a typical winter in Washington,'' Ms. Hamilton said. Officials in Buffalo, N.Y., which averages 92 inches a year, already have exceeded their budget for road salts this year, but not because the city has gotten too much snow, said street commissioner James Makowski. ``It's the minor snowfalls that kill us,'' Makowski said. ``We get a quarter-inch and go out and salt, then get another quarter-inch dropping a couple of hours later and have to go salt again.'' Buffalo, which budgets about $3.5 million a year for snow removal, used 9,500 tons of salt from Thanksgiving to Dec. 19 in 1988 and 23,800 tons for the same period in 1989, he said. Minneapolis spent about $4 million plowing 1,057 miles of streets last winter and has experimented this winter with new equipment that can plow more area at a time, said street maintenance engineer Bob Otto. Minnesota's average snowfall is 49 inches a year. Although homeowners don't spend millions on snow removal, they too are looking for easier ways to clear their front doors, driveways and sidewalks. Walk-behind or riding snowthrowers with a price range of $350 to $1,700 are becoming household items, manufacturers say. Retailers ordered 543,000 snowthrowers in 1988, compared with 348,000 in 1984, said John Liskey of the Outdoor Power Equipment Institute near Washington, D.C. ``Snowthrowers aren't seen as a luxury item anymore,'' said Chad Kelly, marketing manager for The Toro Co. in Bloomington, Minn. ``We're seeing more planned purchases.'' When Toro first manufactured snow removal equipment about 30 years ago, it sold only a gas-powered, walk-behind snowplow, Kelly said. ``We've come a long way,'' he said, noting consumers can now choose from dozens of models and sizes of snowthrowers that can toss snow more than 35 feet. There also are rotating electrical brooms and power shovels. Women and older people who might find conventional snow shoveling too strenuous are being targeted as potential customers. ``It's a very competitive business and very volatile,'' Kelly said. ``When it snows, people come out in droves to buy the product and it can be very profitable. But when it doesn't snow, they're hard to sell.'' Most parts of the nation experienced a mild winter last year, leaving retailers with large leftover inventories that should cut demand for products this year by 10 percent, Liskey said. Kelly said he doesn't foresee any inventions in the near future that will radically change snow removal, although improvements are likely for many of the current products. ``I think products will continue to be made lighter and easier to use,'' he said. But, he said, ``I don't see any laser technology that blasts the snow off your driveway in three seconds.''

DOC.HEAD: Once Again, That's 1-800-44-CHUNK ...
DOC.TEXT: John Lurie keeps popping up in the strangest places _ like right before that ad for ``The Clapper,'' or right after the one for Zamfir, master of the pan flute. ``Hello, I'm John Lurie,'' he begins softly. ``And I want you to know, now you can listen to the very strange and very beautiful music of the Lounge Lizards here in America, just like people in other lands.'' And you can _ by dialing 1-800-44-CHUNK. The Lounge Lizards, whose sound was once likened to ``a Holiday Inn band on acid,'' are now available by dialing the same operators in Omaha, Neb., who take orders for the latest from Slim Whitman, Boxcar Willie and Richard Clayderman. So how does Lurie, a hipster saxophonist-actor-songwriter-screenwriter and bandleader wind up sharing late-night TV space with the Veg-O-Matic? ``I had to do it. I had no other choice,'' he explained recently in his cluttered Manhattan apartment. ``What else am I going to do with my life? What else? I could buy a condo, or I could put my record out.'' The record _ ``Voice of Chunk'' _ is available now, $11.99 for cassette, $14.99 for compact disc. The ads began airing this month in selected markets and nationally on VH-1. In one, Lurie appears as a tall, thin, twisted version of the pitchman who once asked if you remembered the Polovtsian Dance Theme Number Two. ``If you're like me, you like to receive things through the mail. Maybe it's because it makes me feel less lonely,'' Lurie says in another of the 30-second spots. ``Listen _ that's the new Lounge Lizards record, `Voice of Chunk.' And now you can receive it through the mail.'' The ads approach but don't quite reach parody, which is what Lurie had in mind when he decided last year to produce and market the record himself. Fears that some people wouldn't get it were heightened in the first days after the Feb. 1 air debut, the Lounge Lizard said. ``There was a week, 10 days, of absolute terror. It was running on TV, and it looked bad, and it wasn't selling,'' said Lurie, holding a cigarette in one hand while rattling dice in the other. ``I was losing my mind.'' Orders are now coming in every day, and Lurie is finding the experience far more pleasurable than dealing with record company weasels. The saxophonist, who formed the Lizards in 1979, has nothing good to say about major labels: ``Obviously, the music I'm doing is better than what they're putting out. It's just not as saleable.'' So he's selling it himself, which he has found provides a certain instant gratification. ``You go down to the mailbox, and there's all these orders there. It's not like the record company telling you, `Well, yes, you sold 60 records today.' You go downstairs, and there's 50, 60 checks in the mail,'' he said. ``It's like the good old days when the band used to get paid in cash.'' While the ads are showing up in strange places, it's not unusual for Lurie to do the same thing. His band was in Brazil last year to headline a jazz festival; he was in Morocco to play St. James in ``The Last Temptation of Christ''; he's starred in a pair of low-budget, critically hailed Jim Jarmusch films; he's planning a Japanese tour with the Lizards this spring. The eight-piece band, while a relative nonentity in the United States, is a sensation in Europe, Japan and South America. It once bothered Lurie, but he now accepts his limited American audience as a function of the U.S. music business. ``In France or in Germany, we're really the new geniuses of jazz _ though I still don't know if it's jazz or not,'' he said. ``We're hailed, and we play to 10,000 people in Japan. It's a whole different deal. ``And then you come back to America and it's like the air is taken out of your sails. ... The success of music (in the United States) is really inversely proportional to its quality. I'm really beginning to believe that.'' Lurie risked a large chunk of change on the Lizards' fifth album, and he's considered the possibilities either way: If the album sells, or if the album stiffs. ``If it really works, I'll make so much money. I mean, I heard Zamfir is a millionaire,'' he said. ``I read it in the Wall Street Journal, so it must be true.'' And if it doesn't? ``I'm really ruined. I'm going to be so broke. You're going to be seeing me on a lot of TV shows.''

DOC.HEAD: Recycling Industry Trying To Keep Up With Recycling Frenzy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ST2 of Feb. 21
DOC.TEXT: The recycling industry, which quietly went about its business for decades, suddenly has been thrust into the spotlight as everyone scrambles to become ``recycle friendly.'' One industry report estimates more than $2 billion will be spent across the nation for recycling equipment over the next five years to keep up with the enormous interest. Two years ago, the National Solid Wastes Management Association featured only two recycling waste trucks at its annual convention. At the most recent convention, there were 27 models. Supermarkets are collecting plastic grocery sacks for recycling. Procter & Gamble Co., a leading maker of consumer products, has started introducing plastic and paper containers taking advantage of recycled materials. Wal-Mart Stores Inc., a leading retailer, has begun tagging shelves to inform shoppers about recycled materials and other environmentally conscious products. ``I have been in this business a long time, and I have never seen anything like what's going on today,'' said John Veidt, a 20-year veteran of the recycling business who runs the reclamation division of Clayton, Mo.-based Jefferson Smurfit Corp. For a century, the recycling industry has pretty much operated on its own, chugging along on a supply-meets-demand basis with about 2,000 member companies of the National Association of Recycling Industries. But the 1980s brought big changes, most notably the involvement of government, which created unprecedented expansion opportunities. ``Generally, I think industry is recognizing that recycling is just good business,'' said Richard Keller, a spokesman for the National Recycling Coalition and chairman of the group's subcommittee on market development. The government _ at every level _ has become a major player in supplying raw materials that need to be recycled, mandating the use of recycled products and buying the products. In the fall of 1986, 13 states had legislation favoring the use of recycled products. Today, that number has grown to 34 with laws affecting 17 out of every 20 Americans, the coalition says. One measure of the market's growth is the Official Recycled Products Guide. The first edition, published by Robert Boulanger in April 1989, listed 177 products made with recycled materials, mostly paper products. In nine months, the number of listings has climbed to 1,500. Now, the New York-based guide includes building construction, landscaping, rubber and plastic products. Keller remembers the days in the early '80s when he could do his seminars on developing markets for recycled items ``in a phone booth and have room left over.'' ``Today, everybody is interested,'' he said. That interest has been good and bad. The paper side of the business is oversupplied; the glass side is undersupplied. ``The dilemma we have ourselves in is that we have the collection process geared up and hot, but it's going to be three years before ... we are ready to start using the material,'' said Veidt of Jefferson Smurfit, the nation's largest collector of waste paper. Veidt said Jefferson Smurfit, which also makes paper, cardboard and plastic containers, is among those papermakers looking to expand. The company wants to build a new plant devoted completely to recycling newsprint, he said. Jefferson Smurfit also recently announced a joint venture with Waste Management of North America to collect waste paper that will boost the company's collection to more than 4 million tons a year, more than three times its nearest competitor. Many other large paper companies in the United States and Canada plan to build mills closer to cities, or ``urban forests,'' to exploit the abundance of waste paper. The supply glut has dropped prices for a ton of used newspapers to all-time lows, and tons of the stuff are sitting in warehouses. In some parts of the country, people have to pay to drop off their newspapers, Veidt said. The glass industry faces the opposite problem. Glass makers would like to increase the percentage of waste glass used in the manufacture of new containers, but supplies are tight. Interest in waste glass recently was heightened by the success of an Anchor Glass plant in Connellsville, Pa., which ran on nothing but used glass for seven weeks, said Chas Miller, a spokesman for the Glass Packaging Institute in Washington. ``I loved to be able to run all our plants using 60 percent of cullet (used glass) but we can't get the supply,'' said Austin Fiore, regional manager of recycling and public affairs for Owens-Brockway Glass Containers Inc., a division of Owens-Illinois Inc. Fiore, who is based in Philadephia, said the company's 24 plants around the country are capable of using 85 percent used glass, but can find only enough clear glass to use between 22 percent and 45 percent. Experts differ on how profitable the recycling business will be. While government interest has been intense, growth may depend on private investment. ``Companies know that recycling is the wave of the future and they are all trying to get in a position to do it,'' said Vishnu Swarup, a stock analyst for Prudential Bache Securities in New York. ``Right now, they're sharing the profits and losses with the community, but some day they'll tell the community we can't keep doing this.'' That may come by the mid-1990s, he said. Publisher Boulanger summed it up this way: ``The technology is there to do it. There's public awareness. The government's ready. The only thing that hasn't been ironed out is the economic side _ who's going to pay for it.''

DOC.HEAD: GOP Seeks To Gain Enough Senate Strenth To Bid for Control in 1992
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Off-year elections usually are lean years for the party that holds the White House, but Republicans think they can break the pattern in 1990 and gain enough Senate strength to bid for renewed control in 1992. To do it, they'll have to add at least one or two to their current 45-seat minority, reversing the odds that confront a president's party with the liklihood of losses in the congressional elections between presidential campaigns. That and House redistricting make the Nov. 6 elections crucial in shaping congressional politics for the rest of the century. The 36 governors and the legislatures being chosen this year will control the redrawing of congressional districts based on the 1990 cenus. ``The political jackpot is going to be who gets to draw the lines come 1991,'' Vice President Dan Quayle says. It all comes together in 1992 when President Bush presumably will be seeking a second term, the new House districts will be in effect for the first time and Senate control could be within the reach of Republican challengers. The House is too Democratic, and incumbents too strong, for there to be any near-term prospect of a change in the control the Democrats have held for 34 years. They now have 85 seats more than the Republicans, and the president's party has not gained House seats in a midterm election since 1934. ``If 1992 is a good year for Republicans and we do well in 1990, then we stand to gain immeasurably in political terms,'' Quayle said in a recent interview. ``So this is a year to really establish the foundation.'' That won't be done easily. Republicans have 18 Senate seats at risk this year, Democrats 16. Only three incumbents have announced they are retiring, and all are Republicans. But the GOP is almost certain to hold one of those seats, in New Hampshire, and is in good position to recapture the others, in Idaho and Colorado. Overall, Quayle says the Republicans ``have a better crop of challengers this time, on a comparative basis, than we've ever had.'' That includes a half-dozen House members risking those seats to run against Democratic senators. The Democrats, on the other hand, have seen some of their most promising challengers step aside for 1990. In two states where Republican senators would have been heavy favorites anyhow, they may not have a thing to worry about. Virginia Democrats have not found a candidate to oppose Sen. John W. Warner, who says he would ``accept that decision with humility'' and campaign anyhow. Nor is there significant opposition so far to Republican Sen. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, 87 and seeking a seventh term in the Senate he entered as a Democrat. He switched parties in 1964. Democratic Sen. David Pryor of Arkansas has no announced opponents, either, in his bid for a virtually certain third term. Campaigns like those are typical, with incumbents strong and challengers facing long odds. Some will tighten toward upsets; most will run to form. The 1990 Senate battlegrounds will include Iowa, Illinois, Michigan and Rhode Island, with Democratic incumbents, and Kentucky and South Dakota, where Republican senators seek new terms. Sen. Dan Coats of Indiana, appointed to succeed Quayle, is running in his first statewide election, challenged by a Democratic state representative. That's a long shot for the Democrats, but it will be a target. They would delight in capturing the vice president's old Senate seat as they won the seat he and Coats once held in the House. The battle for the Senate itself likely will wait at least two years. With the Democrats up 55 to 45, it would take Republicans an improbable five-seat off-year gain to get to the tie the vice president's vote would make into a GOP majority. But the erosion of Republican Senate strength over the past three elections is, ironically, one basis for GOP optimism this time. Off-year swings against the White House party usually occur because of the vulnerability of first-term members elected on the coattails of the winning presidential candidate. The major impact is in the House, with two-year terms, rather than the Senate, with six. But Democrats have not sustained a net loss of Senate seats in any election since 1980, when the Republicans gained a dozen and captured the control they held for the next six years. Twenty seats now held by Democratic senators will be up for election in 1992, while Republicans will have to defend 14. Bush's name atop the ticket should help GOP Senate candidates, although he showed no coattail strength in the 1988 elections. Then again, the voters may prefer the lineup of power the way it stands now. An NBC News-Wall Street Journal poll conducted last month found 63 percent of those surveyed think it is better to have different parties controlling Congress and the White House, and only 24 percent want both branches in the same political hands.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 26 years.

DOC.HEAD: An AP Newsfeatures Extra
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: As Alice said in Wonderland: ``It gets curiouser and curiouser.'' In another context, Future Shock is already here. That's what the news is like these days, foes become friends, dictatorships become democracies, and the old shock of recognition is gone. In the following, a veteran AP newsman tells of his efforts to keep up with events.

I'm having trouble absorbing the news these days. History now seems to march in exclamation marks. Irony abounds, the time machine looks warped, credulity is stretched and you can't tell the players WITH a score card. The Cold War ends in a strange admixture, reviving both the fears of World War II about a triumphant Germany and the hopes of World War I about a world made safe for democracy. Now a wildly cheering Congress greets the president of the new and independent Czechoslovakia, who was in prison four months ago. It was an American president, Woodrow Wilson, who created Czechoslovakia in the first place, before it was swallowed by Hitler and shackled by Stalin. And here is Vaclav Havel, out from the Soviet shadow, telling the government of the United States that the best way it could help his country and the world was to help the Soviet Union on the ``immensely complicated road to democracy.'' In this way, says the man from a recent slave state, the Cold War can be replaced by ``an era in which all of us, large and small, former slaves and former masters _ will be able to create what your great President Lincoln called the family of man.'' This is but the latest in a racing river of change. In the first joyous rush west after the Berlin Wall came down, it seemed unseemly to recall that the last time there was a unified Germany it tore the world apart. In the 45 years since Hitler was smashed, Western and Eastern Europe mostly worried about each other. Now both seem to be on tiptoe looking for a polite way to get a guarantee of peace from the merging Germanys. Said an East German official: ``Our friendly neighbors should understand the desire of Germans for reunification.'' Said Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France: ``Germans should also understand the worries of their friendly neighbors.'' For most of the Cold War years, the vocabulary of the Kremlin seemed to be limited to one word, nyet. Now suddenly we find the Moscow leadership agreeing on a Thursday to what it positively opposed on Wednesday. There are days when dour Bolsheviks sound like friendly Rotarians. The two superpowers, whose mutual enmity kept the world nervous for four decades, now seem like one and a half superpowers, maybe less. The Soviets appear to be shrinking in a sea of troubles and, after Panama, Uncle Sam looks less than a giant astride the planet. Germany appears to dominate the thoughts of the old world. Drugs command the attention of the new. In Washington, the mayor of the capital of the United States is indicted for possessing cocaine and lying about his drug connections. On the same day, in Colombia, the president of the United States seeks ways to stop cocaine smuggling from South America. In Miami, a sullen little man with an utterly resistible personality awaits trial on charges of cocaine trafficking. Getting him to trial took 12,000 U.S. soldiers, scores of planes and ships and the lives of 23 Americans and several hundred Panamanians. The world was also treated to the picture of American fighting men trying to flush out their quarry with thunderous rock music. In Colombia, four presidents agree on the need to find other crops for Andean farmers to grow instead of coca, from which cocaine derives. President Bush promises to try to expand U.S. markets for coffee and cut flowers. Will the next Marshall Plan be designed to stop coca not communism, dope peddlers not agents of Karl Marx? Or will the next Cold War be fought with midget mercenaries dropped from the air? In an accelerated secret program, the U.S. Department of Agriculture was reported studying the killing power of malumbia, an inch-long white moth which, in its caterpillar stage, adores dining on the green leaves of coca plants. The cocaine summit was guarded by warships, frogmen, high-speed patrol boats, swarms of helicopters, at least one submarine and 5,000 security agents on land. All were there to protect the commander in chief of the United States and his confreres against the gangsters of Colombia who, we are told, now hone their public image with the aid of public relations consultants. In other areas rife with strife, Nelson Mandela of South Africa said that toward the end of his 27 years in prison his jailers let him see old Don Ameche movies; a New York judge ruled that to deny a beggar the chance to beg is to deny him his right of free speech; Ivana Trump said $25 million was nowhere near enough for a divorce; Soviet officials toured the Kennedy Space Center while NASA readied a secret shuttle to spy on their homeland; and tiny Albania, said to be the poorest nation in Europe and one of the most suspicious _ it has no diplomatic relations with the United States or most of the world _ Albania let it be known it would welcome foreign investments but not let foreigners own anything!
DOC.NOTE: END ADV

DOC.HEAD: Quiet Northern Irish Town Rebuilds from Yet Another Bomb
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto EDITOR'S NOTE _ The bombs go off and the news tells of the death toll, the damage and who was responsible _ another episode soon to be lost in all the other tragedy of 20 years of violence in Northern Ireland. But while others forget, the scars remain with the people who were bombed, the survivors of the dead, the maimed. Warrenpoint in Northern Ireland is an example of what ``the troubles'' have wrought. ___
DOC.TEXT: The roof is back on Charlie Wills' gas station, Pat Rice is back in his house, and it takes a second look to see the scars that an IRA bomb left on Mariann Cooper's face. The scars on the town, though, are still raw: a hole next to the police barracks on Charlotte St. where a hardware store and Mrs. Cooper's home once stood; the ``For Sale'' signs on two boarded-up houses; the flowers outside the police station for Joanne Reilly, killed in her 20th year. Warrenpoint, about 40 miles south of Belfast and just across the border from the Irish Republic, has been through this before. But it has become a microcosm of the personal tragedy faced by people and towns in Northern Ireland's 20 years of fighting between the forces loyal to Britain and the partisans of Irish unity. The news reports and broadcasts tell of the death and destruction; time passes, and then the people are alone in their mourning and loss. More than 2,700 people had been killed before Joanne Reilly was killed in Warrenpoint last April 12. While Warrenpoint has tried to rebuild, 47 more have died in Northern Ireland. The British government last year paid out 11.6 million pounds, the equivalent of $19.7 million at current exchange rates, in compensation for personal injuries caused by the conflict, and 20.6 million pounds ($35 million) for property damage, according to the Northern Ireland Office. Mariann Cooper had been about 50 feet away from a bomb big enough to damage houses a mile away. She is now deaf in her left ear, has only partial sight in her left eye and faces more plastic surgery on her face. That explosion at 10 minutes to 10 on a Wednesday morning is like a videotape running and re-running in her head. ``That's the only way I can explain it,'' she said. She keeps a big folder of newspaper clippings about the disaster, and insists she wants to forget. ``Having said forget, I'd like people to remember it happened. Why it happened. It happened for no reason.'' Mrs. Cooper is a Roman Catholic; her husband, Stuart, is a Protestant living through a conflict that has pitted Catholic against Protestant. ``It doesn't make a difference in Warrenpoint,'' Cooper said. The bomb that disrupted their lives was packed into a stolen Toyota van that was driven into a yard behind the Heatley and Morgan hardware store _ next to the police barracks. Miss Reilly, working in the back of the store, was killed instantly; at least two dozen people were injured badly enough to require hospital treatment, and 32 families were put out of their homes. The Daisy Hill hospital was already receiving the wounded when the Irish Republican Army gave its first telephone warning. The IRA later said the bomb exploded prematurely and offered ``sincerest apologies'' to the bereaved and the injured. ``Even if we had two hours' notice and cleared the entire town of Warrenpoint ... you still would have had 364 premises damaged,'' said Jim McCart, a member of the county council. That's one of every six homes in Warrenpoint, a town of 5,600 people, 85 percent of whom, including the dead woman, are Catholics. It's a stronghold of support for the Social Democratic and Labor Party, which rejects violence but shares the IRA's goal of a united Ireland. The bomb did little damage to the police barracks, which is surrounded by high walls and barbed wire and is protected from mortars and missiles by a steel roof. Charlotte St. ``was a happy enough street, everybody got along with everybody,'' said Rice, who had spent a decade renovating his house across the street from the police station. Warrenpoint had been hit before: the Crown Hotel was bombed and is just a vacant lot; the Ulster Bar and the post office were rebuilt after bombings; the ``Seven Steps'' hotel along the shore of Carlingford Lough is still charred and gaping. An IRA bomb outside town, near the ruins of Narrow Water Castle, killed 18 British soldiers Aug. 27, 1979 _ the same day another IRA bomb killed Earl Mountbatten of Burma, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II. After the latest attack, ``people supported each other a lot,'' said Richard Black of the social services office in nearby Newry. ``There was a great groundswell of opinion in Warrenpoint that they were quite determined to get on with life, and live as normally as possible, and that did gel a lot of the families together.'' The flip side of determination, though, is resignation.
