DOC.HEAD: WARRENPOINT: is resignation.
DOC.TEXT: ``We've learned to live with it,'' Black said. ``I think people have become very weary as well. There seems to be no light at the end of the tunnel.'' Among the flowers that still cover Joanne Reilly's hilltop grave in St. Peter's Cemetery are two small potted pines, one with a tiny Santa Claus, and a big display saying ``Happy Birthday, Sis.'' Before her 21st birthday Sept. 24, relatives and friends filled three columns of the Newry Reporter newspaper with memorials. Beneath a picture of a lively, smiling, dark-haired young woman were poems from her parents Ann and Paul, her brothers Paul and Martin, her pal Michelle, her boyfriend Sean, her aunts and uncles and cousins. Paul Reilly's message said: ``My heart still aches, I whisper low, God bless you Sis, I love you so.'' The hardware store and the Coopers' house will not be rebuilt. One other house may be demolished. Joanne Reilly's grandmother is among those who have not moved back to Charlotte St. Just after the bombing, Geraldine McShane advertised a ``Bomb Damage Sale'' at the Pick 'n' Mix shop on Charlotte St. In the summer, she had a going out of business sale. ``Well, I would say the bomb was 50 percent responsible,'' she said. ``No one was coming down that side at all after the bomb.'' The government compensated her for the soft toys that couldn't be sold because they were full of splintered glass. The bomb blew the roof off Wills' gas station, and caused him two months of anxiety for himself and his three employees _ three important jobs in a town where unemployment is estimated to approach 25 percent. ``It's just like it was, maybe better, it is indeed,'' he said. ``We just renovated the place while we're at it. It's not like I wanted, but we'll get there.'' ``Aunty Chris'' Caulfield is still selling cigarettes and candy in her chilly shop across the street but complained, ``business is terrible.'' Charlie Burns had insisted that no bomb would dislodge him from his barber shop, where he was born 85 years ago, but then a long illness changed his mind. ``Oh, I hated to sell it. I loved being on the square, because no one could build in front of you,'' said Burns. His father and his grandfather had worked in the shop, which had one parlor for businessmen and another for grimy longshoremen and other laborers. A basin and cabinets from Burns' shop are now part of the remodeled decor at Bennett's pub, where Burns is a valued regular. Stuart Cooper, said his family salvaged one sweater and the cat from the ruins of their 118-year-old house. Moving increased their mortgage from 40,000 pounds (about $68,000) to 65,000 pounds (about $110,000). No one close to Mariann Cooper had ever been hurt in the troubles, but she wasn't surprised when her turn came. ``I always felt that it had gone on for so long, something was bound to happen,'' she said. ``It can't pass by your door for 20 years.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday, March 4
$Adv04
For Release Sunday March 4, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Romanian Villagers Were Forced to Destroy Their Own Homes
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Constantin Surescu, a 70-year-old farmer, stood in the wreckage of the house, fingering pieces of brick and the yellow balustrade that Nicolae Ceausescu's police had ordered him to destroy. What he couldn't destroy himself, a bulldozer finished off all but a single room, but even then Surescu wouldn't leave. For months, he, his wife, and others huddled in the candle-lit room that had been spared, surviving the freezing winter with only a small charcoal stove. Ceausescu had destroyed their lives and their village as part of his plan to move Romania's rural population into big, concentrated towns. When Ceausescu was overthrown Dec. 22, and executed with his wife three days later, Surescu's family laughed and cried for joy. But the nightmare for Surescu and dozens of neighbors in the village of Cornetu, 13 miles west of Bucharest, didn't end. ``It would have been better if God had taken me,'' Surescu said, clutching a color photograph of the large, well-kept beige house with relief designs he moved into in 1961. ``I don't believe it will ever be the same.'' He continues to live in the room that remains. He said he had developed heart disease because of the trauma. The once leafy outskirts of Cornetu, with neat houses, well-tended gardens, and grapevines climbing the walls, exist no more. ``Not even if we had a war would it look like this,'' said a neighbor, Gheorghe Cristea, a 63-year-old bewhiskered farmer, shaking his head in disbelief. Both sides of the muddy road heading west out of Cornetu are lined with the skeletons of a war Ceausescu tried to hide _ one against the rural population. Many homes are just shells, some are missing roofs, others have holes in walls. Very few escaped relatively unscathed. Surescu and his 65 neighbors on the outskirts of town were luckier than the 350 families living in the center of Cornetu whose homes were destroyed first. Romania's revolution saved the homes on the periphery from final destruction. The debris was to have been buried in huge pits already dug in gardens where flowers and vegetables once grew. The center of Cornetu gives no hint that 350 houses once stood there. The houses were buried, and their grave is now covered with rows of four-story apartment buildings, Ceausescu's response to the possibility of too much rural independence. Some of the buildings destroyed were hovels, and the tenements are improvements, even though they are shoddily built structures that do not take into account rural lifestyles. But the perception is widespread that Ceausescu had motives other than improving the quality of life for peasants. Virgil Ioanid, vice president of the National Commission for Urban and Regional Planning, said Ceausescu was apparently afraid he could not control small villages. In the small villages, he added, local police were on good terms with the people, which angered Ceausescu who felt he couldn't keep tabs on what was happening. With larger towns of 5,000 people or more, Ceausescu could bring in his fiercely loyal and hated Securitate secret police ``and control was easier,'' he added. Ceausescu wanted to concentrate 10 million rural residents in 2,500 to 3,000 agro-industrial centers, said Commission President Serban Popescu-Criveanu. Ceauescu intended to destroy 8,000 to 8,500 of Romania's 11,000 rural villages, Popescu-Criveanu said. ``Fortunately, he didn't have time to carry out his entire plan. ... But about 2,000 small houses were destroyed near Bucharest.'' About 30 villages were affected, and eight were razed, he said. Popescu-Criveanu added that one of the new government's first commitments was to replace the destroyed homes as quickly as possible. He said about 500 families didn't want to return, but the homes of the other 1,500 would be rebuilt. Constantin Surescu recalled the day last May when the bulldozer, the police and town officials arrived. ``They ordered us to destroy our own houses,'' he said. ``Many people said, `I don't want to do this.' If you said `No,' they came in the night and got you and beat you up.'' First, electric power was disrupted, and that frightened some residents enough to start dismantling their homes with whatever implements they had at hand, Sorescu said. But others like Surescu and his neighbor Cristea resisted, arguing with officials at town hall and scurrying into the fields when authorities came to their homes. Cristea said they had heard on Western radio broadcasts that political change was sweeping Eastern Europe, and they expected something to happen in Romania, so they tried to delay the bulldozers as long as possible. All residents whose homes were destroyed were given apartments in pre-fabricated concrete buildings. But in Cornetu's outskirts, more than half the residents refused to leave their homes, begging the wreckers to leave one room intact. ``Even when they were destroying what I couldn't destroy, I didn't want to leave,'' Surescu said. ``They gave me an apartment but I didn't want to stay. ... I felt like I was in a hospital. It was cold. There was water on the walls. It was like being in a grave.'' Now he was picking at the pieces of brick, gently fingering what was left of the home he had loved. ``I'm not leaving from here,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday March 4

DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. Chairman Stephen Wolf said he is willing to consider an employee buyout proposal despite reports he has turned against the plan because it may include dumping him. Also Thursday, UAL board members authorized releasing confidential financial information to the three United Airlines labor unions that are developing a proposal for employee control of United's parent company. ``The entire board stands ready to receive a fair and financed offer from the employee groups and will given any such offer prompt consideration,'' Wolf said a statement released after a UAL board meeting.

The Justice Department and Exxon Corp. are near agreement on settling possible criminal charges over last year's massive Alaska oil spill, several sources said. But Alaska officials said late Thursday they would not endorse a tentative agreement outlined by the Justice Department and hoped improvements can still be made that would make it acceptable to the state. Meanwhile, Exxon announced it was taking another charge against earnings of $300 million for litigation costs in connection with the spill, bringing the company's total costs to more than $2 billion.

The government said it posted its first monthly budget surplus of fiscal 1990 in January, but the federal deficit after four months still totaled nearly 60 percent of the amount permitted for the entire year. Despite January's $9.92 billion surplus, the deficit for the fiscal year so far totaled $59.78 billion, the Treasury Department said Thursday. The deficit last year was $152.1 billion.

Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan said a recent rise in long-term interest rates fueled by prospects for the development of Eastern Europe probably would not continue. Greenspan, presenting the central bank's semi-annual report to Congress on Thursday, noted long-term interest rates have been rising worldwide as the United States and other countries compete for funds. But Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee the trend probably would not continue unless some currently unknown need for investment is revealed.

Bank of New England Corp. said its 1989 losses were worse than expected at $1.11 billion, and the company said it was studying whether loan loss provisions should have been bigger earlier in the year. Analysts said Thursday the review of loan loss provisions indicates the bank might have misstated its financial condition in previous quarters, which could open the bank to further lawsuits from disgruntled shareholders.

The company that makes NutraSweet low-cal sweetener said it had won federal approval for its calorie-cutting fat substitute Simplesse, which it plans to market immediately in frozen dairy desserts. NutraSweet Co., a subsidiary of Monsanto Co., said Thursday the Food and Drug Administration affirmed that the cholesterol- and fat-free substance _ made from egg whites and milk protein _ generally was safe for consumption.

The group that is acquiring Gulfstream Aerospace Corp. has let its $60 million agreement to buy Learjet Corp. expire, due to fears that the bankruptcy filing by Learjet's parent _ Integrated Resources Inc. _ could hamper the deal. A spokesman for Gulfstream said Thursday the company's chairman, Allen E. Paulson, decided to drop plans to acquire the corporate jet maker out of concern that the bankruptcy case could lead to a bidding fight for Learjet.

NEW YORK _ Eastern Airlines has agreed on a plan to pay about $490 million in cash and notes to its unsecured creditors, who are owed about $1 billion, the parties announced. Thursday's agreement, which would require payments by sister carrier Continental Airlines, capped several days of negotiations between officials of Eastern and a committee representing the unsecured creditors in the airline's Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceeding, which started last March. Eastern said the plan would allow it to emerge from bankruptcy protection by mid-year ``with substantial cash resources and a significant debt reduction.''

The airline industry changed its position and asked the government to require infant safety seats for all passengers under 2 years of age. The proposal announced Thursday, if adopted by the Federal Aviation Administration, could require thousands of parents each day to buy tickets for children who now fly free. Airlines would still have the option of offering free rides or reduced fares.

Stock prices ended mixed Thursday in moderate trading, as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 8.79 to 2,574.77. Bond prices rose sharply. The dollar rose against the Japanese yen but finished mostly lower against other major currencies. Coffee futures prices reached seven-month highs; precious metals weakened; petroleum futures rose; wheat and corn futures advanced while soybeans retreated; and most livestock and meat futures moved higher.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Says Publicity on Marriage Troubles Has Helped Business
DOC.TEXT: Tycoon Donald Trump, who usually delights in media attention, says he hates the splashy publicity about his breakup with wife Ivana but believes it has a silver lining: it's good for business. In an interview Thursday, Trump said the screaming tabloid headlines and talk-show jokes about his marital travails actually have benefitted his multibillion-dollar casino, hotel and airline empire. ``The business has never been better,'' he said, ``but because it's a private company most people don't know about it. Unfortunately, for all the wrong reasons, the last two weeks it's been even better yet.'' Trump said business has been up at his two hotel-casinos in Atlantic City, N.J., the Plaza Hotel and the Trump Shuttle, which links New York with Washington and Boston, since the breakup first hit the headlines two weeks ago. Still, he said having his name splashed over the media has taken a toll. ``It's horrible. I hate it. I hate the publicity,'' Trump said in his glitzy 26th-floor office commanding a view of Central Park and the Plaza Hotel, one of his properties. ``It's been on a personal basis difficult because I happen to like Ivana. ... But it's something you have to go through and in many cases a lot of people have to go through it. People grow apart.'' Wearing a bright red-and-blue striped tie and navy blue suit, Trump looked tired as he dealt with the normal everyday hassles of a billionaire mogul. His associates bustled in and out of his office throughout the interview. He said the potential loss of Ivana, his business partner and the manager of the opulent Plaza in Manhattan, wouldn't create a void in his organization or have a negative impact over the long term. ``That's one of the reasons you sign a pre-nuptial agreement,'' Trump said. ``If something should happen, you know what you have to pay out, and that's one of the reasons that when you're in business it's very important to have a pre-nuptial agreement signed.'' Under an agreement Ivana is contesting, she would receive $25 million and the couple's home in Connecticut as well as custody of their children. Trump's holdings are estimated to be worth up to $4 billion. Although Trump insisted the publicity was a business plus, some marketing analysts said the headlines could hurt an empire built the developer's name. ``He's becoming a joke,'' said Jack Trout, president of Trout & Ries, a marketing consulting firm in Greenwich, Conn. ``For a serious brand, that can be a big problem,'' he said, suggesting that the publicity could have a negative impact on the Trump trademark. Mrs. Trump declined through spokesman John Scanlon to comment on her husband's remarks. ``All Mrs. Trump wants is a fair and equitable share of the fortune that they accumulated together while they were married,'' Scanlon said. ``We're disappointed that Mr. Trump is prepared to offer his wife and children less than 1 percent of his accumulated wealth. We really expected better of him.'' In his best-selling book ``The Art of the Deal,'' Trump called Ivana ``incredibly good at anything she's ever done, a natural manager,'' and credited her for the strong performance of his Trump Castle hotel-casino in Atlantic City, which she used to manage. Al Glasgow, publisher of the monthly newsletter Atlantic City Action, said revenues have been up strongly in recent months at both Trump Plaza and Trump Castle, the two leading casinos in the gaming town, followed by Holiday Corp.'s Harrah's. But the growth in the Trump casinos has been due to their new managers and their quality of service, Glasgow said, rather than any publicity about the Trump's personal vicissitudes. ``I don't think it's had any impact at all,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``Donald's marriage breakup is making headlines now, but they'll soon be forgotten in April when the Taj Mahal opens.'' That third Trump casino in Atlantic City is due to open on April 2. Bruce Nobles, president of Trump Shuttle, said passenger traffic on the hourly flights jumped 7 percent last week from the previous week. ``I'm not going to tell you that the publicity didn't help,'' he said. ``It certainly could have.'' Pan Am Corp., which operates a rival shuttle service, saw its traffic increase 8 percent, spokeswoman Elizabeth Manners said. She attributed the rise to heavy traveling before the Presidents Day holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Says It'll Operate Despite Drivers' Strike
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound bus drivers say they'll walk off the job when their contract expires March 1, but the company already has begun hiring replacements and says it will operate a full schedule by the end of next month. The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, which represents 6,300 drivers and 3,075 office and maintenance workers, notified the company Thursday of its decision to go on strike at 12:01 a.m. March 2, Greyhound Lines Inc. spokesman George Gravley said. No talks in the dispute are scheduled, Gravley said. Union officials did not return telephone calls seeking comment. The two sides met together in Phoenix last Friday and Monday and then held separate meetings with a federal mediator Tuesday, but no agreement could be reached, Gravley said. The company and union remain far apart, with Greyhound offering a three-year deal worth about $63 million. Gravely said the union initially had sought a pact valued at $561 million, but reduced that to $475 million. Union membership previously had approved a strike, and Greyhound responded by advertising for permanent replacements. ``We have 600 people in school ... and are still taking applications,'' Gravley said. ``We will ... operate as many schedules as possible on March 2, based on the number of employees who stay on the job and the number of replacements available to us,'' Greyhound Chairman Fred G. Currey said. ``We will build back the service as additional workers become available and as routes are subcontracted. ``We expect to be serving all points on our system before the end of March.'' Greyhound says its drivers earn top pay in the industry, ``except for one or two small ones in the Northeast.'' It said its offer would boost the average of its 1,500 highest paid drivers from $33,218 last year to $40,725 by 1990. Overall, Greyhound says its drivers made an average salary of $24,643 last year. ``It is an excellent offer from a company that lost $20 million over the last three years and it is all this company can afford,'' Currey said. ``The union has not disputed the fact that we cannot afford to pay more than we have offered,'' he said. ``Instead, union leaders have told us repeatedly that an employer's ability to pay is `irrelevant.''' Greyhound said it rejected union suggestions that fares be raised 10 percent to cover the increased cost of their proposal. Currey led the investment group that paid Phoenix-based Greyhound Corp. $350 million for its bus system in March 1987 and then bought Dallas-based Trailways Lines Inc., the nation's largest Trailways system, four months later for $80 million. The company lost $2.6 million in 1987 and $17.4 million in 1988, and expects to report a small profit for 1989 of about $730,000 on revenues of approximately $1 billion. Greyhound says its 3,949 buses serve 9,500 locations, and are the only public transportation available in about 9,000 of those areas.

DOC.HEAD: UAL's Wolf Says He's Eager To Hear Worker Buyout Offer
DOC.TEXT: UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf is still encouraging United Airlines employees to develop a buyout proposal even though the workers may not retain him as head of the parent company. ``The entire board stands ready to receive a fair and financed offer from the employee groups and will give any such offer prompt consideration,'' Wolf said Thursday in a brief statement after a UAL board meeting. Nevertheless, the carrier cautioned in a statement that ``there can be no assurance that any acquisition proposal will be made by the employee groups or any other party or that, if made, the board will determine that such proposal is in the best interest of UAL shareholders.'' UAL stock dropped sharply, apparently indicating investor fears that hopes for a buyout are receding. The stock fell $5.75 in New York Stock Exchange trading Thursday, closing at $126.50. At the meeting, UAL directors authorized the release of confidential financial information to the three United Airlines labor unions that are leading the drive for employee control of the nation's second-largest airline. It was revealed last week that the union group _ representing United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants _ has been looking for a possible replacement for Wolf, who initially gave strong support to an employee buyout proposa. The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday that Wolf had turned against the buyout plan and threatened to take other top managers with him if he is forced out as chairman. The newspaper cited unidentified sources familiar with the company. Airline analysts have said that dumping Wolf, who has taken a hard line in labor negotiations, would weaken United's ability to win back market share from industry leader American Airlines. United's unions last month proposed an employee purchase of 75 percent of UAL's stock. In a rare show of unity, the workers offered to negotiate as a group on a five-year labor package, including wage concessions, to anchor the buyout. At a Jan. 26 meeting, UAL's board encouraged the unions to develop a formal buyout proposal, including a plan for financing the stock purchase. Investors and analysts have been skeptical about the workers' ability to borrow enough money for a buyout, though. In October, an attempted $300-a-share buyout led by Wolf and the pilots flopped after the machinists opposed the plan, causing lenders to balk. The collapse of the proposed $6.75 billion deal helped trigger a 190-point collapse in the Dow Jones industrial average. Conditions for leveraged buyouts have deteriorated since then with the collapse of the junk bond market, a key source of takeover financing. UAL is under pressure from its largest shareholder, Coniston Partners, to take action to increase the value of its shares, which have tumbled from $294 in September to a recent low of $121.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Monsanto Fat Substitute For Use In Frozen Desserts
DOC.TEXT: It's cold, wet and creamy, and sweet on the tongue. It's thicker than top superpremium ice cream brands, and just a little bit harder to scrape with your spoon. It doesn't taste exactly like Haagen-Dasz or Ben & Jerry's, but what do you expect for a product with half the calories and one-fifteenth the fat? NutraSweet Co., the maker of NutraSweet low-cal sweetener, is hoping for a mouthful with Simple Pleasures, a superpremium ice cream substitute with no fat and low cholesterol. Its secret lies in Simplesse, a product made from egg whites and milk protein that has no cholesterol and no fat. Simplesse eventually may be used as a substitute for other dairy products like yogurt, sour cream, butter, margarine and cheese. Simple Pleasures was unveiled for reporters Thursday after becoming the first fat-substitute product to win approval from the Food and Drug Administration. The real taste test will come this summer when it shows up in seven flavors in supermarkets across the country. Distribution in Europe is expected by the end of the year, said Simplesse general manager David L. Morley. ``It's potentially very significant. This is the first non-fat fat, so to speak, to be approved on the market,'' said Harvey Stober, a chemical analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., who said sales could grow to $500 million or $1 billion a year in several years. Monsanto stock jumped higher following the FDA approval, finishing $4.37{ higher at $112.25 on the New York Stock Exchange. Simplesse is aimed at customers who want to cut the amount of fat and cholesterol in their diet while satisfying their taste buds. It will be launched in an age of dieting and health consciousness, when customers have lined their shelves with products such as oat bran and spring water. Simplesse cannot be used in frying or baking, however, because it congeals at higher temperatures. And the company has yet to come up with a vanilla flavor Simple Pleasures that meets its expectations. ``Potentially it could help somebody lower their fat intake. But if you're not careful it might have undesirable effects on the diet,'' said Lisa Lefferts, a staff scientist at the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a Washington watchdog group. ``We don't know whether they'll substitute it for fat, or people will just eat more double-scoop ice cream cones.'' But Robert Shapiro, NutraSweet's chairman and chief executive, said Simple Pleasures could resolve the conflict between eating healthy foods and indulging in what tastes good. Americans reduced the fat in their diets by 3 percent from 1982 to 1988 but still ate an average 5 gallons of ice cream last year, according to NutraSweet. ``Simplesse is in our view nothing less than a historical breakthrough in food technology, in the never-ending conflict between health and indulgence,'' Shapiro said. ``Simplesse means we can now enjoy all the rich, creamy taste of foods ... without the fat, without the calories, without the worry and without the guilt.'' A 4-ounce serving of strawberry flavor has 120 calories and less than 1 gram of fat, compared to 250 calories and 15 grams for superpremium ice cream. Morley said Simple Pleasures uses sugar, not NutraSweet, although the sugar and fat substitutes could be used together. FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit in Washington said NutraSweet would have to seek separate federal approval for other products containing Simplesse, such as mayonnaise, salad dressing, sour cream or frozen yogurt. Nevertheless, NutraSweet already has agreed to supply Simplesse to Kraft-General Foods Inc. for its mayonnaise and Miracle Whip salad dressing. Just as diet soda and other low-calorie products bear the NutraSweet logo, Simple Pleasures and other Simplesse-containing products will bear a special logo, a red and white circle and rectangle imprinted with a blue ``Simplesse.'' All new products will be made and marketed by Simplesse Co., a new division of NutraSweet. Two other companies have petitions pending for fat substitutes. Cincinnati-based Procter & Gamble is seeking permission for Olestra, a synthetic product make of sugar and oils that would be used in shortenings, oils and snacks like potato chips, said spokesman Don Tassone. The petition, submitted in April 1987, remains pending. Kraft, of Glenview, Ill., is seeking permission to use a fat substitute in frozen esserts. Kraft spokeswoman Kathy Knuth said the petition is pending and could be approved later this year.

DOC.HEAD: Bank of New England Reports $1.11 Billion Loss
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp., which went from profits to steep losses late last year, is reviewing whether it should have made bigger provisions against bad loans earlier in 1989. ``I really feel that as we went through 1989, we weren't dealing with a full deck,'' said James Moynihan, senior vice president at Advest Inc. in Boston. Bank of New England reported Thursday its 1989 losses were worse than expected at $1.11 billion. The company also said it was reviewing how its quarterly loan-loss provisions were allocated, indicating the possibility that it should have taken bigger provisions earlier in the year when the bank was still reporting profits. ``I don't think that we could have a loss like that and not say there were mistakes and misjudgments,'' said Marcia Ryan, a bank spokeswoman. Analysts said the review of loan-loss provisions indicates the bank might have misstated its financial condition in previous quarters, which could open the bank to more lawsuits. The bank already faces several lawsuits from shareholders who claim they were misled by the bank. Bank of New England, which has had to boost its reserves against bad real estate loans, estimated earlier this year its l989 losses would be $1.05 billion because it was boosting its reserves against credit losses to $1.65 billion. Other banks also have suffered financial ills because of the region's slumping real estate market, but analysts say Bank of New England has received some of the deepest wounds because it was an aggressive lender during a construction boom in the mid-1980s. Yet Bank of New England's serious troubles did not become apparent until late last year. For the first three quarters of 1989, the bank said it had earned more than $120 million. In its statement Thursday, the company said it was not reporting its fourth quarter results yet because it was ``in the process of reviewing the provision for loan losses to determine how it should be allocated among the 1989 quarters.'' Ryan said the bank ``possibly'' could increase provisions in the previous quarters but no decision has been made. The statement indicated that overall provisions for 1989 would not change. Analysts said the bank's statement indicated the company and its auditors were trying to determine whether the first three quarters should have contained larger provisions against bad loans. ``They are going to put 1989 back together again the way it should have been,'' Moynihan said. Gerard Cassidy, an analyst with Tucker Anthony Inc., said Bank of New England had plenty of signs earlier in the year that its loan portfolio could sour. The economy had already started its downturn, and Bank of Boston Corp., the region's largest bank, reported a record $125 million loss in the third quarter. ``It tells you someone was asleep at the switch,'' Cassidy said. ``Needless to say, in this type of situation there will be lawsuits'' from shareholders, he said. The $1.11 billion loss for the year, which translated to $16.11 a share, compared with earnings of $281.7 million, or $4.06 a share, in 1988. As of Dec. 31, 1988, the bank had $32.2 billion in assets, but that number shrunk to $26.1 billion by Feb. 15, with much of the decline coming since Jan. 1, the bank said. The bank has been trying to sell $6 billion in assets to raise cash, and its primary capital ratio improved to 8.6 percent on Feb. 15, compared with 7.1 percent at year's end. ``The numbers we reported today were in line with our January estimate,'' H. Ridgely Bullock, the bank's interim chairman, said in a statement. ``In the near term, we are proceeding in an orderly fashion to reduce overhead as a part of our downsizing program.'' ``We are presently developing a longer term strategic plan to improve operations and lead the company on a road to profitability,'' he said. The bank said last week it expected to lay off about 2,000 employees, although the specific details were not yet determined. The bank also said earlier this year that it planned to enter a consent order with the federal government to detail what steps it would take to improve its financial condition, but that order has not yet been disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Spray String Recalled After Several People Burned
DOC.TEXT: The government is recalling more than a million cans of spray string confetti because the strings that are sprayed as a party ornament are flammable. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Thursday it recalled the spray string ``because of several terrifying accidents that occurred when this type of product was sprayed near lit candles on birthday cakes and burst into flames,'' said Jacqueline Jones-Smith, who heads the panel. ``These accidents resulted in serious burn injuries, primarily to children,'' she said. In a dramatic demonstration, commission staff members showed reporters how a flash fire could result from spraying the string near lit candles. They also showed a home video of a 6-year-old Clarksville, Tenn., boy who suffered severe burns when some of the string was sprayed during his birthday celebration. The boy, Michael Sheppard, suffered first- and second-degree burns to his face and body last November, said CPSC spokeswoman Amy Palman. At least eight people, three adults and five children, suffered burns, she said. Last month the CPSC recalled 3 million cans of another spray string produced by a New Jersey-based manufacturer that has since reformulated its propellant. Thursday's recall involved 1.13 million cans of the streamers from five manufacturers. The products are: _3.5-ounce cans of ``Streamer Spray,'' distributed by Northeast Imports, Inc. of Central Falls, R.I. _150-gram cans of ``Masquerade Crazy Strings,'' distributed by Masquerade, Inc. of Brooklyn, N.Y. _3.5-ounce cans of ``Goofy Flying String,'' distributed by Franco-American Novelty Co., Inc. of Glendale, N.Y. _3.5-ounce cans of ``Tricky Fun String,'' distributed by Topstone Industries of Danbury, Conn. _3.5-ounce and 7-ounce cans of ``It's Fun Time String Confetti,'' distributed by Fun World Division of Carle Place, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Retailers Get More Time to Consider Lease Agreements
DOC.TEXT: Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. received a bankruptcy court's open-ended approval for more time to consider whether to continue leases at their 260 store locations nationwide. But U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. said Thursday he might reconsider and set a fixed deadline if his court sees a flood of challenges from developers or mall operators who demand earlier decisions because of their own financial deadlines. Aug gave permission for Federated and Allied to postpone making the lease decisions until a reorganization plan is in place, which company officials say could occur in May. Aug agreed in court Thursday not to set a deadline, said David Heiman, a Federated-Allied lawyer. Federated and Allied lawyers cleared the way for Aug's decision by negotiating a proposed agreement during a court recess Thursday that would require the companies to operate the stores until a lease was canceled. The proposal would require that lease rejections be subject to hearings in the bankruptcy court so that objectors could make their arguments. ``We expect only a handful of rejections, ultimately,'' Heiman said. He declined to say how much advance notice the retailers might provide. ``I'm sure that as soon as we make a decision, we will contact the landlord,'' Heiman said. The Cincinnati-based retailers have refused to say which leases might be canceled, saying only that some unprofitable stores are at stake. Federated and Allied both filed Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization petitions Jan. 15 to obtain protection from creditors during their reorganizations. The companies listed $7.7 billion in debts, amassed when the Toronto-based Campeau Corp. bought Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988. Operators of shopping malls and stores from iami Beach, Fla., to Pocatello, Idaho, are concerned that Federated and Allied give notice as soon as possible about whether they intend to continue leases. Stanley Talesnick, lawyer for Melvin Simon & Associates, an Indianapolis-based mall operator, said he expects responses from Federated and Allied within a few weeks or months about lease decisions. Melvin Simon controls 66 million square feet of retail space in 200 shopping centers. The company also is concerned because it plans to build the $625 million Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn. Uncertainty about a Bloomingdale's store planned for the mall is delaying a $600 million loan needed to start construction. Lawyers for developers JMB Realty Corp. and Melvin Simon say long delays in those decisions could hurt tenants of shopping malls that are anchored by such Federated and Allied stores as Lazarus or Bloomingdale's. Under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, a company filing for protection from creditors has 60 days to decide whether to end lease agreements. For Federated and Allied, the deadline is March 14. JMB Realty is the developer of the 900 N. Michigan Ave. project in downtown Chicago, which includes a Bloomingdale's store. JMB has plans to renovate a shopping center in suburban Skokie, Ill., to include a new Bloomingdale's. Aug on Thursday approved continued Federated and Allied spending for auto liability and workers' compensation insurance policies from Liberty Mutual Insurance Co., which cost the companies $11 million a year; operation of a centralized cash management system that records the flow of money between subsidiaries and corporate offices; and contracts for outside operation of New Jersey merchandise distribution centers that serve the Bloomingdale's and the Abraham and Straus stores.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Calls U.S. Demands Severe, Criticizes U.S. Economy in Trade Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. trade representative criticizing Japanese stance, talks ended. Deletes outdated material. Pickup 10th graf, `Today, it... This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama today called for urgent Cabinet-level trade talks, saying U.S. demands at lower-level discussions on the U.S.-Japanese trade imbalance were stronger than expected. American officials criticized Japanese negotiators in the talks, saying they would not go far enough in efforts to reduce Japan's $49 billion trade surplus with the United States. ``We must say we find ourselves frustrated and concerned at this point,'' Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Linn Williams told reporters after the two-day negotiating session ended today. ``We expected this meeting to be a substantial step forward. But what we heard is not enough to be effective, lasting or credible,'' he said. ``It was mainly a defense of the status quo with prospects of only minimal further action.'' Nakayama told reporters the U.S. demands were ``much severer'' than Japanese officials had expected. He called for an urgent meeting of top government officials, after Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu names a new Cabinet next week, to clear up disagreements aired in talks at the bilateral sub-Cabinet level. The Japanese side today was given a chance to critique U.S. plans for structural trade reform. This round of trade talks _ known as the Structural Impediments Initiative _ was delayed from early January until after national parliamentary elections Sunday that kept the conservative Liberal Democratic Party in power. Since the structural trade talks were launched in May, U.S. officials have pressed Japan for evidence of willingness to carry out wide-ranging reform to help reduce Japan's trade surplus with the United States. Today, it was the United States' turn to explain what it is doing to change American practices that contribute to the imbalance. U.S. officials said they would outline Washington's plans to increase the low U.S. savings and investment rates and to bolster the competitiveness of American firms. The U.S. timetable for these changes was unclear. Japan says U.S. problems contributing to the trade imbalance include inadequate savings and investment, the short-term nature of U.S. corporate strategies, ineffective labor training and education and insufficient export promotion. Japanese officials contend many of the U.S. demands for change in their economy cannot be carried out as quickly as Washington hopes. U.S. officials say Japan's high savings and investment rates, its land policies, exclusionary business practices, inefficient retail distribution networks and pricing mechanisms all indirectly restrain trade. In response to those complaints, the Japanese side on Thursday explained measures in a draft budget before Parliament to improve enforcement of anti-monopoly laws; to increase spending on public infrastructure such as roads and sewers, and to reform the retail distribution system. They also explained revisions of Japan's land use law aimed at curbing real estate speculation and increasing the supply of available land in urban areas. Members of the U.S. delegation said the plans ``represented new actions and some progress, but it's clear to us they haven't gone as far as we hoped with bold, new thinking.'' Japanese officials said the U.S. side had asked Japanese spending on public works be increased to 10 percent of the nation's gross national product from the current 5 percent, or $257 billion, a demand they refused. They said they also could not agree to a demand to scrap a law that requires firms wanting to open department stores or supermarkets to obtain consent from existing smaller shops that are generally reluctant to face new competition. The U.S. side says the law tends to restrict imports by driving up prices and by limiting the number of foreign-owned stores and the opening of large Japanese stores more likely to sell imported products.

DOC.HEAD: Traders: Arbitrage Program-Trading Is Yanking Tokyo Market Around
With PM-Japan-Markets Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japanese traders unnerved by the wild swings that have roiled their stock market are blaming a culprit new to them but familiar to their American counterparts _ computerized program trading. Program trading strategies, which involve moving huge blocks of stocks with the flick of a computer key, long been a standard procedure on U.S. markets. One of the best known practices is index arbitrage, which involves buying or selling stocks with opposite, offsetting trades in stock index futures. But such practices _ in which U.S. firms appear to be major players in the Tokyo market _ are new and exasperating to the Japanese. ``We never thought share prices on the Tokyo market would ever go wild as they did this week,'' Michio Katsumata of Nomura Securities Co., Japan's largest brokerage, said today. ``Since foreign traders brought in the method of arbitrage trading by computer into the Tokyo market, share prices here began strange fluctuations we have never seen before,'' he said. Even the government appeared confounded by the trading strategies. The Finance Ministry today directed securities companies to report on their arbitrage practices. A government official speaking on condition of anonymity said the ministry is not yet ``quite sure what to do to solve the problem.'' The 225-issue Nikkei index, the main indicator of the world's biggest stock market, has dropped 2,569.35 points, or nearly 7 percent this week alone and is off more than 10 percent since the beginning of the year. Today, only two days after the benchmark index suffered its third-largest decline, the Nikkei index lost another 2.61 percent to close the week at 34,890.97. It was the first time the index fell below the 35,000-point mark since Oct. 17, 1989. Of primary concern to Japanese dealers, investors and finance ministry officials was the unusually wide range of price fluctuations recently. On Thursday, for example, the Nikkei opened more than 400 points higher as investors took advantage of the previous day's steep price plunge to buy stocks. But it fell more than 1,000 points in less than an hour. At day's end, however, the index rebounded to close with a slight gain. Traders attributed the bearishness to anxiety about a possible interest rate hike, expected shortly, coupled with unstable currency rates. But they believe such fluctuations ``must come from arbitrage program trading,'' said Ichitaro Watanabe of Nikko Securities Co. Traders noted that the market is particularly vulnerable to computerized selling because of the extremely thin volume of shares being traded. Program trading has received its share of criticism in the United States, where the practice was blamed for contributing to Wall Street's stock market crash in October 1987. Because of public outcry over index arbitrage's role in the stock market's roller-coaster performance, several major Wall Street investment houses have suspended the practice, and the New York Stock Exchange agreed to limit computerized program trading in times of sharp market declines. ``The Japanese market has not yet developed an effective immune system against such new methods of computer-aided trading,'' Watanabe said. ``As a result, most market players are only watching recent unstable movements of share prices and the index from the sidelines with their mouths open.'' He noted that computers can buy and sell stocks ``beyond the speed of human judgment. Unless we familiarize ourselves with program trading, we are virtually defenseless against steep ups and downs in share prices.'' Dealers said the U.S.-based firms Salomon Brothers Inc. and Morgan Stanley & Co. Inc. are the two major users of arbitrage trading in Japan. A dealer with a major Japanese securities house, commenting anonymously, said: ``I knew something like this would happen when the Finance Ministry decided to allow foreign companies into the Tokyo exchange.''

DOC.HEAD: Eastern, Creditors Reach Agreement on Reorganization Plan
DOC.NOTE: EDS: ADDS new grafs 12-13 to UPDATE with Lorenzo's comments on possible Eastern-Continental merger; picks up 12th graf pvs bg'ng, In addition ...; ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: A new reorganization agreement between Eastern Airlines and its unsecured creditors would require sister carrier Continental Airlines to step in and make some payments to the creditors. The unsecured creditors, who are owed $980 million by Eastern, would receive about $490 million in cash and notes under the plan announced Thursday. The agreement capped several days of intense negotiations between officials of Miami-based Eastern and a committee representing the unsecured creditors in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, which Eastern entered last March. If the bankruptcy court approves the plan, Eastern says it could fly out of Chapter 11 this summer. A plan proposed several weeks ago by Eastern would have paid the unsecured creditors only 10 percent of their debts in cash when the airline emerges from bankruptcy protection, and 70 percent more over the following 10 years, without interest. The unsecured creditors are mainly equipment suppliers such as aircraft and engine makers who have no collateral backing up what they are owed. Under the new agreement, the creditors would receive repayment of 50 cents on each dollar owed. Eastern would pay them $300 million in cash when the plan was approved by the court. Also, the creditors would receive another $190 million in eight-year, 15 percent notes _ half issued by Eastern and half by Houston-based Continental, which would guarantee both sets of notes. Principal on the notes would begin to be repaid after the first two years. Eastern said the new plan would allow the airline to emerge from bankruptcy protection by mid-year ``with substantial cash resources and a significant debt reduction.'' Eastern and Continental are both subsidiaries of Houston-based Texas Air Corp., the nation's largest airline company. Eastern's previous reorganization proposals, including a plan to offer the unsecured creditors 40 percent of Eastern's equity, hadn't involved the assistance of Continental or Texas Air. In a separate development, Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo said Thursday that merging Continental with Eastern makes sense, but is not planned in the foreseeable future. ``We have no near-term plans for a merger,'' Lorenzo said in a speech to around 1,500 Continental employees at Stapleton International Airport in Denver. However, he added, ``today a merger makes much more sense than it did two years ago.'' In addition to requiring bankruptcy court approval, the new agreement also is subject to completion of Eastern's proposed sale of its lucrative South American routes to American Airlines, and to a resolution of Eastern's labor dispute with the unions representing pilots and flight attendants. Those two unions called off their sympathy walkouts last November, but the airline had replaced the strikers mainly with non-union workers as it rebuilt from the strike that started last March 4. The Machinists union is still on strike against Eastern. The Air Line Pilots Association, which is represented on the creditors' committee, called the agreement ``woefully inadequate in terms of the amounts and types of payments to be made to the various creditors.'' The union is one of the unsecured creditors because of outstanding wage claims and pension obligations. Eastern still hasn't reached agreement with holders of its preferred shares, who are owed about $1 billion. The preferred holders objected to Eastern's earlier plan, which would have paid them only 10 cents on the dollar, and called for the liquidation or sale of the airline. The airline's exclusive right to file a reorganization plan expired on Tuesday, but the creditors and preferred holders have been negotiating with Eastern to try to agree on a consensual plan.

DOC.HEAD: New Wall Street Trick: Transforming Junk into Investment-Grade Bonds
DOC.TEXT: Investment bankers looking to inject life into a moribund market are pushing one of Wall Street's more novel repackaging ideas: turning junk bonds into investment-grade securities. The collateralized bond obligation, or CBO, has grown from scratch into multibillion-dollar market in two years. Some bankers think the market's size could double this year alone, and in the process bring some fresh demand into a junk-bond market sorely in need of buyers. ``I think it has some potential to grow because what it does is put bonds in the hands of long-term holders,'' says Timothy P. Norman, a vice president at Duff & Phelps Investment Management, which manages more than $25 billion from its Chicago offices. Norman manages one of the biggest CBOs done to date, a $301 million deal completed last November. The concept, he says, is sound even if the idea of turning junk into grade-A investment material seems like financial alchemy. The CBO pools bonds issued by a number of different companies to minimize the risk of defaults. Then, it apportions interest and principal payments flowing from the junk pool to several tiers of investors. The top tier or tiers has first priority to payments. Only after they receive their interest and principal does money trickle down to investors at the bottom tiers, where the risk as well as the potential returns are much greater. ``You're able to take a pool of junk bonds and basically carve the risk up and sell it to a buyer who wants a part of it,'' says Andrew Kimball, an associate director who helps issue ratings for CBO deals at Moody's Investors Service. In Norman's case, Duff & Phelps bought just over $300 million of junk bonds, repackaged them under the name of D&P CBO Corp. and then sold off stakes of the pool to four classes of institutional buyers. The top tier, totaling $240 million, got a solid single-A rating from Standard & Poor's Corp. Investors buying into that tier _ mainly insurance companies _ were promised a return of 10.05 percent over an average life of seven years. That was a little more than 1 percentage point above the yield on conventional single-A-rated corporate bonds at the time the deal was done, Norman said. The next level, having a subordinated claim on payments from the pool, totaled $45 million and was priced to yield about 13\ percent, Norman said. The risk at this level didn't merit an investment-grade rating. The third tier of $16 million was packaged as a bond paying about 15\ percent. The remainder of $7 million was an equity rump entitling the holders to any money left after the top three classes of investors are paid off. The two bottom tiers were bought by a limited partnership that includes Duff & Phelps itself and a handful of other institutions willing to accept high risk. As manager, Norman monitors the underlying credit standing of the junk bonds held in the pool. As long as they continue to pay interest, he doesn't have to worry if the price of the bonds falls in the open market. ``It's a cash-flow exercise,'' he says. Ann Thoke, a First Boston Corp. director who helped put together a $200 million CBO for a group led by Equitable Capital Management Corp. earlier this month, says the instrument is winning acceptances from institutional investors after some initial skepticism. The Equitable deal included two senior tiers of $75 million each, which won strong ratings of Aa1 and Aa2 from Moody's. The package is designed to protect investors even if half the underlying junk bonds default. That might sound hard to achieve, but Equitable did it by buying junk bonds yielding perhaps 13 percent to 14 percent and then paying closer to 10 percent interest on the investment-grade portion of the CBO. The difference goes into a reserve that provides coverage in case of any junk defaults. If there are few or no defaults, the bottom-tier investors share the reserve. The depression in the junk bond market makes it a little easier to put CBO packages together simply because bonds can be bought so cheaply, Thoke says. The state of the junk market is so bad, however, that some potential investors are leery of buying repackaged bonds, she adds. Still, Kimball of Moody's forecasts that banks will repackage $3.9 billion of junk this year, up from $2.8 billion last year and $900 million in 1988. Thoke is even more ambitious. She says there are $1 billion worth of deals already in the pipeline, and predicts there could be twice as much paper repackaged this year as in the past two years combined.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Japan-U.S. Trade Talks End With Few Signs Of Progress
DOC.TEXT: Talks between the United States and Japan on reducing the $49 billion trade imbalance between the two countries ended here Friday with few signs of progress and ample evidence of mutual frustration. ``We must say we find ourselves frustrated and concerned at this point,'' Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Linn Williams told reporters after the talks. Japan's Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama, meanwhile, called for urgent Cabinet-level meetings, saying U.S. demands were ``much severer'' than Japan had expected. Williams said U.S. officials had expected to make substantial progress in the negotiations, aimed at addressing the underlying causes of Japan's persistent huge annual trade imbalance with the United States. ``But what we heard is not enough to be effective, lasting or credible. It was mainly a defense of the status quo with prospects of only minimal further action,'' Williams said. Japanese officials during the two days of meetings defended their plans to beef up enforcement of anti-monopoly laws, improve customs and patent systems, reform land use policies, increase public works spending and ease restrictions on new store openings in response to U.S. complaints. ``There's a clear message and already actions have been taken to change the status quo,'' countered a Foreign Ministry official who spoke on condition of anonymity. U.S. officials said they expected bolder proposals for change after this round of trade talks called the Structural Impediments Initiative was postponed for more than a month for Japan's national parliamentary election. The election, held Sunday, returned the ruling Liberal Democratic Party to power. ``We understand the election is just over and a new Cabinet is yet to be formed,'' Williams said. ``But it is clearly time to get ourselves focused.'' Both sides described the atmosphere of the talks as good. Nakayama called for an urgent meeting of top officials from both governments, after Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu names a new Cabinet next week, to determine which problems should be dealt with and when. Since the structural trade talks were launched last May, U.S. officials have pressed Japan for evidence of willingness to carry out wide-ranging reforms to help reduce Japan's $49 billion trade surplus with the United States. The United States claims Japan's high savings and investment rates, its land use policies, exclusionary business practices, inefficient retail distribution networks and pricing mechanisms, among other issues, indirectly restrain trade. Japan, in turn, has singled out inadequate savings and investment, short-term management strategies and insufficient education and worker training as major factors behind the United States' $108.58 billion total trade deficit. On Friday, U.S. officials outlined plans to increase savings and investment and to improve the competitiveness of American firms and worker training. In response, Japanese officials said they suggested tax incentives to encourage more applied research and development and urged an easing of anti-trust regulations to encourage industrial cooperation on new technologies. Officials on both sides declined to comment on specific areas of disagreement, particularly with regard to U.S. plans for structural reforms. Japanese officials contend that many of the U.S. demands for change in their economy cannot be carried out as quickly as Washington hopes. The Foreign Ministry official said he thought the U.S. frustration stemmed from the ``long and complicated Japanese decision-making process.'' Williams, however, blamed ``lack of sufficient political guidance'' for the slow progress. He also criticized Japanese plans for mounting studies rather than taking legislative action in a number of areas. Nonetheless, he said the U.S. side was ``open to wait and see what develops from here.'' But Charles Dallara, assistant secretary of the Treasury, warned that trade negotiators could lose control of the negotiations if progress isn't made soon. ``Others in the legislature who may have different solutions in mind could have a great deal of influence over the outcome,'' said Dallara, alluding to the possibility of more protectionist legislation from an impatient U.S. Congress. President George Bush has stressed the importance of the talks. And U.S. Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney emphasized the importance of the structural trade talks in a policy address here Friday. ``The growing friction between our countries on trade issues and continued trade imbalances may, if unchecked, spill over into other areas of mutual interest and concern,'' Cheney said. Both delegations have said they expected to produce an interim report on progress in the talks by early April, after an additional meeting in March. A final report is expected by summer.

DOC.HEAD: Service on D&H Extended Til March 23
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with ICC extending order til March 23. Picks up 8th graf pvs, ``Under the...''
DOC.TEXT: The Interstate Commerce Commission today extended an order allowing three regional railroads to continue operating for another month on the Delaware & Hudson Railway tracks. ``The commission has extended it until 11:59 p.m. on March 23,'' Dennis Watson, ICC spokesman, said today. ``I guess everything is basically the same.'' The ICC ruled last week that the New York, Susquehanna & Western Corp., Lackawanna Valley Railroad Corp. and North Shore Railroad Co. could run on D&H tracks until 11:59 p.m. EST today while a court-appointed bankruptcy trustee put together a temporary operating plan. The D&H, the nation's oldest continually operated railroad, runs from Montreal to Washington and from Albany to Buffalo, N.Y. Trustee Francis P. Dicello has been putting together a plan under which he would temporarily run the failing D&H using subsidies provided by New York, Pennsylvania, and the railroads and shippers that use the line. Dicello must notify the ICC at least 48 hours before he is prepared to take over but his plan has not yet been approved by the bankruptcy judge who is handling the D&H's reorganization. On Thursday, Dicello canceled a hearing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., but Charles H. White Jr., counsel to the trustee, said he would probably present the plan early next week. Under the plan, Dicello would run the 1,600-mile railroad for at least one month using subsidies totaling approximately $500,000, according to White. Those who would provide subsidies include three railroads _ Canadian Pacific Ltd., Canadian National Railways and Norfolk Southern Corp._ and at least two shippers _ General Electric Co. and International Paper Co. David Murray, a spokesman for the New York state Department of Transporation, said New York and Pennsylvania would each put up about $200,000 a month; the two shippers would contribute $25,000 apiece; the Canadian railroads some $50,000 each; and Norfolk about $60,000. The trustee is hoping that the subsidies would keep the railroad running until he can sell it or negotiate another permanent solution. Meanwhile, Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., has threatened to legislate Consolidated Rail Corp. to the bargaining table in an attempt to save the D&H. He said he, Rep. Norman Lent, R-N.Y., and Pennsylvania's two senators were drafting legislation to force Conrail to deal with a request to sell the D&H trackage rights between Harrisburg, Pa., and Hagerstown, Md. An offer by Canadian Pacific Ltd. to buy the D&H for $35 million was withdrawn earlier this month because Conrail would not discuss a proposal to allow CP to operate on that 90-mile stretch of tracks. ``It's not in the best interest of Conrail simply to force the D&H out of business, because if they do ... it will lead senators like myself and the senators from Pennsylvania to sponsor legislation which will re-regulate those railroads who become monopolistic,'' D'Amato said on the Senate floor. ``I hope the Conrail people begin to listen to the message I am attempting to send them.'' But Conrail spokesman David Neurohr said Thursday that his company's position remained unchanged. ``Conrail has not been offered anything of value in exchange for the trackage rights nor has it been offered anything to offset the harm that would be caused to Conrail's employees,'' Neurohr said, reading from a prepared statement. `` ... In effect, they're seeking a subsidy from Conrail.'' D'Amato said Thursday that Conrail was seeking some $90 million for the rights, which Neurohr would neither confirm nor deny. The D&H filed in June 1988 or protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. bankruptcy laws. The railway has debts of about $100 million.

DOC.HEAD: Saatchi Issues Says Profits ``Unlikely to Meet Market Expectations''
DOC.TEXT: Saatchi & Saatchi Co. PLC said Friday its 1990 profits were ``unlikely to achieve market expectations,'' and disclosed that an American investment company has increased its stake in the troubled British advertising agency. Saatchi, the world's largest advertising holding company, said that Southeastern Asset Management Inc. of Memphis, Tenn., has bought another 2 percent of the company's stock, raising its stake in Saatchi to 13.2 percent. In a telephone call, Lee Blanchard, an administrative assistant, said Southeastern said it had no comment on Saatchi's disclosure. Saatchi shares plunged 44 pence, or 75 cents a share, to 138 pence, or $2.36, a share on London's Stock Exchange Friday. Saatchi also confirmed that it was being sued in the United States by a shareholder, but intends to ``vigorously defend'' its case. A Saatchi official, who was not identified, in accordance with British practice, confirmed that an American shareholder filed a suit in California two weeks ago, alleging that Saatchi failed to disclose difficulties stemming from the company's aggressive acquisition policy beginning in 1985. The suit also claims that Saatchi made a series of false or misleading optimistic financial statements at that time. Warning about its 1990 profits, the company said the rate of growth in the advertising industry was slowing, and that ``against this background, the company was cautious about the short-term.'' Saatchi posted a loss of 58.5 million pounds, or $100 million, for its fiscal year ended Sept. 30. The company also said that it was in negotiations over the disposal of all or part of its interests in each of its consulting activities but that it was not in a position yet to make a more detailed statement. The company previously announced its intention to sell the businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Suits Filed Against Perrier in Wake of Mineral Water Recall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, Perrier spokeswoman ... to include 2 new grafs of comments. Picks up 9th graf pvs, The contamination ...
DOC.TEXT: Several federal lawsuits have been filed against Perrier Group of America Inc., claiming the company knowingly sold bottled spring water that was contaminated with benzene. Lawyers who filed suit here on behalf of B.B. Vahlsing of Wynnewood, Pa., hope it will be declared a class-action lawsuit, permitting them to represent customers of Perrier throughout the country. ``These are people who have been ripped off,'' said Richard Bieder, whose law firm, Koskoff, Koskoff & Bieder, filed the suit in U.S. District Court in Bridgeport on Tuesday. ``They are paying a premium price and they were paying the premium because they believed it was pure when it came from a spring,'' Bieder said. Perrier officials began a worldwide recall of their bottled water last week, admitting that its spring waters naturally contain benzene but saying it is usually filtered out. The Vahlsing lawsuit was filed in Connecticut because Perrier's U.S. headquarters is in Greenwich. C. Oliver Burt III, Vahlsing's lawyer in Haverford, Pa., said six to eight similar suits have been filed in U.S. District Court in Philadelphia. He said the Pennsylvania suits, filed Feb. 16, also seek damages against Perrier and ask the judge to declare a class action. Perrier spokeswoman Jane Lazgin said attorneys hired by her company had not yet had time to review the complaints thoroughly. ``Without really having seen the material, it really isn't proper for us to comment. But it does seem groundless to us,'' she said, adding the company felt it had taken the proper steps to deal with the problem. The contamination question first arose on Feb. 9 when health officials in North Carolina found benzene in several bottles of Perrier. The company recalled 72 million bottles sold in North America. The lawsuit charges that even though Perrier officials knew differently, they first insisted that the contamination was limited to a few bottles and that the problem was caused by a lone Perrier worker who inadvertently contaminated a bottling machine by cleaning it with benzene. On Feb. 15, the company admitted that benzene naturally contaminates its spring in France and that contaminated bottles occurred, in part, because workers failed to replace filters designed to remove benzene from the water source. The company expanded its recall to 160 million bottles, worth $70 million, around the world. The 15-page lawsuit alleges Perrier violated consumer protection laws in several states by advertising its product improperly, Bieder said. The suit also charges the company with violating the Racketeer Influenced, Corrupt Organizations Act, and breaking common law of fraud and negligent misrepresentation. The suit asks unspecified damages, based on Perrier sales figures, mainly for emotional distress caused in finding out the bubbly water contained benzene, Bieder said. The suit names Source Perrier SA, Perrier Group and Perrier Group of America Inc. as defendants.

DOC.HEAD: Volvo, Renault Plan to Swap Stock in Car, Truck Operations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf bgng, Under the ... to CORRECT terms of the deal to show Volvo acquires 20 percent of Renault and option for 5 percent more sted 25 percent of Renault's car operations. Picks up 6th graf pvs, Pehr Gyllenhammar ...
DOC.TEXT: Sweden's car maker Volvo and Renault, the French state-owned automotive concern, announced today they were acquiring major equity stakes in each other's car and truck production operations in a bid to become more competitive. The companies said they also intended to enter into an ``extensive cooperation agreement'' under which they would coordinate product development programs, purchasing operations and investment plans. But they said each company would maintain its trademarks and distribution organizations and would continue assembling and marketing its own cars, trucks and buses. The announcement in the Dutch capital capped months-long rounds of negotiations between the two companies, whose sales have been under pressure in an increasingly competitive world market. Under the agreement AB Volvo and Renault will swap 45 percent of the shares in their truck and bus operations, according to Raymond Levy, Renault's chief executive officer. At the same time, Renault agreed to acquire 25 percent of Volvo's car operations, while Volvo would acquire 20 percent of Renault and an option to acquire another 5 percent at a later date. Pehr Gyllenhammar, president of Volvo, said the agreement meant both companies will ``maintain their integrity ... and will give them the size breadth and depth well above the critical mass necessary to survive in this fiercely competitive industry.'' The stock swap covers an auto conglomerate which would account for production of about 2 million units a year, or about 20 percent of the European market, analysts said. The combination would produce more than 140,000 trucks, beating the current leader in that field, Daimler Benz of West Germany, by a margin of some 25,000 units. In 1988, the latest year for which figures were available, Renault, which produced 1.6 million cars and 80,250 trucks last year, more than doubled its net profit to 8.913 billion francs, or $1.59 billion, from 3.689 billion francs, or $658 million, the year before. Volvo's latest accounts showed an operating profit of 4.06 billion Swedish crowns, or $676 million, for the first nine months of 1989, down 14 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier. However, this figure excluded 750 million crowns, or $125 million, in non-recurring gains. In 1988, the Swedish company's car sales were down by 4 percent, totaling 414,000 cars. In the same year, truck sales were up 25 percent to 60,200 units. Prior to today's announcement, trade in Volvo stock was suspended at both the Paris and the Stockholm bourses. Renault, as a French government agency, has no shares outstanding.

DOC.HEAD: Media General Not Worried About Gabelli Stake
DOC.TEXT: Money manager Mario Gabelli's acquisition of nearly 14 percent of Media General's Class A common stock does not represent a takeover threat, the company said Friday. Gabelli's investment group holds nearly 3.5 million shares of Class A stock, or 13.7 percent of the company's total 25.8 million Class A shares outstanding. Gabelli did not return several telephone calls to his New York office on Friday. Class A shareholders have 30 percent of the voting power in the company. The company's Class B stock, which is controlled by the founding Bryan family, controls 70 percent of the voting power. Media General thwarted a hostile buyout attempt in 1988 by Hollywood producer Burt Sugarman, who had acquired 10 percent of the company's Class A shares. Robert W. Pendergast, spokesman for Richmond-based Media General, said Friday the company is not concerned about another takeover attempt. The company effectively thwarted Sugarman by winning a court ruling upholding the legality of its dual stock structure and a proxy fight in which Sugarman attempted to win three seats on the company's nine-member board of directors. Media General swapped a California paper mill and made a $44 million payment to Sugarman in exchange for his stock and he agreed to drop attempts to take over the company. ``He (Gabelli) started buying it (stock) around the time Sugarman lost the proxy contest, and he has been a consistent buyer,'' Pendergast said. ``He has indicated on several occasions that Media General is a long-term, very profitable investment. ``Last week, he met with the management here and indicated that he continued to believe it was an excellent investment,'' Pendergast said. ``We think it is very positive. We like people who come in on the long term.'' According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, a group led by Gamco Investors Inc. bought 267,400 shares of stock between Jan. 23 and Feb. 15 at prices ranging between $27.97 and $30.50 per share. Gabelli is chief executive officer of Gamco Investors. During the same period, the group sold 2,700 shares at prices ranging between $29.12{ and $30.62{ per share. Media General Inc. owns The Richmond News Leader and the Richmond Times-Dispatch newspapers in Richmond, newspapers in Tampa, Fla., newspapers in Winston-Salem, N.C. and television and cable systems elsewhere in the Southeast. George Shipp, a research analyst with Scott & Stringfellow Investment Corp. in Norfolk, said Friday he did not consider Media General a takeover candidate. ``I think if Mr. Sugarman taught us anything, it was that this company is not subject to a takeover,'' Shipp said. ``I've got to take Mr. Gabelli's word that it's for investment.'' Shipp also said the Bryan family had stated its continued intention not to sell control of the company.
