DOC.HEAD: Company Recalls Catheters After Government Seizes Product
DOC.TEXT: For the third time in the last year, a medical products company recalled one of its catheters Friday after federal authorities seized the devices and warned they could cause serious harm. William Bopp, vice president of C.R. Bard Inc. in Murray Hill, N.J., said his company instituted the recall Friday and was working with the federal government to retrieve the product. U.S. marshals on Thursday seized 2,000 boxes of catheters manufactured by Bard's USCI Division in Billerica. Gail Costello, spokeswoman for the Food and Drug Administration in Boston, said Bard had received complaints about the catheters, which are used to unclog arteries, but failed to fully investigate the trouble. In addition, according to a Justice Department statement, the company ``received complaints of malfunctions of the device indicating that death or serious injury could result if the malfunction were to recur, and yet failed to report the complaints to the FDA as required by FDA regulations.'' About 2,000 catheters were affected by the recall, Bopp said, and the company was sending out letters to customers to inform them of the action. ``I assume they are in use,'' Costello said. ``Of course there is concern.'' Last year, Bard recalled two other catheters, one because it had a problem with tips breaking and the other because changes were made without following FDA rules, Costello said. The two catheters also came from the USCI Division. On the third catheter, the problems related to a balloon device that inflates and presses against deposits blocking arteries, Bopp said. In some cases, he said, the balloon would not deflate properly, making it difficult to remove the catheter. In one case a malfunctioning catheter was used with a patient who died, but Bopp said it has not been determined whether the device caused the death. Bard started receiving complaints about the third catheter shortly after it was introduced in late 1987, Bopp said. Regarding the reporting of complaints, Bopp said: ``We have a corporate guideline that we believe complies with all the requirements.'' Costello declined to say how long the FDA has been aware of the trouble, saying the case remains under investigation.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market seesawed Friday and closed slightly lower after share prices fell sharply on the Tokyo and London exchanges. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lost 10.58 points to close at 2,564.19. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by about 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 468 up, 987 down and 510 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 148.49 million shares, down from 184.32 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 174.77 million shares. The market had ``nervous jitters'' from the decline in the Japanese market, said Ralph E. Blair, a partner at Montgomery Securities Inc. in San Francisco. The key Nikkei index in Tokyo fell 935.87 points, or 2.61 percent, its fifth-worst drop ever. The Nikkei decline, to 34,890.97 points, was blamed on computerized selling and concern about rising interest rates. The fall came two days after the Tokyo market's third-largest decline, which sent stocks plunging in London and New York before the U.S. market recovered for the day. Stocks elsewhere overseas also fell Friday. In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index lost 32.5 points, or 1.4 percent, to close at 2,236.7. In New York, the Dow slipped slightly at the open, then moved above and below Thursday's close. A late-afternoon rally attributed to computerized buying sent the Dow up about 3 points from the previous day, but it retreated in the last half-hour of trading. Walter Murphy, a senior market specialist with Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc., said many observers expected the overheated Tokyo market to make a ``correction.'' But that didn't necessarily mean Wall Street would follow suit, he said. Other observers said the U.S. markets were more concerned Friday about domestic economic uncertainties and pressures on corporate profits. Among blue-chip issues, Philip Morris was down | to 37{, IBM fell { to 102}, USX gained ~ at 35] and American Telephone & Telegraph was unchanged at 38[. Profit-taking hit Monsanto stock after it surged 4] Thursday on news that the government approved its low-calorie fat substitute for food products. Monsanto dropped 3{ to 108}. Pharmaceutical stocks also fell. Merck was down 1} to 68, Warner-Lambert dropped 3| to 99}, Bristol Myers-Squibb slipped } to 51, Upjohn fell \ to 34 and Pfizer fell 3 to 56\. Pfizer, the most-active NYSE issue, restated its 1989 profit downward Friday, from $727.3 million to $681.1 million, to reflect a reduction in the value of a pigment division it plans to sell. On Thursday, Pfizer fell 4{ over concern that the company may face lawsuits from a heart valve once sold by a subsidiary that has a high failure rate. A Warner-Lambert drug for Alzheimer's disease was the subject of a negative study reported in a British medical journal. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $17.985 billion or 0.57 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 0.93 to 179.35. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 2.20 to 373.15, and S&P's 500-stock composite index slipped 1.55 to 324.15. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 3.23 to 419.52. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index dropped 2.25 to 351.10.

DOC.HEAD: Tower, Former CNO Zumwalt On Simmons' List Of Proposed Lockheed Directors
DOC.TEXT: Former Sen. John G. Tower, President Bush's rejected choice to head the Pentagon, and three former military commanders head billionaire Harold Simmons' nominees to replace the board of directors at defense contractor Lockheed Corp. Simmons-controlled companies own nearly 12 million shares, or 18.9 percent of the common stock of Lockheed, maker of the Stealth fighter plane and other military hardware, but the company has rejected his request for six seats on the 15-member board. Chairman Daniel M. Tellep, who has met twice with Simmons since he began investing in Lockheed, says Simmons has offered no suggestions for improving the company, which has seen profits plummet because of cost-overruns and a general downturn in the defense business. Simmons revealed his nominees in a filing late Thursday with the federal Securities and Exchange Commission. The filing also said Simmons expected to spend $6 million on his proxy fight. Lockheed, based in Calabasas, Calif., said it would not comment on the latest Simmons filing. The election of directors will occur at the company's March 29 annual meeting in California. Analysts have suggested Simmons is seeking control of the board to protect his $530 million investment in Lockheed, whose stock has fallen well below the price he paid since he began accumulating the stock in the fall of 1988. Simmons has paid a average of about $44 per share; Lockheed closed at $36.25 a share Friday, unchanged from Thursday, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Tower, a Republican from Texas, spent 26 years in the Senate, and was chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee when he retired in 1985. His nomination by Bush to be secretary of defense was rejected by the Senate amid allegations of womanizing and drinking and disputes about Tower's ties to the defense industry. Tower now operates an investment company in Dallas and serves on a foreign advisory panel to Bush. He was out of the country and unavailable for comment, his office said Friday. Other Simmons' nominees include retired Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., a former chief of naval operations; Hans Michael Mark, former secretary of the U.S. Air Force; and retired Air Force Gen. Earl T. O'Loughlin, who headed the USAF Logistics Command. Mark urrently is chancellor of the University of Texas. Zumwalt's numerous business activities include a seat on the board of NL Industries Inc., a Simmons-controlled chemical company. Analysts had expected Simmons to include nominees with direct military ties to blunt expected concern from the Pentagon over the takeover of the nation's eighth largest defense contractor. Simmons and three of his executives or associates are among 11 others on the Simmon slate. Lockheed's current board includes Tellep and five other executives of the company.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises; Gold Prices Slip
Precedes LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose Friday against most major currencies but continued to give up its usual place on center stage to the Japanese yen. Gold prices slipped. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $415 a troy ounce, down from $415.70 on Thursday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $415.50 an ounce, down from $416.20 late Thursday. Traders said the spotlight was again fixed on the yen, which continued to lose ground as prospects faded for higher Japanese interest rates. Dealers said they are expecting the Bank of Japan to hike the nation's key discount rate. ``The yen has been center stage,'' said Robert Hatcher, a vice president of foreign exchange at the New York office of Barclays Bank PLC. ``We're still waiting for a move on (Japanese) interest rates.'' High interest rates make a country's fixed-income securities attractive to investors, who need hard currency to make their investments. The yen continued to slide against the dollar despite interventions by the Bank of Japan to boost the currency, which dealers said occurred twice in the Tokyo market, once later in European trading and once in New York. In Tokyo, where the business day ends before Europe's begins, the dollar rose strongly against the yen, closing at 146.47 yen, up 1.24 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 146.95 yen. By the end of the day in New York, the dollar had jumped to 147.07 yen from 146.53 yen late Thursday. Market watchers said the dollar also benefitted somewhat from concern about German reunification, which hurt the West German mark. The U.S. currency finished in London at 1.6779 marks, up from 1.6695 marks late Thursday. It continued the advance in New York to end at 1.6785 marks, up from 1.6717. Also in London, the British pound fell to $1.7090 from $1.7145 late Thursday. Later, in New York, one pound fetched $1.7095, less than $1.7133 late Thursday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.4740 Swiss francs, down from 1.4755; 5.6825 French francs, up from 5.6620; 1,241.50 Italian lire, up from 1,236.00; and 1.1983 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1949. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.6779 West German marks, up from 1.6695; 1.4770 Swiss francs, up from 1.4725; 5.6715 French francs, up from 5.6580; 1.8890 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8845; 1,240.75 Italian lire, up from 1,234.25; and 1.1965 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1945. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $416.50 a troy ounce from $417.45 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, Switzerland, the metal fell to a closing bid of $415.50 from $417.25 late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped $3.14 an ounce to close at $413.69. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid of $5.27 a troy ounce from Thursday's $5.28. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery closed at $5.238 a troy ounce, down from $5.268 late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Corn Futures Keep Climbing On Supply Tightness, Steady Demand
DOC.TEXT: Corn futures prices on Friday added to the steady gains of the three previous sessions and analysts said strong demand and relatively tight supplies could keep the market advancing into the spring. On other commodity markets, wheat futures also rose Friday while soybeans slumped; precious metals retreated; oil futures were mixed; and livestock and meat were mixed. Corn futures settled } cent to 1{ cents higher on the Chicago Board of Trade with the contract for delivery in March up } cent at $2.45} a bushel. Wheat settled { cent to 4{ cents higher in Chicago with March at $3.94 a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent higher with March at $1.37{ a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents to 3 cents lower with March at $5.65\ a bushel. Friday's gain in the corn market was attributed largely to perceptions that the Soviet Union is preparing to buy more U.S. corn. But Soviet demand is just one of the factors contributing to corn's slow, steady advance from about $2.37 a bushel at the beginning of February. Analysts cite the Agriculture Department's Feb. 9 supply-and-demand report, which predicted the amount of U.S. corn in storage on Aug. 31, the end of the current marketing year, at 1.48 billion bushels compared with an estimated 1.93 billion at the end of the 1988-89 year. The relatively low ending stocks projection assumes continued steady demand for feed grains in the United States and abroad. Heavy buying of futures on Friday by several major grain-handling companies stirred speculation the Soviets were getting ready to buy more U.S. corn after making some of their largest purchases ever in December. ``The corn market, pure and simply, is bullish,'' said Pat O'Connell, an analyst in Chicago with the futures brokerage Refco Inc. He predicted the May contract, which settled at $2.53\ Friday, could climb to $2.60 with little trouble. Merrill Lynch's senior grain analyst, Katharina Zimmer, told a meeting of the National Corn Growers Association on Thursday that corn usage warrants a near-term price increase of up to 20 cents, and analyst Michael Mann of Blunt, Ellis and Loewi Inc. predicted the December contract would rise from about $2.55 a bushel to $2.70. In other crop-futures news, the Agriculture Deparment said Friday it had targeted the Soviet Union for sales of another 1 million metric tons of wheat at subsidized prices. Gold and silver futures edged lower on New York's Commodity Exchange, reflecting a stronger dollar and surprise that the U.S. stock market did not fall sharply following a steep drop Friday on the Japanese stock market. Gold futures settled 70 cents to 80 cents lower with February at $415 a troy ounce; silver futures settled 3 cents to 3.8 cents lower with March at $5.24 a troy ounce. Crude oil prices for near-term delivery fell moderately on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid perceptions of slack demand for spot crude. Forecasts for cold weather in the Northeast supported heating oil futures. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 33 cents lower to 19 cents higher with April at $21.42 a barrel; heating oil was .10 cent to .34 cent higher with March at 58.30 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .40 cent lower to .30 cent higher with March at 59.85 cents a gallon. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle futures finished mostly lower in line with weak cash markets. Most pork futures advanced, lifted by firm cash markets and expectations for tightening supplies of market-ready hogs. After the close, the Agriculture Department released its monthly cold-storage report, which showed a higher-than-expected 79.5 million pounds of pork bellies in the nation's commercial freezers as of Jan. 31. Live cattle futures settled .43 cent lower to .03 cent higher with April at 75.55 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .23 cent lower with March at 80.22 cents a pound; live hogs were .52 cent lower to .50 cent higher with April at 49.15 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .30 cent lower to 1.4 cents higher with March at 54.25 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Mid-February Sales Fall
With BC-Auto Sales-Table, f0240
DOC.TEXT: Vehicle sales by the major automakers fell 12.1 percent in mid-February compared with last year as January's minivan buying frenzy appeared to take some steam out of this month's sales, the companies said Friday. The eight companies with North American plants reported selling cars and trucks at an average daily rate of 32,258 during the Feb. 11-20 period this year, compared with a rate of 36,687 during the same time last year. Car sales were down 1.5 percent, and truck sales, which include minivans, slumped 13 percent. Truck sales in mid-January, when Chrysler Corp. offered incentives on its popular minivan models, were up 9.4 percent over the same period the previous year. The minivan rebates, the first Chrysler ever offered on the popular vehicles, began Dec. 15 and ended Jan. 31. Combined sales of Chrysler's minivans _ the Dodge Caravan, Plymouth Voyager and Chrysler Town & Country _ exceed combined sales of minivans made by General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co., Toyota Motor Corp., Mitsubishi Motors Corp. and Mazda Motor Corp. ``It's slow this month,'' said Alan Helfman, general manager of River Oaks Chrysler-Plymouth in Houston. He said he sold about 100 minivans last month and ``I'll be lucky to get 30'' in February. In January, car and truck sales by the Big Three, which accounted for about 90 percent of the sales of North American-built vehicles, were up 4.1 percent compared with January last year. A 2.1-percent decrease in car sales was offset by a 13.9-percent increase in truck sales, spurred by the Chrysler minivan rebates. Mid-February truck sales ran 4.7 percent behind truck sales during the same period the month before. That's an indication that some people who had planned to buy minivans in February may have bought in January instead to take advantage of the incentives. ``They bought everything for the next six months because of that,'' Helfman said of the rebates. So far this year, car sales for the eight companies were running 1.3 percent ahead of last year's pace and truck sales were up 5.9 percent. That works out to a combined car and truck sales pace 3 percent ahead of last year's rate. ``It tapered off a little bit at the first part of the month,'' said Patrick Callabretto, sales manager at Crowley Chrysler-Plymouth in Bristol, Conn. ``With the rebates they (minivans) sold very well. They were tough to come by.'' Chrysler's combined car and truck sales for mid-February ran 17.6 percent below last year's pace with car sales down 13.7 percent and truck sales off 21.2 percent. But for the entire year, the No. 3 automaker's sales of domestic vehicles were up 6.3 percent based on a 17.1-percent increase in truck sales diluted by a 5.2-percent slide in car sales. GM's mid-February vehicle sales were down 16 percent compared with last year, with car sales off 19.7 percent and truck sales down 7.4 percent. So far this year, GM's cars and trucks were selling at a pace 0.9 percent ahead of last year, with cars sales down 2.2 percent and truck sales up 7.4 percent. Ford said its combined car and truck sales for mid-February were down 14.7 percent as car sales dropped 13.7 percent and truck sales fell 15.4 percent. So far this year, Ford's car sales were running 5.1 percent behind last year's pace and truck sales were down 1.9 percent, combining for a 3.8 percent decline in vehicle sales.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Up Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices rose slightly Friday, benefitting from a sharp drop in stock trading overseas. The Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond was up 3-32 point, or 94 cents for every $1,000 in face value. Its yield fell to 8.55 percent from 8.56 percent late Thursday. In Tokyo, computerized selling and worries that interest rates are headed higher pushed stock prices into a tailspin, causing the fifth-worst loss in history on the world's largest exchange. Stocks in London also stumbled. In New York, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lost 10.58 points to close at 2,564.19. Bond traders tracked the stock movements throughout the day looking for signals on whether to buy or sell, said James Capra, senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities Inc. Trading was light. Capra said many market participants had expected a sell-off following a sharp rise on Thursday, when the long bond gained 23-32 point after an auction of Treasury notes and upbeat comments on the inflation outlook by Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan. ``The reaction was in terms of what really didn't happen,'' he said. ``The market didn't sell off.'' Capra said that if prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange did not slide further in Monday trading he expected prices of U.S. Treasury securities to decline next week. In trading in the secondary market for Treasury securities, prices of short-term government issues were unchanged to up 1-32 point, intermediate maturities were unchanged and long-term issues advanced 1-16 point to 3-32 point, according to figures provided by Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 0.18 to 1,154.78. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 91 13-16, up 1-16 point. The average yield to maturity declined to 7.42 percent from 7.43 percent late Thursday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.92 percent as the discount lost 2 basis points to 7.67 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 8.08 percent as the discount declined 2 basis points to 7.67 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 8.09 percent as the discount slipped 3 basis points to 7.54 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8\ percent, unchanged from late Thursday.

DOC.NOTE: $adv26
For release Monday Feb. 26
DOC.HEAD: Israeli Mystery: Killing at the Diamond Exchange
DOC.TEXT: The stabbing murder of an Israel Diamond Exchange dealer has sent shudders through an industry known for such trust that deals for millions of dollars in precious stones are sealed with a handshake. Israel's tight-knit diamond community has thrived on secrecy, protected by an elaborate security system once reputed to be the best in Israel outside military installations. So it was unusual that Diamond Exchange president Moshe Schnitzer made a public statement earlier this month warning that the killing had frightened buyers away from the world's largest market for gemstones. ``Today, any buyer who comes asks, `Is it true there was a murder here? Is this building secure?''' said Schnitzer, who has run the exchange for more than two decades. ``We have to let the world know that this is an isolated case that happened once in 50 years.'' Thieves last month evaded the exchange building's security system, stabbed Israeli broker Uri Shlibovsky to death in an upper-floor office and purloined about $4 million in jewels. Newspaper reports have said a shutdown of video cameras during the murder suggested an inside job, and some dealers expressed fears that their private world of trust and security had been breached. The setback in confidence couldn't have come at a worse time for Israel's diamond industry, already beset by a squeeze in profits and several other disquieting incidents. Last year, the industry was caught between slumping world sales and a sharp rise in the cost of rough stones, controlled by the South African De Beers marketing cartel in London. A half a dozen diamond brokerages went bankrupt, and more than 2,000 cutters and polishers were laid off. The diamond fraternity also was shaken last summer when a financially troubled Israeli dealer fled the country, leaving behind millions of dollars in debt. There also have been reports, repeatedly denied, that Israeli and U.S. diamond markets are laundering points for South American drug money. In Israel, the diamond exchange is the heart of three modern high-rise buildings that make up the Diamond Center in this northern Tel Aviv suburb. About 2,500 brokers, dealers and manufacturers are members, and many spend their days seated at rows of simple, black wooden tables buying and selling gems on the exchange floor. To the dealers, diamonds are known simply as ``goods,'' passed around in small bits of folded white paper that belie their real worth. The industry was born during World War II in what is now Israel, when the historical diamond centers in Holland and Belgium were put out of operation by the Nazi invasion. Israel's first dealers were Jewish refugees from Europe who traded gems over coffee at Tel Aviv cafes. Their sons and grandsons, often ultra-Orthodox Jews distinguishable by their black homburgs, remain at the center of a business that can operate on trust because of long friendships and kinships. ``There are no contracts, no lawyers, no deposits,'' notes diamond dealer Joseph Nadel, who has spent five decades in the business. ``You make business with a `mazel'.'' The word is Hebrew for ``luck,'' uttered when a deal has been struck, be it for a sack of rough stones or a single, brilliant solitaire. Nobody knows for sure how much business is transacted daily on the exchange floor or in the dozens of private offices on upper levels of the Diamond Center, admits Moshe Persky, deputy managing director of the bourse. But each year, nearly half the world's gem-quality rough diamonds pass through Israel for cutting and polishing in the factories that line the alleyways around the exchange, he says. Last year, more than 7 million carats in rough diamonds were imported into Israel, and 3.8 million carats in polished diamonds valued at $2.74 billion were exported. A carat, the main measure for diamonds, is one-fifth of a gram. The Diamond Center is protected by double gates, hidden video cameras, metal detectors and an undisclosed number of guards that scrutinize the 12,000 daily visitors. But evidently that now is considered insufficient. Since the murder, a Canadian company named Technologia Systems Ltd. has disclosed it's been retained by the exchange to embellish the security with voice-identification checkpoints and a digitally operated telephone system that records all calls. Inside the exchange, there are jail-like vaults for overnight diamond storage, banks to arrange credit, armored trucks for transport, specialized insurance agents, even courts to arbitrate disputes. In the midst of this private, self-policing world, police are seeking a murder suspect. A $250,000 reward has been offered for information leading to the killer's capture. One broker, insisting on anonymity, said the most disturbing question in the slaying was how the thieves carried it off: ``They somehow managed to turn off the building's video cameras and get away. It's very worrying.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday Feb. 26

DOC.HEAD: House, Senate Panels Looking into Drexel Collapse
With AM-Drexel Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two congressional panels plan to look into the circumstances surrounding the collapse of onetime Wall Street powerhouse Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., it was disclosed Friday. The Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee scheduled a hearing next Friday into the downfall of Drexel, whose parent company filed for bankruptcy court protection last week in New York. Among the scheduled witnesses are Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden, in what would be his first public comment on the matter since Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. Meanwhile, Rep. John D. Dingell, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee has asked the SEC to supply all the information it has on bonuses Drexel paid to employees in the months preceding its Feb. 13 bankruptcy filing. Drexel's parent company was forced to seek protection from some 2,000 creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code after it defaulted on $100 million in loans and lenders refused to grant new financing. Drexel said Friday it had paid $260 million in cash and stock bonuses to top executives in December and January, but claimed the decision to make the payments came long before its financial woes became apparent. Earlier reports had indicated the bonus payments had been as high as $350 million in the weeks preceding the company's collapse. Dingell, D-Mich., asked the SEC to report on whether the bonus payments ``impaired the capital of the firm or have constituted fraudulent transfers under the bankruptcy laws.'' The request was in a Feb. 21 letter to the SEC made public on Friday. Dingell, in his capacity as chairman of the oversight and investigations subcommittee, asked the SEC to ``provide the subcommittee with the commission's analysis of these payments in relation to violations of both the letter and spirit of the applicable provisions of the federal securities laws.'' The subcommittee also asked the SEC to deliver by March 16 ``a copy of Drexel's bankruptcy contingency plan, and copies of any minutes, transcripts or other memorializations of any board of directors meetings where any such plan was discussed or approved.''

DOC.HEAD: Bolar Announces Resignations, Warns of Possible Criminal Liability
DOC.TEXT: Bolar Pharmaceutical Co., the beleaguered generic drug manufacturer that is undergoing a Food and Drug Administration audit and facing fraud charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission, said Thursday its president and executive vice president had resigned. The company also said it might face criminal charges as a result of the FDA investigation, which involves the application and manufacturing processes for the firm's drugs. Bolar said in a statement it currently is not selling products that account for nearly all of its sales, and warned that earnings are likely to suffer as a result. Bolar said its president, Robert Shulman, was replaced by the company's chief financial officer, Larry Raisfeld. Jack Rivers, the firm's executive vice president, also stepped down, but both he and Shulman were remaining on Bolar's board. The firm also said its director of scientific affairs, Seymour Inkles, was named acting head of research and development. The SEC filed civil fraud charges against Bolar in federal court in Washington earlier this month, accusing the company of making misleading and inadequate disclosure to the public about its agreement with the FDA to temporarily suspend shipment of some of its drugs. Bolar halted distribution pending the FDA audit of its application and manufacturing procedures. The company also withdrew its version of the high-blood-pressure drug Dyazide recently because it appeared false documents had been used to support its claims for the product. The company said Thursday it has resumed shipping some of its drug lines, but many remain under audit, and some are being recalled for the purposes of an audit. ``The FDA has not indicated that these products are unsafe or ineffective and the company intends to reintroduce some or all'' of the recalled drugs after its own review and approval by the FDA, Bolar said. Bolar said the drugs being recalled were in addition to earlier recalls of its versions of Dyazide and two other widely-used drugs, Macrodantin and Dilantin. There have been no recalls or questions raised by the FDA about those drugs, which are manufactured by other companies. The firm said it did not know how long of the government audits might take, and ``there can be no assurance that FDA approvals will be forthcoming.'' Bolar said it was not selling products that accounted for 94 percent of its 1989 sales. ``Such cessation of sales ... will have a material adverse effect on the company's financial position,'' it said. Bolar said it believed some of the FDA audits might ``give rise to criminal liability, including possible criminal liability with respect to the company.'' It did not elaborate. The SEC action, the second against Bolar in as many months, also named Shulman, the now-departed president. In January, the SEC suspended trading in Bolar's securities for 10 days after allegations that the company falsified safety claims about its high-blood-pressure drug. That suspension came after a House subcommittee disclosed a letter from Bolar's attorneys that indicated the company apparently falsified documents about safety tests for Dyazide.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Signs Agreements For $360 Million; More Promised
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for 5th pvs, `He said ... to UPDATE with U.S. envoy's talks with Polish officials. Picks up 6th graf, The entry . .. Minor editing to conform, trim. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Poland signed World Bank loan agreements for $360 million Thursday, delivered with the promise that up to $2.5 billion will be available if Poland sticks to its dramatic economic reform plan. World Bank President Barber Conable also pledged that the total of $5 billion his agency plans to lend in Eastern Europe in the next three years won't come at the expense of aid to impoverished nations elsewhere which have traditionally borrowed from the international development bank. ``We are expanding our role in Eastern Europe precisely because of our worldwide responsibilities and experience _ and because Eastern Europe's agenda of change, growth and expanded human opportunity make a compelling claim on our resources,'' Conable told government officials. But he said ``assistance to Eastern Europe should be additional so as not to come at the expense of the poorer parts of the Third World.'' U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger, chosen by President Bush to coordinate aid to Poland, was in Warsaw Thursday for a two-day working visit with Polish officials mapping the nation's economic reform efforts. He met with Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz and other economic leaders. Conable said no Eastern European country is poor enough to qualify for the World Bank loans provided by its International Development Agency, and that the World Bank's strong capital position and access to funds will allow it to expand other lending without crowding out other regions. The entry of the newly democratic nations of the East bloc and their shattered economies into the competition for aid has left nations in Africa, Latin America and elsewhere worried that resources will dry up. Even in Poland there has been concern in some quarters that the other East bloc countries following Warsaw's course toward reform, some of which have less-damaged industrial bases, will draw away needed Western assistance. Poland withdrew from the Washington-based World Bank in 1954 and returned in 1986. The other East bloc members are Hungary and Romania. Czechoslovakia, which also withdrew in 1954, applied in January to rejoin the bank, owned by the governments of 152 countries. The loan agreements signed by Conable, Balcerowicz and Polish National Bank President Wladyslaw Baka, with Mazowiecki looking on, are the first for Poland since it rejoined the World Bank. A $260 million loan will support industrial export, while the second $100 million loan will finance agricultural development. Both 17-year loans are intended for enterprises that will ``break bottlenecks'' impeding production in Poland's outmoded industries and under-mechanized farming, said Janel Loos, the World Bank's expert on Poland. The loans will go to the Polish National Bank, which will extend credit to commercial banks for lending to industries that meet the World Bank's criteria for viability and repayment potential. The World Bank expects to lend up to $2.5 billion to Poland in the next three years, and Baka said Poland expects to receive about $1 billion in the next year. But the National Bank president said Poland's infrastructure is not yet sufficient to handle additional lending, and that the expansion of commercial banking and other changes are required. The World Bank will extend further credit as long as Poland continues its unprecedented effort to convert its staggering centrally controlled economy into a market-driven system, Conable said. ``The international community can, and will, be of assistance but ultimately, the peoples and their governments must shoulder the burden of economic modernization,'' he told Polish officials. ``Choice already exists in the political sphere and it must be dramatically extended in the economic sector,'' Conable said. Among the required steps, he listed an overhaul of the monopoly state enterprise system, an opening of the Polish economy to the West, creation of a capital market, and revisions of business regulations and labor laws. He said protection must be provided for those displaced by the economic reform, expected to create substantial unemployment as unprofitable state enterprises close. The ``alarming decline'' in health standards in Eastern Europe must be halted, education modernized and the housing shortage abated, he said. And, he said, because Eastern Europe includes some of the world's most polluted regions, ``action on the environmental front cannot be postponed until some future date with the economic crisis has been overcome.'' To advise on these efforts, Conable said, the World Bank will within three months establish a mission in Warsaw with a high-level director, one of only three such offices worldwide. Conable and Baka said further funding also depends on far-reaching restructuring or reduction of Poland's $40 billion debt to the West. The ``first encouraging step'' was taken last week, Conable said, when the Paris Club, an informal grouping of 17 countries holding $27 billion of the debt agreed to a one-year moratorium on payments and a 14-year restructuring covering $10 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Media General Reports $20.7 Million Net Income For 1989
DOC.TEXT: Media General Inc. reported a sharply narrower fourth quarter loss and said earnings more than doubled in 1989, largely reflecting the impact of a major writeoff in 1988. The company reported a loss of $1.2 million, or 4 cents a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31, compared with a loss of $29.6 million, or $1.03 a share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenues fell to $165 million from $191 million. For the full year, net income rose to $20.7 million, or 80 cents a share, from $8.8 million, or 31 cents a share, in 1988. Revenues fell 19.8 percent to $606 million from $756 million. The company's results for the year and the fourth quarter of 1988 were depressed by a $41.5 million writeoff largely stemming from the sale of its broadcast services operation. The latest quarter's results included a $9.9 million gain from the sale of a newspaper by Garden State Newspapers, of which Media General owns 40 percent. That gain was largely offset by a $6.5 million loss representing unrecovered costs and expenses relating to the company's lawsuit against William B. Tanner, former head of Tanner Co., and other former Tanner executives. Earlier this month, Richmond-based Media General settled a lawsuit stemming from its acquisition of Tanner, a broadcasting company later investigated for federal tax and mail fraud violations. Media General sued Tanner executives in 1984 after the federal charges were filed. Tanner pleaded guilty in 1985 to three tax charges and one mail fraud charge, the company said. Fourth-quarter 1989 earnings also were reduced by $9.5 million in charges to cover the writeoff of discontinued printing equipment as well as revisions to the estimated tax rate and certain liabilities and reserves for the year. Media General publishes the Richmond Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader, as well as other newspapers.

DOC.HEAD: Says It Paid $260 Million in Bonuses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Drexel releasing details on bonus payments, creditor reaction. Tightens elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said Friday it paid 1989 bonuses of $196 million in cash and $64 million in company stock, less than reports that pointed to large payments prior to the firm's collapse. Drexel released details about the payments after harsh reaction from bankruptcy court creditors who criticized the firm for reportedly paying up to $350 million in bonuses shortly before its parent filed for Chapter 11 protection. Drexel said 44 percent, or $113 million, of the total bonuses was guaranteed to executives and top professionals early in 1989 in an effort to keep them at the firm after it agreed to plead guilty to securities crimes and pay $650 million in penalties. With the firm's demise, the value of bonuses taken in stock in Drexel's parent became potentially worthless. ``What it says is these bonuses were part of the ongoing business activities,'' Drexel spokesman Steven Anreder said. ``There was nothing extraordinary and in fact they were prudently pared back in light of the changed business conditions.'' But William Schopf, general counsel for First City Bancorp. of Texas, one of the largest creditors, said the disclosure does not resolve questions about Drexel's financial state at the time of the payments and why the firm made guarantees despite its uncertain condition. ``It's still a lot of money to go out the door,'' Schopf said. Drexel said the bonuses, of which $150 million were paid in December and $110 million in January, were 60 percent below the amount paid in the same two months a year earlier, when Drexel said it paid $505 million. The disclosure came as questions about Drexel's demise grew and anger over the bonuses intensified. Two congressional panels scheduled inquiries into the collapse and creditors asked a bankruptcy court judge to appoint an examiner to oversee the company's management. In papers filed in U.S. Bankruptcy Court, a leading creditor accused the parent company and its brokerage subsidiary of dissipating billions of dollars in assets without prior knowledge or court supervision. Drexel said its 22 senior management members received $14.2 million in bonuses, including $7.5 million that had been guaranteed earlier. Of the remainder, executives invested ``a sizable share'' in preferred stock. Chief executive Frederick Joseph reportedly took his entire bonus in stock. Anreder said the guarantees were made because of the firm's uncertain status after it agreed to enter the guilty plea, which followed a lengthy government investigation. ``In order to show a sense of comfort that their compensation would be on a par or close to what they had received previously, the guarantees were necessary,'' he said. Meanwhile, former employees met about attempting to recover the value of their stock holdings in the collapsed firm. The workers' 54 percent ownership of the parent was wiped out by the bankruptcy filing. ``Most of us have written it down to zero,'' said Geoffrey Snyder, who was promoted to corporate vice president a few weeks before Drexel's demise. ``A lot of us didn't have a say in what went on in terms of the reasons it's gone down to zero. We want to see if we have any rights.'' Snyder said shareholders planned to form a committee to join a general meeting of creditors set for next Tuesday in Manhattan. Many employees had most or all of their wealth locked in Drexel shares. Shareholders generally are last to receive payments in a bankruptcy case, behind other creditors. Drexel's parent company filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors on Feb. 13. The motion seeking an examiner was filed by First City, which is owed $25 million and has emerged as the most active creditor. The matter will be considered at a hearing next Thursday before U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard Buschman III. First City said it wants more information about the liquidation of billions of dollars in assets by the brokerage subsidiary, including Drexel's payment of as much as $350 million in bonuses in the weeks before its collapse. Some executives reportedly received up to $20 million. An examiner ``can zero in directly on the two questions we're interested in right now: the massive and rapid disposal of assets that seems to be going on and the bonus payments,'' said James E. Day, a First City senior vice president. In court papers, First City said it has been unable to obtain information about Drexel's assets and operations despite a meeting with a Drexel employee on Thursday. The creditor also said an order by Buschman granting Drexel a 90-day extension to file financial data disclosure, which First City has challenged, also has slowed the process. Under federal bankruptcy law, a judge can order a debtor to return assets sold before a bankruptcy filing if the judge finds that creditors were defrauded. Asset transfers to another creditor, such as a corporate insider, also may qualify for an order. But creditors may have trouble recovering assets already sold because the brokerage subsidiary has not filed for bankruptcy protection. Drexel earlier this week said it had sold nearly $38 billion in securities holdings and was liquidating remaining assets.

Stock prices stumbled on Wall Street but the decline appeared mild compared with an overnight plunge in Tokyo, where stocks took their fifth-biggest drop ever. The decline in Japan reverberated Friday in key foreign markets, which not only declined on the day but also posted big losses for the week. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials finished 10.58 points lower at 2,564.19. Broader market indicators also dropped.

Some Japanese traders are blaming foreigners and the sophisticated computer program trading strategies they brought to the Tokyo market for the recent volatility in stock prices. Though unnerved by recent wild swings on the Tokyo exchange, traders concede that they must familiarize themselves with such techniques, which involve moving huge blocks of stocks with the flick of a computer key. In the past week or so, the Tokyo market suffered two of its five worst daily declines ever and experienced volatility in several sessions.

Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said it paid 1989 bonuses of $196 million in cash and $64 million in company stock, less than reports that pointed to large payments prior to the firm's collapse. On Friday, Drexel released details about the payments after harsh reaction from bankruptcy court creditors who criticized the firm for reportedly paying up to $350 million in bonuses shortly before its parent filed for Chapter 11 protection. Drexel said 44 percent, or $113 million, of the total bonuses was guaranteed to executives and top professionals early in 1989 in an effort to keep them at the firm after it agreed to plead guilty to securities crimes and pay $650 million in penalties.

Sweden's car maker Volvo and Renault, the French state-owned automotive company, said they intend to make sizeable investments in each other in hopes of making both companies more competitive. The announcement Friday capped a year of negotiations between the two companies, whose worldwide sales have been under pressure. Volvo has been suffering from the slump in European auto sales on the previously profitable U.S. market, while Renault is rapidly losing ground to the Japanese at the top end of the market.

General Motors Corp. will shut down parts of three assembly plants Monday, laying off 4,200 people in a reflection of the wave of cutbacks by major automakers attempting to weather the industry's hard times. GM will eliminate one of two shifts at each of its car assembly plants in Doraville, Ga., and Linden, N.J., resulting in 1,900 and 1,600 layoffs, respectively. The nation's largest automaker also is trimming production effective Monday at its assembly plant in Fairfax, Kan., causing about 700 layoffs.

Vehicle sales by the major automakers fell 12.1 percent in mid-February compared with last year as January's minivan buying frenzy appeared to take some steam out of this month's sales. The eight companies with North American plants reported Friday they sold cars and trucks at an average daily rate of 32,258 during the Feb. 11-20 period this year, compared with a rate of 36,687 during the same time last year. Car sales were down 1.5 percent, and truck sales, which include minivans, slumped 13 percent.

Federal regulators seized the savings and loan industry's second-largest holder of junk bonds, a California institution that worked closely with indicted financier Michael Milken. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision on Friday turned Imperial Savings Association, San Diego, over to the Resolution Trust Corp., a federal agency created in August to dispose of insolvent S&Ls. Also seized was Mercury Savings and Loan Association, Huntington Beach, Calif.

The Justice Department said any settlement with Exxon Corp. over possible criminal charges from the Alaskan oil spill won't compromise civil claims by the state or its citizens. Spokesman David Runkel delivered a statement Friday in response to criticism from environmentalists and Alaskan officials that the department was trying to force the state to go along with what it considered an inadequate settlement of the federal case.

Talks between the United States and Japan on reducing the $49 billion trade imbalance between the two countries ended with few signs of progress and ample evidence of mutual frustration. ``We must say we find ourselves frustrated and concerned at this point,'' Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Linn Williams told reporters Friday after the talks. Japan's Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama, meanwhile, called for urgent Cabinet-level meetings, saying U.S. demands were ``much severer'' than Japan had expected.

The dollar rose against most other curreencies in foreign exchange trading. Bond prices rose slightly. Corn futures prices added to the steady gains of the three previous sessions; wheat futures also rose while soybeans slumped; precious metals retreated; oil futures were mixed; and livestock and meat were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Nosedive with Nikkei Down More Than 700 Points; Dollar Firms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with closing Nikkei, dollar; picks up 6th graf pvs, `Dealers attributed ...'
DOC.TEXT: Shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange took another nosedive Friday, with computerized program selling sending the main market index falling more than 900 points to a four-month low. The dollar rose against the yen, meanwhile, as the Japanese currency reflected the weakness in stocks. The dollar closed at 146.47 yen, up 1.24 yen from Thursday's close. The 225-issue Nikkei average fell 935.87 points _ or about 2{ percent _ to 34,890.97. It was the first time the Nikkei index had fallen below the 35,000 mark since Oct. 17, when it closed at 34,996.08. The market's leading indicator, which on Wednesday lost 1,161.19 points in the third biggest one-day decline ever, had finished Friday morning's session down 718.01 points, or 2.0 percent. Share prices showed signs of recovery at the start of afternoon trading, encouraged by some buying orders from investors taking advantage of the downswing, but a wave of program selling by arbitragers soon depressed the Nikkei. Dealers attributed the Nikkei's recent decline mainly to speculation of an increase in the Bank of Japan's discount rate, the key rate the central bank charges on loans to commercial banks. Higher interest rates tend to discourage stock investment. The discount rate stands at 4.25 percent following three increases in the last year. Central bank officials have said only that they are watching economic conditions, but a rise in inflation in recent months along with fast growth in the economy and the money supply have led many analysts to predict a further increase. Widespread bearish sentiment caused by the recent volatility of the exchange also contributed to Friday's decline, dealers said. So far this week, the Nikkei index has dropped 1,645.15 points, or 4.4 percent, not counting Friday morning's losses. On Thursday, the index swung more than 800 points during the day before ending with a modest gain. Computer-aided arbitrage selling amid the extremely thin trading was another factor in Friday's drop, dealers said. As a result of the falling stock futures index, institutional investors _ primarily foreign trust funds _ sold a large volume of shares on the stock market. ``The market is extremely vulnerable right now to such selling, because of the low volume of stocks being traded and small number of investors taking part,'' said Michio Katsumata of Nomura Securities Co. ``Most major players remain on the sidelines because of uncertain prospect of the market's directions.'' He said securities and trust fund companies hesitate to increase their holdings for fear of reporting losses at the end of the fiscal year, which ends March 31. Most Japanese companies close their annual accounts at the end of March and securities companies often cash in some of their holdings at the end of the fiscal year to offset earlier losses. Speculation about the emergence of another stock scandal also discouraged many investors from entering the already-bearish market, dealers said. One rumor suggested a major ruling-party politician may be arrested for illegal stock dealings. There was no news to back up the rumors. ``I don't know how serious the rumors are this time, but they surely make investors think twice about buying new stocks,'' said a dealer with Tachibana Securities Co., speaking on condition of anonymity. In Tokyo's foreign exchange market, the dollar started trading at 146.20 yen, up a sharp 0.97 yen from Thursday's close. It moved in a range of 145.95-146.32 yen in moderate trading. The U.S. currency opened higher following its overnight surge against the yen, which also lost ground against other major currencies including the West German mark, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. In New York the dollar closed at 146.53 yen, up from 145.50 yen on Wednesday. ``Currently, market players are not sure which direction the dollar may go,'' Kanai said. ``About half of traders say the dollar will go lower, and others predict it will rise further.'' Dealers said market participants are frustrated with the Bank of Japan's failure to raise interest rates. As a result, the yen is likely to remain weak, they predicted. Traders said the central bank was selling dollars intermittently throughout the morning in an attempt to buck up the yen. The bank does not comment on its monetary actions.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier, Stung by Recall, Now Faces Lawsuits From Former Customers
DOC.TEXT: Perrier, the spring water giant already reeling from a worldwide recall, is being sued by a number of angry consumers who claim the company knowingly sold water tainted with the toxic chemical benzene. Several lawsuits filed in the last week in U.S. District Courts in Bridgeport and Philadelphia charge the company with misleading the public by portraying its water as pure, natural and superior to other brands. ``In fact, Perrier water was not better than the other leading brands. The opposite was true,'' said a lawsuit filed Tuesday in federal court in Bridgeport on behalf of B.B. Vahlsing, a longtime Perrier drinker from Wynnewood, Pa. Richard Bieder, whose law firm of Koskoff, Koskoff & Bieder is representing Vahlsing, said Friday that his client has ``purchased Perrier for a substantial period of time, relying on the fact she thought it was pure, as anybody who watches their ads would think, when they stick that straw into the mountain and suck water out.'' The suit was filed in Connecticut because Perrier Group of America Inc. is based in Greenwich, Bieder said. At least six other lawsuits were filed Feb. 16 in Philadelphia, because the plaintiffs live in Pennsylvania and Perrier was sold there, said C. Oliver Burt III of Greenfield & Chimicles, a Haverford, Pa., law firm that represents some plaintiffs. The plaintiffs are seeking unspecified damages for anguish they say they suffered when they found out that the water bottled in Vergeze, France, was tainted with tiny amounts of benzene, a toxic chemical and industrial solvent. The lawsuits name as defendants Source Perrier SA, Perrier Group and Perrier Group of America. All the lawsuits ask the courts to declare a class action, which would allow Perrier drinkers across the country to join. Perrier spokeswoman Jane Lazgin said attorneys hired by her company had not yet read the complaints in detail and had no comment. ``But it does seem groundless to us,'' she said. ``We feel we've taken the necessary measures and have acted rightly.'' Perrier recalled 72 million bottles in North America on Feb. 9 after a few bottles in North Carolina were found to contain traces of benzene, a substance linked to cancer in animals when fed in high doses. The company initially said the problem was caused by a worker who inadvertently contaminated a bottling machine by cleaning it with benzene. But the recall was expanded to 160 million bottles around the world the next week after more contamination was discovered overseas. Perrier acknowledged benzene is found naturally in its spring in France and contamination occurred because workers failed to replace filters designed to remove the benzene. Lazgin said she could not comment on whether Perrier knew about the benzene in the spring before the recall. The chemical is made from petroleum but also occurs naturally in drinking water and groundwater at low concentrations. Perrier sparkling water was the third best-selling bottled water in the United States in 1988, capturing about 5.7 percent of the $2.2 billion in industrywide sales for the year, according to Beverage Marketing Corp., an industry research consultant. The suits filed in Connecticut and Pennsylvania are the only known legal actions by Perrier drinkers, said Andrew J. Ogilvie, a San Francisco attorney who specializes in consumer fraud cases and is also involved in the suits. The lawsuits allege Perrier violated consumer protection laws in several states and committed fraud and misrepresentation through improper advertising, Bieder and Burt said.

DOC.HEAD: Memo: $11 Million Profit in 1989, $1.2 Billion in Bridge Loan Exposure
DOC.TEXT: First Boston Corp., the Wall Street firm buffeted by rumors of impending layoffs and financial problems, made only $11 million in 1989 and has about $1.2 billion in exposed bridge loans, according to an internal memo obtained Friday. The memo to employees maintained that First Boston is healthy and said that large additions to the firm's reserves to protect against the loans were responsible for the low profit last year. The memo from parent company president and chief executive John M. Hennessey and chairman Rainer E. Gut, distributed after a regularly scheduled board meeting, sought to distance First Boston from the recent collapse of another Wall Street giant of the 1980s, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ``The board shares your frustration with the current spate of unfounded rumors and wants to reassure each of you that this firm is in sound financial condition, is well funded and has sufficient back-up credit resources to weather any short-term disruptions caused by fallout from the Drexel bankruptcy,'' the memo said. Drexel's parent sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection from creditors Feb. 13 after it defaulted on short-term loans after its bank credit dried up, in part because of large holdings in the souring junk bond market. The First Boston memo reported the firm had a portfolio of $107 million in high-yield bonds at current market value, including $30 million in bonds of two Campeau Corp. subsidiaries that have filed for bankruptcy protection. The bridge loans by CS First Boston Inc., parent of the investment firm, total $257 million to Campeau and $953 million to Ohio Mattress Co., Jerrico Inc. and American Medical International, said the memo, which was obtained from a source inside the company. A bridge loan is temporary financing used until permanent financing is in place. The firm has nearly $2 billion in capital, including more than $1.1 billion in equity and ``sufficient reserves to cover any further exposures from our merchant banking portfolio,'' Hennessey and Gut said. They also said the firm's credit ratings have been reaffirmed in the last month. First Boston was the subject of intensified market rumors Friday that began several weeks ago, when speculation rose that it planned to lay off hundreds of employees and had missed a credit payment to London-based sister company Financiere Credit Suisse-First Boston. Spokesman Fred Garcia denied both rumors. The privately held firm recently said it was phasing out its fixed-income futures brokerage business in Chicago and laying off 29 employees and said the reductions were part of a six-month ``rolling review'' of businesses that would continue. The memo said the firm's 1990 budget ``anticipates a disciplined look at our cost structure to ensure that we are as lean as possible.'' First Boston merged with Credit-Suisse last year in a $1.1 billion deal. The combined entity, CS First Boston, is 45 percent owned by Credit Suisse.

DOC.HEAD: Penny Stock Mogul, Four Others Charged for Racketeering, Securities Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Penny-stock mogul Meyer Blinder and four associates were indicted Friday in Las Vegas on federal racketeering and securities fraud charges. The 11-count indictment seeks $9.5 million to be forfeited to the government by the five defendants if they are convicted. Blinder founded Blinder, Robinson & Co., which once was the nation's largest penny stock brokerage. Also indicted were Stuart Cohen, the company's national sales director; Anthony Beshara, its head trader; and Ronald Wheeler Jr. and Ronald Wheeler Sr., who operated a retail securities brokerage, Stoneridge Securities, in Las Vegas, said U.S. Attorney General Mike Norton in Denver. All five face charges of racketeering conspiracy, racketeering and securities fraud. Blinder, Cohen and Beshara face charges of unlawful distribution of securities, and the Wheelers face wire fraud charges. Within the racketeering conspiracy charges are several ``predicate crimes,'' authorities said, including securities fraud, money laundering and wire fraud. In a statement, Blinder Robinson called the charges against Blinder ``baseless.'' It said the company ``can and will carry on its business affairs as always in accordance with the highest standards of fair play and fair dealing.'' The five defendants will not be arrested, but have been summoned to appear for arraignment in Las Vegas on March 9, said Special Assistant U.S. Attorney Joe Dion in Las Vegas. A trial date had not been set. The charges involve about $9.5 million in sales of three stocks, Onnix Financial Group Inc., Executive Capital Inc. and SBB Inc. The indictment alleges Michael Wright and Arnold Kimmes formed sham public corporations, gained control of the stocks and conspired with Blinder Robinson to resell the stocks to the public as if they were publicly registered from late 1984 until about May 1988. ``Two people really controlled all the stock when it looked like it was publicly controlled by a bunch of investors,'' Dion said. He said Stoneridge was ``used as a conduit to give stocks to Blinder.'' Kimmes pleaded guilty to racketeering charges last March and is scheduled for sentencing March 8, Dion said. He would not comment on Wright. The investigation began in 1987 and was led by the Internal Revenue Service, with help from the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department. A raid at Blinder Robinson's Englewood headquarters in November 1988, in which federal agents seized more than a million documents, was part of the investigation, Dion said. Blinder Robinson spokesman and attorney David Aufhauser did not immediately answer phone calls to his Washington, D.C., office Friday. Since the 1988 raid, Blinder Robinson has posted losses, including a $10 million loss for 1988 and a $1.5 million loss for the first three quarters of 1989. Last fall, it had about 44 sales offices nationwide, down from 82 in 1988, and its brokers had dropped to 600 or fewer from a 1988 high of about 1,800. Penny stocks are cheap securities, sometimes selling for just cents, that are traded over the counter rather than on a stock exchange.
